refashioned: The first duty of any government is to protect its society from the violence and invasion of other independent nations. This can only be accomplished through military force. However, the cost of both preparing this military force during peacetime and deploying it during wartime varies enormously across different stages of social development and different levels of economic advancement.
elegant: A government's foremost duty is protecting society from foreign violence, achievable only through military force. The cost of maintaining and deploying that force varies greatly with a society's stage of development.
summary: Smith introduces the sovereign's first duty: national defense through military force. He notes that the expense of this duty changes dramatically as societies advance through different stages of development.
distilled: National defense is the first duty of government, and its cost varies with a society's stage of development.
notes: Opening of Book V on government expenses -- Framework: stages of social development determine military costs -- Cross-reference: Smith's four stages theory (hunters, shepherds, farmers, commercial society) -- Key concept: the relationship between economic progress and the cost of defense

refashioned: Among hunting nations -- the most primitive state of society, such as existed among the native tribes of North America -- every man is both a warrior and a hunter. When he goes to war, whether to defend his society or to avenge injuries inflicted by other societies, he supports himself through his own labor, just as he does in peacetime. His society (for at this stage there is really neither sovereign nor state) bears no expense whatsoever, either to prepare him for battle or to sustain him while he fights.
elegant: In hunting societies like those of North America's native tribes, every man is both hunter and warrior. He sustains himself at war just as at home, so his society bears zero military expense.
summary: In the most primitive hunting societies, every man is simultaneously a warrior and a hunter. Since warriors support themselves entirely through their own labor during wartime, the society bears no military costs.
distilled: In hunting societies, every man is a self-sustaining warrior, so the community bears no military expense.
notes: Stage 1 of Smith's social development model -- Zero cost of defense in hunter societies -- No distinction between civil and military roles -- Smith's four-stages theory: hunting, pastoral, agricultural, commercial

refashioned: Among pastoral nations -- a more advanced state of society, such as that of the Tartars and Arabs -- every man is likewise a warrior. These nations typically have no permanent settlements but live in tents or covered wagons that are easily moved from place to place. The entire tribe shifts its location according to the seasons and the availability of pasture. When their herds have consumed the grazing in one area, they move to another, and then to a third. In dry seasons they descend to the riverbanks; in wet seasons they retreat to higher ground. When such a nation goes to war, the warriors will not entrust their herds and flocks to the weak defense of the elderly, women, and children -- and those groups will not be abandoned without protection or means of subsistence. The whole nation, already accustomed to a wandering life even in peacetime, easily mobilizes for war. Whether marching as an army or traveling as a company of herders, their way of life is essentially the same, even though the purpose is entirely different. They all go to war together, and everyone contributes as best they can. Among the Tartars, even women have frequently been known to fight in battle. If they conquer, everything belonging to the enemy tribe becomes the spoils of victory. If they are defeated, all is lost -- not only their herds and flocks, but their women and children become the property of the conqueror. Most of the survivors are forced to submit to the victor for the sake of immediate survival. The rest scatter and disappear into the desert.
elegant: Among pastoral peoples like the Tartars and Arabs, every man is a warrior. These nomadic nations, already accustomed to constant movement with their herds, mobilize for war with their entire population -- women and children included -- since none can be left behind without defense or subsistence. Victory means total plunder; defeat means total loss, as herds, families, and freedom all pass to the conqueror. Survivors either submit or scatter into the wilderness.
summary: Pastoral nations like the Tartars and Arabs are naturally organized for war because their nomadic lifestyle means the entire population moves together. In warfare, the stakes are total: victory brings complete plunder while defeat means loss of everything, including family members.
distilled: Nomadic pastoral nations go to war as entire populations, with total victory or total ruin as the only outcomes.
notes: Stage 2: pastoral societies -- Total war concept: entire population mobilized -- Nomadic lifestyle as natural military preparation -- Winner-take-all warfare -- Cross-reference: similar analysis in Lectures on Jurisprudence

refashioned: The everyday life and routine activities of a Tartar or Arab provide all the preparation needed for war. Running, wrestling, stick-fighting, throwing javelins, archery -- these are the common pastimes of people who live outdoors, and all of them mirror the skills of warfare. When a Tartar or Arab actually goes to war, he feeds himself from his own herds and flocks, which he brings along, just as in peacetime. His chief or sovereign (for all such nations have leaders) bears no expense in preparing him for battle. Once in the field, the prospect of plunder is the only compensation the warrior either expects or demands.
elegant: The daily life of Tartars and Arabs -- running, wrestling, archery, and outdoor living -- is itself military training. Warriors feed themselves from their own herds during campaigns, and the prospect of plunder is their only expected pay. Their leaders bear no military expense whatsoever.
summary: Pastoral peoples are naturally prepared for war through their everyday activities and outdoor lifestyle. Their leaders bear no military expense because warriors sustain themselves from their own herds and fight for plunder alone.
distilled: Pastoral peoples' daily outdoor activities serve as military training, and warriors fund themselves through their herds and the prospect of plunder.
notes: Natural military preparation through daily life -- Zero-cost military force for the sovereign -- Plunder as sole military compensation -- Division of labor not yet applied to warfare

refashioned: An army of hunters can rarely exceed two or three hundred men. The unreliable food supply that hunting provides simply cannot sustain a larger group for any significant period. An army of shepherds, by contrast, may sometimes number two or three hundred thousand. As long as nothing blocks their advance -- as long as they can move from one district whose pasture they have consumed to another still untouched -- there seems to be almost no limit to how many can march together. A nation of hunters can never pose a serious threat to neighboring civilized nations; a nation of shepherds certainly can. Nothing is more contemptible than a war fought by North American Indians; nothing more terrifying than the Tartar invasions that have repeatedly devastated Asia. The judgment of Thucydides -- that neither Europe nor Asia could resist the Scythians united -- has been confirmed by the experience of every age. The inhabitants of the vast but defenseless plains of Scythia or Tartary have frequently been united under the rule of some conquering clan's chief, and the devastation of Asia has always followed their unification. The inhabitants of Arabia's inhospitable deserts, the other great nation of shepherds, were never united except once -- under Muhammad and his immediate successors. Their union, driven more by religious enthusiasm than by conquest, was marked by the same pattern of devastation. If the hunting nations of America were ever to become shepherds, they would pose a far greater danger to the European colonies than they do at present.
elegant: Hunting armies can rarely exceed a few hundred, limited by their precarious food supply. Shepherd armies can number in the hundreds of thousands, moving continuously to fresh pasture. Hunter nations are therefore no threat to civilized neighbors, but shepherd nations are terrifying -- as the Tartar devastations of Asia and the Arab conquests under Muhammad have repeatedly demonstrated. Thucydides' judgment that united Scythians could overwhelm Europe and Asia has been verified across all ages.
summary: Hunter armies are tiny and unthreatening because of their unreliable food supply, while shepherd armies can be enormous and devastating because they carry their sustenance with them. History confirms this through the Tartar invasions of Asia and the Arab conquests under Muhammad.
distilled: Pastoral nations can field vastly larger and more dangerous armies than hunting nations because they carry their food supply with them.
notes: Military capacity determined by mode of subsistence -- Scale difference: hundreds vs. hundreds of thousands -- Historical examples: Tartars, Arabs under Muhammad, Scythians -- Thucydides reference on Scythian military power -- Speculative warning about American colonies

refashioned: In a still more advanced state of society -- among agricultural nations with little foreign trade and only the crude household manufactures that every family produces for its own use -- every man is similarly either a warrior or easily becomes one. Those who live by farming spend their days outdoors, exposed to the harshness of every season. The toughness of their ordinary life prepares them for the hardships of war, to which many of their regular tasks bear a strong resemblance. A ditch-digger's daily work prepares him for digging trenches and fortifying a camp just as well as it does for enclosing a field. The common pastimes of farmers are the same as those of shepherds, and are likewise imitations of war. But because farmers have less leisure than shepherds, they practice these activities less frequently. They are soldiers, but soldiers not quite so skilled in their exercises. Nevertheless, it rarely costs the government any expense to prepare them for the field.
elegant: In agricultural societies with little trade, every man is a natural soldier. Outdoor farm labor toughens people for war, and tasks like ditch-digging directly mirror military skills. But farmers have less leisure than shepherds for martial exercises, making them somewhat less practiced warriors. Still, the government bears almost no cost in preparing them to fight.
summary: Agricultural peoples are naturally prepared for warfare through their hard outdoor labor, though they have less leisure for martial exercises than shepherds. Their government bears almost no expense in readying them for battle.
distilled: Agricultural peoples are hardened for war by outdoor labor but less practiced than shepherds, yet their governments still bear minimal military expense.
notes: Stage 3: agricultural society -- Farm labor as military preparation -- Less leisure than shepherds means less martial practice -- Still zero-cost military for the sovereign -- Ditch-digging as parallel to trench warfare

refashioned: Agriculture, even in its most basic form, requires a settled habitation that cannot be abandoned without great loss. When a farming nation goes to war, therefore, the entire population cannot take the field. At minimum, the elderly, women, and children must remain behind to tend the homestead. However, all men of military age can serve, and in small nations of this kind, they frequently have. In every nation, men of military age are estimated to make up roughly a fourth or fifth of the total population. If a campaign begins after sowing and ends before harvest, both the farmer and his main laborers can be spared without much economic loss. He trusts that the remaining work can be handled well enough by the elderly, women, and children. He is therefore willing to serve without pay for a short campaign, and it frequently costs the government as little to maintain him in the field as to prepare him for it. The citizens of the ancient Greek states appear to have served on this basis until after the second Persian War, and the Peloponnesians until after the Peloponnesian War. Thucydides notes that the Peloponnesians generally left the field in summer to return home for harvest. Roman citizens served similarly under their kings and during the early republic. It was not until the siege of Veii that those who stayed home began contributing something to support those who went to war. In the European monarchies founded on the ruins of the Roman Empire, both before and for some time after the establishment of feudal law, the great lords and their immediate dependents served the crown at their own expense, maintaining themselves in the field from their own revenues rather than any stipend from the king.
elegant: Agriculture requires fixed settlement, so only men of military age can go to war while others tend the farms. If campaigns fit between sowing and harvest, farmers serve willingly and without pay. Ancient Greek citizens served this way until after the Persian Wars, and Romans until the siege of Veii. European feudal lords likewise served at their own expense. In all these cases, the government bore minimal military cost.
summary: Agricultural societies cannot send their entire population to war because farms must be tended. However, if military campaigns are timed between planting and harvest, farmers can serve at little or no cost to the government, as demonstrated by ancient Greek, Roman, and early feudal European practice.
distilled: Agricultural peoples can fight seasonal campaigns at minimal government expense, as long as warfare is timed around the farming calendar.
notes: Settlement creates new military constraints -- Seasonal warfare aligned with agricultural calendar -- Historical examples: Greek city-states, Roman Republic, feudal Europe -- Siege of Veii as turning point in Roman military financing -- About 20-25% of population available for military service

refashioned:
In a more advanced state of society, two different factors make it completely impossible for those who take the field to sustain themselves at their own expense. These two factors are the progress of manufacturing and the improvement in the art of war.

Even if a farmer is called away on a military expedition, provided it falls between sowing and harvest, the interruption to his business will not significantly reduce his income. Without his active labor, nature does most of the remaining work. But the moment a craftsman -- a smith, carpenter, or weaver, for example -- leaves his workshop, his sole source of income is completely cut off. Nature does nothing for him; he does everything for himself. When he takes the field to defend the public, he has no income to support himself and must therefore be supported by the public. In a country where a large proportion of the population consists of craftsmen and manufacturers, many of those who go to war must be drawn from these occupations and must therefore be maintained at public expense for as long as they serve.
elegant: Two forces make self-funded military service impossible in advanced societies: the growth of manufacturing and the evolution of warfare. A farmer called to short campaigns loses little income because nature continues his work. But when a craftsman leaves his workshop, his income stops entirely -- nature does nothing for him. In manufacturing societies, many soldiers must therefore be drawn from craft occupations and maintained at public expense.
summary: As societies advance, the growth of manufacturing makes self-funded military service impossible. Unlike farmers whose crops grow in their absence, craftsmen lose all income the moment they leave their workshops, requiring public funding to sustain them as soldiers.
distilled: The rise of manufacturing forces governments to fund military service because craftsmen, unlike farmers, earn nothing when they stop working.
notes: Key transition: from self-funded to publicly-funded military -- Nature works for farmers but not for craftsmen -- Manufacturing creates dependency on continuous labor income -- Division of labor applied to understanding military finance -- Cross-reference: Book I on division of labor

refashioned: As the art of war gradually becomes an intricate and complex science -- when the outcome of war is no longer decided by a single irregular skirmish or battle, but when conflicts are drawn out across multiple campaigns, each lasting most of the year -- it becomes universally necessary for the public to maintain those who serve in war, at least during their time of service. Whatever their peacetime occupation, such a long and expensive period of service would otherwise be far too heavy a burden on them. Accordingly, after the second Persian War, Athenian armies were generally composed of mercenary troops -- partly citizens, partly foreigners -- all equally hired and paid by the state. From the siege of Veii onward, Roman armies received pay for their field service. Under feudal governments, the military obligation of the great lords and their dependents was eventually replaced universally by a money payment, which was used to maintain those who served in their place.
elegant: As warfare becomes a complex science requiring multi-year campaigns, warriors can no longer bear the cost of service themselves. The public must pay them. Athens hired mercenaries after the second Persian War, Rome began paying soldiers from the siege of Veii, and feudal military obligations were eventually converted into money payments funding professional substitutes.
summary: As warfare grew more complex and campaigns longer, self-funded military service became unsustainable. Societies transitioned to publicly-funded armies, as seen in Athens' mercenary forces, Rome's paid legions, and feudal commutation of military service into cash payments.
distilled: Extended, complex warfare makes publicly-funded professional armies an unavoidable necessity.
notes: Evolution of military finance -- Three historical transitions: Athens after Persian Wars, Rome after siege of Veii, feudal commutation -- Complexity and duration of war drive professionalization -- Mercenary armies emerge from economic necessity -- Cross-reference: feudal commutation of service

refashioned: The proportion of a nation's population that can serve as soldiers is necessarily much smaller in a civilized society than in a primitive one. In a civilized society, since soldiers are maintained entirely by the labor of non-soldiers, their number can never exceed what the civilian population can support -- after also sustaining themselves and the other officers of government and law that they must maintain. In the small agrarian states of ancient Greece, a fourth or fifth of the entire population considered themselves soldiers and would sometimes take the field. Among the civilized nations of modern Europe, it is generally estimated that no more than one hundredth of the population can be employed as soldiers without financially ruining the country that pays for their service.
elegant: Civilized societies can field proportionally far fewer soldiers than primitive ones. Since soldiers must be entirely supported by civilian labor, their number is limited by what the productive population can sustain. Ancient Greek states fielded one-fourth of their people; modern European nations can afford no more than one percent.
summary: The proportion of the population that can serve in the military shrinks dramatically as societies advance, from roughly one-fourth in ancient Greece to approximately one percent in modern Europe, because civilized armies must be fully supported by civilian labor.
distilled: Civilized societies can sustain proportionally far fewer soldiers than primitive ones because professional armies must be entirely funded by civilian economic output.
notes: Inverse relationship between civilization and military participation rate -- One-fourth (ancient Greece) vs. one-hundredth (modern Europe) -- Soldiers as economic dependents in civilized society -- Civilian economic capacity as constraint on army size -- Fiscal limits on military power

refashioned: The expense of preparing an army for battle does not appear to have become significant in any nation until long after the cost of maintaining it in the field had already fallen entirely on the government. In every ancient Greek republic, learning military exercises was a mandatory part of education imposed by the state on every free citizen. Each city had a public training ground where, under the supervision of public officials, young men were taught various exercises by different instructors. This simple institution represented the entire expense any Greek state seems to have incurred in preparing its citizens for war. In ancient Rome, the exercises of the Campus Martius served the same purpose as the Greek gymnasium. Under feudal governments, the many public ordinances requiring citizens of every district to practice archery and other military exercises were intended to achieve the same goal, but appear to have been far less successful. Whether from lack of interest among the officials responsible for enforcement, or some other cause, these ordinances seem to have been universally neglected. Over time, military exercises gradually fell into disuse among the general population.
elegant: The expense of military training became significant only long after governments had already assumed the cost of maintaining armies in the field. Greek city-states required every citizen to train at public gymnasiums -- a minimal expense. Rome's Campus Martius served the same purpose. Feudal governments mandated archery practice, but these ordinances were universally neglected due to poor enforcement, and military exercises gradually fell into disuse among the population.
summary: Military training expenses became significant only after governments had already taken on the cost of maintaining armies. Ancient Greek and Roman systems of citizen military training were simple and cheap, while feudal mandates for military exercises were universally neglected and eventually abandoned.
distilled: Government spending on military training arose later than spending on army maintenance, and mandated citizen training programs gradually deteriorated from Greek effectiveness to feudal neglect.
notes: Sequence: maintenance costs precede training costs -- Greek gymnasium system as minimal-cost military education -- Campus Martius parallel in Rome -- Feudal failure to enforce military training mandates -- Decline of citizen military readiness over time

refashioned: In the republics of ancient Greece and Rome throughout their entire existence, and under feudal governments for a considerable period after their establishment, soldiering was not a separate profession constituting the sole or primary occupation of a particular class of citizens. Every subject of the state, regardless of his ordinary trade or livelihood, considered himself on all normal occasions fit to serve as a soldier, and on many extraordinary occasions, obligated to do so.
elegant: Throughout ancient Greece and Rome, and for much of the feudal period, soldiering was not a distinct profession. Every citizen considered himself both capable of and, when needed, duty-bound to serve as a warrior, regardless of his regular occupation.
summary: In ancient Greece, Rome, and early feudal Europe, soldiering was not a separate profession. Every citizen regarded himself as a part-time warrior ready to serve alongside whatever trade he normally practiced.
distilled: Before the rise of professional armies, soldiering was a universal civic duty rather than a specialized occupation.
notes: Universal military obligation vs. professional specialization -- Citizen-soldier model across ancient and medieval periods -- Transition point toward standing armies not yet reached -- Cross-reference: division of labor applied to warfare in next entry

refashioned: The art of war, while certainly the noblest of all arts, inevitably becomes one of the most complex as society advances. The state of related arts -- mechanical and otherwise -- determines how far warfare can be perfected at any given time. But to reach that level of perfection, warfare must become the sole or primary occupation of a dedicated class of citizens. The division of labor is just as necessary for improving warfare as it is for every other art. In other fields, the division of labor arises naturally from the self-interest of individuals who discover they profit more by specializing in one trade than by dabbling in many. But only the wisdom of the state can make soldiering a distinct, specialized profession. A private citizen who, during a time of deep peace and without any public encouragement, devoted most of his time to military training would certainly improve his skills and might enjoy himself greatly -- but he would not be advancing his own financial interests. Only the state can make it worthwhile for a person to dedicate his life to this particular occupation. And states have not always possessed this wisdom, even when circumstances demanded it for their very survival.
elegant: War, the noblest art, becomes increasingly complex as society advances, requiring specialization through division of labor. In other trades, individuals naturally specialize out of self-interest. But no private citizen would rationally devote himself to military exercises without state incentive -- only government wisdom can make professional soldiering a viable career. Yet states have not always recognized this necessity, even when their survival depended on it.
summary: As society advances, warfare becomes so complex that it requires the same division of labor that improves every other profession. Unlike other trades where specialization arises naturally from self-interest, only the state can create incentives for professional soldiering.
distilled: The division of labor must be applied to warfare by the state, since no individual would rationally specialize in soldiering without government support.
notes: Division of labor applied to military profession -- Key distinction: private interest drives specialization in commerce, but state action is required for military specialization -- War as 'noblest of arts' -- Government responsibility to create professional armies -- Cross-reference: Book I on division of labor

refashioned: A shepherd has abundant leisure; a farmer in a primitive agricultural society has some; a craftsman or manufacturer has none at all. The first can devote a great deal of time to martial exercises without any financial loss; the second can devote some; the third cannot devote a single hour without suffering losses, and his attention to his own interests naturally leads him to abandon them entirely. Moreover, the improvements in farming that the progress of arts and manufacturing inevitably brings leave the farmer with as little leisure as the craftsman. Military exercises come to be as neglected in the countryside as in the towns, and the great mass of the population becomes entirely unwarlike. Yet the very wealth that always accompanies improvements in agriculture and manufacturing -- wealth that is nothing more than the accumulated output of those improvements -- invites invasion from all neighboring nations. An industrious and therefore wealthy nation is the most likely of all nations to be attacked. And unless the state takes new measures for public defense, the natural habits of its people render them completely incapable of defending themselves.
elegant: Shepherds have ample leisure for martial training, farmers have some, craftsmen have none. As agriculture improves and approaches manufacturing in its demands, even farmers lose their leisure for military exercises. The entire population becomes unwarlike. Paradoxically, the wealth generated by this very industriousness invites invasion. A rich nation is the most tempting target and the least capable of self-defense -- unless the state intervenes.
summary: As economic development progresses, all classes lose their leisure for military training -- shepherds first had plenty, then farmers some, now craftsmen none. The resulting wealth attracts invaders while the population becomes incapable of self-defense, creating a dangerous paradox only the state can resolve.
distilled: Economic progress makes nations wealthy but unwarlike, creating a paradox where prosperity invites the very invasions the population can no longer repel.
notes: Paradox of prosperity: wealth invites attack while undermining defense capacity -- Leisure as determinant of military readiness -- All classes eventually lose martial capability -- State intervention becomes necessary -- Cross-reference: relationship between commercial society and vulnerability

refashioned:
Under these circumstances, there appear to be only two methods by which the state can make adequate provision for public defense.

First, through very strict enforcement, and despite going against the natural interests, talents, and inclinations of the people, the state may compel the practice of military exercises, obligating either all citizens of military age or a certain number of them to combine the role of soldier with whatever other trade or profession they happen to pursue.
elegant: In these conditions, the state has only two options for defense. The first is to forcibly mandate military exercises for citizens of military age, compelling them to combine soldiering with their civilian occupations despite their natural disinclination.
summary: Smith identifies two possible solutions for defending a commercially advanced but unwarlike nation. The first option is compulsory military training for citizens, forcing them to add soldiering to their regular occupations.
distilled: One solution for defending a prosperous but unwarlike nation is compulsory military training imposed against the population's natural inclinations.
notes: First of two defense options: compulsory citizen training (militia) -- Against natural inclination of commercial populations -- Sets up militia vs. standing army debate -- State coercion required to maintain military readiness

refashioned:
Alternatively, by maintaining and employing a certain number of citizens in the constant practice of military exercises, the state may make soldiering a distinct, specialized profession, entirely separate from all others.

When the state adopts the first approach, its military force is called a militia. When it adopts the second, it is called a standing army. For soldiers in a standing army, military exercises are their sole or primary occupation, and the pay provided by the state is their principal means of support. For soldiers in a militia, military exercises are only an occasional activity, and they derive their primary income from some other occupation. In a militia, the character of the laborer, craftsman, or tradesman predominates over that of the soldier. In a standing army, the character of the soldier predominates over all others. This distinction is the essential difference between these two types of military force.
elegant: The second option is maintaining a class of professional soldiers in constant training -- a standing army. The fundamental distinction: in a militia, the civilian identity predominates over the military one, and soldiers train only occasionally while earning their living elsewhere. In a standing army, the military identity predominates, and state pay is the soldiers' primary income.
summary: The second defense option is a standing army of professional soldiers. The essential distinction between militia and standing army lies in which identity predominates: in a militia, the civilian tradesman; in a standing army, the professional soldier.
distilled: The essential difference between militia and standing army is whether the civilian or military identity predominates in the soldier.
notes: Militia vs. standing army -- the central framework for this section -- Key distinction: occasional vs. full-time military practice -- Professional specialization in warfare -- Primary income source as defining criterion -- Division of labor applied to national defense

refashioned: Militias have taken several different forms throughout history. In some countries, citizens designated for defense were given training but were not organized into regiments -- that is, they were not divided into distinct military units, each drilling under its own permanent officers. In the republics of ancient Greece and Rome, each citizen practiced his military exercises independently or with companions of his choosing while at home, and was not assigned to any particular unit until actually called to take the field. In other countries, the militia has been both trained and organized into permanent regiments. In England, Switzerland, and I believe every other modern European country that has established some form of imperfect militia, every militiaman is attached to a specific unit even in peacetime, drilling under its own permanent officers.
elegant: Militias have taken two forms: unregmented, where citizens train independently and join units only when called to fight (as in ancient Greece and Rome), and regimented, where citizens are permanently assigned to units with standing officers even in peacetime (as in England and Switzerland).
summary: Militias vary between two models: the ancient system where citizens trained independently and formed units only for actual campaigns, and the modern European system where militiamen are permanently assigned to regimented units with standing officers.
distilled: Militias range from unregmented systems where citizens train independently to regimented ones where they belong to permanent units with standing officers.
notes: Two types of militia organization: unregmented vs. regimented -- Ancient model (Greece, Rome): independent training, ad hoc units -- Modern model (England, Switzerland): permanent regimental assignment -- Organizational structure affects military effectiveness

refashioned: Before the invention of firearms, the superior army was the one whose soldiers possessed the greatest individual skill and dexterity with their weapons. Physical strength and agility were of the highest importance and commonly decided the outcome of battles. But this skill could only be acquired -- much like fencing today -- by practicing individually, in a dedicated school, under a particular instructor, or with one's personal training companions. Since the invention of firearms, strength, agility, and even exceptional weapon skill, while far from irrelevant, matter considerably less. The nature of the firearm, while by no means making the unskilled equal to the skilled, brings them much closer together than ever before. All the skill necessary for using firearms, it is believed, can be adequately acquired through practice in large groups.
elegant: Before firearms, individual weapon skill and physical prowess decided battles, requiring personal training under dedicated instructors. Firearms reduced the importance of individual dexterity -- they do not equalize the skilled and unskilled, but narrow the gap considerably. The necessary proficiency with firearms can be acquired through group drill rather than individual practice.
summary: The invention of firearms fundamentally changed military training. Before firearms, individual skill acquired through personal training decided battles. Firearms narrowed the gap between skilled and unskilled fighters, making group drill sufficient for adequate training.
distilled: Firearms reduced the military importance of individual weapon skill, making group drill sufficient where personal training was once essential.
notes: Firearms as military revolution -- Shift from individual skill to collective discipline -- Equalizing effect of technology on warfare -- Group training replaces individual instruction -- Implications for militia vs. standing army debate

refashioned: Regularity, order, and prompt obedience to command are the qualities that, in modern armies, matter most in determining the outcome of battles -- more than individual weapon skill. But the noise of firearms, the smoke, and the invisible death to which every soldier feels exposed the moment he comes within cannon range -- often long before the battle has truly begun -- make it extremely difficult to maintain this regularity, order, and obedience, even at the start of a modern engagement. In ancient battles, there was no noise beyond the human voice, no smoke, and no invisible source of wounds or death. Every man could see clearly that no lethal weapon was near him until one actually approached. Under those conditions, among troops confident in their individual skill, maintaining order and regularity was considerably easier -- not just at the beginning, but throughout an entire battle, until one army was decisively defeated. But the habits of regularity, order, and prompt obedience can only be acquired by troops that drill together in large formations.
elegant: In modern war, collective discipline -- regularity, order, and obedience -- matters more than individual skill. Yet the smoke, noise, and invisible death of firearms make discipline far harder to maintain than in ancient battles, where threats were visible and personal. This paradox means that only troops trained extensively in large formations can develop the disciplined habits modern warfare demands.
summary: Modern warfare demands collective discipline over individual skill, yet the chaos of firearms -- noise, smoke, and invisible death -- makes maintaining that discipline far harder than in ancient combat. Only extensive group drill can instill the habits of order and obedience that modern battles require.
distilled: Modern warfare paradoxically demands greater collective discipline while making it harder to maintain, requiring extensive group training in large formations.
notes: Discipline vs. individual skill in modern warfare -- Psychological effects of firearms on battlefield cohesion -- Ancient warfare: visible threats enabled easier discipline -- Modern warfare: invisible threats require trained discipline -- Argument building toward standing army superiority

refashioned:
A militia, however it may be trained or drilled, must always be considerably inferior to a well-disciplined and well-trained standing army.

Soldiers who practice only once a week or once a month can never become as proficient with their weapons as those who practice every day or every other day. Although this point may matter less in modern times than in ancient ones, the acknowledged superiority of the Prussian troops -- attributed largely, it is said, to their superior proficiency in drill -- demonstrates that it remains of very considerable importance even today.
elegant: A militia is always inferior to a well-trained standing army. Part-time soldiers practicing weekly or monthly can never match professionals who drill daily. Even in the age of firearms, the Prussian army's superiority -- attributed to relentless drill -- proves that practice frequency still matters greatly.
summary: Militias are inherently inferior to standing armies because part-time training cannot match daily professional drill. The Prussian army's acknowledged superiority, credited to intensive practice, demonstrates that training frequency remains crucial even in modern warfare.
distilled: Part-time militia training can never match the proficiency achieved through daily professional drill, as Prussian military superiority demonstrates.
notes: Standing army superiority over militia -- Training frequency as key variable -- Prussian army as contemporary example of drill superiority -- Even with firearms, practice matters -- Building case for standing armies

refashioned: Soldiers who are bound to obey their officer only once a week or once a month, and who are otherwise free to manage their own affairs without any accountability to him, can never feel the same awe in his presence or possess the same readiness to obey as those whose entire lives are directed by him daily -- who even rise and go to bed, or at least return to their quarters, on his orders. In what is called discipline -- the habit of ready obedience -- a militia must be even more inferior to a standing army than it is in the manual exercise or the management of weapons. And in modern warfare, the habit of ready and instant obedience is of far greater consequence than superior weapon handling.
elegant: Part-time soldiers who answer to their officers only occasionally can never develop the instinctive obedience of those whose daily lives are entirely governed by military authority. A militia's disadvantage in discipline -- the habit of instant obedience -- is even greater than its disadvantage in weapon skills, and in modern warfare, discipline matters far more than marksmanship.
summary: The militia's greatest disadvantage is not in weapon skills but in discipline. Soldiers who obey their officers only occasionally can never develop the instinctive, ready obedience of professionals under constant military authority, and this discipline gap matters most in modern warfare.
distilled: A militia's deficit in discipline and habitual obedience is more damaging than its deficit in weapon skills, because modern warfare prizes instant compliance above all.
notes: Discipline more important than skill in modern warfare -- Constant authority breeds habitual obedience -- Part-time authority produces part-time obedience -- Psychological dimension of military effectiveness -- Further building the case for standing armies

refashioned: Those militias that go to war under the same leaders they are accustomed to obeying in peacetime -- like the Tartar and Arab militias -- are by far the best. In respect for their officers and in habitual obedience, they come closest to standing armies. The Scottish Highland militia, when it served under its own clan chieftains, shared something of this advantage. However, since the Highlanders were not wandering but settled shepherds with fixed homes, they were less willing to follow their chieftain over great distances or to remain in the field for extended periods during wartime. After capturing any plunder, they were eager to return home, and the chieftain's authority was rarely sufficient to keep them in service. In obedience, they were always much inferior to what is reported of the Tartars and Arabs. And since the Highlanders' settled life meant they spent less time outdoors, they were always less accustomed to military exercises and less skilled with their weapons than the Tartars and Arabs are said to be.
elegant: Militias that serve under their peacetime leaders -- like Tartars and Arabs -- are the best, closest to standing armies in discipline. The Highland Scots had a similar advantage under clan chieftains, but as settled shepherds rather than nomads, they were less willing to march far or serve long, less practiced in martial skills, and always inferior in obedience to truly nomadic warrior peoples.
summary: Militias led by their peacetime authorities are most effective, with Tartar and Arab militias being the finest examples. The Highland Scots had a partial version of this advantage but were weakened by their settled lifestyle, which reduced both their willingness to campaign and their martial skills.
distilled: Militias are most effective when led by their peacetime leaders, but settled peoples always produce weaker militias than nomadic ones.
notes: Quality hierarchy among militias -- Peacetime authority structure transfers to military effectiveness -- Highland Scots as intermediate case -- Nomadic vs. settled pastoral peoples -- Settled life reduces both martial skill and willingness to campaign

refashioned: It must be observed, however, that any militia that has served through several successive campaigns in the field effectively becomes a standing army in every respect. The soldiers drill daily with their weapons and, being constantly under their officers' command, develop the same prompt obedience found in standing armies. What they were before they took the field matters little. After a few campaigns, they necessarily become a standing army in every meaningful sense. Should the war in America drag on through another campaign, the American militia may become fully equal to the standing army whose valor in the last war proved no less formidable than that of the most hardened veterans of France and Spain.
elegant: Any militia that serves through several consecutive campaigns effectively becomes a standing army -- daily drill and constant command instill professional discipline regardless of the soldiers' previous occupations. Smith observes that if the American war continues, the American militia may become the equal of any standing army.
summary: Extended field service transforms any militia into a standing army through daily practice and constant command. Smith suggests the American militia, if given another campaign, could match the professional armies of Europe.
distilled: Prolonged active service transforms a militia into a standing army through the daily discipline and obedience that continuous campaigning instills.
notes: Militia-to-standing-army transformation through continuous service -- Practical experience as equalizer -- American Revolution reference -- Timely political observation for 1776 publication -- Transition mechanism between militia and professional forces

refashioned:
With this distinction clearly understood, the history of all ages confirms the irresistible superiority that a well-regulated standing army holds over a militia.

One of the first standing armies for which we have a reliable historical account is that of Philip of Macedon. His frequent wars with the Thracians, Illyrians, Thessalians, and neighboring Greek cities gradually transformed his troops, which were probably a militia at the outset, into a disciplined standing army. During the rare and brief intervals of peace, he was careful never to disband this force. It conquered and subdued -- after a long and fierce struggle -- the gallant and well-trained militias of the principal Greek republics, and afterwards, with very little struggle, the decadent and poorly trained militia of the vast Persian Empire. The fall of the Greek republics and of the Persian Empire resulted from the irresistible superiority of a standing army over every other form of militia. It represents the first great revolution in human affairs of which history has preserved a detailed account.
elegant: History uniformly demonstrates the irresistible superiority of standing armies over militias. Philip of Macedon's forces, forged through continuous warfare and never disbanded, defeated first the well-trained Greek militias and then the feeble Persian militia. The fall of Greece and Persia constitutes the first great revolution in history attributable to standing army supremacy.
summary: Philip of Macedon's army, transformed from militia to standing army through continuous warfare, defeated both the formidable Greek citizen-soldiers and the weak Persian militia. Smith presents this as the first great historical revolution demonstrating standing army superiority.
distilled: Philip of Macedon's standing army conquered both Greek and Persian militias, establishing the first historical proof of professional military supremacy.
notes: Historical proof of standing army superiority -- Philip of Macedon as first well-documented case -- Continuous warfare as army-building mechanism -- First of three 'great revolutions' in military history -- Greek militias were good but still inferior to standing army

refashioned:
The fall of Carthage and the consequent rise of Rome represent the second great revolution. All the twists of fortune between these two famous republics can be explained by the same principle.

From the end of the first Carthaginian war to the beginning of the second, Carthaginian armies were continuously in the field under three great generals who succeeded one another in command: Hamilcar, his son-in-law Hasdrubal, and his son Hannibal. They first crushed their own rebellious slaves, then subdued the revolted nations of Africa, and finally conquered the great kingdom of Spain. The army Hannibal led from Spain into Italy had necessarily been forged through these successive wars into a fully disciplined standing army. The Romans, meanwhile, though not entirely at peace, had not been engaged in any war of great consequence during this period, and their military discipline had reportedly grown slack. The Roman armies that Hannibal met at Trebia, Trasimene, and Cannae were militias opposing a standing army. This circumstance probably contributed more than anything else to deciding the outcome of those battles.
elegant: The fall of Carthage and rise of Rome form the second great military revolution. Carthage's armies, hardened through continuous wars under Hamilcar, Hasdrubal, and Hannibal, had become a standing army. Rome's forces, idle during the same period, had relaxed into militia. At Trebia, Trasimene, and Cannae, Hannibal's standing army crushed Roman militias -- the militia-versus-standing-army dynamic decided those famous battles.
summary: Hannibal's victories at Trebia, Trasimene, and Cannae are explained by the same principle: his army had been forged into a professional standing force through continuous warfare, while Roman forces had deteriorated into a poorly disciplined militia during a period of relative peace.
distilled: Hannibal's early victories over Rome resulted from his war-hardened standing army facing Roman forces that had deteriorated into an undisciplined militia.
notes: Second 'great revolution' in military history -- Continuous warfare creates standing armies -- Idle periods degrade military quality -- Hannibal's campaigns as case study -- Trebia, Trasimene, Cannae explained by militia vs. standing army

refashioned:
The standing army Hannibal left behind in Spain held similar superiority over the militia Rome sent to oppose it, and within a few years, under his brother Hasdrubal's command, it expelled the Romans almost entirely from the country.

Meanwhile, Hannibal was poorly supplied from home. The Roman militia, being continuously in the field, gradually became a well-disciplined standing army, and Hannibal's advantage diminished daily. Hasdrubal judged it necessary to lead his entire standing army from Spain to reinforce his brother in Italy. During this march, he was reportedly misled by his guides and, in unfamiliar country, was surprised and attacked by another standing army that was in every respect equal or superior to his own. He was completely defeated.
elegant: Hannibal's standing army in Spain initially dominated the Roman militia there. But as Rome's continuously deployed forces gradually became a standing army themselves, Hannibal's advantage eroded. When Hasdrubal marched his army from Spain to reinforce Hannibal, he was intercepted by a now-professional Roman force and utterly destroyed.
summary: While Hannibal's Spanish standing army initially dominated Roman militia forces, prolonged campaigning gradually transformed the Roman troops into a standing army. When Hasdrubal attempted to reinforce Hannibal, he was destroyed by these newly professional Roman forces.
distilled: Rome's continuous campaigning transformed its militia into a standing army that eventually matched and defeated Hannibal's professional forces.
notes: Militia-to-standing-army transformation in practice -- Rome's military evolution during the Second Punic War -- Hasdrubal's defeat as turning point -- Continuous field service as professionalizing force -- Confirms the principle from 5.1.23

refashioned: After Hasdrubal left Spain, the great Scipio found nothing opposing him but a militia inferior to his own forces. He conquered and subdued it, and in the course of the war, his own militia necessarily became a well-disciplined standing army. That standing army was then carried to Africa, where it found only a militia to oppose it. To defend Carthage, it became necessary to recall Hannibal's standing army. The demoralized and repeatedly defeated African militia joined Hannibal's forces and, at the Battle of Zama, composed the greater part of his army. The outcome of that day decided the fate of the two rival republics.
elegant: After Hasdrubal's departure, Scipio conquered Spain and forged his forces into a standing army, which he then carried to Africa. To defend Carthage, Hannibal was recalled, but his army at Zama was largely composed of demoralized African militia. The battle's outcome decided the fate of both republics.
summary: Scipio's forces, hardened into a standing army through the Spanish campaign, invaded Africa and forced Hannibal's recall. At Zama, Hannibal's army was diluted with demoralized militia, and his defeat decided the contest between Rome and Carthage.
distilled: Scipio's war-forged standing army defeated Hannibal at Zama, where inferior militia reinforcements fatally weakened the Carthaginian force.
notes: Battle of Zama as climax of the second military revolution -- Standing army quality vs. militia dilution -- Scipio's transformation mirrors earlier Roman pattern -- Continuous warfare as army builder -- Decisive moment in ancient history

refashioned: From the end of the Second Punic War until the fall of the Roman Republic, Rome's armies were in every respect standing armies. The standing army of Macedon offered some resistance to Roman power. At the height of their greatness, it cost Rome two major wars and three great battles to subdue that small kingdom -- a conquest that would probably have been even more difficult had it not been for the cowardice of its last king. The militias of all the civilized nations of the ancient world -- Greece, Syria, Egypt -- offered only feeble resistance to Roman standing armies. The militias of some barbarous nations defended themselves much better. The Scythian and Tartar militia that Mithridates recruited from north of the Black and Caspian seas were the most formidable enemies Rome faced after the Second Punic War. The Parthian and German militias were also always respectable and occasionally won significant victories over Roman forces. Generally, however, when well commanded, Roman armies proved greatly superior. If Rome never completed the conquest of Parthia or Germany, it was probably because the Romans judged it not worth adding those barbarous territories to an empire already too vast. The ancient Parthians appear to have been of Scythian or Tartar origin and retained much of their ancestors' customs. The ancient Germans, like the Scythians and Tartars, were a nation of wandering shepherds who followed the same chieftains in war as in peace. Their militia was essentially identical to that of the Scythians and Tartars, from whom they probably descended.
elegant: After the Second Punic War, Rome maintained permanent standing armies that overwhelmed every civilized militia -- Greek, Syrian, Egyptian. Only barbarous militias offered real resistance: the Scythian forces of Mithridates were Rome's most formidable post-Punic foes, and Parthian and German militias won occasional victories. Rome's failure to conquer Parthia and Germany likely reflected strategic choice rather than inability. These formidable opponents were all shepherd peoples whose nomadic lifestyle naturally produced superior militias.
summary: Rome's standing armies easily defeated the militias of civilized nations like Greece, Syria, and Egypt, but faced serious resistance from the pastoral militias of Scythians, Parthians, and Germans, whose nomadic lifestyle made them natural warriors.
distilled: Rome's standing armies dominated civilized militias but struggled against the naturally formidable militias of nomadic pastoral peoples.
notes: Standing army dominance over civilized militias -- Pastoral militia superiority over civilized militia -- Rome's strategic limits of conquest -- Mithridates and Scythian warriors -- German and Parthian resistance -- Hierarchy: standing army > pastoral militia > civilized militia

refashioned: Many factors contributed to the deterioration of Roman military discipline. Its extreme severity may itself have been one cause. During their era of supremacy, when no enemy seemed capable of opposing them, Roman soldiers laid aside their heavy armor as unnecessarily burdensome and neglected their rigorous training as unnecessarily exhausting. Under the emperors, moreover, Rome's standing armies -- particularly those guarding the German and Pannonian frontiers -- became dangerous to their masters, frequently elevating their own generals to imperial power. To reduce this threat, according to some historians Diocletian, according to others Constantine, first withdrew these armies from the frontier, where they had always been stationed in large bodies of two or three legions each, and dispersed them in small units throughout provincial towns. Rarely moved from these posts, small groups of soldiers quartered in trading and manufacturing towns themselves became tradesmen, craftsmen, and manufacturers. The civilian character came to dominate over the military one, and Rome's standing armies gradually degenerated into a corrupt, neglected, and undisciplined militia, incapable of resisting the German and Scythian militias that soon invaded the western empire. Only by hiring the militia of some of these nations to fight against others could the emperors defend themselves for a time. The fall of the western empire is the third great revolution in human affairs of which ancient history preserves a detailed account. It was brought about by the irresistible superiority of a barbarous nation's militia over a civilized nation's militia -- of a nation of shepherds over a nation of farmers, craftsmen, and manufacturers. The victories won by militias have generally been not over standing armies, but over other, inferior militias. Such were the victories of the Greek militia over the Persian militia, and such were the later victories of the Swiss militia over those of the Austrians and Burgundians.
elegant: Rome's armies decayed through their own success: severity relaxed, armor was abandoned, training neglected. Emperors dispersed frontier legions into small town garrisons to prevent military coups, but soldiers quartered among traders became traders themselves. Rome's standing army degenerated into an undisciplined militia, vulnerable to invasion by the superior pastoral militias of Germanic and Scythian peoples. The fall of the western empire -- the third great military revolution -- demonstrated the superiority of barbarous shepherd militias over degraded civilized ones. Militia victories throughout history have always been over inferior militias, not over true standing armies.
summary: Rome's standing army degenerated into a corrupt militia through neglect, deliberate dispersal, and the civilianizing effect of garrison life in trading towns. The resulting fall of the western empire to Germanic pastoral militias represents the third great military revolution, confirming that militia victories occur over inferior militias, never over true standing armies.
distilled: Rome's standing army degenerated into a civilian militia through garrison life in trading towns, enabling its destruction by superior barbarian pastoral militias -- the third great revolution in military history.
notes: Third 'great revolution' in military history -- Standing armies can degenerate back into militias -- Civilianizing effect of garrison life -- Diocletian/Constantine dispersal policy -- Hiring barbarian militias as stopgap -- Swiss victories over Austria/Burgundy as militia-vs-militia example -- Complete cycle: militia to standing army back to militia

refashioned: The military forces of the Germanic and Scythian nations that established themselves on the ruins of the western empire continued for some time to function in their new territories as they had in their original homelands. They remained a militia of shepherds and farmers, taking the field under the same chieftains they obeyed in peacetime. This force was therefore reasonably well trained and disciplined. But as arts and industry advanced, the authority of the chieftains gradually diminished and the general population had less time for military training. Both the discipline and training of the feudal militia therefore gradually deteriorated, and standing armies were gradually introduced to replace it. Once one civilized nation adopted a standing army, all its neighbors were compelled to do the same. They quickly discovered that their security depended on it, and that their own militia was completely incapable of withstanding such a force.
elegant: After conquering Rome, the Germanic nations maintained their pastoral militia system under traditional chieftains. But as economic development advanced, chiefly authority weakened and people had less time for training. The feudal militia decayed, and standing armies emerged to replace it. Once one nation adopted a standing army, all neighbors had to follow -- their militias could not compete.
summary: The Germanic conquerors initially maintained their traditional militia system, but economic development eroded both chiefly authority and military training. Standing armies gradually replaced feudal militias, and once one nation adopted this model, all neighbors were forced to follow suit for survival.
distilled: Economic development degraded feudal militias, forcing the adoption of standing armies that then compelled all neighboring nations to follow suit.
notes: Post-Roman military evolution -- Economic development as driver of military change -- Arms race dynamic: one standing army forces universal adoption -- Feudal militia decline mirrors earlier Roman decline -- Competitive pressure in military organization

refashioned: The soldiers of a standing army, even if they have never seen an enemy, have frequently demonstrated all the courage of veteran troops and appeared, from the very moment they entered the field, ready to face the most hardened and experienced fighters. In 1756, when the Russian army marched into Poland, its soldiers' valor appeared no less impressive than that of the Prussians, then considered the most formidable veterans in Europe -- despite Russia having enjoyed nearly twenty years of deep peace, during which very few of its soldiers could have ever seen combat. When the Spanish war broke out in 1739, England had been at peace for about twenty-eight years. Yet the valor of English soldiers, far from being diminished by that long peace, was never more distinguished than in the attack on Cartagena, the first unfortunate action of that unfortunate war. In prolonged peace, generals may sometimes lose their edge, but where a well-regulated standing army has been maintained, the soldiers themselves never seem to forget their courage.
elegant: Standing armies maintain their fighting quality even through long periods of peace. Russia's soldiers in 1756 matched Prussian veterans despite twenty years of peace. England's troops in 1739 fought with distinction after twenty-eight peaceful years. Generals may lose their edge during peacetime, but well-maintained standing armies never forget their valor.
summary: Well-regulated standing armies retain their fighting capability even after extended periods of peace, as demonstrated by Russian forces in 1756 and English forces in 1739. While generals may grow rusty, professional soldiers maintain their courage through constant drill.
distilled: Standing armies preserve their fighting quality through long periods of peace because constant professional training maintains courage even without combat experience.
notes: Standing army resilience through peacetime -- Russian army in 1756 -- English attack on Cartagena 1739 -- Distinction between general's skill decay and soldier's valor retention -- Peacetime drill as preservative of military quality

refashioned: When a civilized nation depends on a militia for its defense, it is perpetually vulnerable to conquest by any neighboring barbarous nation. The frequent conquests of civilized Asian countries by the Tartars amply demonstrate the natural superiority of a barbarous nation's militia over a civilized one. A well-regulated standing army is superior to every militia. Such an army, since it can best be sustained by a wealthy and civilized nation, is also the only force capable of defending such a nation against invasion by poor and barbarous neighbors. It is only through a standing army, therefore, that civilization itself can be preserved or even maintained for any considerable length of time.
elegant: A civilized nation relying on militia is permanently vulnerable to barbarous invasion, as the Tartar conquests of Asia demonstrate. Only a standing army -- affordable only by wealthy civilized nations -- can defend civilization against barbarous neighbors. A standing army is therefore essential to civilization's very survival.
summary: Civilized nations depending on militias are perpetually vulnerable to barbarous invasion. Since only wealthy civilized nations can afford standing armies, and only standing armies can defend against barbarous militias, standing armies are essential to civilization's preservation.
distilled: Standing armies are the only means by which civilized nations can protect themselves from barbarous invasion and preserve civilization itself.
notes: Standing army as prerequisite for civilization -- Tartar conquests as historical evidence -- Wealth enables standing armies, standing armies protect wealth -- Circular reinforcement of civilization and military power -- Culminating argument for standing armies

refashioned: Just as a well-regulated standing army is the only means by which a civilized country can be defended, it is also the only means by which a barbarous country can be rapidly and effectively civilized. A standing army enforces the sovereign's law with irresistible power throughout even the most remote provinces, maintaining some degree of orderly government in regions that could not otherwise sustain any. Anyone who examines the reforms that Peter the Great introduced into the Russian Empire will find that nearly all of them ultimately depended on the establishment of a well-regulated standing army. That army was the instrument that implemented and maintained all his other reforms. The degree of order and internal peace that Russia has enjoyed ever since is entirely owed to the influence of that army.
elegant: A standing army not only defends civilization but can create it. By enforcing law throughout the most remote provinces, it establishes order where none could otherwise exist. Peter the Great's transformation of Russia demonstrates this perfectly -- virtually all his reforms depended on and were maintained by his standing army.
summary: Standing armies serve not only to defend civilized nations but to civilize barbarous ones, by enforcing law and order throughout remote provinces. Peter the Great's modernization of Russia was built entirely on the foundation of a well-regulated standing army.
distilled: Standing armies are instruments of civilization itself, as Peter the Great demonstrated by using his army as the foundation for all of Russia's modernization.
notes: Standing army as civilizing force -- Peter the Great's reforms as case study -- Law enforcement function of standing armies -- Military power as prerequisite for institutional development -- Dual role: defense and internal order

refashioned: Republicans have always been suspicious of standing armies as threats to liberty. And they certainly can be, whenever the interests of the commanding general and principal officers are not firmly connected to the preservation of the constitutional order. Caesar's standing army destroyed the Roman Republic. Cromwell's standing army expelled the Long Parliament. But where the sovereign himself serves as general and the principal nobility and gentry of the country are the chief officers -- where military force is commanded by those with the greatest stake in preserving civil authority, because they hold the largest share of it -- a standing army can never threaten liberty. On the contrary, it can sometimes promote it. The security a standing army provides to the sovereign eliminates the need for that anxious jealousy which, in some modern republics, monitors every citizen's smallest actions and stands ready at all times to disturb the peace. Where a government's security, even when backed by the leading citizens, is endangered by every popular disturbance -- where a small riot can trigger a revolution in hours -- the government must use its full power to suppress even the mildest complaint. But a sovereign who feels supported not only by the natural aristocracy but by a well-regulated standing army can safely pardon or ignore even the most groundless and extreme protests. His consciousness of his own security naturally inclines him to do so. The degree of liberty that approaches license can only be tolerated in countries where the sovereign is secured by a standing army. Only in such countries is it unnecessary to entrust the sovereign with discretionary power to suppress even the most frivolous provocations of licentious liberty.
elegant: Republicans rightly fear standing armies -- Caesar's destroyed Rome's republic, Cromwell's expelled Parliament. But when the sovereign commands the army and its officers are the nation's leading citizens, a standing army actually protects liberty. A secure sovereign can tolerate dissent; an insecure one must suppress it. Only where a standing army provides security can a society afford the degree of freedom that approaches license, because only then need the sovereign not fear every murmur of discontent.
summary: While standing armies can threaten liberty when commanded by ambitious generals, they can actually protect it when led by the sovereign and staffed by the nation's leading citizens. A militarily secure government can afford to tolerate dissent and protest, while an insecure one must suppress all opposition.
distilled: Standing armies threaten liberty when led by ambitious generals but protect it when commanded by the sovereign, because military security enables tolerance of dissent.
notes: Standing armies and liberty -- nuanced argument -- Caesar and Cromwell as dangers -- Officer class alignment with civil authority as safeguard -- Security enables tolerance -- Counter-intuitive argument: military power supports free speech -- Distinction between republican fears and actual dynamics -- Cross-reference: political economy of freedom

refashioned: The first duty of the sovereign, therefore -- defending society from the violence and injustice of other nations -- grows progressively more expensive as society advances in civilization. The military force that originally cost the sovereign nothing, either in peace or war, must eventually be maintained by the government during wartime, and eventually even during peacetime as well.
elegant: National defense grows ever more expensive as civilization advances. Military force that once cost governments nothing must eventually be funded in wartime, and ultimately in peacetime too.
summary: Smith summarizes his argument: the cost of national defense increases continuously with civilization, from zero cost in primitive societies to the permanent expense of standing armies in advanced ones.
distilled: The expense of national defense rises inexorably as societies advance from primitive self-sufficiency to the need for permanently funded standing armies.
notes: Summary of Part I on military expense -- Progressive cost increase with civilization -- Zero cost to permanent expense trajectory -- Transition from self-funded to state-funded defense -- Bridges to next topic on firearms

refashioned: The great transformation in warfare brought about by the invention of firearms has further increased both the expense of training soldiers in peacetime and the cost of deploying them in war. Both weapons and ammunition have become more expensive. A musket costs more than a javelin, bow, and arrows; a cannon or mortar costs more than a ballista or catapult. The gunpowder spent in a modern military review is lost forever and represents considerable expense. The javelins and arrows shot in an ancient review could easily be collected and reused, and were of very little value to begin with. Cannons and mortars are not only much more expensive but much heavier than ancient siege weapons, requiring greater expense to both prepare and transport. And because modern artillery so greatly surpasses ancient siege equipment, it has become far more difficult and costly to fortify a town against even a few weeks of bombardment. In modern times, many factors combine to make national defense more expensive. The natural effects of economic progress have been greatly amplified by a revolution in the art of war, triggered by what was essentially an accident: the invention of gunpowder.
elegant: Firearms dramatically increased military costs. Modern weapons are more expensive than ancient ones, ammunition is consumed rather than recovered, and heavy artillery requires costly transport. The superiority of modern artillery has also made fortification far more expensive. The natural rise in defense costs from economic progress has been compounded by the accidental invention of gunpowder.
summary: The invention of firearms dramatically increased military expenses by making weapons, ammunition, and fortifications all far more costly. This technological revolution compounded the already rising defense costs that economic development naturally produces.
distilled: Firearms multiplied defense costs by making weapons more expensive, ammunition consumable, artillery heavier, and fortifications costlier.
notes: Firearms revolution and military costs -- Consumable ammunition vs. recoverable projectiles -- Artillery superiority drives fortification costs -- Gunpowder invention as 'mere accident' with vast consequences -- Technology compounding economic trends in defense spending

refashioned: In modern warfare, the enormous expense of firearms gives a clear advantage to the nation that can best afford it -- and consequently to wealthy, civilized nations over poor, barbarous ones. In ancient times, wealthy civilized nations found it difficult to defend themselves against poor barbarous peoples. In modern times, the reverse is true: poor barbarous nations find it difficult to defend themselves against wealthy civilized ones. The invention of firearms, which at first glance appears so destructive, is actually favorable to both the survival and the spread of civilization.
elegant: Firearms give wealthy civilized nations a decisive advantage over poor barbarous ones -- reversing the ancient pattern where barbarians threatened civilization. The invention of firearms, seemingly destructive, actually promotes the permanence and expansion of civilization.
summary: Firearms reversed the ancient military balance: where once barbarous nations threatened civilized ones, now the expense of modern weapons gives wealthy nations a decisive advantage. This apparently destructive invention actually serves to protect and extend civilization.
distilled: Firearms reversed the military balance between civilized and barbarous nations by making wealth the decisive factor in military power.
notes: Firearms as civilizing force -- paradoxical argument -- Reversal of ancient military dynamics -- Wealth becomes decisive military advantage -- Technology as protector of civilization -- Optimistic view of military technology -- Cross-reference: 5.1.32 on standing armies preserving civilization

refashioned:
The second duty of the sovereign -- protecting every member of society from the injustice or oppression of every other member, or in other words, establishing an exact administration of justice -- requires very different levels of expense at different stages of society.

Among hunting nations, where there is scarcely any property, or at least none worth more than two or three days' labor, there is seldom any established magistrate or regular justice system. People who have no property can injure each other only in their persons or reputations. When one person kills, wounds, beats, or slanders another, the victim suffers but the perpetrator gains nothing. Property crimes are different: the benefit to the criminal is often equal to the loss suffered by the victim. Envy, malice, and resentment are the only passions that can drive someone to harm another in person or reputation.
elegant: The sovereign's second duty is administering justice -- protecting every citizen from the injustice of others. In hunting societies with virtually no property, there is little need for justice systems. Personal injuries harm the victim without benefiting the attacker. Only property crimes offer gain equal to the loss inflicted, and where property barely exists, neither do courts.
summary: Smith introduces the second duty of government: the administration of justice. In hunting societies with minimal property, formal justice systems are unnecessary because personal injuries offer no benefit to the aggressor, and there is little property to steal.
distilled: Justice systems are unnecessary in hunting societies because minimal property means crimes of personal violence offer no gain to the attacker.
notes: Second duty of sovereign: administration of justice -- Property as driver of need for justice -- Personal injuries vs. property crimes distinguished -- Rational crime theory: benefit-to-perpetrator analysis -- Stage theory applied to judicial institutions

refashioned: Most people are not frequently driven by envy, malice, or resentment, and even the worst individuals only act on these passions occasionally. Since gratifying these urges, however pleasing it may be to certain temperaments, brings no real or lasting advantage, most people are restrained by practical considerations. People can live together with reasonable security even without a civil magistrate to protect them from such passions. But avarice and ambition in the rich, and in the poor the hatred of work and the love of immediate ease and pleasure -- these are the passions that drive people to invade others' property. These passions operate far more steadily and influence behavior far more universally. Wherever there is great property, there is great inequality.
elegant: Malice and resentment rarely motivate crime because they bring no lasting benefit. People can coexist tolerably without courts to restrain such passions. But avarice in the rich and laziness in the poor -- steady, universal passions -- constantly drive property invasion. Where great property exists, great inequality follows.
