refashioned: Second, a weight-based tax on carriages, though perfectly equitable when applied solely to road repair, becomes a very unequal tax when applied to any other purpose or to meet general state expenses. When used solely for road maintenance, each vehicle pays exactly for the wear and tear it causes. When applied to other purposes, each vehicle pays more than its wear and tear, contributing to some unrelated state expense. Since the turnpike toll raises the price of goods in proportion to their weight rather than their value, it falls primarily on consumers of cheap, bulky commodities rather than on consumers of expensive, lightweight ones. Whatever state expense such a tax is meant to fund would therefore be borne chiefly by the poor rather than the rich -- by those least able to pay rather than those most able.
elegant: Second, weight-based tolls are equitable only for road maintenance because each vehicle pays for the damage it causes. Repurposed as general taxation, they become deeply regressive: since tolls raise prices by weight not value, they fall hardest on consumers of cheap, heavy goods -- the poor -- while barely affecting consumers of expensive, light goods -- the rich.
summary: Smith's second objection: weight-based tolls are fair only when funding road repair. As general taxation, they become regressive because they increase the price of cheap, heavy goods consumed by the poor while barely affecting the expensive, light goods bought by the rich.
distilled: Weight-based tolls become regressive general taxes because they raise prices of cheap, bulky goods consumed by the poor while barely affecting expensive, light goods bought by the rich.
notes: Regressive taxation problem -- Weight vs. value as tax base -- Equitable for specific purpose, inequitable for general purpose -- Poor bear disproportionate burden -- Second objection to nationalization -- Cross-reference: Smith's tax equity principles -- Earmarked taxes vs. general taxes

refashioned: Third, if the government ever neglected highway repair, it would be even harder than it now is to ensure that toll revenues were properly spent. A large revenue might be extracted from the people without any of it being applied to the only purpose for which such a revenue should ever be collected. If the relative poverty and insignificance of current turnpike trustees sometimes makes it difficult to hold them accountable for their mismanagement, how much more difficult would it be to hold the government itself accountable?
elegant: Third, government neglect of roads would be harder to remedy than trustee neglect. Toll revenue could be extracted without being spent on roads, and holding a powerful government accountable for misapplication would be far more difficult than holding mere trustees accountable.
summary: Smith's third objection: if the government neglected road maintenance, compelling proper use of toll revenue would be nearly impossible, since holding a powerful government accountable is far harder than holding minor trustees accountable.
distilled: Government control of toll revenue reduces accountability because it is far harder to compel a powerful state to maintain roads than to compel local trustees.
notes: Accountability problem with government control -- Power vs. accountability inverse relationship -- Third objection to nationalization -- Local trustees more accountable than central government -- Revenue diversion risk -- Cross-reference: principal-agent problems in government

refashioned: In France, the funds designated for highway repair are under the direct control of the executive power. These funds consist partly of a certain number of days of forced labor that country people across most of Europe are required to contribute to highway maintenance, and partly of whatever portion of the general revenue the king chooses to allocate from his other expenditures.
elegant: In France, highway funds are controlled by the executive, drawn from forced labor (corvee) imposed on rural people throughout Europe, supplemented by whatever the king allocates from general revenue.
summary: French highway maintenance is funded by the executive through a combination of forced rural labor (corvee) and discretionary allocations from the king's general revenue.
distilled: French highway funding combines forced rural labor with discretionary royal allocations, both controlled entirely by the executive power.
notes: French highway funding system -- Corvee (forced labor) for road maintenance -- Executive control of infrastructure funds -- Discretionary royal allocation -- Contrast with British turnpike system -- Continental European practice

refashioned: Under ancient French law, as under that of most other European countries, the forced labor of country people was directed by local or provincial magistrates independent of the king's council. Under current practice, however, both the forced labor and whatever other funds the king may assign for highway repair in any particular province are entirely under the control of the intendant -- an officer appointed and removable by the king's council, who receives his orders from it and is in constant communication with it. In the progress of despotism, executive power gradually absorbs the authority of every other power in the state and takes over management of every branch of revenue designated for any public purpose. In France, the main highways connecting the principal cities are generally kept in good condition and are in some provinces even considerably superior to most British turnpike roads. But the secondary roads -- the vast majority of roads in the country -- are entirely neglected and in many places completely impassable for heavy vehicles. In some areas it is even dangerous to travel on horseback, and mules are the only safe means of transport. The proud minister of an ostentatious court may enjoy executing a grand, visible work like a major highway, frequently seen by the principal nobility, whose praise both flatters his vanity and strengthens his position at court. But executing a great number of small works that offer nothing impressive to display, that excite no admiration in any traveler, and that have nothing to recommend them but their practical usefulness -- this is a task that seems, in every respect, too insignificant to merit the attention of such a great official. Under such an administration, therefore, these lesser works are almost always entirely neglected.
elegant: France's centralization -- from local magistrates to royal intendants -- exemplifies how despotism absorbs all power. The results are predictable: main highways between great cities are excellent, showcasing ministerial grandeur and winning aristocratic praise. But cross-roads, comprising the vast majority of the network, are completely neglected -- sometimes impassable even on horseback. Proud ministers pursue visible prestige projects while ignoring the utilitarian small works that lack glamour but serve the people.
summary: French centralization of road administration under royal intendants produces excellent main highways that showcase ministerial prestige but completely neglected secondary roads. Proud officials pursue glamorous projects visible to the nobility while ignoring the unglamorous but essential local infrastructure.
distilled: Centralized executive control of infrastructure produces impressive showpiece highways while neglecting the essential secondary roads that lack prestige value.
notes: Centralization vs. local control of infrastructure -- French intendant system -- Despotism absorbs all administrative power -- Prestige bias: main roads vs. cross-roads -- Vanity projects vs. utilitarian works -- Ministerial incentives misaligned with public need -- British turnpike comparison -- Cross-reference: incentive problems in centralized government

refashioned: In China, and in several other Asian governments, the executive power assumes responsibility for both highway repair and the maintenance of navigable canals. In the instructions given to each provincial governor, these matters are reportedly emphasized consistently, and the court's judgment of a governor's performance is heavily influenced by how well he has attended to this aspect of his duties. This branch of public administration is said to be well managed in all those countries, but especially in China, where the highways, and still more the navigable canals, are said to far surpass anything comparable in Europe.
elegant: In China and other Asian governments, the executive manages both roads and canals directly, with governors evaluated partly on their infrastructure performance. This system reportedly produces excellent results -- Chinese roads and canals are said to surpass anything in Europe.
summary: Asian governments, particularly China, achieve excellent infrastructure by making provincial governors directly accountable for road and canal maintenance as part of their performance evaluations.
distilled: China's reportedly superior infrastructure results from direct executive management where provincial governors are evaluated on their maintenance of roads and canals.
notes: Chinese infrastructure management model -- Governor performance evaluation includes infrastructure -- Executive-managed infrastructure can work with proper incentives -- China and Asia as counterexamples to European models -- Performance-based accountability -- Smith expresses some skepticism in next entry

refashioned: The accounts of these works transmitted to Europe have generally been produced by credulous and easily impressed travelers, and frequently by foolish and dishonest missionaries. Had they been examined by more discerning observers and reported by more reliable witnesses, they would perhaps not appear so remarkable. Bernier's account of similar works in India falls far short of what other, more wonder-prone travelers had reported. It may also be the case in those countries, as it is in France, that the great thoroughfares likely to be discussed at court and in the capital receive attention while everything else is neglected. Moreover, in China, India, and several other Asian governments, the sovereign's revenue derives almost entirely from a land tax or land rent that rises and falls with the annual produce of the land.
elegant: Reports of Asian infrastructure come from credulous travelers and unreliable missionaries; more discerning observers like Bernier found India's works less impressive. As in France, major routes may receive attention while lesser ones are neglected. Crucially, Asian sovereigns derive revenue primarily from land taxes that fluctuate with agricultural output -- a connection relevant to their infrastructure incentives.
summary: Smith is skeptical of glowing reports about Asian infrastructure, noting they come from unreliable sources. He suggests the same prestige bias found in France may apply, and identifies the land-tax revenue model as a key factor explaining Asian governments' attention to infrastructure.
distilled: Reports of superior Asian infrastructure are unreliable, and the real explanation for whatever attention exists lies in sovereigns' land-tax revenues being directly tied to agricultural productivity.
notes: Skepticism about Asian infrastructure reports -- Credulous travelers and unreliable missionaries -- Bernier as more reliable source on India -- Same prestige bias as France possible -- Key insight: land tax revenue creates infrastructure incentive -- Revenue linked to agricultural output -- Transition to next argument

refashioned: The sovereign's principal interest -- his revenue -- is in such countries necessarily and directly linked to the cultivation of the land, to the volume of its output, and to the value of that output. But to make that output as large and valuable as possible, it is essential to provide the widest possible market for it, which requires establishing the freest, easiest, and cheapest transportation between all parts of the country. This can only be achieved through the best possible roads and navigable canals.
elegant: Where sovereign revenue depends on land taxes, the ruler's self-interest directly aligns with maximizing agricultural output -- which requires the widest possible markets, achievable only through excellent roads and canals. Revenue incentives drive infrastructure investment.
summary: When sovereign revenue derives from land taxes, the ruler's financial self-interest naturally drives investment in roads and canals because better transportation expands markets, increases agricultural output, and therefore raises tax revenue.
distilled: Land-tax-dependent sovereigns invest in infrastructure because better transportation expands markets, increases agricultural output, and directly raises their revenue.
notes: Self-interest alignment: land tax and infrastructure -- Revenue incentive for transportation investment -- Market expansion through infrastructure -- Agricultural productivity and sovereign revenue linked -- Explains Asian attention to roads and canals -- Cross-reference: incentive alignment as governance principle

refashioned: But in no part of Europe does sovereign revenue arise chiefly from a land tax or land rent. In the great European kingdoms, the greater part of revenue may ultimately depend on the produce of the land, but that dependence is neither direct nor obvious. European sovereigns therefore do not feel themselves as directly motivated to promote increases in both the quantity and value of agricultural output, or to maintain good roads and canals to provide the widest possible market for that output. Even if it were true -- which I consider quite doubtful -- that in parts of Asia this department of public administration is well managed by the executive power, there is not the slightest probability that it could be tolerably managed by executive power anywhere in Europe under present circumstances.
elegant: European sovereign revenue does not derive directly from land taxes, so European rulers lack the direct incentive Asian sovereigns have to invest in infrastructure. The connection between European revenue and land productivity is too indirect and obscure to motivate road and canal building. Even if Asian executive management of infrastructure works -- which Smith doubts -- it could not succeed in Europe.
summary: European sovereigns lack the direct revenue incentive that drives Asian infrastructure investment because European tax systems do not tie royal income directly to agricultural output. Smith concludes that executive management of infrastructure cannot work in Europe.
distilled: European sovereigns lack the direct revenue incentive to maintain infrastructure because their tax systems do not directly link royal income to agricultural productivity.
notes: European vs. Asian revenue structures -- Indirect tax link weakens infrastructure incentive -- No direct motivation for European sovereigns -- Skepticism about executive infrastructure management in Europe -- Institutional context determines policy effectiveness -- Cross-reference: tax structure shapes government behavior

refashioned: Even those public works which by their nature cannot generate revenue to maintain themselves, but whose benefits are largely confined to a particular locality or district, are always better maintained by a local or provincial revenue under local administration than by the general revenue of the state managed by the executive power. If London's streets were lit and paved at the expense of the national treasury, is there any chance they would be as well lit and paved as they are now, or even at as low a cost? The expense, instead of being raised through a local tax on the inhabitants of each particular street, parish, or district in London, would in that case be drawn from the general revenue of the state and therefore raised by taxes on all the inhabitants of the kingdom -- the great majority of whom derive no benefit whatsoever from the lighting and paving of London's streets.
elegant: Local public works that cannot generate their own revenue are always better managed by local government than by central authority. London's streets would neither be better maintained nor cheaper if funded from the national treasury instead of local taxes. National funding would tax the entire kingdom for a benefit enjoyed only by Londoners.
summary: Public works with purely local benefits should be funded and managed locally. Central government funding would be less efficient, more expensive, and would unjustly tax the entire nation for benefits enjoyed only by local residents, as the example of London's street lighting and paving demonstrates.
distilled: Local public works are always better managed and more justly funded by local government than by central authority, which would tax the entire nation for purely local benefits.
notes: Subsidiarity principle: local management for local works -- London street lighting as example -- Local taxation matches benefits to costs -- National funding creates free-rider problem in reverse -- Efficiency of local administration -- Geographic equity in taxation -- Cross-reference: modern fiscal federalism and subsidiarity

refashioned: The abuses that creep into local and provincial administration of local revenues, however enormous they may seem, are in reality almost always trivial compared to those that routinely occur in the administration and spending of a great empire's revenue. They are also much easier to correct. Under the local administration of justices of the peace in Great Britain, the six days of labor that country people must give for highway repair is not always applied with perfect judgment, but it is rarely enforced with cruelty or oppression. In France, under the administration of the intendants, the application is no more judicious, and the enforcement is frequently cruel and oppressive. These forced labor duties -- corvees, as they are called -- serve as one of the principal instruments of tyranny by which those officers punish any parish or community that has had the misfortune to fall out of their favor.
elegant: Abuses in local revenue administration, however large they appear, are trivial compared to those in a great empire's finances -- and far easier to fix. In Britain, forced highway labor is sometimes poorly directed but rarely oppressive. In France, the same corvee system becomes an instrument of tyranny, wielded by intendants to punish disfavored communities.
summary: Local administrative abuses, though visible, are minor compared to imperial-scale corruption and easier to correct. Britain's highway labor system is imperfect but not oppressive, while France's corvee system is routinely used as a tool of tyranny.
distilled: Local government abuses are always smaller and more correctable than those of large centralized administrations.
notes: Corvees -- compulsory unpaid labor duties owed to the state, a major grievance in pre-revolutionary France. Contrasts British decentralized administration (justices of the peace) with French centralized intendant system. Key principle: smaller jurisdictions produce smaller abuses. Cross-reference to Smith's general preference for local over imperial administration (5.1.82-91).

refashioned:
Of the Public Works and Institutions Necessary for Facilitating Particular Branches of Commerce.

The public works and institutions discussed above are meant to facilitate commerce in general. But to support certain specific branches of commerce, specialized institutions are needed, which in turn require their own particular and extraordinary expense.
elegant: The public works discussed so far serve commerce generally. But specific branches of trade require specialized institutions with their own dedicated funding.
summary: Beyond general commercial infrastructure, particular branches of trade need specialized public institutions that require their own extraordinary expenses.
distilled: Specific branches of commerce require dedicated public institutions beyond those serving trade in general.
notes: Section heading and transitional passage. Shifts from general infrastructure (roads, bridges, canals) to trade-specific institutions. Sets up the discussion of trading companies, consulates, and ambassadors that follows.

refashioned: Certain branches of commerce carried on with uncivilized nations require extraordinary protection. An ordinary warehouse or trading office could offer little security to merchants trading on the west coast of Africa. To protect their goods from hostile locals, the trading post must be somewhat fortified. The disorders in India's government were thought to make similar precautions necessary, even among that mild and gentle people; and it was under the pretense of securing their persons and property from violence that both the English and French East India companies were first allowed to build forts there. Among other nations with strong governments that permit no foreigners to maintain fortified positions within their territory, it may be necessary to station an ambassador, minister, or consul who can settle disputes among his own countrymen according to their customs, and who can use his official standing to intervene with more authority in disputes with locals than any private person could. Commercial interests have frequently made it necessary to maintain ministers in foreign countries where neither war nor alliance would have required them. The Turkey Company's trade first prompted the appointment of a permanent ambassador at Constantinople. England's first embassies to Russia arose entirely from commercial interests. The constant friction that trade necessarily creates between subjects of different European states has probably established the custom of keeping ambassadors or ministers permanently resident in all neighboring countries, even in peacetime. This custom, unknown in ancient times, appears to date from the late fifteenth or early sixteenth century -- precisely when commerce first began extending to most European nations, and when they first began paying serious attention to its interests.
elegant: Trade with unstable or hostile regions requires fortified trading posts -- as on the African coast and in India, where both English and French companies built forts ostensibly for protection. Where strong governments forbid foreign fortifications, ambassadors and consuls serve instead, settling disputes and protecting merchants with official authority. Commercial interests, not diplomacy, drove the first permanent embassies: the Turkey Company prompted Constantinople's, and Russia's arose entirely from trade. The modern custom of permanent ambassadors even in peacetime dates from the late fifteenth century, when European commerce first expanded widely.
summary: Trade with dangerous or distant regions requires extraordinary protection -- fortified posts in hostile areas, ambassadors and consuls where governments are strong. The modern system of permanent diplomatic representation originated not from military or political needs but from commercial interests, beginning in the late fifteenth century.
distilled: The modern system of permanent diplomacy originated from commercial necessity, not from war or alliance.
notes: Links the origins of modern diplomacy to commercial expansion -- a striking historical claim. Notes the pretextual nature of East India Company fortifications in India. Cross-references the Turkey Company (discussed further in 5.1.99-104). The dating of permanent embassies to the late 15th/early 16th century aligns with the Age of Exploration and the rise of mercantile states.

refashioned: It seems reasonable that the extraordinary expense of protecting any particular branch of commerce should be covered by a moderate tax on that branch -- for example, a moderate fee paid by traders when they first enter it, or, what is fairer, a specific duty of so much per cent on goods imported into or exported from the countries where that trade is conducted. The protection of trade in general from pirates and freebooters is said to have given rise to the first customs duties. But if it was considered reasonable to impose a general tax on trade to cover the cost of protecting trade generally, it should seem equally reasonable to impose a specific tax on a particular branch of trade to cover the extraordinary cost of protecting that branch.
elegant: The extraordinary cost of protecting a specific trade should be funded by a moderate tax on that trade -- either an entry fee or a duty on its imports and exports. If general customs duties are justified by the general protection of trade from pirates, then specific duties for protecting specific trades are equally justified.
summary: The cost of protecting particular branches of commerce should be funded by taxes on those branches, just as general customs duties fund the general protection of trade from piracy.
distilled: Specific trade protection costs should be funded by specific taxes on the trade being protected.
notes: Applies the benefit principle of taxation -- those who benefit from protection should pay for it. Notes the historical origin of customs duties in anti-piracy protection. Distinguishes general trade taxes from branch-specific levies. This principle later informs Smith's critique of trading companies that collect these duties themselves rather than leaving them to the state.

refashioned: Protecting trade in general has always been considered essential to national defense and therefore a necessary duty of the executive power. The collection and application of general customs duties have accordingly always been left to that power. But protecting any particular branch of trade is simply part of the general protection of trade -- and therefore part of the executive's duty. If nations always acted consistently, the specific duties levied for such particular protection should likewise have been left to the executive's control. But nations have not always acted consistently. In most commercial states of Europe, particular companies of merchants have managed to persuade legislators to entrust them with this part of the sovereign's duty, along with all the powers necessarily connected with it.
elegant: Protecting trade is a duty of the executive, which is why customs collection belongs to the state. Protecting specific branches of trade is merely a subset of this duty. Yet in most European commercial states, merchant companies have persuaded legislators to hand them this sovereign function -- along with all the powers it entails.
summary: Trade protection is inherently a state function, but merchant companies across Europe have persuaded governments to delegate this sovereign duty to them, along with the powers that come with it.
distilled: Merchant companies have captured a sovereign function -- trade protection -- by persuading legislatures to delegate it along with its associated powers.
notes: Identifies regulatory capture avant la lettre -- private companies assuming state functions. The key insight is that protecting particular trades is logically part of the executive's general trade-protection duty. Sets up the extended critique of regulated and joint-stock trading companies that follows. Cross-reference to Book IV's critique of mercantile influence on legislation.

refashioned:
These companies, though perhaps useful for first introducing certain branches of commerce by conducting experiments at their own expense that the state might not have thought it prudent to undertake, have in the long run universally proved either burdensome or useless, and have either mismanaged or confined the trade.

When these companies do not trade on a joint stock but are required to admit any properly qualified person upon paying a certain fee and agreeing to follow the company's regulations -- each member trading on his own capital and at his own risk -- they are called regulated companies. When they trade on a joint stock, each member sharing in common profits or losses in proportion to his stake, they are called joint-stock companies. Both types sometimes have exclusive privileges and sometimes do not.
elegant: Trading companies may have been useful for pioneering new trades at their own risk, but they have universally proven either burdensome or useless over time, mismanaging or restricting the trade they were meant to promote. There are two types: regulated companies, where members trade individually under shared rules; and joint-stock companies, where members share common profits and losses proportionally. Either type may or may not hold exclusive privileges.
summary: Trading companies may pioneer new commerce but inevitably become burdensome or useless, mismanaging or restricting trade. They come in two forms: regulated companies with individual trading, and joint-stock companies with shared capital and profits.
distilled: Trading companies useful for pioneering new commerce inevitably become either burdensome or useless, mismanaging or restricting the very trade they were meant to promote.
notes: Introduces the key distinction between regulated companies and joint-stock companies -- central to the analysis that follows through 5.1.155. Smith's verdict is sweeping: 'universally, either burdensome or useless.' The initial-experiment justification anticipates modern arguments for temporary infant-industry protection and patent monopolies.

refashioned: Regulated companies resemble the trade guilds common in cities and towns across Europe; they are essentially enlarged monopolies of the same kind. Just as no town resident can practice an incorporated trade without first gaining membership in the guild, in most cases no citizen can lawfully conduct foreign trade in a regulated company's territory without first becoming a member. The monopoly is more or less strict depending on how difficult the admission terms are and how much power the directors have to channel most of the trade to themselves and their friends. In the oldest regulated companies, apprenticeship privileges worked the same as in other guilds: someone who had served their time under a company member could become a member themselves, either for free or for a much smaller fee than others paid. The usual corporate spirit prevails in all regulated companies wherever the law does not restrain it. When allowed to follow their natural instincts, they have always tried to restrict competition to the smallest possible number of traders by imposing burdensome regulations on the trade. When the law has prevented them from doing this, they have become entirely useless and insignificant.
elegant: Regulated companies are enlarged trade guilds -- monopolies that bar outsiders from foreign trade in their territory. Their restrictiveness depends on admission difficulty and directors' power to funnel trade to themselves. The guild mentality prevails wherever law permits: they restrict competition through burdensome regulations. When law prevents this, they become entirely useless.
summary: Regulated companies function as enlarged trade guilds, restricting foreign commerce to their members. They naturally tend toward monopoly by imposing burdensome regulations to limit competition, and when prevented from doing so by law, they become completely useless.
distilled: Regulated companies are enlarged monopolistic guilds that either restrict trade through burdensome rules or, when prevented from doing so, become entirely useless.
notes: Draws explicit parallel between regulated foreign trading companies and domestic trade guilds -- both are monopolistic rent-seeking institutions. 'Corporation spirit' is Smith's term for the universal tendency of organized groups to restrict competition. Key observation: these companies are useful only insofar as they restrict trade, which is harmful -- so they are harmful when effective and useless when restrained. Cross-reference to Book I's critique of guild apprenticeship restrictions.

refashioned:
The regulated companies for foreign commerce currently operating in Great Britain are the ancient Merchant Adventurers Company (now commonly called the Hamburg Company), the Russia Company, the Eastland Company, the Turkey Company, and the African Company.

The terms of admission to the Hamburg Company are now said to be quite easy, and its directors either lack the power to impose troublesome restraints on trade or at least have not recently exercised it. This was not always the case. Around the middle of the last century, the admission fee was fifty pounds, at one point reaching one hundred pounds, and the company was said to be extremely oppressive. In 1643, 1645, and 1661, the clothiers and free traders of western England complained to Parliament that the company was acting as a monopoly, confining trade and oppressing manufacturers. Though these complaints produced no legislation, they probably intimidated the company enough to force reform. Since then, at least, there have been no complaints against them. By the statute of William III, the Russia Company's admission fee was reduced to five pounds, and by the statute of Charles II, the Eastland Company's to forty shillings, while Sweden, Denmark, Norway, and all northern Baltic countries were exempted from the Eastland Company's charter. The conduct of these companies had probably prompted these parliamentary acts. Before that time, Sir Josiah Child had described both companies and the Hamburg Company as extremely oppressive, blaming their bad management for the poor state of trade with countries under their respective charters. But though such companies may no longer be very oppressive in current times, they are certainly altogether useless. To be merely useless is perhaps the highest praise that can ever justly be given to a regulated company; and all three companies mentioned seem, in their present state, to deserve this praise.
elegant: Britain's regulated trading companies -- Hamburg, Russia, Eastland, Turkey, and African -- have histories of oppressive monopoly practices. The Hamburg Company once charged enormous admission fees and was denounced to Parliament as monopolistic. Parliamentary acts forced fee reductions on the Russia and Eastland companies. Sir Josiah Child condemned all three as badly managed. Though no longer actively oppressive, they are now entirely useless -- and being merely useless is the highest compliment a regulated company can earn.
summary: Britain's regulated trading companies have histories of monopolistic oppression, prompting parliamentary reforms that reduced admission fees and exempted territories. Though no longer actively oppressive, they have become entirely useless -- which Smith considers the best that can be said of any regulated company.
distilled: Britain's regulated trading companies have evolved from actively oppressive monopolies to merely useless ones -- the best outcome such institutions can achieve.
notes: Historical survey of five specific regulated companies. Sir Josiah Child (1630-1699) -- prominent mercantilist writer and East India Company director. The progression from oppressive to useless illustrates Smith's general thesis about regulated companies (5.1.98). The sardonic observation that 'merely useless' is the highest eulogy such companies deserve is vintage Smith.

refashioned: The Turkey Company formerly charged an admission fee of twenty-five pounds for anyone under twenty-six and fifty pounds for anyone older. Only merchants could be admitted, a restriction that excluded all shopkeepers and retailers. By a company bylaw, no British manufactures could be exported to Turkey except in the company's general ships, and since those ships always sailed from London, this confined the trade to that expensive port and its nearby traders. Another bylaw prohibited anyone living within twenty miles of London who was not a freeman of the city from becoming a member -- a restriction that, combined with the first, effectively excluded everyone except London's freemen. Since the timing for loading and sailing the general ships depended entirely on the directors, they could easily fill them with their own goods and those of their friends, excluding others on the pretext that their proposals had come too late. Under these conditions, this company was in every respect a strict and oppressive monopoly. These abuses led to the act of 26 George II.
elegant: The Turkey Company maintained an oppressive monopoly through layered restrictions: high age-graded admission fees, exclusion of non-merchants, mandatory use of company ships sailing only from London, and bylaws limiting membership to London freemen. Directors exploited their control over ship scheduling to favor their own cargo. These stacked restrictions made it a textbook case of monopolistic abuse, prompting parliamentary intervention.
summary: The Turkey Company operated as an oppressive monopoly through high admission fees, exclusion of non-merchants, mandatory use of London-only company ships, and membership restricted to London freemen -- all allowing directors to monopolize trade for themselves.
distilled: The Turkey Company exemplified how regulated companies stack multiple restrictions to create oppressive monopolies favoring their own directors.
notes: Detailed anatomy of how a regulated company constructs a monopoly through layered bylaws rather than a single restriction. Each rule individually seems moderate; combined, they create near-total exclusion. The ship-scheduling manipulation is an early example of what economists now call 'gatekeeping.' The act of 26 George II (1753) is the reform discussed in 5.1.101.

refashioned: This act reduced the admission fee to twenty pounds for all persons, without any distinction of age, and without restriction to mere merchants or to London's freemen. It granted all such persons the liberty of exporting British goods from any port in Great Britain to any port in Turkey -- provided those goods were not otherwise prohibited from export -- upon paying both the general customs duties and the particular duties assessed for the company's necessary expenses, and upon submitting to the lawful authority of the British ambassador and consuls in Turkey and to the company's properly enacted bylaws. To prevent oppression through bylaws, the same act provided that if any seven members felt aggrieved by a bylaw enacted after the act's passage, they could appeal to the Board of Trade and Plantations (whose authority has since passed to a committee of the Privy Council), provided the appeal was filed within twelve months of the bylaw's enactment. If any seven members felt aggrieved by a bylaw enacted before the act, they could file a similar appeal within twelve months of the act taking effect.
elegant: Parliament reformed the Turkey Company by reducing its admission fee to a flat twenty pounds, removing age and occupational restrictions, and opening exports from all British ports. Members needed only to pay customs duties and company levies and submit to the ambassador's authority. To check future abuses, any seven members could appeal oppressive bylaws to the Board of Trade within twelve months.
summary: Parliamentary reform opened the Turkey trade by reducing fees, removing membership restrictions, allowing exports from all ports, and creating an appeals process for oppressive bylaws.
distilled: Parliament opened the Turkey trade by eliminating the company's most exclusionary restrictions and creating an appeals mechanism against oppressive bylaws.
notes: The act of 26 George II c.18 (1753) -- a case study in partial deregulation. The seven-member appeal threshold is notably low, designed to make challenges feasible. The twelve-month limitation period, however, creates a window problem that Smith criticizes in the next entry. Board of Trade and Plantations -- predecessor to modern trade departments.

refashioned: One year's experience, however, may not always be enough for all members of a large company to discover the harmful tendency of a particular bylaw. And if several members discover it only later, neither the Board of Trade nor the committee of the Privy Council can offer them any remedy. Besides, the main purpose of most bylaws in all regulated companies, as in all other corporations, is not so much to oppress existing members as to discourage others from joining -- which can be accomplished not only by high fees but by many other devices.
elegant: A twelve-month appeals window is often too short for members to recognize a harmful bylaw. Once it expires, no remedy exists. Moreover, most corporate bylaws aim less at oppressing current members than at deterring new entrants -- through not just fees but countless other devices.
summary: The twelve-month limit for appealing bylaws is often insufficient, as harmful effects take longer to appear. Furthermore, corporate bylaws primarily aim to deter new entrants rather than oppress existing members.
distilled: Appeal deadlines are too short to catch harmful bylaws, and the real purpose of most corporate rules is to deter new competitors from entering.
notes: Two distinct criticisms: (1) the statute of limitations problem in regulatory appeals, and (2) the insight that corporate rules primarily serve as barriers to entry rather than as internal governance. The latter observation anticipates modern economics on barriers to entry and incumbent protection. Cross-reference to 5.1.98 on 'corporation spirit.'

refashioned: The constant aim of such companies is always to raise their own profits as high as possible by keeping the market understocked -- both for the goods they export and those they import -- which can only be done by restricting competition and discouraging new entrants. A fee of even twenty pounds, though perhaps not enough to discourage a man intending to enter the Turkey trade permanently, may be sufficient to discourage a speculative merchant from risking a single venture. In all trades, the established traders, even when not formally incorporated, naturally combine to raise profits. Nothing is as likely to keep profits at their proper level as the occasional competition of speculative adventurers.
elegant: Trading companies aim to maximize profits by keeping markets understocked through restricting competition and deterring new entrants. Even a modest admission fee can discourage speculative one-time ventures. Since established traders naturally combine to raise profits, occasional competition from speculative adventurers is the best mechanism for keeping profits at their proper level.
summary: Trading companies seek to maximize profits by keeping markets understocked through restricting competition. Established traders naturally combine to raise prices, and the best check on this is the threat of occasional competition from speculative adventurers, which even moderate entry fees can effectively deter.
distilled: The occasional competition of speculative adventurers is the best check on the tendency of established traders to combine and raise profits above their natural level.
notes: Key insight on market dynamics: it is not just active competitors but the threat of entry that disciplines prices and profits. Even modest barriers to entry (twenty pounds) can be enough to eliminate this competitive threat from occasional speculators. Anticipates the concept of 'contestable markets' in modern economics. 'Proper level' of profits -- Smith's notion of the natural rate of profit from Book I.

refashioned: The Turkey trade, though somewhat opened by this act of Parliament, is still considered by many people to be far from fully free. The Turkey Company pays to maintain an ambassador and two or three consuls who, like other public ministers, ought to be entirely maintained by the state, with the trade laid open to all of His Majesty's subjects. The various taxes levied by the company for this and other corporate purposes could easily provide revenue more than sufficient for the state to maintain such ministers itself.
elegant: Despite parliamentary reform, the Turkey trade remains far from free. The company still funds an ambassador and consuls -- officials that should be maintained by the state, with the trade opened to all. The company's own tax revenues would more than cover these costs if transferred to government.
summary: The Turkey trade remains partially restricted because the company still funds diplomatic officials that should be maintained by the state. The company's existing tax revenues would more than suffice for government to provide this service directly.
distilled: The Turkey trade should be fully opened by transferring diplomatic costs from the company to the state, which the company's own tax revenues could easily fund.
notes: Practical policy recommendation: eliminate the trading company as middleman and have the state directly fund the diplomats that trade requires. The company's continued role as tax collector and diplomat-funder is the residual justification for its existence -- remove that, and the company has no purpose. Cross-reference to 5.1.96 on trade protection as a sovereign duty.

refashioned: As Sir Josiah Child observed, regulated companies, though they frequently maintained public ministers, never maintained forts or garrisons in the countries where they traded, whereas joint-stock companies frequently did. And in reality, regulated companies are far less suited for this kind of service. First, the directors of a regulated company have no particular interest in the prosperity of the company's general trade, for whose sake forts and garrisons are maintained. The decline of general trade may actually benefit their own private dealings by reducing the number of competitors, allowing them to buy cheaper and sell dearer. The directors of a joint-stock company, by contrast, share only in profits made on the common stock they manage and have no separate private trade whose interest can diverge from the company's general trade. Their private interest is aligned with the company's general prosperity and with maintaining the forts and garrisons necessary for its defense. They are therefore more likely to give these the continual, careful attention they require. Second, joint-stock company directors always manage a large common capital, part of which they can properly use for building, repairing, and maintaining forts and garrisons. Regulated company directors manage no common capital and have no fund for this purpose beyond the unpredictable revenue from admission fees and corporate duties. Even if they had the same interest in maintaining forts and garrisons, they would rarely have the same ability to do so effectively. Maintaining a public minister, which requires little attention and only moderate expense, is a task much better suited to the temperament and resources of a regulated company.
elegant: Regulated companies have never maintained forts or garrisons, while joint-stock companies frequently have -- and for good reason. Regulated company directors have no stake in the general trade's prosperity; its decline may actually benefit their private dealings by reducing competition. Joint-stock directors, sharing only in common profits, have interests aligned with general trade and fort maintenance. Moreover, joint-stock companies command large common capitals for construction and repair, while regulated companies have only unpredictable fee revenue. Regulated companies are suited only to the modest task of maintaining a public minister.
summary: Joint-stock companies are better suited than regulated companies to maintain forts and garrisons because their directors' interests align with the general trade and they command large common capitals. Regulated company directors may actually benefit from the general trade's decline, and they lack the funds for serious infrastructure.
distilled: Joint-stock companies can maintain forts and garrisons because their directors' interests align with the general trade and they command common capital; regulated companies can manage neither.
notes: Structural comparison of incentive alignment in two corporate forms. The regulated company directors' perverse incentive -- profiting from general trade decline -- is a principal-agent problem. Joint-stock alignment works only because directors have no separate private trade. Sir Josiah Child (1630-1699) -- ironic authority, as he was himself a notorious manipulator of the East India Company. This passage anticipates modern corporate governance debates about management incentives.

refashioned: Long after Sir Josiah Child's time, however, in 1750, a regulated company was established -- the present Company of Merchants Trading to Africa -- which was expressly charged with maintaining all British forts and garrisons between Cape Blanc and the Cape of Good Hope, and later only those between Cape Rouge and the Cape of Good Hope. The act establishing this company (23 George II, c.51) appears to have had two distinct objectives: first, to effectively restrain the oppressive and monopolizing spirit natural to regulated company directors; and second, to compel them, as much as possible, to give an attention to fort maintenance that does not come naturally to them.
elegant: In 1750, despite the general unsuitability of regulated companies for the task, Parliament charged the new African Company with maintaining British forts from Cape Rouge to the Cape of Good Hope. The establishing act had two aims: to restrain the company's natural monopolizing tendencies and to force an unnatural attentiveness to fort maintenance.
summary: Parliament in 1750 established the African Company as a regulated company charged with maintaining forts -- a task poorly suited to such companies. The legislation aimed both to restrain monopolistic tendencies and to compel attention to fort maintenance.
distilled: Parliament's 1750 African Company experiment attempted to force a regulated company to do what such companies are structurally unsuited for: maintain forts and restrain their own monopolistic instincts.
notes: Sets up a case study in institutional design failure. The act's two objectives are essentially contradictory to the nature of regulated companies as described in 5.1.98 and 5.1.105. Cape Blanc and Cape Rouge -- reference points on the West African coast demarcating zones of British commercial interest. The 23 George II c.51 (1750) -- one of several mid-18th century attempts to reform colonial trading arrangements.

refashioned: To achieve the first objective, the admission fee was limited to forty shillings. The company was prohibited from trading in its corporate capacity or on a joint stock, from borrowing money under its corporate seal, or from imposing any restraints on trade, which could be carried on freely from all places by all British subjects who paid the fee. Governance rested in a committee of nine persons meeting in London, elected annually by the company's freemen in London, Bristol, and Liverpool -- three from each city. No committee member could serve more than three consecutive years. Any committee member could be removed by the Board of Trade and Plantations (now succeeded by a committee of the Privy Council) after being heard in his own defense.
elegant: To prevent monopoly, the African Company's admission fee was capped at forty shillings. It was barred from trading corporately, borrowing under seal, or restricting trade. Any British subject could trade freely upon paying the fee. A nine-member committee, elected annually from London, Bristol, and Liverpool, governed with three-year term limits and could be removed by the Board of Trade after a hearing.
summary: The African Company's charter included strong anti-monopoly provisions: minimal admission fees, prohibition on corporate trading, free trade for all British subjects, and a rotating elected committee with term limits and removability.
distilled: The African Company's charter attempted to prevent monopoly through low fees, open trade, term limits, and government oversight of its governing committee.
notes: Detailed institutional design to counter the 'corporation spirit.' Term limits (three years), geographic representation (London, Bristol, Liverpool -- the three major slave-trading ports), and government removal power all aim to prevent entrenchment. The prohibition on corporate trading distinguishes it from joint-stock companies. Despite these safeguards, Smith argues in subsequent entries that the design failed.

refashioned: The committee was forbidden to export enslaved people from Africa or to import any African goods into Great Britain. But since they were charged with maintaining forts and garrisons, they could export goods and stores from Great Britain to Africa for that purpose. From the money they received from the company, they were allowed a sum not exceeding eight hundred pounds for clerks' and agents' salaries at London, Bristol, and Liverpool, office rent in London, and all other management expenses, commissions, and agency costs in England. Whatever remained after covering these expenses, they could divide among themselves as compensation for their trouble, in whatever manner they saw fit. Under this arrangement, one might have expected the spirit of monopoly to be effectively restrained and the first objective sufficiently met. It would seem, however, that it was not.
elegant: The committee was barred from the slave trade and African imports but could export supplies for fort maintenance. Their compensation was capped at eight hundred pounds for all administrative costs, with any remainder divided among themselves. This arrangement should have restrained monopolistic behavior -- but it apparently did not.
summary: The African Company's committee was barred from direct trading and limited to modest administrative compensation. Despite these restrictions designed to prevent monopoly, the spirit of monopoly was not effectively restrained.
distilled: Even strict limitations on the African Company committee's trading rights and compensation failed to prevent monopolistic behavior.
notes: The committee's prohibition on exporting enslaved people and importing goods was meant to remove their incentive to manipulate trade for personal gain. The eight-hundred-pound cap on expenses shows the modest scale of the operation. Smith's dry conclusion -- 'it would seem, however, that it was not' -- signals that institutional design alone cannot overcome entrenched incentive problems. The failure anticipates public choice theory on regulatory design.

refashioned: Although the fort of Senegal and all its dependencies had been vested in the African Company by the statute of 4 George III, the very next year, by another statute (5 George III, c.44), not only Senegal and its dependencies but the entire coast from the port of Sallee in southern Barbary to Cape Rouge was exempted from the company's jurisdiction, placed under the crown, and the trade declared free to all of His Majesty's subjects. The company had been suspected of restraining trade and establishing some sort of improper monopoly.
elegant: Parliament first gave the African Company control of Senegal, then within a year stripped away that territory and the entire coast from Sallee to Cape Rouge, placing it under the crown with free trade. The company was suspected of monopolistic behavior.
summary: Parliament quickly reversed its grant of Senegal to the African Company, stripping away an entire coastal territory and returning it to crown control with free trade, after suspecting the company of monopolistic practices.
distilled: Parliament's rapid reversal of the African Company's territorial control confirmed suspicions of monopolistic behavior despite anti-monopoly safeguards.
notes: Illustrates the speed with which institutional safeguards can fail. The reversal within a single year suggests Parliament recognized its error quickly. Sallee (Sale, Morocco) to Cape Rouge (Senegal) covers the northwest African coast. The episode demonstrates Smith's broader argument that regulated companies inevitably tend toward monopoly regardless of charter provisions.

refashioned: It is not easy to see how, under the regulations of 23 George II, they could have established a monopoly. In the printed debates of the House of Commons -- not always the most reliable records of truth -- I observe, however, that they have been accused of doing so. Since all nine committee members were merchants, and all the governors and agents in the company's various forts and settlements depended on them, it is not unlikely that those agents may have given preferential treatment to the committee members' consignments and commissions, thereby establishing a real monopoly in practice.
elegant: Though the regulations seemingly prevented monopoly, parliamentary debates accused the company of it. Since all committee members were merchants and all fort agents depended on them, the agents likely favored their superiors' goods -- creating a de facto monopoly through informal favoritism rather than formal rules.
summary: Despite regulatory safeguards, the African Company likely achieved a de facto monopoly because its merchant committee members could use their authority over dependent fort agents to secure preferential treatment for their own trade.
distilled: The African Company created a de facto monopoly not through formal rules but through the informal power committee members exercised over dependent agents in the forts.
notes: Distinguishes between de jure and de facto monopoly -- a crucial analytical distinction. Formal rules can be circumvented through informal hierarchical power. The parenthetical about Commons debates being 'not always the most authentic records of truth' is a characteristically dry Smithian aside about political reliability. This passage illustrates how principal-agent relationships can undermine regulatory design.

refashioned: For the second objective -- maintaining forts and garrisons -- Parliament allotted the company an annual sum, generally around thirteen thousand pounds. The committee was required to account annually to the Cursitor Baron of the Exchequer for the proper application of this sum, with the accounts afterwards laid before Parliament. But a Parliament that gives so little attention to how millions are spent is unlikely to pay much attention to thirteen thousand pounds a year. And the Cursitor Baron of the Exchequer, by his professional training and background, is unlikely to have any deep expertise in the proper costs of maintaining forts and garrisons.
elegant: Parliament funded fort maintenance at around thirteen thousand pounds annually, requiring the committee to account to the Cursitor Baron of the Exchequer. But Parliament barely scrutinizes millions, let alone thirteen thousand pounds, and the Cursitor Baron's legal training gives him no expertise in military fortification costs.
summary: Parliament's oversight of the African Company's thirteen thousand pound annual fort budget was ineffective because Parliament barely scrutinizes much larger sums, and the designated auditor lacked any expertise in military construction costs.
distilled: Parliamentary oversight of the company's fort budget failed because the sums were too small for Parliament to notice and the auditor lacked relevant expertise.
notes: Two distinct oversight failures: (1) attention is proportional to scale -- small budgets get lost in large legislatures, and (2) expertise mismatch -- legal officers auditing military expenditures. The Cursitor Baron was a junior Exchequer official responsible for issuing writs. The observation that Parliament neglects small sums while debating large ones anticipates modern concerns about budget oversight and the 'bicycle shed' problem (Parkinson's Law of Triviality).

refashioned: Royal Navy captains or other commissioned officers appointed by the Board of Admiralty may inspect the condition of the forts and garrisons and report their findings to that board. But the Admiralty appears to have no direct jurisdiction over the company's committee, nor any authority to correct those whose conduct it may investigate. Navy captains, moreover, are not generally assumed to be deeply learned in the science of fortification. Removal from an office that lasts only three years and pays very modest lawful emoluments seems to be the most severe punishment any committee member faces for any fault short of outright embezzlement of public or company money. And the fear of such a punishment can never be a sufficient motive to force the continual, careful attention to a business in which the committee member has no other personal interest.
elegant: The Admiralty can inspect forts but has no authority to discipline the company's committee. Navy captains are not fortification experts. The worst punishment a committee member faces -- removal from a three-year position with modest pay -- is too trivial to motivate careful attention to business in which he has no personal stake.
summary: Oversight of the African Company's forts was ineffective because the Admiralty could inspect but not discipline, naval officers lacked fortification expertise, and the only punishment -- removal from a short, low-paying position -- was too weak to motivate real diligence.
distilled: Weak punishment, fragmented authority, and mismatched expertise rendered oversight of the African Company's forts entirely ineffective.
notes: Three-layered accountability failure: (1) inspectors without enforcement power, (2) inspectors without relevant expertise, (3) penalties too weak to motivate compliance. The analysis of incentives is precise -- why would someone carefully maintain forts when the worst consequence is losing a minor, short-term position? Anticipates modern organizational theory on the relationship between accountability, incentives, and performance.

refashioned: The committee was accused of having shipped bricks and stones from England for repairing Cape Coast Castle on the coast of Guinea -- a project for which Parliament had repeatedly granted extraordinary funds. These materials, shipped on such a long voyage, were said to be of such poor quality that the walls repaired with them had to be entirely rebuilt from their foundations. The forts and garrisons north of Cape Rouge are not only maintained at government expense but are under the direct control of the executive power. Why those south of that cape -- which are also, at least partly, maintained at government expense -- should be under a different form of government is a question for which it seems difficult even to imagine a good answer.
elegant: The committee allegedly shipped such poor-quality bricks from England for repairing Cape Coast Castle that the repaired walls had to be completely rebuilt. Meanwhile, forts north of Cape Rouge were directly governed by the state. Why forts south of that line -- also partly state-funded -- should be under a different, inferior administration has no good explanation.
summary: The African Company's alleged mismanagement included shipping defective building materials from England for Cape Coast Castle repairs. There was no good reason for state-funded forts south of Cape Rouge to be under company rather than direct government control.
distilled: The African Company's mismanagement of fort repairs exemplified why state-funded military infrastructure should be under direct government control, not delegated to trading companies.
notes: Cape Coast Castle -- major British slave-trading fort in present-day Ghana, one of the most important European fortifications in West Africa. The absurdity of shipping bricks from England to tropical Africa illustrates either incompetence or corruption. The logical inconsistency of different governance regimes for forts on either side of Cape Rouge strengthens Smith's argument for direct state control.

refashioned: Protecting Mediterranean trade was the original purpose -- or pretense -- for the garrisons of Gibraltar and Minorca, and the maintenance and governance of those garrisons have always, quite properly, been entrusted to the executive power rather than the Turkey Company. The pride and dignity of executive power largely reside in the extent of its dominion, and it is not likely to neglect what is necessary for that dominion's defense. The garrisons at Gibraltar and Minorca have accordingly never been neglected. Though Minorca has been taken twice, and is now probably lost forever, that disaster has never been blamed on any neglect by the executive. I would not, however, wish to suggest that either of these expensive garrisons was ever, even in the smallest degree, necessary for the purpose for which they were originally taken from Spain. That seizure perhaps served no real purpose except to alienate England's natural ally, the king of Spain, and to unite the two principal branches of the House of Bourbon in a much tighter and more permanent alliance than ties of blood could ever have achieved.
elegant: Gibraltar and Minorca, garrisoned ostensibly to protect Mediterranean trade, were properly placed under direct executive control -- not the Turkey Company. Executive power takes pride in its dominions and never neglects their defense. But neither garrison was ever truly necessary for its stated purpose. Their seizure from Spain served only to alienate a natural ally and drive the two Bourbon branches into a tighter alliance than blood alone could have forged.
summary: Gibraltar and Minorca were properly maintained under direct government control, unlike trading company forts. However, their original seizure from Spain served no genuine commercial purpose and merely alienated a natural ally while strengthening the Bourbon alliance.
distilled: Gibraltar and Minorca prove that executive power maintains forts well, but their seizure from Spain was a strategic blunder that alienated allies and strengthened enemies.
notes: Dual argument: (1) executive power is better than trading companies at maintaining military installations, but (2) the installations themselves may be unnecessary or counterproductive. Minorca -- taken by Britain in 1708, lost to France in 1756 (Seven Years' War), returned by treaty, lost again in 1782. The House of Bourbon critique refers to the Family Compact between France and Spain. Smith subtly questions imperial acquisitions even while defending state administration over corporate administration.

refashioned:
Joint-stock companies, whether established by royal charter or by act of Parliament, differ in several respects not only from regulated companies but from private partnerships.

First, in a private partnership, no partner can transfer his share to another person or introduce a new member without the company's consent. Each partner may, however, upon proper notice, withdraw from the partnership and demand payment of his share of the common stock. In a joint-stock company, by contrast, no member can demand payment of his share from the company, but each member can, without the company's consent, transfer his share to another person and thereby introduce a new member. The value of a share in a joint-stock company is always whatever price it will bring in the market, and this may be either greater or less, in any proportion, than the sum for which the owner is credited in the company's books.
elegant: Joint-stock companies differ fundamentally from both regulated companies and private partnerships. In a partnership, shares cannot be transferred without consent, but partners can withdraw and demand their capital back. In a joint-stock company, shares are freely transferable without consent, but members cannot demand their capital back from the company. Share value is set by the market and may diverge widely from the book value.
summary: Joint-stock companies differ from partnerships in two key ways: shares are freely transferable without consent but cannot be redeemed from the company. Share prices are determined by the market and may deviate significantly from book value.
distilled: Joint-stock companies feature freely transferable but non-redeemable shares whose market value may differ greatly from book value -- the opposite of partnership arrangements.
notes: Foundational distinction between partnerships and joint-stock companies that remains central to corporate law. The transferability-without-redemption structure creates the basis for stock markets. The observation that market price diverges from book value is an early recognition of what we now call market capitalization vs. net asset value. This passage essentially defines the modern corporation's basic financial structure.

refashioned:
Second, in a private partnership, each partner is liable for the company's debts to the full extent of his personal fortune. In a joint-stock company, by contrast, each partner is liable only to the extent of his share.

A joint-stock company's trade is always managed by a court of directors. This court is frequently subject, in many respects, to the control of a general court of proprietors. But most proprietors rarely pretend to understand anything about the company's business. When the spirit of faction does not prevail among them, they take no trouble about it and contentedly accept whatever half-yearly or yearly dividend the directors think proper to pay. This total exemption from trouble and from risk beyond a limited sum encourages many people to invest in joint-stock companies who would never hazard their fortunes in any private partnership. Such companies therefore commonly attract much larger pools of capital than any private partnership can boast. The South Sea Company's trading stock once exceeded thirty-three million eight hundred thousand pounds. The Bank of England's divided capital currently stands at ten million seven hundred and eighty thousand pounds. The directors of such companies, however, being managers of other people's money rather than their own, cannot be expected to watch over it with the same anxious vigilance that partners in a private firm frequently bring to their own funds. Like the stewards of a rich man, they tend to consider attention to small matters beneath their master's dignity, and easily excuse themselves from bothering with it. Negligence and extravagance must therefore always prevail, more or less, in managing such a company's affairs. This is why joint-stock companies in foreign trade have rarely been able to compete against private adventurers. They have accordingly seldom succeeded without an exclusive privilege, and frequently have not succeeded even with one. Without an exclusive privilege, they have generally mismanaged the trade. With one, they have both mismanaged and confined it.
elegant: In partnerships, partners face unlimited liability; in joint-stock companies, liability is limited to one's share. This limited liability, combined with passive ownership and delegated management, attracts vast capital pools -- but creates an inherent governance problem. Directors managing other people's money lack the vigilance of partners managing their own. Like a rich man's stewards, they neglect details and tolerate waste. Joint-stock companies therefore rarely compete successfully against private firms in foreign trade. Without monopoly privileges they mismanage; with them, they both mismanage and restrict trade.
summary: Joint-stock companies attract vast capital through limited liability and passive ownership, but their directors, managing other people's money, inevitably lack the vigilance of private partners. This is why they have rarely succeeded in foreign trade without monopoly privileges -- and even with privileges, they both mismanage and confine the trade.
distilled: Limited liability attracts vast capital to joint-stock companies but creates a principal-agent problem: directors managing other people's money are inherently less vigilant than partners managing their own.
notes: Contains Smith's famous principal-agent critique of the joint-stock corporation -- one of the most cited passages in Wealth of Nations. The steward analogy ('managers of other people's money') is foundational to modern corporate governance theory. The observation that limited liability attracts capital but undermines management discipline anticipates Jensen and Meckling's agency theory (1976). The South Sea Company and Bank of England figures provide concrete scale. The final verdict -- without monopoly they mismanage, with monopoly they mismanage and confine -- is devastating.

refashioned: The Royal African Company, predecessor of the present African Company, held an exclusive privilege by charter. But since that charter had not been confirmed by act of Parliament, the trade was, soon after the Glorious Revolution and in keeping with the Declaration of Rights, laid open to all of His Majesty's subjects. The Hudson's Bay Company is in the same legal position: its exclusive charter has never been confirmed by Parliament. The South Sea Company, for as long as it remained a trading company, held an exclusive privilege confirmed by Parliament, as does the present United Company of Merchants Trading to the East Indies.
elegant: The Royal African Company's exclusive charter, unconfirmed by Parliament, was invalidated after the Glorious Revolution. The Hudson's Bay Company remains in the same legally precarious position. Only the South Sea Company and the East India Company held parliamentary-confirmed monopolies.
summary: After the Glorious Revolution, trading company monopolies required parliamentary confirmation. The Royal African and Hudson's Bay companies held only royal charters, while the South Sea and East India companies had parliamentary backing.
distilled: The Glorious Revolution established that trading monopolies required parliamentary confirmation, not just royal charter.
notes: The Declaration of Rights (1689) -- constitutional foundation limiting royal prerogative, including the power to grant exclusive trading privileges. Distinguishes between royal charter (weaker, challengeable) and parliamentary act (stronger, legally binding). The Hudson's Bay Company's precarious legal position is explored further in 5.1.120-122. Sets up the detailed histories of each company that follow.

refashioned: The Royal African Company soon found it could not compete against private traders, whom it continued for some time to call interlopers and to persecute as such, despite the Declaration of Rights. In 1698, however, private traders were subjected to a ten per cent duty on nearly all branches of their trade, the revenue to be used by the company for maintaining forts and garrisons. But even with this heavy tax on competitors, the company still could not maintain the competition. Its stock and credit gradually declined. By 1712, its debts had grown so large that a special act of Parliament was needed to protect both the company and its creditors, requiring a two-thirds supermajority of creditors (by number and value) to approve any debt restructuring terms. By 1730, its affairs were in such disorder that it was completely unable to maintain its forts and garrisons -- the sole purpose and pretext of its existence. From that year until its final dissolution, Parliament found it necessary to grant an annual subsidy of ten thousand pounds for that purpose. In 1732, after years of losses in the business of transporting enslaved people to the West Indies, the company finally abandoned that trade altogether, selling its human cargo to private traders for transport to America, and redirecting its servants to an inland African trade in gold dust, ivory, and dyeing materials.
elegant: The Royal African Company could not compete even after private traders were taxed ten per cent for its benefit. Its stock and credit declined steadily. By 1712 it needed special debt legislation; by 1730 it could no longer maintain its forts and required annual parliamentary subsidies. In 1732, after years of losses, it abandoned the slave trade entirely and pivoted to inland African trade in gold, ivory, and dyes.
summary: The Royal African Company failed despite taxing its private competitors ten per cent. Its steady decline required special debt legislation, parliamentary subsidies for fort maintenance, and ultimately the abandonment of its core slave trade business in favor of inland African commodities.
distilled: The Royal African Company's decline -- from monopoly to subsidized failure to abandonment of its core trade -- demonstrated joint-stock companies' inability to compete with private traders.
notes: A detailed case study in monopoly failure. Even a ten per cent handicap on competitors could not save the company. The progression from monopoly to debt crisis to parliamentary subsidy to trade abandonment follows a pattern Smith sees as universal for joint-stock trading companies. The slave trade is discussed matter-of-factly as a commercial venture -- Smith's moral critique of slavery appears elsewhere. The 1712 creditor-supermajority mechanism is an early form of corporate bankruptcy proceeding.

refashioned: Their success in this more limited trade was no greater than in their former extensive one. Their affairs continued to decline steadily until, bankrupt in every respect, they were dissolved by act of Parliament, and their forts and garrisons were transferred to the present regulated Company of Merchants Trading to Africa. Before the Royal African Company, three other joint-stock companies had been successively established for the African trade. All were equally unsuccessful. All held exclusive charters which, though not confirmed by Parliament, were in those days supposed to convey real exclusive privileges.
elegant: The Royal African Company's inland trade failed as badly as its previous ventures. It was eventually dissolved as bankrupt, its forts transferred to the new regulated African Company. Three prior joint-stock companies for African trade had all failed equally, despite holding exclusive charters.
summary: The Royal African Company's attempts to pivot to inland trade also failed, leading to dissolution and transfer of its forts to a regulated company. All four successive joint-stock companies for African trade ended in failure despite holding exclusive privileges.
distilled: Four successive joint-stock companies for African trade all failed despite exclusive privileges -- a pattern demonstrating the structural inadequacy of the joint-stock form for competitive foreign trade.
notes: The serial failure of four joint-stock African trading companies is Smith's strongest empirical evidence against the joint-stock form in foreign trade. Each failure led to replacement by a similar structure -- institutional inertia despite repeated evidence of dysfunction. The transfer to a regulated company represents Parliament's attempt at a different institutional solution, itself critiqued in 5.1.106-113.

refashioned: The Hudson's Bay Company, before its misfortunes in the recent war, had been much more fortunate than the Royal African Company. Its necessary expenses are much smaller. The total number of people it maintains at its various settlements and outposts -- which it has honored with the name of forts -- is said not to exceed one hundred and twenty persons. This small number is sufficient to prepare the cargo of furs and other goods needed to load the company's ships, which, because of the ice, can seldom remain in those waters for more than six or eight weeks.
