This advantage of having a cargo ready and waiting could not, for several years, be matched by private traders, and without it there seems to be no possibility of trading to Hudson's Bay.
elegant: The Hudson's Bay Company fared better than the African Company because its costs are minimal -- just one hundred and twenty people at modestly named 'forts,' preparing fur cargoes for ships that can only spend six to eight weeks in icy waters. This ready-cargo advantage, difficult for private traders to replicate, made the company's position naturally defensible.
summary: The Hudson's Bay Company succeeded where others failed because its low costs, small workforce, and the logistical advantage of having pre-prepared cargoes for ships limited by ice to brief trading windows created a natural barrier that private traders could not easily overcome.
distilled: The Hudson's Bay Company's success owed not to corporate efficiency but to natural barriers -- Arctic ice and the need for pre-staged cargoes -- that shielded it from competition.
notes: The parenthetical about 'forts' (Smith's skeptical quotation marks) suggests these were barely fortified trading posts given grand names. The ice constraint creates a natural monopoly condition: ships have only six to eight weeks, making pre-staged cargoes essential. This is a structural advantage independent of management quality -- a key distinction in Smith's analysis. The 'recent war' refers to the American Revolutionary War period.

refashioned: The company's moderate capital, said not to exceed one hundred and ten thousand pounds, may also be sufficient to engross the whole or nearly the whole trade and surplus produce of the vast but miserable country covered by its charter. No private traders have accordingly ever attempted to compete with it in that territory. The company has therefore always enjoyed an exclusive trade in practice, even if it has no legal right to one. Beyond all this, its moderate capital is said to be divided among a very small number of proprietors.
elegant: The company's modest capital of around one hundred and ten thousand pounds is enough to absorb virtually all the trade of the vast but impoverished territory under its charter. No private competitor has ever tried to enter. The company thus holds a de facto monopoly without legal right to one, and its small capital is concentrated among few proprietors.
summary: The Hudson's Bay Company's moderate capital suffices to monopolize trade in its vast but poor territory, and no private trader has ever challenged it. It holds a de facto monopoly without legal right, with capital concentrated among very few owners.
distilled: The Hudson's Bay Company maintains a de facto monopoly because its territory is too poor and remote to attract competing private capital.
notes: Distinguishes between de jure monopoly (legal right) and de facto monopoly (practical result of conditions). The territory's poverty paradoxically protects the company -- insufficient surplus to attract competitors. The small number of proprietors becomes important in the next entry, where Smith argues this makes it function more like a partnership. The 'miserable though extensive' characterization of the Hudson's Bay territory reflects 18th-century European assessment of sub-Arctic Canada.

refashioned: But a joint-stock company consisting of a small number of proprietors with a moderate capital approximates the nature of a private partnership and may be capable of nearly the same degree of vigilance and attention. It is not surprising, therefore, that given these various advantages, the Hudson's Bay Company had been able to carry on its trade with considerable success before the recent war. It does not seem likely, however, that its profits ever approached what the late Mr. Dobbs imagined. A much more sober and judicious writer, Mr. Anderson, author of the Historical and Chronological Deduction of Commerce, rightly observes that upon examining the accounts Mr. Dobbs himself provided for several years of the company's exports and imports, and upon making proper allowances for its extraordinary risk and expense, its profits do not appear to deserve envy, and can scarcely, if at all, exceed the ordinary rate of profit in trade.
elegant: A small joint-stock company with moderate capital behaves much like a private partnership, with comparable vigilance. This explains the Hudson's Bay Company's relative success. But its profits were likely modest -- Mr. Anderson's careful analysis of the company's own accounts shows profits barely matching ordinary trade rates, despite Mr. Dobbs's inflated claims.
summary: The Hudson's Bay Company succeeded because its small ownership and moderate capital made it function like a private partnership. But its profits, despite exaggerated claims, appear to have barely matched ordinary trade returns after accounting for extraordinary risks and expenses.
distilled: The Hudson's Bay Company's success came from functioning like a small partnership, not from any advantage of the joint-stock form -- and its profits merely matched ordinary trade rates.
notes: Key theoretical point: the Hudson's Bay Company is the exception that proves the rule -- it succeeded precisely because its small scale and few owners made it behave like a partnership, not a typical joint-stock company. Arthur Dobbs (1689-1765) -- Irish politician and critic of the Hudson's Bay Company who exaggerated its profits to argue for breaking its monopoly. Adam Anderson (1692-1765) -- author of the major commercial history Smith often cites. The ordinary rate of profit benchmark comes from Book I.

refashioned: The South Sea Company never had forts or garrisons to maintain and was therefore exempt from one great expense that other joint-stock foreign trading companies bear. But it had an immense capital divided among an immense number of proprietors. It was naturally to be expected, therefore, that folly, negligence, and extravagance would pervade its entire management. The fraud and excess of its stock-jobbing schemes are well enough known, and explaining them here would be beside the point. Its trading ventures were not much better managed. Its first trade was supplying enslaved people to the Spanish West Indies under the Assiento Contract granted by the Treaty of Utrecht, over which it held an exclusive privilege. But since this trade was not expected to be very profitable -- both the Portuguese and French companies that had previously held it on the same terms had been ruined by it -- the company was also allowed, as compensation, to send one ship of a certain size annually to trade directly with the Spanish West Indies. Of the ten voyages this annual ship was permitted to make, the company is said to have profited considerably by only one -- that of the Royal Caroline in 1731 -- and to have lost money on nearly all the rest. Its agents blamed the Spanish government's extortion and oppression, but the losses were probably owed mainly to the extravagance and embezzlement of those very agents, some of whom reportedly amassed great fortunes in a single year. In 1734, the company petitioned the king for permission to dispose of the trade and tonnage of its annual ship, on account of its meager profits, and to accept whatever compensation the king of Spain might offer.
elegant: The South Sea Company had no forts to maintain but had immense capital spread among vast numbers of owners -- a recipe for mismanagement. Its stock-jobbing scandals are well known. Its trading was equally poor: the Assiento slave trade contract had already ruined Portuguese and French predecessors. Of ten permitted annual trading voyages to the Spanish West Indies, only one was profitable. Agents blamed Spanish extortion, but their own embezzlement -- some amassing fortunes in a single year -- was the likelier cause. By 1734 the company petitioned to abandon the trade entirely.
summary: The South Sea Company's immense, widely-held capital predictably produced mismanagement. Its slave trade under the Assiento Contract and its annual ship to the Spanish West Indies were both unprofitable, with agents' embezzlement the primary cause of losses. By 1734 it sought to abandon trading altogether.
distilled: The South Sea Company's vast dispersed ownership produced the predictable result: pervasive mismanagement, agent embezzlement, and abandonment of virtually every trading venture.
notes: The South Sea Bubble (1720) is the most famous financial scandal of the 18th century -- Smith deliberately sets it aside to focus on the less-known but equally damning trading failures. The Assiento Contract (1713, Treaty of Utrecht) -- granted Britain the right to supply enslaved Africans to Spanish colonies, a coveted but ultimately unprofitable privilege. The agent problem -- managers enriching themselves while the company loses money -- perfectly illustrates the principal-agent critique from 5.1.116. The Royal Caroline's 1731 success was the sole exception in a decade of losses.

refashioned: In 1724, the South Sea Company had undertaken the whale fishery. It held no monopoly over this trade, but as long as it participated, no other British subjects appear to have engaged in it. Of the eight voyages its ships made to Greenland, the company profited from only one and lost money on all the rest. After the eighth and final voyage, when it had sold its ships, stores, and equipment, it found that its total loss on this venture -- including both capital and interest -- amounted to upwards of two hundred and thirty-seven thousand pounds.
elegant: The South Sea Company also tried whale fishing without a monopoly. Of eight Greenland voyages, only one was profitable. After selling everything, total losses exceeded two hundred and thirty-seven thousand pounds, capital and interest included.
summary: The South Sea Company's whale fishing venture lost over two hundred and thirty-seven thousand pounds across eight voyages to Greenland, with only one profitable trip. The venture's failure further demonstrated the company's inability to manage competitive trade.
distilled: The South Sea Company lost over two hundred and thirty-seven thousand pounds on whale fishing -- yet another demonstration that joint-stock companies cannot manage competitive trade.
notes: The whale fishery venture had no monopoly protection, making it a pure test of joint-stock management competence in competitive trade -- which it failed spectacularly. The Greenland whale fishery was a major 18th-century industry. The precise loss figure (237,000+ pounds) suggests Smith had access to detailed accounts. This example strengthens his argument that joint-stock companies fail without monopoly protection.

refashioned: In 1722, the South Sea Company petitioned Parliament to divide its immense capital of over thirty-three million eight hundred thousand pounds -- all of which had been lent to the government -- into two equal halves. One half, upwards of sixteen million nine hundred thousand pounds, would be placed on the same footing as other government annuities, no longer subject to debts or losses from the directors' trading ventures. The other half would remain as trading stock, exposed to those debts and losses. The petition was too reasonable to refuse. In 1733, the company again petitioned Parliament, asking that three-fourths of its trading stock be converted to annuity stock, leaving only one-fourth as trading stock exposed to directorial mismanagement. Both the annuity and trading stocks had by then been reduced by over two million pounds each through government payments, so this remaining fourth amounted to only about three million six hundred and sixty-two thousand pounds. In 1748, by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle, all the company's claims against the king of Spain under the Assiento Contract were surrendered for what was supposed to be an equivalent. Its trade with the Spanish West Indies ended. The remainder of its trading stock was converted into annuity stock, and the company ceased entirely to be a trading concern.
elegant: The South Sea Company progressively retreated from trade. In 1722, it split its immense capital -- all lent to government -- into protected annuity stock and exposed trading stock. By 1733, three-fourths of its trading stock was converted to annuities. In 1748, the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle ended its Spanish trade, the last trading stock became annuities, and it ceased to be a trading company entirely.
summary: The South Sea Company progressively converted its trading capital into government annuities, shrinking from an immense trading operation to a mere annuity holder. By 1748, with the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle ending its Spanish trade, it ceased to be a trading company altogether.
distilled: The South Sea Company's gradual conversion from trading company to passive annuity holder -- completed by 1748 -- was an orderly retreat from commercial failure.
notes: The progressive capital conversion tells a story of managed decline: 1722 (50% protected), 1733 (87.5% protected), 1748 (100% converted). The original capital of 33.8 million pounds was enormous -- equivalent to a significant fraction of British GDP. The Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle (1748) ended the War of Austrian Succession and resolved the Assiento claims. The company's transformation from trader to government creditor illustrates how joint-stock companies often survive not through commercial success but by becoming vehicles for government debt.

refashioned: It should be noted that in the trade the South Sea Company carried on through its annual ship -- the only trade from which it was ever expected to make considerable profit -- it faced competition in every market. At Cartagena, Porto Bello, and Vera Cruz, it competed with Spanish merchants bringing European goods from Cadiz of the same kinds as its outward cargo. In England, it competed with English merchants importing Spanish West Indian goods of the same kinds as its return cargo. The goods of both Spanish and English merchants may indeed have been subject to higher duties. But the losses caused by the negligence, extravagance, and embezzlement of the company's servants were probably a far heavier tax than all those duties combined. That a joint-stock company should be able to carry on any branch of foreign trade successfully when private adventurers can enter into any sort of open and fair competition with them seems contrary to all experience.
elegant: In the only trade expected to yield real profits -- its annual ship -- the South Sea Company faced competition everywhere: from Spanish merchants at colonial ports and from English importers at home. Competitors may have paid higher duties, but the company's losses from servant negligence and embezzlement were a far heavier burden. All experience shows that joint-stock companies cannot succeed in foreign trade when facing open competition from private traders.
summary: The South Sea Company faced competition from Spanish and English merchants in every market its annual ship served. Though competitors paid higher duties, the company's internal losses from mismanagement and embezzlement exceeded any duty advantage. Joint-stock companies cannot compete with private traders in open markets.
distilled: All experience confirms that joint-stock companies cannot compete successfully against private traders in open foreign trade markets.
notes: Generalizes from the South Sea Company case to a universal principle: joint-stock companies fail in competitive foreign trade. The specific ports -- Cartagena, Porto Bello, Vera Cruz -- were the major Spanish colonial trading centers. The key comparison: external duties on competitors vs. internal 'tax' of mismanagement on the company. The internal tax always proves heavier. This is the empirical foundation for Smith's conclusion in 5.1.145.

refashioned: The old English East India Company was established in 1600 by a charter from Queen Elizabeth. In its first twelve voyages to India, it appears to have traded as a regulated company with separate stocks, though only in the company's general ships. In 1612, the members united into a joint stock. Their charter was exclusive, and though not confirmed by Parliament, it was in those days believed to convey a real exclusive privilege. For many years, therefore, they were not much troubled by interlopers. Their capital, which never exceeded seven hundred and forty-four thousand pounds (with fifty pounds per share), was not so large as to provide either a pretext for gross negligence and extravagance or a cover for gross embezzlement. Nor were their dealings so extensive as to invite such abuses. Despite some extraordinary losses -- caused partly by the hostility of the Dutch East India Company and partly by other misfortunes -- they carried on for many years a successful trade.
elegant: The old East India Company, chartered in 1600, initially traded with separate stocks before uniting into a joint stock in 1612. Its exclusive charter went largely unchallenged. With capital never exceeding seven hundred and forty-four thousand pounds, it was small enough to avoid the worst joint-stock pathologies of negligence and embezzlement. Despite losses from Dutch competition and other setbacks, it traded successfully for many years.
summary: The original East India Company succeeded for many years because its moderate capital kept it manageable, its unchallenged charter provided protection, and its scale was not large enough to invite the gross mismanagement typical of larger joint-stock ventures.
distilled: The old East India Company's initial success owed to moderate scale that prevented the worst joint-stock pathologies -- not to any inherent advantage of the corporate form.
notes: Elizabeth I's 1600 charter established one of history's most consequential corporations. The evolution from regulated (separate stocks) to joint-stock (1612) is historically important. Smith's explanation of success through smallness parallels his Hudson's Bay Company analysis (5.1.122) -- small joint-stock companies mimic partnerships. Dutch East India Company (VOC) rivalry was a major theme of 17th-century commercial warfare. The fifty-pound share price and 744,000-pound cap were modest by later standards.

refashioned: But over time, as the principles of liberty came to be better understood, it became increasingly doubtful whether a royal charter not confirmed by Parliament could really convey an exclusive privilege. Court decisions on this question were inconsistent, varying with the government's authority and the temper of the times. Interlopers multiplied. Toward the end of Charles II's reign, throughout James II's, and during part of William III's, the company was reduced to great distress. In 1698, a proposal was made to Parliament: subscribers who advanced two million pounds to the government at eight per cent interest would be incorporated as a new East India company with exclusive privileges.
elegant: As constitutional principles advanced, the legal basis of unconfirmed royal charters became increasingly doubtful, and courts ruled inconsistently. Interlopers multiplied, distressing the company through several reigns. In 1698, subscribers offered Parliament two million pounds at eight per cent to fund a rival East India company with parliamentary-confirmed exclusive privileges.
summary: Growing constitutional awareness undermined the old East India Company's unconfirmed royal charter. Interlopers multiplied, and in 1698, rival subscribers offered two million pounds to the government in exchange for parliamentary confirmation of a new East India company with exclusive privileges.
distilled: Constitutional progress undermined royal charter monopolies, and the old East India Company's unconfirmed privilege was challenged by a rival group offering Parliament two million pounds for a new, properly authorized monopoly.
notes: Connects the evolution of constitutional liberty to commercial regulation. The Glorious Revolution (1688) and Declaration of Rights changed the legal status of royal prerogatives, including trading monopolies. The 1698 proposal exemplifies how governments sold monopoly privileges to finance state debt -- a pattern central to 18th-century public finance. The eight per cent interest rate reflects the government's credit standing.

refashioned: The old East India Company offered seven hundred thousand pounds -- nearly its entire capital -- at four per cent on the same conditions. But the state of public credit at that time made it more convenient for the government to borrow two million at eight per cent than seven hundred thousand at four. The new subscribers' proposal was accepted, and a new East India company was established. The old company, however, retained the right to continue trading until 1701. It had also, through its treasurer, artfully subscribed three hundred and fifteen thousand pounds into the new company's stock. Due to careless drafting of the act of Parliament, it did not clearly appear that all subscribers to the two-million-pound loan were required to unite into a single joint stock. A few private traders whose subscriptions totaled only seven thousand two hundred pounds insisted on their right to trade separately on their own capital and at their own risk.
elegant: The old East India Company offered 700,000 pounds at four per cent, but the government preferred two million at eight -- it needed more money regardless of rate. A new company was established, though the old one retained trading rights until 1701 and cleverly subscribed 315,000 pounds into the new company's stock. Loose legislative drafting allowed some private traders with just 7,200 pounds in subscriptions to insist on trading independently.
summary: The government chose the new company's larger loan over the old company's cheaper offer. The old company hedged by subscribing into the new one, while poor legislative drafting allowed some private traders to insist on independent trading rights.
distilled: Government preference for larger loans over cheaper ones created a new East India Company, while sloppy legislation allowed the old company and private traders to maintain competing positions.
notes: Illustrates how government borrowing needs -- not commercial efficiency -- determined which company received the monopoly. The old company's subscription of 315,000 pounds into the new company was a defensive hedge -- maintaining influence within its rival. The legislative drafting error that allowed separate trading anticipates modern debates about statutory interpretation and regulatory loopholes. The interest rate comparison (4% vs 8%) shows the fiscal pressure driving policy.

refashioned: The old East India Company had retained the right to trade separately on its own stock until 1701, and it also had the right -- like any other private trader -- to trade separately on the three hundred and fifteen thousand pounds it had subscribed into the new company's stock. The competition between the two companies, along with private traders, is said to have nearly ruined both. Later, in 1750, when a proposal was made to Parliament to reorganize the trade under a regulated company and thereby open it up somewhat, the East India Company argued strenuously against it. They described, in vivid terms, what they considered the miserable effects of the earlier competition. In India, they said, competition had driven up the price of goods so high that they were not worth buying; and in England, by overstocking the market, it had driven prices so low that no profit could be made. That this competition supplied English consumers more plentifully and cheaply, to the great advantage of the public, can hardly be doubted. But whether it really raised prices significantly in the Indian market seems improbable, since all the extra demand this competition could generate would have been like a drop of water in the immense ocean of Indian commerce.
elegant: Competition between the old and new companies, plus private traders, reportedly nearly ruined both. The East India Company later cited this experience to oppose any opening of trade, claiming competition raised Indian prices prohibitively while collapsing English ones. Smith replies: cheaper English prices were precisely the public benefit, and additional European demand was a drop in the ocean of Indian commerce -- hardly enough to raise Indian prices.
summary: Competition between rival East India companies and private traders was said to have nearly ruined both companies. But Smith argues their complaints about competition actually described its benefits: lower consumer prices in England. Their claim that competition raised Indian prices was implausible given the tiny scale of European demand relative to Indian commerce.
distilled: The East India Company's complaints about ruinous competition were actually descriptions of its benefits -- cheaper goods for English consumers -- while its claims about inflated Indian prices were implausible.
notes: Classic Smithian move: reframing a company's complaint as a proof of competition's benefits. 'Cheapness of consumption and encouragement of production' are the two goals of political economy. The 'drop of water in the immense ocean' metaphor for European demand relative to Indian commerce is a powerful quantitative intuition. The 1750 proposal for a regulated company represents yet another institutional experiment for managing India trade. Cross-reference to Book IV on monopoly complaints about competition.

refashioned: Increased demand, though it may sometimes raise prices initially, never fails to lower them in the long run. It encourages production, thereby increasing competition among producers, who resort to new divisions of labor and new technical improvements that might never otherwise have been conceived. The 'miserable effects' the company complained about were in fact cheaper goods for consumers and encouragement of production -- precisely the two outcomes that political economy exists to promote. This competition, however, was not allowed to last long. In 1702, the two companies were partially united by a tripartite indenture in which the queen was the third party. In 1708, they were fully consolidated by act of Parliament into a single entity under their current name: the United Company of Merchants Trading to the East Indies. A clause allowed the remaining separate traders to continue until Michaelmas 1711, while empowering the directors to redeem their small capital of seven thousand two hundred pounds on three years' notice, thereby converting the entire stock into a joint stock. Under the same act, the company's capital was increased from two million to three million two hundred thousand pounds in consequence of a new loan to the government. In 1743, the company advanced another million to the government.
elegant: Rising demand may initially raise prices but ultimately lowers them by encouraging production, new divisions of labor, and technical innovation. The East India Company's complaints about competition actually described political economy's two primary goals: cheap consumption and productive encouragement. Competition was soon ended: the companies merged in stages (1702 partially, 1708 fully), and the capital grew to 3.2 million pounds through government loans, reaching 4.2 million by 1743.
summary: Increased demand ultimately lowers prices by stimulating production and innovation -- the two central aims of political economy. The rival East India companies merged in 1702-1708, ending competition. The consolidated company's capital grew through successive government loans to over four million pounds.
distilled: Competition lowers prices by encouraging production and innovation -- the twin goals of political economy -- but the East India companies were merged in 1708, ending this beneficial competition to create a monopoly.
notes: Contains Smith's concise statement of how competition drives innovation through new divisions of labor and technical improvements -- a core mechanism of his growth theory. The merger timeline (1702 partial, 1708 full) shows how quickly monopoly was restored. The growing capital through government loans shows the company functioning as a vehicle for public debt. 'Cheapness of consumption and encouragement of production' -- Smith's summary of political economy's purpose. Michaelmas (September 29) was a traditional English legal and financial quarter day.

refashioned: But this additional million was raised not by a call on the proprietors but by selling annuities and taking on bond debts, so it did not increase the stock on which proprietors could claim dividends. It did, however, increase their trading stock, since it was equally exposed to the company's commercial losses and debts alongside the existing three million two hundred thousand pounds. From 1708, or at least from 1711, the company -- now free of all competitors and securely established in its monopoly of English trade to the East Indies -- carried on a successful trade and paid moderate dividends. During the French war beginning in 1741, the ambitions of Mr. Dupleix, the French governor of Pondicherry, drew the company into the wars of the Carnatic and into Indian political intrigues. After alternating signal successes and equally signal losses, they lost Madras, then their principal Indian settlement. It was restored by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle. Around this time, a spirit of war and conquest seems to have seized the company's servants in India and never left them. During the French war beginning in 1755, the company's military fortunes shared in Britain's general good luck. They defended Madras, captured Pondicherry, recovered Calcutta, and acquired the revenues of a rich and extensive territory said to yield upwards of three million pounds a year. They held this revenue peacefully for several years. But in 1767, the government claimed their territorial acquisitions and revenues as rightfully belonging to the crown. In compensation, the company agreed to pay the government four hundred thousand pounds annually. Before this, they had gradually raised their dividend from about six to ten per cent -- that is, on their capital of three million two hundred thousand pounds, they had increased annual payments from one hundred and ninety-two thousand to three hundred and twenty thousand pounds. They were then attempting to raise the dividend further to twelve and a half per cent, which would have made their annual payments to proprietors equal to what they had agreed to pay the government: four hundred thousand pounds.
elegant: The company's additional million in capital came from debt, not proprietor contributions -- enlarging exposure without enlarging ownership returns. Freed from competition after 1708, the company traded successfully and paid modest dividends until drawn into Indian military adventures by Dupleix's ambitions in the 1740s. After losing and recovering Madras, a spirit of conquest permanently seized its Indian servants. Military successes in the 1750s yielded territorial revenues of three million pounds annually. The government in 1767 claimed these as crown property, accepting 400,000 pounds yearly as compensation. The company had been raising dividends from six toward twelve and a half per cent.
summary: After achieving monopoly in 1708, the East India Company traded successfully until drawn into Indian wars and territorial conquest. Military success yielded enormous territorial revenues, but the government claimed these for the crown in 1767, accepting annual compensation while the company pursued ever-higher dividends.
distilled: The East India Company's transformation from trading monopoly to territorial power created immense revenues that the government claimed as crown property -- converting a commercial enterprise into an instrument of imperial rule.
notes: Pivotal passage tracing the East India Company's transformation from commercial to territorial power. Dupleix (1697-1763) -- French colonial administrator whose ambitions triggered the Carnatic Wars. The Carnatic Wars (1746-1763) reshaped the Indian subcontinent. The 1767 crown claim to territorial revenues marks the beginning of formal government involvement in Indian governance. The dividend arithmetic (6% to 10% to targeted 12.5%) shows proprietors trying to extract maximum returns. Three million pounds in territorial revenue was enormous -- roughly 3-4% of British GDP.

refashioned: But during the two years in which their agreement with the government was to take effect, two successive acts of Parliament restrained them from any further dividend increase, aiming to accelerate their debt repayment -- debts then estimated at six or seven million pounds. In 1769, they renewed their agreement with the government for five more years, stipulating that they could gradually increase their dividend to twelve and a half per cent, but never by more than one per cent in any single year. Even at its maximum, this dividend increase would raise their combined annual payments to proprietors and government by only six hundred and eighty thousand pounds beyond what they had been before their territorial acquisitions. According to accounts brought by the Cruttenden East Indiaman in 1769, the net territorial revenue -- clear of all deductions and military charges -- stood at over two million forty-eight thousand pounds. They were also said to possess additional revenue from lands and customs at their various settlements amounting to four hundred and thirty-nine thousand pounds.
elegant: Parliament restricted the company's dividend increases to force faster debt repayment on debts of six to seven million pounds. A renewed 1769 agreement allowed gradual dividend increases to twelve and a half per cent -- adding only 680,000 pounds annually to combined payments to proprietors and government. Meanwhile, net territorial revenue exceeded two million pounds, with an additional 439,000 pounds from settlement customs and land revenue.
summary: Parliament restricted dividend growth to accelerate debt repayment. Even the maximum planned dividend increase would have added only 680,000 pounds to annual obligations, despite net territorial revenues exceeding two and a half million pounds -- suggesting vast sums were being consumed by mismanagement.
distilled: The enormous gap between the East India Company's territorial revenues and its modest dividend capacity revealed that vast sums were being consumed by mismanagement and corruption.
notes: The gap between revenues (2.5+ million pounds) and the dividend increase capacity (680,000 pounds) implies massive waste -- the difference was consumed by military expenses, administrative costs, and corruption. The Cruttenden East Indiaman -- named after a ship that carried the revenue accounts to England. The six to seven million pounds in debt was staggering for a commercial company. The graduated dividend increase (max 1% per year) shows Parliament trying to impose fiscal discipline.

refashioned: The profits of their trade, according to their chairman's testimony before the House of Commons, amounted to at least four hundred thousand pounds a year; according to their accountant, at least five hundred thousand -- at minimum equal to the highest dividend they were to pay proprietors. So great a revenue might certainly have supported a six-hundred-and-eighty-thousand-pound increase in annual payments while still leaving a large sinking fund sufficient for the speedy reduction of their debts. In 1773, however, their debts had not been reduced but had instead grown: they were in arrears to the Treasury on the four-hundred-thousand-pound payment, owed additional duties to the customs house, had borrowed heavily from the Bank, and had recklessly accepted bills drawn upon them from India totaling over twelve hundred thousand pounds.
elegant: Trade profits of 400,000-500,000 pounds annually, combined with territorial revenues, should easily have funded the dividend increase and rapid debt repayment. Instead, by 1773 the company's debts had grown: it was in arrears to the Treasury, owed customs duties, had borrowed from the Bank, and had accepted over 1.2 million pounds in bills from India.
summary: Despite ample revenues from both trade and territory that should have easily funded debt repayment, the East India Company's debts grew by 1773 through Treasury arrears, unpaid customs, bank borrowing, and over a million pounds in recklessly accepted bills from India.
distilled: The East India Company's debts grew despite enormous revenues because corruption and mismanagement consumed every surplus its territories and trade could generate.
notes: The contrast between theoretical capacity (more than enough revenue) and actual outcome (growing debt) is the core of Smith's indictment. The recklessly accepted bills from India (1.2 million pounds) represent a classic agency problem -- servants in India creating obligations the London directors had to honor. The chairman vs. accountant discrepancy (400,000 vs. 500,000) in parliamentary testimony itself suggests loose financial control.

refashioned: The distress caused by these accumulated claims forced the company not only to slash its dividend at once to six per cent but to throw itself on the government's mercy, begging first for relief from the four-hundred-thousand-pound annual payment, and second for a loan of fourteen hundred thousand pounds to avoid immediate bankruptcy. It seems that the enormous increase in the company's fortune had only provided its servants with a pretext for greater extravagance and a cover for greater embezzlement, in proportion even beyond the increase of fortune itself. The conduct of the company's servants in India, and its overall state of affairs both in India and Europe, became the subject of a parliamentary inquiry. As a result, several important changes were made to the company's governance at home and abroad. In India, its principal settlements at Madras, Bombay, and Calcutta -- previously entirely independent of one another -- were placed under a governor-general assisted by a council of four assessors. Parliament itself appointed the first governor and council, who were to reside at Calcutta, that city having now replaced Madras as the most important English settlement in India.
elegant: Accumulated debts forced the company to cut its dividend to six per cent and beg the government for debt relief and a 1.4-million-pound emergency loan. Greater fortune had only enabled greater extravagance and embezzlement by its servants. Parliamentary inquiry led to major governance reforms: India's three independent presidencies were unified under a governor-general at Calcutta, with Parliament appointing the first appointees.
summary: The East India Company's financial crisis forced dividend cuts and emergency government loans. Parliamentary inquiry revealed that increased revenues had only funded proportionally greater corruption. Reforms unified India's three presidencies under a parliamentary-appointed governor-general at Calcutta.
distilled: The East India Company's financial collapse -- despite immense revenues -- proved that greater corporate fortune only funds proportionally greater corruption without proper governance.
notes: The Regulating Act of 1773 -- one of Parliament's most important interventions in Indian governance. Warren Hastings became the first Governor-General. The shift of primacy from Madras to Calcutta reflects Bengal's economic importance after Plassey (1757). Smith's observation that greater fortune enabled proportionally greater embezzlement is a key insight about corruption scaling with resources. The 1.4-million-pound bailout was effectively an 18th-century corporate rescue.

refashioned: The Court of the Mayor of Calcutta, originally established for mercantile disputes in the city and its neighborhood, had gradually expanded its jurisdiction as the empire grew. It was now reduced and confined to its original purpose. In its place, a new Supreme Court of Judicature was established, consisting of a chief justice and three judges appointed by the crown. In Europe, the property qualification required for a proprietor to vote at general courts was raised from five hundred pounds -- the original price of a company share -- to one thousand pounds. To vote on this qualification, it was further required that the proprietor must have held it, if acquired by purchase rather than inheritance, for at least one year instead of the previous six months.
elegant: Reforms restructured Indian courts -- the Mayor's Court in Calcutta was confined to its original mercantile scope and replaced by a crown-appointed Supreme Court. In London, the voting qualification for company proprietors was doubled from 500 to 1,000 pounds and required a year's holding period instead of six months.
summary: Parliamentary reforms created a new crown-appointed Supreme Court in Calcutta and restricted the expanded Mayor's Court. In London, voting qualifications for company proprietors were doubled and holding period requirements increased to reduce speculative influence.
distilled: The 1773 reforms attempted to improve East India Company governance through crown-appointed Indian courts and higher, longer-held voting qualifications for proprietors.
notes: The Supreme Court of Calcutta (established 1774) represented direct crown judicial authority in India -- a major step toward formal colonial governance. The doubled voting qualification and extended holding period aimed to reduce speculative short-term stock purchases made solely to influence company elections. The original 500-pound share price had been the benchmark since the company's early days. These reforms foreshadow modern corporate governance measures like minimum holding periods for shareholder voting rights.

refashioned: The court of twenty-four directors had previously been elected annually; it was now enacted that each director should serve for four years, with six rotating out each year and being ineligible for re-election at the next year's ballot. These changes were expected to make both the proprietors' and directors' courts act with more dignity and steadiness. But it seems impossible, by any institutional changes, to make these courts even remotely fit to govern -- or even share in governing -- a great empire. The majority of their members will always have too little personal stake in that empire's prosperity to give it serious attention. Frequently a man of great fortune, sometimes even one of small fortune, is willing to purchase a thousand-pound share in East India stock merely for the influence a vote in the proprietors' court gives him. It provides a share, though not in the plunder itself, in appointing the plunderers of India. The directors' court, though it makes those appointments, is inevitably influenced by the proprietors who elect them, and who sometimes directly override the appointments of their servants in India.
elegant: Directors were given four-year staggered terms to promote steadiness, but no institutional reform can make these courts fit to govern an empire. Most members care only about the patronage power their shares confer -- appointing officials in India rather than governing wisely. Men buy shares not for dividends but for influence over appointments, gaining a share in appointing the plunderers of India even if not in the plunder itself.
summary: Staggered director terms were meant to improve governance, but no reform can make a commercial company fit to govern an empire. Shareholders buy stock for patronage influence -- the power to appoint officials in India -- not for commercial returns, making good governance structurally impossible.
distilled: No institutional reform can make a joint-stock company fit to govern an empire when shareholders buy stock for patronage power rather than commercial returns.
notes: One of Smith's most devastating passages on corporate imperialism. The phrase 'a share not in the plunder but in the appointment of the plunderers' is among his most quoted lines. The structural problem: shareholders' incentives are entirely misaligned with good governance of the territory. Stock purchased for political influence rather than investment return creates a governance pathology that no term-limit reform can fix. Anticipates modern concerns about activist shareholders with non-financial motives.

refashioned: Provided he can enjoy this influence for a few years and thereby provide positions for a certain number of his friends, a proprietor frequently cares little about the dividend, or even about the value of the stock on which his vote is based. About the prosperity of the great empire in whose government that vote gives him a share, he seldom cares at all. No other sovereigns ever were, or from the nature of things ever could be, so perfectly indifferent about the happiness or misery of their subjects, the improvement or waste of their dominions, the glory or disgrace of their administration, as the majority of proprietors in such a mercantile company necessarily must be. This indifference was more likely to be increased than diminished by some of the new regulations enacted after the parliamentary inquiry. By a resolution of the House of Commons, for example, it was declared that once the company repaid its government loan of one million four hundred thousand pounds and reduced its bond debts to one million five hundred thousand, it could then divide eight per cent on its capital. Whatever surplus remained of its revenues and net profits at home would be split four ways: three-fourths paid to the Exchequer for public use, and one-fourth reserved for further debt reduction or other contingencies.
elegant: Proprietors care about patronage, not dividends, stock value, or the empire they nominally govern. No sovereigns in history have ever been so indifferent to their subjects' welfare as joint-stock company proprietors necessarily are. The post-inquiry reforms made this worse: the rule that three-fourths of surplus profits go to the Exchequer further disconnected proprietors from the consequences of good or bad governance.
summary: Joint-stock company proprietors are uniquely indifferent sovereigns, caring only about patronage appointments, not about dividends, stock value, or the welfare of the territories they govern. Parliamentary reforms that redirected three-fourths of surplus profits to the Exchequer only deepened this indifference.
distilled: No sovereigns in history have been as indifferent to their subjects' welfare as joint-stock company proprietors, whose only interest is patronage -- and reforms redirecting profits to the state made this worse.
notes: Extends the devastating critique of corporate imperialism. The claim that no sovereigns ever were so indifferent is deliberately sweeping. The reform paradox: requiring three-fourths of profits to go to the Exchequer removed whatever residual financial incentive proprietors had for good governance. More oversight produced worse outcomes because it further separated proprietors from consequences. A powerful illustration of how well-intentioned regulation can backfire when it ignores incentive structures.

refashioned: But if the company was a bad steward and a bad sovereign when all of its net revenues and profits belonged to itself and were at its own disposal, it was surely not likely to be any better when three-fourths of them were to belong to other people, and the remaining fourth -- though to be spent for the company's benefit -- was to be spent under others' inspection and with their approval.
elegant: If the company governed badly when it kept all its own profits, it would certainly not govern better when three-fourths went to the state and the remainder was spent under external oversight.
summary: The company could not be expected to improve its governance when most of its profits were redirected to the state and the remainder placed under external supervision -- removing whatever self-interest might have motivated better management.
distilled: Redirecting a company's profits to the state while supervising the remainder destroys whatever self-interest might have motivated good management.
notes: Concise statement of the incentive paradox in public-private governance. If self-interest could not motivate good management when the company kept everything, external claims on profits will only reduce motivation further. This is Smith's application of his general theory of self-interest to corporate governance -- people perform better when they benefit directly from their own effort. Anticipates modern debates about the effects of profit-sharing mandates on corporate performance.

refashioned: It might be more agreeable to the company that its own servants and dependents should have the pleasure of wasting, or the profit of embezzling, whatever surplus remained after paying the proposed eight per cent dividend, rather than seeing it fall into the hands of people with whom those financial arrangements could hardly fail to create some friction. The interest of those servants and dependents might so far dominate the proprietors' court as to lead it sometimes to support the very people who had committed violations of the company's own authority. For the majority of proprietors, supporting the company's own institutional authority might sometimes matter less than supporting the individuals who had defied it.
elegant: The company would rather let its own servants waste or steal the surplus than see it go to the government. The servants' influence in the proprietors' court was strong enough to secure support even for those who had defied the company's authority -- because proprietors cared more about their patronage networks than about institutional integrity.
summary: The company's proprietors preferred their own servants' embezzlement to surrendering profits to the government. Patronage networks were so powerful that the proprietors' court would even protect servants who had defied the company's own authority.
distilled: Proprietors preferred corruption by their own patronage networks to surrendering profits to the state, even protecting servants who defied the company's own authority.
notes: Describes a deeply dysfunctional governance equilibrium: proprietors, servants, and appointees form an interlocking network of mutual protection that tolerates corruption and defiance of institutional authority. The preference for internal waste over external transfer is rational from the patronage perspective -- embezzled money at least stays within the influence network. Anticipates modern analysis of kleptocratic governance and institutional capture.

refashioned: The regulations of 1773 accordingly did not end the disorder in the company's Indian governance. Despite having at one point, during a momentary fit of good conduct, accumulated over three million pounds in the Calcutta treasury, and despite having afterwards extended their dominion or their depredations over a vast addition of some of the richest and most fertile countries in India, all was wasted and destroyed. They found themselves entirely unprepared to resist the incursion of Hyder Ali. In consequence of these disorders, the company is now, in 1784, in greater distress than ever, and is once again reduced to begging the government for help to prevent immediate bankruptcy. Different parliamentary factions have proposed different plans for better managing its affairs, and all these plans agree on what was always abundantly obvious: that the company is entirely unfit to govern its territorial possessions. Even the company itself seems to be convinced of its own incapacity, and appears, on that account, willing to surrender them to the government.
elegant: The 1773 reforms failed. Despite accumulating over three million pounds in Calcutta and conquering some of India's richest territories, everything was wasted. The company was unprepared for Hyder Ali's invasion and by 1784 faced greater distress than ever, again begging for government rescue. All parliamentary reform plans agreed on what was always obvious: the company was unfit to govern territories. Even the company conceded this, willing to surrender them.
summary: The 1773 reforms failed to fix the East India Company's governance. Despite immense territorial revenues, all was wasted, leaving the company unprepared for military threats and bankrupt again by 1784. All parties -- including the company itself -- finally agreed it was unfit to govern its territorial possessions.
distilled: By 1784, even the East India Company conceded what was always obvious: a joint-stock trading company is structurally unfit to govern territorial possessions.
notes: Smith writes in real time -- 1784, as Pitt's India Act was being debated. Hyder Ali of Mysore (1720-1782) -- formidable Indian ruler whose invasion exposed the company's military weakness. The progression from the 1773 Regulating Act to the 1784 India Act represents Parliament's incremental assumption of Indian governance. Smith's phrase 'dominion or their depredations' deliberately blurs the line between conquest and plunder. The company's willingness to surrender territory is the ultimate admission of institutional failure.

refashioned: With the right to possess forts and garrisons in distant and uncivilized countries comes the right to make peace and war in those countries. The joint-stock companies that have held the one right have consistently exercised the other, and have frequently had it expressly conferred upon them. How unjustly, how capriciously, how cruelly they have commonly exercised it is too well known from recent experience.
elegant: Possessing forts in distant countries necessarily entails the power to make war and peace. Joint-stock companies have always exercised this power -- unjustly, capriciously, and cruelly, as recent experience makes all too clear.
summary: The right to maintain forts abroad necessarily includes the power to make war and peace, and joint-stock companies have exercised this power with notorious injustice and cruelty.
distilled: Joint-stock companies that possess foreign forts inevitably acquire the power to wage war, which they exercise with notorious cruelty and injustice.
notes: Brief but devastating indictment of corporate military power. 'Recent experience' refers to the East India Company's wars in India -- the Carnatic Wars, Bengal campaigns, and conflicts with Hyder Ali. The logical chain -- forts require defense, defense requires military force, military force means war-making power -- shows how commercial privilege escalates to sovereign authority. Smith's condemnation is moral as well as economic.

refashioned: When a company of merchants undertakes, at its own risk and expense, to establish a new trade with some remote and uncivilized nation, it may not be unreasonable to incorporate them as a joint-stock company and to grant them, in case of success, a monopoly of the trade for a certain number of years. This is the easiest and most natural way for the state to compensate them for risking a dangerous and expensive experiment from which the public will afterwards benefit. A temporary monopoly of this kind can be justified on the same principles as granting a monopoly on a new machine to its inventor, or on a new book to its author.
elegant: A temporary monopoly may be justified when merchants pioneer trade with remote nations at their own risk -- the easiest way to compensate them for a dangerous experiment that will ultimately benefit the public. The principle is the same as patent protection for inventors or copyright for authors.
summary: Temporary monopolies for pioneering traders can be justified as compensation for dangerous commercial experiments, on the same principle as patents for inventors and copyrights for authors.
distilled: Temporary trade monopolies are justified as compensation for pioneering commercial risk, just as patents reward inventors and copyrights reward authors.
notes: Smith's qualified defense of temporary monopoly -- one of the few cases where he accepts monopoly as legitimate. The parallel to patents and copyrights is significant: all three reward risk-taking and innovation with time-limited exclusive rights. The key qualifications are 'temporary' and 'at their own risk and expense.' This passage is often cited in intellectual property debates as evidence that even free-market thinkers accept limited monopoly for innovation incentives. Cross-reference to Book IV's broader critique of permanent monopolies.

refashioned: But when the term expires, the monopoly should certainly end. The forts and garrisons, if any were found necessary, should be taken over by the government, their value paid to the company, and the trade opened to all citizens. A perpetual monopoly taxes all other citizens in two absurd ways: first, through the high prices of goods that would be much cheaper under free trade; and second, through their total exclusion from a branch of business that many of them might find both convenient and profitable to engage in.
elegant: When a temporary monopoly expires, the trade should be fully opened and any forts transferred to the government at fair value. Perpetual monopoly imposes two absurd taxes on the public: inflated prices for goods, and total exclusion from potentially profitable business.
summary: Temporary monopolies should expire on schedule, with forts transferred to government and trade opened to all. Perpetual monopolies impose a double tax on the public: higher prices and exclusion from profitable business opportunities.
distilled: Perpetual monopolies are doubly absurd: they force the public to pay higher prices while excluding them from profitable business they could otherwise pursue.
notes: Smith's 'two taxes' formulation of monopoly costs is analytically precise: (1) consumer surplus loss from higher prices, and (2) producer surplus loss from excluded entrepreneurs. The prescription -- government buyout of forts plus trade liberalization -- is a practical policy recommendation. The word 'absurdly' signals Smith's moral as well as economic objection. Cross-reference to Book IV, Chapter 7 on monopoly costs.

refashioned: It is for the most worthless of purposes, too, that they are taxed this way. It is merely to enable the company to sustain the negligence, extravagance, and embezzlement of its own servants, whose disorderly conduct rarely allows the company's dividend to exceed the ordinary rate of profit in unregulated trades, and very frequently drives it well below that rate. Without a monopoly, however, experience shows that a joint-stock company cannot long carry on any branch of foreign trade. To buy in one market to sell profitably in another, when facing many competitors in both; to monitor not only occasional shifts in demand but the much larger and more frequent variations in supply from other competitors; and to adapt with skill and judgment both the quantity and quality of each shipment to all these circumstances -- this is a kind of warfare whose operations are constantly changing. It can hardly ever be conducted successfully without the unrelenting vigilance and attention that cannot long be expected from the directors of a joint-stock company.
elegant: The public pays this double monopoly tax merely to fund the company's servants' negligence, extravagance, and embezzlement -- which keep dividends at or below ordinary profit rates anyway. Without monopoly, joint-stock companies cannot sustain foreign trade, because competitive trade is a constantly shifting warfare of buying and selling across markets, adapting to changing demand and supply, requiring vigilance that corporate directors inherently cannot maintain.
summary: Monopoly taxes fund only the company's internal waste, since dividends barely reach ordinary profit levels. Without monopoly protection, joint-stock companies fail in foreign trade because competitive commerce requires constant, adaptive vigilance that corporate directors structurally cannot provide.
distilled: Joint-stock companies cannot sustain competitive foreign trade because it requires constant entrepreneurial vigilance that their directors structurally cannot provide -- so they survive only through monopoly, which merely funds their own waste.
notes: Smith's definitive verdict on joint-stock companies in foreign trade. The 'warfare' metaphor for competitive trade captures the dynamism of markets vs. the bureaucratic nature of corporate management. The observation that dividends rarely exceed ordinary profit despite monopoly protection means monopoly benefits are consumed entirely by internal waste -- the public pays, but even shareholders barely benefit. This is the theoretical capstone of the entire joint-stock critique running from 5.1.115.

refashioned: The East India Company, upon the redemption of its government funds and the expiration of its exclusive privilege, has a right by act of Parliament to continue as a corporation with a joint stock and to trade in its corporate capacity to the East Indies alongside all other British subjects. But in that situation, the superior vigilance and attention of private traders would, in all probability, soon make them weary of the trade.
elegant: If the East India Company lost its monopoly, it could still trade alongside private competitors -- but private traders' superior vigilance would quickly drive it from the market.
summary: Without its monopoly, the East India Company would have the legal right to continue trading but would be quickly outcompeted by more vigilant private traders.
distilled: Without monopoly protection, the East India Company would be quickly driven from trade by the superior vigilance of private competitors.
notes: A prediction about the East India Company's fate without monopoly, based on the general theory developed in 5.1.145. The confidence of the prediction ('in all probability, soon') reflects Smith's certainty about the joint-stock form's competitive disadvantage. The company's actual monopoly was gradually reduced (1813 India trade opened, 1833 China trade opened) and formally ended in 1858 -- the company's abolition broadly confirming Smith's analysis.

refashioned: An eminent French author with great knowledge of political economy, the Abbe Morellet, compiled a list of fifty-five joint-stock companies for foreign trade established in various parts of Europe since 1600, all of which, according to him, failed due to mismanagement despite holding exclusive privileges. He was misinformed about two or three of them, which were not joint-stock companies and had not failed. But to compensate, there were several failed joint-stock companies that he omitted.
elegant: The Abbe Morellet listed fifty-five joint-stock trading companies established across Europe since 1600, all of which failed despite exclusive privileges. He was wrong about two or three, but he also missed several others that failed -- so his tally, if anything, understated the scale of failure.
summary: The Abbe Morellet documented fifty-five failed joint-stock trading companies across Europe since 1600. Though he miscategorized a few, he also missed several failures, making his count conservative rather than exaggerated.
distilled: Fifty-five joint-stock trading companies across Europe have failed since 1600 despite exclusive privileges -- a record so comprehensive that miscounts only strengthen the pattern.
notes: Abbe Andre Morellet (1727-1819) -- French economist and encyclopedist, friend of Smith's, author of works on commercial companies. The figure of fifty-five failures is powerful empirical evidence. Smith's correction (some were not joint-stock, some failures were omitted) shows scholarly precision while strengthening the argument. This is the empirical complement to the theoretical argument in 5.1.145.

refashioned: The only trades in which a joint-stock company seems capable of succeeding without an exclusive privilege are those whose operations can all be reduced to a routine -- a uniformity of method that admits little or no variation. Of this kind are, first, banking; second, insurance against fire, sea risk, and wartime capture; third, building and maintaining navigable canals; and fourth, the similar business of supplying a great city with water.
elegant: Joint-stock companies can succeed without monopoly only in trades reducible to strict routine: banking, insurance, canal operation, and water supply. These admit little variation and require no entrepreneurial adaptability.
summary: Joint-stock companies can succeed without monopoly privileges only in routine businesses -- banking, insurance, canals, and water supply -- where operations follow strict rules and require no entrepreneurial judgment.
distilled: Joint-stock companies succeed without monopoly only in routine businesses like banking, insurance, canals, and water supply -- never in trades requiring entrepreneurial judgment.
notes: Smith's positive theory of where joint-stock companies work: only in 'routine' businesses. The four examples share key features -- rule-based operations, large capital requirements, and limited need for adaptive judgment. Banking and insurance require actuarial rules; canals and water supply are infrastructure with predictable operations. This analysis anticipates modern theories of transaction costs and organizational boundaries -- corporations work for routine tasks, markets for adaptive ones. Cross-reference to 5.1.152 for the full criteria.

refashioned: Though the principles of banking may seem somewhat abstract, the practice can be reduced to strict rules. To depart from those rules because of some flattering speculation of extraordinary gain is almost always extremely dangerous and frequently fatal to the banking company that attempts it. But the constitution of joint-stock companies makes them, in general, more committed to established rules than any private partnership. Such companies therefore seem extremely well suited to banking. Europe's principal banking companies are accordingly joint-stock companies, and many manage their business very successfully without any exclusive privilege. The Bank of England's only exclusive privilege is that no other banking company in England may consist of more than six persons. The two banks of Edinburgh are joint-stock companies without any exclusive privilege.
elegant: Banking's abstract principles reduce to strict rules in practice, and departing from them for speculative gains is almost always fatal. Joint-stock companies' inherent conservatism -- their attachment to established rules -- makes them well suited to banking. Europe's major banks are joint-stock companies, many successful without exclusive privileges. The Bank of England's sole privilege is that no English rival may have more than six partners.
summary: Banking's reducibility to strict rules makes it well suited to joint-stock companies, whose natural conservatism and rule-following are advantages rather than liabilities. Europe's major banks succeed as joint-stock companies, most without monopoly privileges.
distilled: Joint-stock companies' inherent conservatism and rule-following, liabilities in competitive trade, become advantages in banking where strict rules and avoidance of speculation are essential.
notes: Elegant reversal: the very quality that makes joint-stock companies fail in foreign trade (rigid, rule-bound management) makes them succeed in banking. The Bank of England's restriction (no rival with more than six partners) effectively prevented joint-stock competition until 1826 -- a more significant privilege than Smith suggests. The Edinburgh banks -- the Bank of Scotland (1695) and the Royal Bank of Scotland (1727) -- operated successfully without monopoly. Cross-reference to Book II's extensive discussion of banking.

refashioned: The value of risk -- whether from fire, sea loss, or wartime capture -- though perhaps not calculable with precision, admits of a rough estimation sufficient to make it, in some degree, reducible to strict rule and method. The insurance trade can therefore be carried on successfully by a joint-stock company without any exclusive privilege. Neither the London Assurance nor the Royal Exchange Assurance companies have any such privilege.
elegant: Insurance risks from fire, shipwreck, and wartime capture can be roughly estimated and reduced to rules, making insurance suitable for joint-stock management. Neither of London's two major insurance companies holds any exclusive privilege.
summary: Insurance risks can be estimated roughly enough to operate by rules, making it suitable for joint-stock companies. London's two major insurance companies succeed without exclusive privileges.
distilled: Insurance succeeds as a joint-stock business because risks can be estimated well enough to operate by systematic rules rather than entrepreneurial judgment.
notes: The key phrase is 'gross estimation' -- insurance does not require precise risk calculation, just workable approximations. This anticipates actuarial science's development. The London Assurance and Royal Exchange Assurance, both chartered in 1720 (the Bubble Act year), were the major English insurance companies. Their success without exclusive privilege supports Smith's theory. Cross-reference to 5.1.154 on insurance's broader social function.

refashioned: Once a navigable canal has been built, managing it becomes quite simple and easy, fully reducible to strict rules and methods. Even the construction itself can be so managed, since it can be contracted out to builders at a fixed rate per mile and per lock. The same applies to aqueducts or great pipes for supplying a city with water. Such undertakings can therefore be, and frequently are, managed very successfully by joint-stock companies without any exclusive privilege.
elegant: Canal management is simple and rule-based once construction is complete, and even construction can be contracted at fixed rates per mile and lock. Water supply works the same way. Both are routinely and successfully managed by joint-stock companies without monopoly privileges.
summary: Canals and water supply systems are simple to manage once built, with even construction reducible to standard contracts. Joint-stock companies successfully operate both without exclusive privileges.
distilled: Canals and water supply, reducible to routine management and standard construction contracts, are natural fits for joint-stock companies without monopoly protection.
notes: The canal mania of the 1760s-1790s was a major feature of the early Industrial Revolution in Britain. Smith's analysis of why canals suit joint-stock organization is precise: both construction (contractible) and operation (routine) are rule-based. The 'per mile, per lock' pricing shows standardized contracting. These are what economists now call 'natural monopolies' -- large fixed costs, routine operations, limited competition. Cross-reference to 5.1.82-86 on canals as public works.

refashioned: To establish a joint-stock company merely because such a company might be capable of managing a particular undertaking successfully, or to exempt a particular set of dealers from general laws merely because they might thrive with such an exemption, would certainly not be reasonable. To make such an establishment perfectly reasonable, two additional conditions must be met beyond the business being reducible to strict routine. First, it must be clearly evident that the undertaking is of greater and more general utility than most ordinary trades. Second, it must require a larger capital than can easily be assembled in a private partnership. If a moderate capital were sufficient, the undertaking's great utility would not justify a joint-stock company, because the demand for its products would be readily and easily supplied by private enterprise. In the four trades mentioned above, both conditions are met.
elegant: Three conditions justify a joint-stock company: the business must be reducible to routine, it must serve greater public utility than ordinary trades, and it must require more capital than a private partnership can assemble. If moderate capital suffices, private enterprise will meet the demand -- no joint-stock company is needed. Banking, insurance, canals, and water supply meet all three conditions.
summary: A joint-stock company is justified only when three conditions converge: the business is routine, it serves exceptional public utility, and it requires capital beyond what private partnerships can provide. Only banking, insurance, canals, and water supply meet all three criteria.
distilled: Joint-stock companies are justified only when the business is routine, serves exceptional public utility, and requires capital exceeding what private partnerships can raise.
notes: Smith's three-part test for when the corporate form is appropriate -- routine operations, public utility, and capital requirements beyond private capacity. This is a remarkably modern framework for evaluating when incorporation is socially beneficial. The emphasis on necessity (not just capability) prevents over-extension of the corporate form. The test implicitly argues against most existing joint-stock companies of Smith's day. Anticipates modern debates about when public utilities should be privately or publicly organized.

refashioned: The great and general utility of banking, when prudently managed, was fully explained in the second book of this inquiry. But a public bank that must support public credit and, in emergencies, advance to the government the entire proceeds of a tax -- potentially several millions -- a year or two before the revenue actually comes in, requires a capital far larger than any private partnership can easily assemble.
elegant: Banking's great public utility was established in Book II. But a bank that must support public credit and advance millions to the government before tax revenues arrive requires capital far beyond any private partnership's capacity.
summary: Banking serves great public utility and requires capital beyond private partnership capacity, especially when the bank must support public credit and advance tax revenues to the government before they are collected.
distilled: Public banking requires capital beyond private partnership capacity because it must support government credit and advance tax revenues years before they arrive.
notes: Applies the three-part test from 5.1.152 to banking. The specific function described -- advancing tax revenues before collection -- is central banking in embryo. The 'several millions' advanced to government shows the scale mismatch between public credit needs and private capital capacity. Cross-reference to Book II's extended analysis of banking, particularly the Bank of England's role in government finance.

refashioned: Insurance gives great security to the fortunes of private people, and by distributing among many the loss that would ruin any one individual, makes it fall lightly and easily upon society as a whole. To provide this security, however, insurers must have very large capital. Before the establishment of the two joint-stock insurance companies in London, a list was reportedly presented to the attorney general of one hundred and fifty private insurers who had failed within a few years.
elegant: Insurance protects individual fortunes by spreading losses that would ruin one person across many, making them light for society. This requires very large capital -- before London's joint-stock insurers were established, one hundred and fifty private insurers had failed in just a few years.
summary: Insurance serves a vital social function by distributing catastrophic individual losses across many parties, but requires large capital that private insurers often lack -- as shown by the failure of one hundred and fifty private insurers before London's joint-stock companies were established.
distilled: Insurance requires joint-stock scale because the capital needed to spread catastrophic losses reliably exceeds what private insurers can sustain, as mass private insurer failures demonstrated.
notes: Smith's description of insurance as risk-pooling -- 'dividing among a great many that loss which would ruin an individual' -- is the classic statement of the insurance principle. The one hundred and fifty private insurer failures provide dramatic empirical support for the capital-requirement argument. The attorney general's list suggests regulatory awareness of the problem before the corporate solution. This passage applies the 5.1.152 test: public utility (risk distribution) plus capital requirements beyond private capacity.

refashioned:
That navigable canals and waterworks for supplying great cities are of great and general utility, while frequently requiring expense beyond the fortunes of private individuals, is sufficiently obvious.

Except for the four trades mentioned above, I have been unable to identify any other in which all three conditions necessary to justify a joint-stock company are present. The English Copper Company of London, the Lead-Smelting Company, and the Glass-Grinding Company cannot even claim any great or singular utility in what they do, nor does their business seem to require expenses beyond what many private individuals could afford. Whether their trade is reducible to strict routine or whether they can boast of extraordinary profits, I do not claim to know. The Mine-Adventurers Company has long since gone bankrupt. A share in the British Linen Company of Edinburgh currently sells well below par, though less so than it did some years ago. The joint-stock companies established for the public-spirited purpose of promoting particular manufactures not only manage their own affairs badly -- diminishing the general stock of society -- but can in other respects hardly fail to do more harm than good. Despite the most upright intentions, the unavoidable partiality of their directors toward particular branches of manufacture, whose promoters mislead and manipulate them, is a real discouragement to all the rest. It necessarily disrupts the natural proportion that would otherwise establish itself between judicious industry and profit -- which, for the general industry of the country, is the greatest and most effective encouragement of all.
elegant: Canals and waterworks obviously meet the utility and capital tests. Beyond these four trades, no others satisfy all three conditions for justifying a joint-stock company. Companies for copper, lead-smelting, and glass-grinding lack either singular utility or exceptional capital needs. The Mine-Adventurers Company went bankrupt; the British Linen Company trades below par. Joint-stock companies established to promote specific manufactures do particular harm: their directors' unavoidable partiality toward favored branches disrupts the natural proportion between industry and profit that is the most powerful encouragement to economic activity.
summary: Only four trades meet all conditions justifying joint-stock companies. Manufacturing promotion companies are particularly harmful because their directors' inevitable favoritism toward particular branches disrupts the natural market relationship between effort and reward that best encourages productive industry.
