distilled: Joint-stock companies for manufacturing promotion are uniquely harmful because their directors' unavoidable favoritism toward particular industries disrupts the natural market mechanism that best allocates resources.
notes: Comprehensive application of the three-part test to reject all joint-stock companies beyond the four approved trades. The critique of manufacturing promotion companies anticipates modern concerns about industrial policy and government picking winners. The 'natural proportion between judicious industry and profit' is Smith's invisible hand at the industry level -- market signals directing resources efficiently. The British Linen Company (founded 1746) evolved into a bank, eventually becoming part of the Bank of Scotland. The specific companies named (Copper, Lead-Smelting, Glass-Grinding, Mine-Adventurers) are historical examples of failed or struggling joint-stock ventures.

refashioned:
Article II -- Of the Expense of the Institutions for the Education of Youth.

The institutions for educating the young may, in the same way, furnish revenue sufficient to cover their own expenses. The fee or honorarium that the student pays the teacher naturally constitutes a revenue of this kind.
elegant: Educational institutions can be self-funding through student fees paid to teachers -- a natural revenue source that requires no external subsidy.
summary: Educational institutions can fund themselves through student fees, which constitute a natural revenue source for teachers.
distilled: Student fees paid to teachers are the natural revenue source for educational institutions, potentially making them self-funding.
notes: Section heading introducing Smith's extended analysis of education (5.1.156-182). Opens with the market principle: education can be funded by those who benefit from it (students paying fees). This sets up the contrast with endowed institutions that follows. The term 'honorary' (honorarium) reflects the convention that teaching was a respected profession compensated by voluntary gifts rather than commercial transactions.

refashioned: Even where the teacher's income does not arise entirely from student fees, it need not come from the general revenue of the state -- the revenue whose collection and spending are, in most countries, assigned to the executive power. Throughout most of Europe, the endowment of schools and colleges either places no burden on general revenue or only a very small one. Their funding comes chiefly from some local or provincial source: the rent of some landed estate, or the interest on some sum of money, set aside and placed under the management of trustees for this specific purpose -- sometimes by the sovereign, sometimes by a private donor.
elegant: Teachers' salaries need not come from general state revenue. Across Europe, schools and colleges are mostly funded by local endowments -- rents from landed estates or interest on dedicated funds -- managed by trustees and established by sovereigns or private donors.
summary: European educational institutions are mostly funded not by general state revenue but by local endowments -- land rents or investment income managed by trustees -- established by sovereigns or private donors.
distilled: European education is funded primarily through local endowments rather than general taxation, with dedicated land rents or investment income managed by trustees.
notes: Describes the 18th-century educational funding model: endowed institutions rather than state-funded ones. The distinction between general revenue (state taxation) and local endowment (dedicated funds) is important for Smith's subsequent critique. The trustee management model creates the agency problems he will analyze. This sets up the central question: do endowments improve or undermine educational quality?

refashioned: Have these public endowments generally served the purpose for which they were established? Have they encouraged the diligence and improved the abilities of teachers? Have they directed education toward subjects more useful to both individuals and the public than those it would naturally have pursued on its own? It should not be very difficult to give at least a probable answer to each of these questions.
elegant: Three questions about educational endowments: Have they achieved their purpose? Have they made teachers more diligent and able? Have they directed education toward more useful subjects? The answers should not be difficult to discern.
summary: Smith poses three critical questions about educational endowments: whether they fulfilled their purpose, improved teaching quality, and directed education toward more useful subjects.
distilled: The test of educational endowments is whether they improved teaching, increased diligence, and directed learning toward genuinely useful subjects -- and the answers are likely negative.
notes: Rhetorical setup for the critique that follows. The three questions correspond to three failures Smith will identify: endowments fail their purpose, reduce teacher effort, and misdirect curriculum. The implied negative answers are signaled by 'it should not seem very difficult' -- Smith's characteristic understatement before a devastating critique. This framework anticipates modern education policy debates about institutional incentives and curriculum relevance.

refashioned: In every profession, most practitioners exert themselves in proportion to the necessity they face. This necessity is greatest for those whose professional earnings are their sole source of income and even of basic subsistence. To acquire their fortune, or merely to subsist, they must complete a certain quantity of work of known value each year; and where competition is free, the rivalry of others trying to take their place forces every practitioner to work with a certain degree of skill. The prospect of great rewards in some professions may inspire extraordinary effort from a few exceptionally ambitious individuals. But great prizes are clearly not necessary to produce the greatest exertions. Rivalry and emulation can make excellence an object of ambition even in humble professions, frequently drawing out the greatest efforts. Great prizes alone, without the pressure of necessity, have rarely been enough to inspire much exertion. In England, success in law leads to some very great prizes of ambition; yet how few people born to comfortable fortunes have ever distinguished themselves in that profession?
elegant: Professional exertion is proportional to necessity. Those who depend entirely on their earnings for survival work hardest. Free competition forces everyone to maintain standards, as rivals stand ready to replace them. Great prizes may inspire a few ambitious individuals, but rivalry and emulation motivate far more effectively than the mere prospect of reward. Without the pressure of necessity, great prizes alone rarely produce great effort -- as shown by how few wealthy-born Englishmen have excelled in law despite its enormous rewards.
summary: Professional effort is driven by necessity and competition, not by the size of potential rewards. Rivalry among practitioners forced to earn their living produces far more exertion than great prizes offered to those without financial pressure, as the legal profession demonstrates.
distilled: Necessity and competition drive professional excellence far more effectively than the prospect of great rewards, which alone rarely motivate those without financial pressure.
notes: Foundational statement of Smith's incentive theory applied to education. The key distinction is between extrinsic rewards (prizes) and structural pressure (necessity and competition). The legal profession example is empirically testable and personally observed. The insight that competition among the necessity-driven produces more excellence than prizes for the comfortable anticipates modern research on intrinsic vs. extrinsic motivation. This sets up the critique of endowed teachers whose necessity has been removed.

refashioned:
The endowment of schools and colleges has necessarily diminished, more or less, the necessity for teachers to exert themselves. Their subsistence, insofar as it comes from their salaries, derives from a fund entirely independent of their success and reputation in their profession.

In some universities, the salary forms only a part, and frequently a small part, of the teacher's earnings, the greater part arising from student fees. The necessity of exertion, though always somewhat diminished, is not in this case entirely removed. Reputation still matters to the teacher, and he still depends on the affection, gratitude, and favorable reports of former students. He is most likely to earn these favorable sentiments by actually deserving them -- that is, by the ability and diligence with which he performs every part of his duty.
elegant: Endowments diminish teachers' necessity to exert themselves by providing income independent of performance. Where salary is only part of earnings and fees form the rest, some incentive remains -- reputation and student goodwill still matter, and the best way to earn these is by genuinely deserving them through ability and diligence.
summary: Endowments reduce teaching effort by providing income independent of performance. Where student fees supplement salary, some incentive for diligence remains through the need to maintain reputation and student goodwill.
distilled: Endowments weaken teaching incentives by decoupling income from performance, though partial fee-dependence preserves some motivation through reputation effects.
notes: Introduces the key mechanism: salary independence from performance reduces effort. The two-tier system (salary plus fees) preserves partial incentives. Smith's insight that 'the best way to gain favorable sentiments is by deserving them' embeds the market mechanism within the educational relationship -- students are consumers whose satisfaction disciplines teacher quality. This is the moderate case; the extreme case (salary only, no fees) follows in 5.1.161.

refashioned: In other universities, the teacher is prohibited from receiving any fee from students, and his salary constitutes his entire income from the position. His interest is, in this case, set in direct opposition to his duty, as completely as it is possible to set it. It is in every person's interest to live as much at ease as possible; and if his income will be exactly the same whether he performs a very laborious duty or not, it is certainly in his interest -- at least as interest is commonly understood -- either to neglect the duty altogether, or, if some authority prevents that, to perform it in as careless and slovenly a manner as that authority will permit. If he is naturally active and hardworking, it is in his interest to employ that energy in any activity from which he can derive some advantage, rather than in performing his duty, from which he can derive none.
elegant: Where teachers are barred from receiving fees and paid only salary, their interest is set in direct opposition to their duty. Since income is the same whether they work diligently or not, rational self-interest dictates either neglecting the duty entirely or performing it as carelessly as possible. Even naturally energetic teachers have incentive to redirect their efforts toward more rewarding activities.
summary: When teachers receive only salary with no fee income, their financial interest directly opposes their duty. Rational self-interest leads them to neglect teaching or perform it as carelessly as authority permits, redirecting their energy toward personally rewarding activities.
distilled: Salary without performance-linked fees sets a teacher's self-interest in direct opposition to his duty, rationally incentivizing neglect or minimal effort.
notes: Smith's most direct application of self-interest theory to education. The phrase 'as interest is vulgarly understood' acknowledges that some people are intrinsically motivated, but argues that institutional design should not depend on this. The insight that even active, energetic teachers will redirect effort away from unrewarded duties toward rewarding alternatives is a sophisticated application of opportunity cost. This is the theoretical foundation for performance-based pay in education -- a still-active policy debate. Cross-reference to the butcher-baker-brewer passage in Book I on self-interest as the basis for institutional design.

refashioned: If the authority to which the teacher is subject resides in the corporate body -- the college or university -- of which he himself is a member, and in which most other members are likewise teachers or supposed to be, they are likely to form a common cause, all being very indulgent to one another. Every teacher consents that his colleague may neglect his duty, provided he himself is allowed to neglect his own. At the University of Oxford, the greater part of the public professors have, for many years, given up altogether even the pretense of teaching.
elegant: When teachers are accountable only to each other within a college, they form a mutual tolerance pact -- each ignoring the other's neglect in exchange for permission to neglect his own duties. At Oxford, most public professors have for many years abandoned even the pretense of teaching.
summary: When teachers are accountable only to their fellow teachers within a university, they form a mutual non-enforcement pact, tolerating each other's neglect. At Oxford, most professors have long since stopped even pretending to teach.
distilled: Peer accountability among teachers produces mutual tolerance of neglect, as Oxford's professors demonstrate by abandoning even the pretense of teaching.
notes: Smith's devastating critique of Oxford -- where he studied for six years (1740-1746) and found the experience deeply unsatisfying. The 'mutual indulgence' mechanism is a collective action problem: enforcing standards on others would invite enforcement on oneself. This is the academic equivalent of a cartel -- members cooperate to minimize effort rather than compete on quality. The passage has become one of the most cited critiques of academic self-governance in economics.

refashioned: If the authority to which the teacher is subject resides not in the college but in some external person -- the bishop of the diocese, the provincial governor, or perhaps a government minister -- then the teacher is not likely to be allowed to neglect his duty entirely. But all that such superiors can force him to do is attend his students for a certain number of hours, giving a certain number of lectures per week or year. What those lectures contain must still depend on the teacher's diligence, and that diligence will be proportional to his motives for exerting it. An external authority of this kind is, moreover, liable to be exercised both ignorantly and capriciously. It is inherently arbitrary and discretionary, and the people who wield it -- neither attending the lectures themselves nor perhaps understanding the subjects taught -- are rarely able to exercise it with good judgment. Furthermore, the insolence of office frequently makes them indifferent about how they exercise it, and they are apt to censure or dismiss a teacher without just cause. The teacher subject to such jurisdiction is necessarily degraded by it and, instead of being one of the most respected members of society, is rendered one of the most contemptible. His only effective protection against bad treatment is powerful patronage, which he is most likely to gain not through ability or diligence in his profession but through obsequiousness to his superiors -- being always ready to sacrifice the rights, interests, and honor of the academic body to their will. Anyone who has spent considerable time observing the administration of a French university will have had occasion to see the effects that naturally result from this kind of arbitrary external authority.
elegant: External authorities -- bishops, governors, ministers -- can force attendance but not quality. They exercise power ignorantly and capriciously, rarely understanding the subjects taught. Their oversight degrades teachers from respected to contemptible figures who survive through patronage and obsequiousness rather than professional excellence. The teacher's only protection against arbitrary authority is powerful connections gained by sacrificing his institution's integrity to his superiors' will. French universities demonstrate these effects clearly.
summary: External oversight of teachers forces attendance but not quality, since authorities exercise power ignorantly and arbitrarily. Teachers are degraded to dependence on patronage rather than professional merit, surviving through obsequiousness. French universities exemplify the dysfunctions of such external academic governance.
distilled: External authority over teachers forces attendance but not quality, degrades the profession, and rewards obsequiousness over competence -- as French universities demonstrate.
notes: Completes the analysis of accountability structures: peer accountability (5.1.162) produces mutual neglect; external accountability produces degradation and patronage-seeking. Neither works. French universities were under close state and church supervision -- the intendant system applied to education. The 'insolence of office' is a Shakespearean phrase (Hamlet, Act III). Smith's solution, implied by the preceding analysis, is market accountability through student fees -- the only mechanism that aligns teacher incentives with performance. The passage also critiques bureaucratic oversight generally.

refashioned:
Whatever forces a certain number of students to attend any college or university, regardless of the teachers' merit or reputation, tends to diminish the necessity of maintaining that merit or reputation.

The privileges of graduates in arts, law, medicine, and divinity, when obtainable only by residing for a certain number of years at certain universities, necessarily compel students to attend those universities regardless of teaching quality. The privileges of graduates are a sort of statute of apprenticeship, and they have contributed to the improvement of education just as other apprenticeship statutes have to the improvement of arts and manufactures.
elegant: Any force compelling students to attend particular institutions regardless of teaching quality reduces the incentive to teach well. Graduation requirements that mandate residency at specific universities function like apprenticeship statutes -- and have improved education just as much as apprenticeship statutes improved manufacturing: that is, not at all.
summary: Mandatory residency requirements for degrees force students to attend regardless of teaching quality, eliminating competitive pressure on teachers. These requirements are academic equivalents of apprenticeship statutes, and equally harmful.
distilled: Mandatory degree residency requirements destroy competitive pressure on teachers by forcing student attendance regardless of teaching quality -- the academic equivalent of apprenticeship restrictions.
notes: The devastating comparison to apprenticeship statutes, which Smith thoroughly critiqued in Book I as impediments to labor mobility and skill development, makes the point without needing to elaborate. Residency requirements function as barriers to market competition: students cannot 'shop' for quality because their degrees require attendance at specific institutions. This is the demand-side complement to the supply-side analysis of teacher incentives. Together, they explain why endowed universities with captive students produce poor education.

refashioned: Charitable foundations of scholarships, exhibitions, and bursaries necessarily attach a certain number of students to particular colleges regardless of those colleges' merit. If students receiving such charitable support were free to choose whichever college they preferred, this freedom might stimulate some competitive emulation among colleges. A regulation that prohibited even the independent members of each college from leaving it for another without first obtaining permission from the college they wished to leave would, on the contrary, tend strongly to extinguish that emulation.
elegant: Scholarships tied to specific colleges eliminate student choice and competitive pressure. If scholarship holders could choose freely among colleges, competition would emerge. Regulations preventing even non-scholarship students from transferring without permission destroy competitive emulation entirely.
summary: Scholarships tied to specific colleges eliminate student choice and competition. Allowing free choice would create emulation among institutions, while transfer restrictions destroy it.
distilled: Tying scholarships to specific colleges and restricting student transfers eliminates the competitive pressure that would force colleges to improve their teaching.
notes: Extends the market analysis to charitable endowments: even well-intentioned scholarships can reduce educational quality by eliminating student choice. The distinction between tied and portable scholarships anticipates modern debates about school vouchers and student-following funding. The transfer restriction Smith describes is a real feature of Oxbridge colleges. The argument is pure market logic: student mobility = competitive discipline = better teaching.

refashioned: If, within each college, the tutor assigned to instruct each student in all subjects were not voluntarily chosen by the student but appointed by the head of the college; and if, in cases of neglect, incompetence, or bad treatment, the student were not permitted to change tutors without first obtaining permission from the college authorities -- such a regulation would not only tend strongly to extinguish all competitive emulation among tutors within the same college but would greatly diminish, in all of them, the necessity for diligence and attention to their students. Such teachers, though very well paid by their students, might be just as inclined to neglect them as those who receive no student fees at all or whose only compensation is their salary.
elegant: If tutors are assigned rather than chosen by students, and students cannot switch tutors without institutional permission, all competitive incentive among tutors is destroyed. Even fee-paid tutors will neglect students when those students have no power to choose alternatives or leave.
summary: Assigning tutors rather than allowing student choice, combined with restrictions on switching, destroys competitive incentives even when tutors are paid by student fees. The inability to exit neutralizes the market mechanism.
distilled: Assigned tutors without student choice of exit are as negligent as salaried teachers, because the market mechanism requires the freedom to choose alternatives.
notes: Crucial theoretical refinement: fees alone are insufficient -- the market mechanism requires both payment and choice. A captive customer paying fees is in the same position as no customer at all, because the threat of exit is what disciplines the provider. This is the educational equivalent of Smith's general insight that competition, not just payment, drives quality. Anticipates Albert Hirschman's 'exit and voice' framework (1970) -- without exit, voice is impotent.

refashioned: If the teacher happens to be a person of sense, it must be unpleasant for him to be conscious, while lecturing, that he is speaking or reading nonsense, or something very close to it. It must also be unpleasant to observe that most of his students either desert his lectures or attend them with obvious marks of neglect, contempt, and mockery. If he is required to give a certain number of lectures, these motives alone, without any financial interest, might lead him to take some trouble to make them tolerably good. Several expedients, however, can effectively blunt these motivations. Instead of explaining the subject himself, the teacher may simply read from a book. If the book is in a foreign and dead language, he may interpret it for his students, or -- what requires even less effort -- have them interpret it for him, occasionally adding a remark of his own. He may flatter himself that this constitutes a lecture. The slightest knowledge and effort will allow him to do this without exposing himself to ridicule by saying anything genuinely foolish or absurd. The college's disciplinary system, meanwhile, can compel all his students to attend these sham lectures with perfect regularity and to maintain the most respectful behavior throughout the performance.
elegant: A sensible teacher finds it unpleasant to lecture in nonsense or face empty seats and mockery. These feelings might motivate some effort. But easy evasions exist: reading from a book, having students translate dead-language texts, adding occasional remarks -- all passing as 'lectures' while requiring minimal knowledge or effort. College discipline then compels students to attend these performances with forced regularity and respect.
summary: Even teachers with some self-respect might be motivated by the unpleasantness of lecturing badly to empty or mocking rooms. But institutional evasions -- reading from books, having students translate texts, adding minimal commentary -- allow teachers to avoid genuine effort while college discipline forces student attendance and outward respect.
distilled: Institutional structures allow teachers to evade real instruction through book-reading and student translation exercises, while college discipline forces captive attendance at these sham lectures.
notes: Vivid portrait of academic dysfunction drawn from Smith's own Oxford experience (1740-1746). The specific evasions described -- reading from books in dead languages, having students translate, adding occasional remarks -- were actual common practices. The word 'performance' is deliberately theatrical, reducing the lecture to empty ritual. The college discipline that enforces attendance completes the dysfunction: students are forced to participate in a charade. Smith's personal frustration with Oxford is well-documented in his correspondence.

refashioned: The discipline of colleges and universities is generally designed not for the benefit of the students but for the interest, or more accurately, for the ease of the teachers. Its purpose is always to maintain the teacher's authority, and whether he neglects or performs his duty, to force students to behave as if he performed it with the greatest diligence and ability. It presumes perfect wisdom and virtue in the one party, and the greatest weakness and folly in the other. Where teachers actually perform their duty, however, I believe there are no examples of students generally neglecting theirs. Discipline is never needed to force attendance at lectures that are truly worth attending, as is well known wherever such lectures are given. Force and restraint may be necessary to some degree for children and young boys during the early period of education that is thought essential for them. But after twelve or thirteen years of age, provided the teacher does his duty, force or restraint is almost never needed. Such is the generosity of most young people that, far from being disposed to neglect or despise their teacher's instruction -- provided he shows genuine intention of being useful to them -- they are generally inclined to forgive a great deal of imperfection in how he performs his duty, and sometimes even to conceal from the public considerable gross negligence.
elegant: University discipline serves teachers' ease, not students' benefit -- maintaining the teacher's authority regardless of whether he earns it. It presumes perfect wisdom in teachers and perfect folly in students. Yet where teachers genuinely perform their duties, students never neglect theirs. No discipline is needed for lectures worth attending. After age twelve or thirteen, provided the teacher is sincere, students are generous enough to forgive considerable imperfection and even conceal their teacher's gross negligence.
summary: University discipline is designed for teachers' comfort, not students' benefit, presuming teacher perfection and student incompetence. Yet good teaching never requires forced attendance -- students willingly attend worthwhile lectures and generously tolerate imperfection in sincere teachers.
distilled: University discipline exists for teachers' ease, not students' benefit -- and is never needed where teaching is genuinely good, because students willingly attend worthwhile instruction.
notes: Smith inverts the conventional justification for academic discipline: it protects lazy teachers, not wayward students. The observation that good lectures need no compulsory attendance is empirically testable and psychologically astute. The insight about students' generosity -- their willingness to forgive imperfection in sincere teachers -- humanizes the argument and distinguishes between lazy neglect and honest limitation. The age threshold of twelve or thirteen for when self-directed learning begins is remarkably progressive for the 18th century.

refashioned: It is worth observing that the subjects for which there are no public institutions are generally the best taught. When a young person goes to a fencing or dancing school, he does not always learn to fence or dance very well, but he seldom fails to learn to fence or dance. The benefits of riding schools are not usually so evident. The expense of a riding school is so great that in most places it operates as a public institution. The three most essential parts of literary education -- reading, writing, and arithmetic -- are still more commonly acquired in private schools than public ones; and it very rarely happens that anyone fails to acquire them to the necessary degree.
elegant: Subjects without public institutions are generally the best taught. Fencing and dancing students may not achieve mastery, but they reliably learn the skills. Public riding schools are less effective. The three foundational skills -- reading, writing, and arithmetic -- are still mostly taught privately, and virtually everyone who needs them acquires them adequately.
summary: Education is generally better where no public institutions exist. Private fencing, dancing, and basic literacy schools reliably teach their subjects, while publicly funded institutions like riding schools show less consistent results.
distilled: Privately funded education consistently outperforms publicly endowed instruction because market competition ensures that students actually learn what they pay to be taught.
notes: Powerful empirical argument for market-based education. The contrast between fencing/dancing (private, effective) and riding (public, less effective) isolates the institutional variable. The observation that reading, writing, and arithmetic -- the most essential skills -- are taught privately and universally acquired is Smith's strongest evidence. The logic is consistent: private teachers who fail to teach lose students and income; endowed teachers face no such consequences. This passage is frequently cited in school choice and education reform debates.

refashioned: In England, the public schools are much less corrupted than the universities. In schools, young people are taught, or at least may be taught, Greek and Latin -- everything the masters claim to teach or are expected to teach. In the universities, young people are neither taught, nor can always find proper means of being taught, the subjects that these incorporated bodies exist to teach. Schoolmasters' pay depends principally, and in some cases almost entirely, on student fees. Schools have no exclusive privileges. To obtain the honors of graduation, one need not produce a certificate of having studied for a certain number of years at a public school. If, upon examination, a candidate appears to understand what is taught there, no questions are asked about where he learned it.
elegant: English public schools are far less corrupted than universities. Schools teach what they claim to teach -- Greek and Latin -- because schoolmasters depend on fees and have no exclusive privileges. Universities fail to teach their own subjects because they lack these competitive pressures. School graduates are tested on knowledge, not on where they studied -- eliminating institutional protectionism.
summary: English schools outperform universities because schoolmasters depend on fees, schools hold no exclusive privileges, and graduation examines knowledge rather than institutional attendance. These competitive mechanisms force schools to actually teach their subjects.
distilled: English schools outperform universities because fee-dependence, absence of exclusive privileges, and knowledge-based examination force schools to actually deliver education.
notes: Systematic comparison isolating the institutional variables that determine educational quality. Schools succeed because of three market mechanisms: (1) fee-dependence motivates teaching, (2) no exclusive privileges allow competition, and (3) examination tests knowledge, not institutional attendance. Universities fail on all three counts. 'Public schools' in 18th-century English usage means endowed grammar schools (Eton, Westminster, etc.), not state-funded schools in the modern sense. The knowledge-based examination standard anticipates modern competency-based education movements.

refashioned:
It may perhaps be said that the subjects commonly taught in universities are not very well taught. But had it not been for those institutions, they would not have been commonly taught at all; and both individuals and the public would have suffered considerably from the absence of those important branches of education.

The present universities of Europe were originally, for the most part, ecclesiastical corporations established for the education of clergymen. They were founded by papal authority and were so entirely under the pope's immediate protection that their members, whether teachers or students, all enjoyed what was then called the benefit of clergy -- that is, they were exempt from the civil jurisdiction of the countries where their universities were located and answerable only to ecclesiastical courts. What was taught in most of these universities was suited to their original purpose: either theology, or subjects that served merely as preparation for theology.
elegant: Though universities teach badly, without them certain subjects would not be taught at all -- a genuine loss. Europe's universities originated as ecclesiastical corporations for training clergymen, founded by papal authority. Their members enjoyed clerical immunity from civil courts. Their curricula naturally served their ecclesiastical purpose: theology and its preparatory subjects.
summary: Despite their poor teaching, universities provide education that would otherwise not exist. Europe's universities originated as papal-authorized ecclesiastical corporations for training clergy, with curricula naturally centered on theology and its prerequisites.
distilled: Universities teach badly but provide education that would otherwise not exist -- a legacy of their ecclesiastical origins as papal-authorized institutions for training clergymen.
notes: Smith's one concession to universities: they are bad but necessary for subjects too specialized or impractical for private education markets. This honest qualification strengthens his overall critique. The historical account of universities as ecclesiastical corporations explains their institutional culture -- papal authority, clerical immunity, theological orientation. The 'benefit of clergy' exemption from civil jurisdiction created the institutional independence that later became self-governing academic freedom -- and, in Smith's view, academic irresponsibility.

refashioned: When Christianity was first established by law, a corrupted form of Latin had become the common language of all western Europe. Church services and the Bible translations read in churches were both in this corrupted Latin -- that is, in the everyday language of the people. After the invasions of the peoples who overthrew the Roman Empire, Latin gradually ceased to be spoken anywhere in Europe. But the reverence of the people naturally preserves the established forms and ceremonies of religion long after the circumstances that first introduced them have disappeared. Though Latin was no longer understood by ordinary people anywhere, church services continued to be performed entirely in that language. Two different languages were thus established in Europe, just as in ancient Egypt: a language of the priests and a language of the people; a sacred and a profane; a learned and an unlearned language. But it was necessary for the priests to understand something of their sacred and learned language in order to conduct services, and so the study of Latin became, from the very beginning, an essential part of university education.
elegant: When Christianity became law, corrupted Latin was Europe's common tongue, and church services were conducted in it. After the barbarian invasions, Latin ceased to be a living language, but religious conservatism preserved it in worship. Europe thus developed two languages -- priestly Latin and popular vernacular -- as Egypt had sacred and profane tongues. Since priests needed to understand their ritual language, Latin study became foundational to university education.
summary: Church services remained in Latin long after it ceased to be a living language, creating a split between priestly and popular language. Since priests needed Latin for their duties, its study became the foundation of university education.
distilled: Latin persisted in church services after it ceased to be spoken, creating the need for Latin instruction that became the foundation of university education.
notes: Traces the institutional root of classical language education to religious necessity, not intellectual value. The Egyptian parallel (priestly vs. popular language) places European experience in comparative context. The key insight: university curricula are shaped by institutional origins, not by what is most useful. Latin education persisted not because Latin was intrinsically valuable but because the Church needed Latin-literate priests. This historical path-dependence explains curriculum inertia that Smith criticizes throughout the education section.

refashioned: This was not the case with Greek or Hebrew. The infallible decrees of the Church had declared the Latin Vulgate Bible to be equally divinely inspired, and therefore of equal authority with the Greek and Hebrew originals. Knowledge of those two languages was therefore not indispensable for a clergyman, and their study did not for a long time form a necessary part of the standard university curriculum. I am assured that there are some Spanish universities where Greek has never been part of the course of study at all. The first Protestant reformers found the Greek New Testament, and even the Hebrew Old Testament, more favorable to their views than the Vulgate translation, which had naturally been gradually adapted to support Catholic doctrine. They set about exposing the Vulgate's many errors, and Catholic clergy were forced to defend or explain them. This could not be done without some knowledge of the original languages, so their study was gradually introduced into most universities -- both those that accepted and those that rejected the Reformation. Greek was connected to the classical learning that, though first cultivated mainly by Catholic Italians, came into fashion around the same time as the Reformation. In most universities, therefore, Greek was taught before philosophy, as soon as a student had made some progress in Latin. Hebrew, having no connection to classical learning and being the language of no esteemed book except the Holy Scriptures, was usually not studied until after philosophy, when the student entered theological studies.
elegant: Greek and Hebrew were not originally taught at universities because the Church declared the Latin Vulgate equally authoritative with the originals. Protestant reformers changed this by finding the Greek and Hebrew texts more favorable to their doctrines, forcing Catholics to study the originals to defend the Vulgate. Greek, connected to fashionable classical learning, entered the curriculum before philosophy; Hebrew, useful only for Scripture, was deferred to theological studies. Some Spanish universities never taught Greek at all.
summary: Greek and Hebrew entered university curricula only because the Reformation forced both sides to engage with original biblical texts. Greek, linked to classical learning, was taught early; Hebrew, with no secular literary tradition, was deferred to theology. Some universities never added Greek at all.
distilled: Greek and Hebrew entered university curricula not for their intrinsic value but because the Reformation forced engagement with original biblical texts to settle doctrinal disputes.
notes: Illustrates how theological controversy, not intellectual need, drove curriculum development. The Vulgate's 'infallible' status is presented with characteristic Smithian irony. The differential treatment of Greek (tied to classical culture, taught early) vs. Hebrew (purely theological, taught late) shows how non-academic cultural prestige shapes curricula. Spanish universities' omission of Greek entirely demonstrates extreme institutional inertia. The passage reinforces Smith's theme that university education serves institutional rather than public purposes.

refashioned: Originally, the first rudiments of both Greek and Latin were taught at universities, and in some universities they still are. In others, the student is expected to have previously acquired at least the rudiments of one or both languages, the study of which continues to form a very considerable part of university education everywhere.
elegant: Universities originally taught basic Greek and Latin from scratch. Some still do; others now expect students to arrive with rudimentary knowledge. Either way, classical languages remain a major component of university education.
summary: Classical language instruction, originally starting from the basics at university, now often assumes prior preparation, but remains a substantial part of university education throughout Europe.
distilled: Classical languages remain a major part of university education, whether taught from scratch or building on prior preparation.
notes: Brief transitional passage noting the shift in where basic classical language instruction occurs -- from university to preparatory schools. The persistence of classical languages as a 'very considerable part' of university education, despite their diminishing practical utility, illustrates curriculum inertia driven by institutional tradition rather than educational need.

refashioned:
Ancient Greek philosophy was divided into three great branches: physics, or natural philosophy; ethics, or moral philosophy; and logic. This division seems perfectly suited to the nature of things.

The great phenomena of nature -- the movements of the heavenly bodies, eclipses, comets, thunder and lightning, and other extraordinary events; the generation, life, growth, and decay of plants and animals -- are objects that necessarily excite wonder and naturally call forth our curiosity about their causes. Superstition first tried to satisfy this curiosity by attributing all these wonders to the direct action of the gods. Philosophy later attempted to explain them through more familiar causes -- causes that humanity understood better than the agency of gods. Since these great phenomena are the first objects of human curiosity, the science that attempts to explain them was naturally the first branch of philosophy to be cultivated. The earliest philosophers on record were accordingly natural philosophers.
elegant: Greek philosophy divided naturally into three branches: physics (natural philosophy), ethics (moral philosophy), and logic. Natural philosophy came first because nature's great phenomena -- celestial movements, eclipses, weather, biological life and death -- naturally excite curiosity. Superstition first explained these through divine agency; philosophy replaced this with natural causes. The earliest known philosophers were natural philosophers.
summary: Ancient Greek philosophy naturally divided into physics, ethics, and logic. Natural philosophy came first because humanity's earliest curiosity was about nature's great phenomena, which superstition first attributed to divine agency before philosophy sought natural explanations.
distilled: Greek philosophy's three natural branches -- physics, ethics, and logic -- emerged in order of human curiosity, with natural philosophy first replacing superstitious explanations of natural phenomena.
notes: Begins Smith's history of philosophy as curriculum -- tracing how the ancient division was distorted by medieval universities. The progression from superstition to philosophy parallels Enlightenment narratives of intellectual progress. The threefold division (physics, ethics, logic) comes from Aristotle and the Stoics. Smith's claim that this division is 'perfectly agreeable to the nature of things' endorses the ancient framework against the medieval distortion he will describe. Cross-reference to Smith's earlier work, 'History of Astronomy,' which traces the same superstition-to-philosophy arc.

refashioned: In every age and country, people have observed the characters, intentions, and actions of those around them, and many respected rules and maxims for conducting human life have been established and approved by common consent. As soon as writing was invented, those who considered themselves wise naturally tried to add to these established maxims and to express their own views on proper and improper conduct -- sometimes in the artificial form of fables, like those attributed to Aesop; sometimes in the simpler form of proverbs and wise sayings, like the Proverbs of Solomon, the verses of Theognis and Phocylides, and parts of Hesiod's works. They might have continued in this way for a long time, merely multiplying moral maxims without attempting to arrange them in any systematic order, much less to connect them through general principles from which they could all be derived, as effects from their natural causes. The beauty of systematic arrangement -- different observations connected by a few common principles -- was first perceived in the crude early attempts at natural philosophy. Something similar was afterwards attempted in morals. The maxims of common life were arranged in methodical order and connected by a few common principles, just as philosophers had tried to arrange and connect the phenomena of nature. The science that investigates and explains these connecting principles is what is properly called moral philosophy.
elegant: Every society develops moral maxims through observation of human conduct, expressed in fables, proverbs, and wise sayings. These accumulated for ages without systematic organization until natural philosophy demonstrated the beauty of connecting diverse observations through common principles. Moral philosophy then applied the same method: arranging life's maxims in systematic order and deriving them from general principles, as natural philosophers had done with physical phenomena.
summary: Moral philosophy arose when the systematic method of natural philosophy -- connecting diverse observations through common principles -- was applied to humanity's accumulated moral maxims and rules of conduct.
distilled: Moral philosophy was born when the systematic method of natural philosophy was applied to organizing humanity's accumulated practical wisdom about human conduct.
notes: Traces moral philosophy's origin to methodological imitation of natural philosophy -- systematization, not new moral content, was the innovation. The examples span cultures: Aesop (Greek fables), Solomon (Hebrew wisdom), Theognis and Phocylides (Greek gnomic poetry), Hesiod (Greek didactic poetry). The progression from scattered maxims to systematic theory mirrors the development of any science. Smith's own moral philosophy (Theory of Moral Sentiments) follows this pattern -- deriving moral rules from the principle of sympathy.

refashioned: Different authors proposed different systems of both natural and moral philosophy. But the arguments supporting these systems, far from being demonstrations, were frequently at best weak probabilities and sometimes mere sophisms with no foundation other than the imprecision and ambiguity of common language. Speculative systems have, in every era, been adopted for reasons too flimsy to have influenced any sensible person's judgment in a matter of the smallest financial interest. Gross sophistry has rarely had any influence on human opinion except in philosophy and speculation, where it has frequently had the greatest influence. The proponents of each system of natural and moral philosophy naturally tried to expose the weaknesses of rival systems. In examining rival arguments, they were inevitably led to consider the difference between probable and demonstrative arguments, between fallacious and conclusive ones. Logic -- the science of the general principles of good and bad reasoning -- naturally arose from the scrutiny this competition required. Though logic originated after both physics and ethics, it was commonly taught before either of them in most ancient schools of philosophy. The thinking was that students should first understand the difference between good and bad reasoning before being led to reason about subjects of such great importance.
elegant: Competing philosophical systems were defended with arguments that were often mere sophisms rooted in linguistic ambiguity -- reasoning too weak to influence anyone's judgment about money, yet powerful enough to dominate speculative thought. The mutual critique of rival systems naturally generated logic -- the science of distinguishing good reasoning from bad. Though logic arose after physics and ethics, it was taught first, on the principle that students should learn to reason well before tackling important subjects.
summary: Competing philosophical systems forced scrutiny of each other's arguments, giving rise to logic -- the science of reasoning. Though it originated after physics and ethics, logic was taught first so students could distinguish good from bad reasoning before engaging with substantive questions.
distilled: Logic arose from the competitive critique of rival philosophical systems and was taught first so students could evaluate reasoning before engaging with physics or ethics.
notes: Contains the sharp observation that speculative sophistry influences philosophical opinion where it would never influence practical judgment -- people are more rigorous about money than about truth. This asymmetry between practical and speculative reasoning is a profound epistemological insight. The origin of logic in inter-school competition shows how intellectual rivalry drives methodological progress. The pedagogical placement of logic first (learn to think before thinking about important things) is the Aristotelian tradition. Smith's account of philosophy as competitive system-building anticipates Kuhn's structure of scientific revolutions.

refashioned:
This ancient three-part division of philosophy was, in most European universities, replaced by a five-part division.

In ancient philosophy, whatever was taught about the nature of the human mind or of the divine was part of physics. These beings, whatever their essence, were parts of the great system of the universe and among its most important causal agents. Whatever human reason could conclude or conjecture about them constituted two chapters -- important ones, no doubt -- of the science that sought to explain the origins and workings of the universal system. But in European universities, where philosophy was taught only as preparation for theology, it was natural to dwell on these two chapters more than on any other part of the science. They were gradually expanded and subdivided until the doctrine of spirits -- about which so little can be known -- came to occupy as much space in the philosophical system as the doctrine of bodies -- about which so much can be known. The doctrines of these two subjects were treated as separate sciences. What was called metaphysics, or pneumatics, was set in opposition to physics and was cultivated not only as the more sublime but, for professional theological purposes, as the more useful science. The proper subject of experiment and observation -- a subject in which careful attention can make so many useful discoveries -- was almost entirely neglected. The subject in which, beyond a very few simple and nearly obvious truths, the most careful attention can discover nothing but obscurity and uncertainty, producing only subtleties and sophisms, was greatly cultivated.
elegant: European universities replaced ancient philosophy's three branches with five, inflating the study of mind and God from two chapters of physics into a separate science -- metaphysics or pneumatics -- set against and valued above physics. The doctrine of spirits, about which almost nothing can be known, came to occupy as much curriculum as the doctrine of bodies, about which much can be discovered. The result: experiment and observation were neglected in favor of a subject that produces nothing beyond its few obvious truths except subtleties and sophisms.
summary: Medieval universities expanded the study of mind and God from two chapters of ancient physics into an independent science -- metaphysics -- valued above natural philosophy. This inflated the unknowable at the expense of the observable, substituting subtlety and sophism for experiment and discovery.
distilled: Medieval universities inflated metaphysics -- the study of the largely unknowable -- to dominate over physics, the study of the discoverable, distorting ancient philosophy to serve theological purposes.
notes: Central passage in Smith's critique of scholastic philosophy. The contrast between 'so little can be known' (spirits/metaphysics) and 'so much can be known' (bodies/physics) is a foundational Enlightenment argument for empiricism over speculation. 'Pneumatics' (from Greek pneuma, spirit/breath) was the scholastic term for the study of immaterial beings. Smith's argument that theology distorted philosophy's natural structure by inflating metaphysics at the expense of physics anticipates the modern separation of science from theology. The five-part division: logic, ontology, pneumatology, ethics, physics.

refashioned: When these two sciences -- physics and metaphysics -- had been set in opposition to one another, the comparison between them naturally gave birth to a third: ontology, or the science that treated of the qualities and attributes common to the subjects of both. But if subtleties and sophisms made up the greater part of scholastic metaphysics, they comprised the entirety of this cobweb science of ontology, which was also sometimes called metaphysics.
elegant: The artificial opposition between physics and metaphysics spawned a third science -- ontology -- treating qualities common to both material and immaterial subjects. If metaphysics was mostly subtlety and sophism, ontology was nothing but: a cobweb science spun entirely from abstract speculation.
summary: The artificial separation of physics and metaphysics generated ontology -- a science of qualities common to both -- which consisted entirely of the subtleties and sophisms that only partly characterized metaphysics.
distilled: Ontology, born from the artificial opposition between physics and metaphysics, was pure scholastic cobweb -- subtlety and sophism with no empirical content whatsoever.
notes: The phrase 'cobweb science' is memorably dismissive -- ontology is too insubstantial even for the partial criticism Smith levels at metaphysics. The genealogy is important: an unnecessary division (physics vs. metaphysics) generates an even more unnecessary synthesis (ontology). Each step away from the original three-part ancient division produces more vacuous abstraction. Smith's contempt for ontology reflects the broader Enlightenment rejection of scholastic metaphysics. The confusion of names ('also sometimes called metaphysics') adds to his case that the field lacks even clear self-definition.

refashioned: What constitutes human happiness and perfection -- considered not only as an individual, but as a member of a family, a state, and the great society of mankind -- was the question that ancient moral philosophy set out to investigate. In that philosophy, the duties of human life were treated as means to happiness and perfection in this life. But when moral philosophy, like natural philosophy, came to be taught only as preparation for theology, the duties of human life were treated as primarily means to happiness in the life to come. In ancient philosophy, the perfection of virtue was represented as necessarily producing the most perfect happiness in this life for the person who possessed it. In modern philosophy, virtue was frequently represented as generally, or even almost always, inconsistent with any degree of happiness in this life. Heaven was to be earned only through penance and mortification, through the austerities and self-abasement of a monk, not through the liberal, generous, and spirited conduct of a citizen. Casuistry and ascetic morality made up, in most cases, the greater part of the moral philosophy taught in the schools. The most important branch of philosophy was thereby the most corrupted of all.
elegant: Ancient moral philosophy asked what makes a person happy and complete -- as individual, family member, citizen, and member of humanity -- treating life's duties as paths to earthly fulfillment. Theology transformed this: duties became means to afterlife happiness, virtue was portrayed as incompatible with worldly happiness, and heaven was earned through monastic self-denial rather than generous, spirited conduct. Moral philosophy -- the most important branch -- became the most corrupted, reduced to casuistry and ascetic mortification.
summary: Ancient moral philosophy pursued happiness through virtue in this life, treating duties as means to earthly fulfillment. Medieval theology inverted this, treating virtue as incompatible with earthly happiness and replacing generous civic conduct with monastic self-denial. Moral philosophy -- the most important philosophical branch -- suffered the worst corruption.
distilled: Medieval theology corrupted moral philosophy from a guide to earthly happiness through virtuous civic conduct into a system of ascetic self-denial aimed at afterlife rewards.
notes: Smith's strongest statement on how theology corrupted moral philosophy. The ancient view (virtue produces happiness) vs. the medieval view (virtue requires earthly suffering) is a fundamental Enlightenment contrast. Smith clearly sides with the ancients. The shift from 'liberal, generous, and spirited conduct' to 'austerities and abasement of a monk' maps directly onto Smith's own moral philosophy in Theory of Moral Sentiments, which celebrates social virtues over ascetic ones. Casuistry -- the application of moral rules to particular cases -- is dismissed as a degenerate form of ethics. The final sentence -- 'by far the most important became by far the most corrupted' -- is devastating.

refashioned: Such, therefore, was the standard course of philosophical education in most European universities. Logic was taught first; ontology came second; third came pneumatology, encompassing the doctrines of the human soul and of God; fourth followed a debased system of moral philosophy, considered as directly connected to pneumatology, the immortality of the soul, and the rewards and punishments to be expected from divine justice in the afterlife; and a short, superficial system of physics usually concluded the course.
elegant: The standard university curriculum ran: logic first, then ontology, then pneumatology (doctrine of soul and God), then debased moral philosophy tied to afterlife rewards and punishments, and finally a brief, superficial treatment of physics.
summary: The standard European university curriculum prioritized logic, ontology, and pneumatology, followed by a theology-subordinated moral philosophy, with natural philosophy reduced to a brief afterthought at the end.
distilled: European universities taught philosophy in reverse order of usefulness: abstract speculation first, debased morality in the middle, and actual natural science last and most superficially.
notes: Summary of the five-part scholastic curriculum replacing the ancient three-part division. The ordering reveals institutional priorities: theology-serving subjects first and longest, empirical science last and shortest. The adjectives tell the story: ontology (cobweb), pneumatology (unknowable), moral philosophy (debased), physics (short and superficial). Only logic escapes criticism. This curriculum persisted for centuries, demonstrating the power of institutional inertia in education. Smith's critique influenced university reform movements of the late 18th and 19th centuries.

refashioned: The changes that European universities introduced into the ancient course of philosophy were all designed for educating clergymen and making philosophy a more suitable introduction to the study of theology. But the additional subtlety and sophistry, the casuistry and ascetic morality that these changes brought in, certainly did not make the curriculum more suitable for educating gentlemen or men of the world, or more likely to improve the understanding or to cultivate the heart.
elegant: The universities' changes to ancient philosophy served ecclesiastical training, not general education. The added subtlety, sophistry, casuistry, and asceticism made the curriculum less -- not more -- suited to educating worldly, thoughtful, humane people.
summary: University curriculum reforms served only to prepare clergymen for theology. The added sophistry, casuistry, and ascetic morality made education less suitable for producing well-rounded, thoughtful citizens.
distilled: University curriculum changes served clerical training at the direct expense of general education, producing neither better understanding nor better character in secular students.
notes: Closing summary of the education critique. The distinction between education for clergymen and education for 'gentlemen or men of the world' reflects Smith's Enlightenment vision of education as preparing citizens for useful, engaged lives. The final phrase -- 'improve the understanding or mend the heart' -- captures the dual purpose of education: intellectual and moral development. Both were undermined by the theological capture of the curriculum. This passage sets up the transition to Smith's positive proposals for educational reform. Cross-reference to Theory of Moral Sentiments on the virtues of worldly engagement vs. monastic withdrawal.

refashioned: This corrupted course of philosophy is still what most European universities teach, with varying degrees of diligence depending on how much each university's structure makes diligence necessary for its teachers. At some of the wealthiest and best-endowed universities, tutors content themselves with teaching a few disconnected scraps of this corrupted curriculum -- and even those they typically teach negligently and superficially.
elegant: Most European universities still teach this corrupted philosophical curriculum, with diligence varying by institutional incentives. At the richest universities, tutors teach only disconnected fragments of it, and even those they teach negligently.
summary: European universities continue teaching a corrupted philosophical curriculum, with the wealthiest institutions being the most negligent in their instruction.
distilled: The wealthiest universities teach the least and worst of an already corrupted curriculum because their endowments make diligence unnecessary.
notes: Institutional incentives and teaching quality -- endowment wealth inversely correlates with instructional effort. Continues Smith's argument that guaranteed income destroys motivation. Cross-reference with 5.1.170-182 on corrupted philosophy curriculum. The 'corrupted course' refers to the medieval scholastic tradition derived from Aristotle.

refashioned: The improvements that have been made in modern times across several branches of philosophy were not, for the most part, made in universities -- though some undoubtedly were. Most universities have not even been quick to adopt these improvements after they were made elsewhere. Several of these learned societies have chosen to remain, for a long time, sanctuaries where discredited systems and obsolete prejudices found shelter and protection after they had been driven out of every other corner of the world. In general, the richest and best-endowed universities have been the slowest to adopt improvements and the most resistant to permitting any considerable change in their established educational plan. Improvements were more easily introduced at some of the poorer universities, where teachers -- depending on their reputation for the greater part of their income -- were obliged to pay more attention to the current state of knowledge in the world.
elegant: Most philosophical advances were made outside universities. Many universities became sanctuaries for discredited ideas long after the rest of the world had abandoned them. The richest institutions were slowest to change, while poorer universities -- where teachers depended on their reputation for income -- adopted improvements more readily.
summary: Most intellectual progress happened outside universities, which often became refuges for outdated ideas. Wealthy universities resisted change the most, while poorer ones whose teachers depended on reputation for income adapted more quickly.
distilled: Intellectual progress mostly occurred outside universities, with the wealthiest institutions being the most resistant to change because their teachers had no financial incentive to stay current.
notes: Key insight: institutional wealth creates intellectual conservatism. Market discipline (reputation-dependent income) drives innovation and adaptation. Poorer universities innovate faster -- an early argument for competitive pressure in education. Cross-reference with 5.1.148-155 on teacher incentives. Anticipates modern critiques of tenure and institutional inertia.

refashioned: Although the public schools and universities of Europe were originally intended only for educating churchmen, and though they were not always diligent in instructing their students even in the sciences thought necessary for that profession, they gradually drew to themselves the education of nearly all other people -- particularly gentlemen and men of fortune. It seemed that no better method could be found for spending, with any advantage, the long interval between infancy and the period when people begin applying themselves seriously to the real business of the world -- the business that will employ them for the rest of their days. The greater part of what is taught in schools and universities, however, does not seem to be the most appropriate preparation for that business.
elegant: Universities, originally designed solely to train clergy, gradually captured the education of nearly all gentlemen and men of fortune -- simply because no better way was found to occupy the years between childhood and adulthood. Yet most of what universities teach is poor preparation for the real business of life.
summary: Universities originally existed to train clergy but gradually monopolized the education of all upper-class men, mainly because no alternative existed for filling the years before adulthood. Most of what they teach, however, poorly prepares students for real life.
distilled: Universities, designed for clergy training, monopolized elite education by default rather than by merit, while teaching content largely irrelevant to practical life.
notes: Mission creep in educational institutions -- clergy schools becoming general education by lack of alternatives. The disconnect between curriculum and practical life is a recurring Smith theme. 'The real business of the world' -- Smith values practical application over abstract learning. Cross-reference with 5.1.186 on the rise of the Grand Tour as an alternative.

refashioned: In England, it is becoming increasingly common to send young people to travel abroad immediately after leaving school, without sending them to any university. Our young people, it is said, generally return much improved by their travels. A young man who goes abroad at seventeen or eighteen and returns at twenty-one comes back three or four years older -- and at that age it would be difficult not to improve considerably in three or four years. During his travels, he usually picks up some knowledge of one or two foreign languages, though seldom enough to speak or write them properly. In other respects, he commonly returns home more conceited, more unprincipled, more dissipated, and less capable of serious application to study or business than he could have become in so short a time had he stayed at home. By traveling so young -- spending the most precious years of his life in frivolous dissipation, far from the oversight and control of parents and family -- every useful habit that his earlier education might have begun to form is almost inevitably weakened or erased rather than strengthened and confirmed. Nothing but the discredit into which universities have allowed themselves to fall could ever have made so absurd a practice as early foreign travel seem respectable. By sending his son abroad, a father at least temporarily frees himself from the disagreeable sight of a son who is unemployed, neglected, and going to ruin before his eyes.
elegant: The English practice of sending young men abroad immediately after school, bypassing university, produces mostly negative results. Whatever improvement occurs is merely the natural effect of aging. The young traveler typically acquires superficial language skills while becoming more conceited, dissipated, and incapable of serious work. Early travel weakens rather than strengthens the habits education began to form. Only the discredit of universities could have made so absurd a practice fashionable -- it mainly serves to spare fathers the sight of idle sons deteriorating at home.
summary: The growing English practice of sending young men abroad instead of to university produces mostly negative results -- superficial language skills paired with increased conceit and dissipation. The practice became fashionable only because universities fell into such disrepute, and it mainly serves to remove idle sons from their fathers' sight.
distilled: The Grand Tour became popular only because universities became so worthless, yet it typically makes young men more dissolute while teaching them little of value.
notes: Smith's critique of the Grand Tour -- a sharp commentary on 18th-century elite education. The argument that any improvement is merely natural maturation, not educational benefit, is characteristically empirical. 'The most precious years of his life' -- the opportunity cost argument. The father's motivation reveals how bad incentives propagate: universities fail, so parents choose an even worse alternative. Cross-reference with 5.1.183-184 on university decline.

refashioned:
Such have been the effects of some modern educational institutions.

Very different plans and institutions for education have existed in other ages and nations.
elegant: Such are the results of modern education. Other ages and nations took very different approaches.
summary: Modern educational institutions have produced poor results. Smith now turns to examine the very different educational systems of earlier civilizations.
distilled: Having critiqued modern education, Smith transitions to examining ancient educational models for comparison.
notes: Transitional passage -- pivots from the critique of 18th-century European education (universities, Grand Tour) to a comparative study of ancient Greek and Roman education. Sets up the contrast between market-driven ancient education and endowment-driven modern education.

refashioned: In the republics of ancient Greece, every free citizen was instructed under the direction of public magistrates in both gymnastic exercises and music. The gymnastic exercises were intended to harden the body, sharpen courage, and prepare citizens for the hardships and dangers of war. Since the Greek militia was, by all accounts, one of the best that ever existed, this part of their public education must have fully achieved its intended purpose. Through music -- the other part of education -- philosophers and historians who have described these institutions tell us it was meant to humanize the mind, soften the temperament, and prepare citizens for performing all the social and moral duties of public and private life.
elegant: In ancient Greek republics, every free citizen received public instruction in gymnastics and music. Gymnastics hardened the body and prepared citizens for war -- and given the excellence of the Greek militia, it clearly succeeded. Music was intended to humanize the mind and cultivate the social and moral virtues needed for public and private life.
summary: Ancient Greek public education consisted of gymnastics for military preparation and music for moral cultivation. The gymnastic component demonstrably succeeded, as evidenced by the excellence of the Greek militia.
distilled: Greek public education combined gymnastics for military readiness with music for moral development, and the military component clearly achieved its purpose.
notes: Begins comparative analysis of ancient education systems. State-directed education for citizenship and military service -- contrasts with the clergy-origin of European universities. The two-part curriculum (body and mind) reflects Greek holistic philosophy. Smith will question whether the music component actually worked (see 5.1.190). The success of gymnastic education is empirically verified by military outcomes.

refashioned: In ancient Rome, the exercises of the Campus Martius served the same purpose as the gymnasium in ancient Greece, and they seem to have served it equally well. But among the Romans, there was nothing corresponding to the Greeks' musical education. Roman morals, however, in both private and public life, seem to have been not merely equal but, on the whole, considerably superior to those of the Greeks. That Roman private morals were superior is explicitly attested by Polybius and Dionysius of Halicarnassus, two authors well acquainted with both nations. The entire course of Greek and Roman history bears witness to the superiority of Roman public morals as well.
elegant: Rome's Campus Martius served the same military purpose as the Greek gymnasium, equally well. But Romans had no equivalent to Greek musical education -- yet their morals, both public and private, were generally superior to the Greeks', as Polybius and Dionysius of Halicarnassus both attest, and as the full sweep of their respective histories confirms.
summary: Roman military exercises matched Greek gymnastics in effectiveness, but Rome had no equivalent to Greek musical education. Despite this, Roman morals in both public and private life were generally superior to Greek morals, as ancient historians confirm.
distilled: Romans achieved superior morals to the Greeks despite lacking their musical education, suggesting that music instruction was not the cause of moral development.
notes: Empirical challenge to the Greek theory of moral education through music. Smith uses a natural experiment: Rome achieved better moral outcomes without the supposedly essential musical component. Cites Polybius and Dionysius of Halicarnassus as authorities. The Campus Martius -- Rome's public exercise ground -- parallels the Greek gymnasium. Cross-reference with 5.1.190 for the explicit conclusion.

refashioned: The good temper and moderation of contending factions seem to be the most essential measures of a free people's public morals. But Greek factions were almost always violent and bloody, whereas until the time of the Gracchi, no blood had ever been shed in any Roman factional dispute -- and from the time of the Gracchi onward, the Roman republic may be considered as effectively dissolved. Despite the very respectable authority of Plato, Aristotle, and Polybius, and despite the very ingenious arguments by which Montesquieu attempts to support that authority, it seems probable that the Greeks' musical education had little real effect on improving their morals. Without any such education, Roman morals were, on the whole, superior.
elegant: The truest test of a free people's public morals is how moderately their political factions behave. Greek factions were almost always violent and bloody; Roman factions shed no blood until the Gracchi, after which the republic was effectively finished. Despite the authority of Plato, Aristotle, Polybius, and Montesquieu, Greek musical education probably contributed little to morals -- Rome achieved superior results without it.
summary: Smith argues that political moderation is the best measure of public morals. Since Greek factions were consistently violent while Roman factions remained bloodless until the late republic, and Rome had no musical education, the Greek theory that music improves morals appears unfounded.
distilled: The violent factional politics of Greece versus the long civic peace of Rome proves that musical education did little for morals, despite the claims of ancient and modern philosophers.
notes: Smith's empirical method applied to political philosophy -- measuring moral claims against observable political outcomes. Directly challenges Plato, Aristotle, Polybius, and Montesquieu. The Gracchi (133-121 BC) mark the beginning of Roman political violence. Smith's measure of public morality -- factional moderation -- is characteristically practical. Cross-reference with 5.1.189 on the Rome-Greece comparison.

refashioned: The respect these ancient sages had for the institutions of their ancestors probably led them to find great political wisdom in what was perhaps merely an ancient custom, continued without interruption from the earliest period of their societies to more refined times. Music and dancing are the great amusements of nearly all primitive nations, and the great accomplishments supposedly qualifying any man to entertain his society. This is still so among the peoples of the coast of Africa. It was so among the ancient Celts, among the ancient Scandinavians, and -- as we may learn from Homer -- among the ancient Greeks in the period before the Trojan War.
elegant: Ancient philosophers probably attributed deep political wisdom to what was merely an inherited custom from primitive times. Music and dancing are the chief entertainments of nearly all primitive peoples -- true in Africa, among the ancient Celts, Scandinavians, and Homer's pre-Trojan War Greeks. The sages elevated a primitive amusement into a theory of moral education.
