refashioned: In the condition of things that prevailed throughout most of Europe during the tenth, eleventh, twelfth, and thirteenth centuries, and for some time both before and after that period, the constitution of the Church of Rome may be considered as the most formidable combination that ever was formed against the authority and security of civil government, as well as against the liberty, reason, and happiness of mankind, which can flourish only where civil government is able to protect them. In that constitution, the grossest delusions of superstition were supported by the private interests of so great a number of people as to be safe from any assault of human reason. For though human reason might perhaps have been able to unveil some of the delusions of superstition even to the eyes of the common people, it could never have dissolved the ties of private interest. Had this constitution been attacked by no other enemies than the feeble efforts of human reason, it must have endured forever. But that immense and well-built fabric, which all the wisdom and virtue of man could never have shaken, much less overturned, was by the natural course of things first weakened and afterwards in part destroyed -- and is now likely, in the course of a few more centuries perhaps, to crumble into ruins altogether.
elegant: The medieval Church of Rome was the most formidable combination ever formed against civil government, liberty, reason, and human happiness. Its superstitions were sustained not by their plausibility but by the private interests of vast numbers of people -- an edifice that reason alone could never have dismantled, because reason cannot dissolve the ties of self-interest. Yet what human wisdom and virtue could never have shaken, the natural course of things -- commerce and manufactures -- first weakened and is now gradually destroying.
summary: The medieval Catholic Church was history's most powerful institutional threat to civil government, liberty, and reason. Its superstitions were impervious to rational criticism because they were sustained by the self-interest of vast numbers of people. Only the natural course of economic development -- not reason or reform -- weakened this edifice, which is still gradually crumbling.
distilled: The medieval church was invulnerable to reason because its superstitions were sustained by the self-interest of millions, and only the impersonal force of economic development could undermine what no rational argument ever could.
notes: One of Smith's most powerful passages -- the church as 'the most formidable combination that ever was formed against the authority and security of civil government.' The key insight: reason cannot defeat institutions sustained by self-interest. This is Smith's general theory of institutional change: ideas alone cannot overcome entrenched interests; only changes in the underlying economic structure can. 'The natural course of things' -- commerce and manufactures -- is the real solvent of feudal and clerical power (elaborated in 5.1.256-258). This parallels Book III's analysis of how commerce dissolved feudal power. 'Liberty, reason, and happiness of mankind, which can flourish only where civil government is able to protect them' -- a foundational Enlightenment principle.

refashioned: The gradual improvements of arts, manufactures, and commerce -- the same causes that destroyed the power of the great barons -- destroyed in the same manner, throughout most of Europe, the entire temporal power of the clergy. In the products of arts, manufactures, and commerce, the clergy, like the great barons, found things for which they could exchange their crude produce, and thereby discovered the means of spending their whole revenues on themselves, without giving any considerable share to other people. Their charity became gradually less extensive, their hospitality less generous or less lavish. Their retainers became consequently less numerous and, by degrees, dwindled away altogether.
elegant: Commerce destroyed clerical temporal power exactly as it destroyed baronial power. Once manufactures offered goods to buy, the clergy -- like the barons -- spent their revenues on personal consumption rather than on hospitality and charity. Their generosity contracted, their retainers disappeared, and their temporal power dissolved.
summary: The rise of commerce and manufactures destroyed clerical temporal power through the same mechanism that dissolved baronial power: clergy redirected their surplus from hospitality and charity toward personal consumption of manufactured goods, causing their retainer base to evaporate.
distilled: Commerce destroyed the church's temporal power the same way it destroyed feudal power -- by giving clergy goods to buy with revenues they had previously been forced to distribute through hospitality and charity.
notes: Exact parallel with Book III, Chapter 4 on the dissolution of feudal power through commerce. The mechanism: commerce creates consumer options that redirect surplus from dependent relationships (hospitality, charity, retainers) to personal consumption. The clergy are not morally worse -- they simply respond to new incentive structures. The temporal power dissolves because it was built on forced generosity, and commerce provides alternatives to forced generosity. Cross-reference with Book III, Ch. 4 on the 'silent revolution' and 5.1.249-253 on the hospitality-based power system.

refashioned: The clergy, too, like the great barons, wished to get a better rent from their landed estates so they could spend it in the same way -- on gratifying their own private vanity and folly. But this increase of rent could only be obtained by granting leases to their tenants, who thereby became largely independent of them. The ties of interest that had bound the lower ranks to the clergy were in this manner gradually broken and dissolved. They were broken and dissolved even sooner than those binding the same ranks to the great barons, because the benefices of the church, being for the most part much smaller than the estates of the great barons, the possessor of each benefice was much sooner able to spend its entire revenue on his own person. During the greater part of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, the power of the great barons was, throughout most of Europe, in full vigor.
elegant: Seeking higher rents to fund personal consumption, the clergy -- like the barons -- granted leases that made their tenants independent. The bonds of dependence dissolved even faster for the clergy than for the barons, because smaller benefices meant each clergyman could sooner consume his entire revenue personally. While baronial power remained strong through the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, clerical temporal power had already significantly decayed.
summary: The clergy's pursuit of higher personal income led them to grant tenant leases, dissolving the bonds of dependence even faster than for secular barons. Since church benefices were smaller than baronial estates, clergy could sooner spend their entire revenue on themselves, accelerating the loss of their retainer-based temporal power.
distilled: Clerical temporal power dissolved faster than baronial power because smaller benefices allowed clergy to redirect their entire revenue to personal consumption sooner, destroying the dependence relationships that sustained their political influence.
notes: The size-of-estate accelerator: smaller estates dissolve feudal bonds faster because the surplus that once funded retainers is more quickly absorbed by personal consumption. A nice application of Smith's general theory to explain the chronological difference between clerical and baronial decline. The lease mechanism: converting tenants-at-will to leaseholders trades direct control for higher rent -- the same market-driven transition described for secular estates in Book III. Cross-reference with 5.1.256 on the general mechanism and Book III, Ch. 4 on the baronial parallel.

refashioned: But the temporal power of the clergy -- the absolute command they had once held over the great body of the people -- was very much decayed. The power of the church was, by that time, very nearly reduced throughout most of Europe to what arose from their spiritual authority alone. And even that spiritual authority was much weakened when it ceased to be supported by the charity and hospitality of the clergy. The lower ranks no longer looked upon that order as they had before -- as the comforters of their distress and the relievers of their poverty. On the contrary, they were provoked and disgusted by the vanity, luxury, and expense of the richer clergy, who appeared to spend on their own pleasures what had always before been regarded as the patrimony of the poor.
elegant: By the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, clerical temporal power had largely dissolved, leaving only spiritual authority -- which was itself weakened once charity and hospitality ceased. The poor no longer saw the clergy as their benefactors. Instead, they were disgusted by clerical vanity and luxury, seeing it as the theft of what had been the patrimony of the poor.
summary: Once clerical hospitality and charity ended, both temporal and spiritual power decayed. The common people, who had venerated the clergy as their benefactors, now despised them for spending on personal luxury what had been considered the patrimony of the poor.
distilled: The end of clerical charity destroyed not only temporal power but spiritual authority as well, as the common people's veneration turned to disgust at clergy who spent the poor's patrimony on personal luxury.
notes: The complete cycle: charity built veneration, which built power; the end of charity destroyed veneration, which destroyed power. The common people's perception shift -- from benefactors to parasites -- is devastating. 'The patrimony of the poor' -- the people still considered church wealth as belonging to the poor, so personal consumption by clergy was perceived as theft. This moral outrage will fuel the Reformation (5.1.262). The spiritual authority that survives is 'much weakened' -- a residual, not a replacement for temporal power. Cross-reference with 5.1.253 on how charity built power and 5.1.262 on the Reformation exploiting this sentiment.

refashioned: In this situation, the sovereigns of different European states endeavored to recover the influence they had once had in disposing of the great church benefices. They sought to restore to the deans and chapters of each diocese their ancient right of electing the bishop, and to the monks of each abbey their right of electing the abbot. The re-establishment of this ancient order was the aim of several statutes enacted in England during the fourteenth century, particularly the Statute of Provisors, and of the Pragmatic Sanction established in France in the fifteenth century. To make these elections valid, the sovereign needed both to consent to them beforehand and to approve the person elected. Though the election was still supposed to be free, the sovereign had all the indirect means that his position necessarily afforded him for influencing the clergy in his own dominions. Other regulations of a similar tendency were established in other parts of Europe. But the power of the pope in appointing the great benefices of the church seems, before the Reformation, to have been nowhere so effectively and universally restrained as in France and England. The Concordat afterwards, in the sixteenth century, gave the kings of France the absolute right of presenting to all the great, or so-called consistorial, benefices of the French church.
elegant: As clerical power declined, sovereigns moved to recover influence over church appointments. England's Statute of Provisors and France's Pragmatic Sanction restored electoral processes that required royal consent and approval, giving sovereigns indirect control. No country restricted papal appointment power before the Reformation as effectively as France and England. The later French Concordat gave the crown absolute control over all major church appointments.
summary: Weakened clerical power allowed European sovereigns to reclaim influence over church appointments through legislation like England's Statute of Provisors and France's Pragmatic Sanction. These required royal consent for elections, giving indirect control. France and England most effectively restrained papal appointment power before the Reformation.
distilled: As the church's temporal power declined, European sovereigns used legislation to reclaim control over church appointments -- most successfully in France and England, where papal authority over benefices was curtailed before the Reformation.
notes: The state's counterattack: recovering the patronage power that the papacy had centralized (see 5.1.248). The Statute of Provisors (1351) and Pragmatic Sanction (1438) are landmark legislation in the church-state struggle. The mechanism: restoring elections that require royal consent gives the sovereign a veto and indirect influence. The Concordat of Bologna (1516) completes the process for France -- absolute royal control of major appointments. France and England as leaders in this process -- both are large, powerful states able to resist papal pressure. Cross-reference with 5.1.247-248 on how the pope centralized appointments and 5.1.260-261 on the effects.

refashioned: Since the establishment of the Pragmatic Sanction and the Concordat, the French clergy have in general shown less respect to the papal court's decrees than the clergy of any other Catholic country. In all the disputes between their sovereign and the pope, they have almost constantly taken the sovereign's side. This independence of the French clergy from the court of Rome seems to be principally founded on the Pragmatic Sanction and the Concordat. In earlier periods of the monarchy, the French clergy appear to have been as devoted to the pope as those of any other country. When Robert, the second prince of the Capetian line, was most unjustly excommunicated by the court of Rome, his own servants, it is said, threw the food from his table to the dogs and refused to taste anything that had been contaminated by contact with a person in his situation. They were taught to do so, it may very safely be presumed, by the clergy of his own dominions.
elegant: Since gaining control of appointments through the Pragmatic Sanction and Concordat, the French clergy have consistently sided with their sovereign against the pope -- unlike earlier periods when they were as devoted to Rome as any other nation's clergy. The contrast is dramatic: when the early Capetian king Robert was excommunicated, his own servants -- presumably coached by French clergy -- refused to eat food he had touched. Once preferment depended on the crown rather than Rome, loyalty followed.
summary: French clergy shifted from devoted papal servants to consistent royal allies once the crown gained control of church appointments. The transformation demonstrates that clerical loyalty follows the source of preferment: when the pope controlled appointments, clergy served Rome; when the crown did, they served the king.
distilled: French clerical loyalty shifted from the pope to the king exactly when control of church appointments transferred from Rome to the crown, proving that clergy serve whoever controls their advancement.
notes: The clearest empirical demonstration of Smith's preferment thesis (5.1.246): clergy serve whoever controls their promotion. The before-and-after comparison is stark -- the Robert II anecdote (c. 998 AD) versus post-Pragmatic Sanction behavior. The French church's 'Gallican liberties' are explained not by theology but by institutional incentives. The excommunication story illustrates how completely the French clergy served Rome before the institutional shift. Cross-reference with 5.1.246 on preferment as the key management tool and 5.1.247-248 on papal centralization.

refashioned: The claim to appoint the great benefices of the church -- a claim in defense of which the court of Rome had frequently shaken, and sometimes overturned, the thrones of some of the greatest sovereigns in Christendom -- was in this manner either restrained, modified, or given up altogether in many different parts of Europe, even before the time of the Reformation. As the clergy had now less influence over the people, the state had more influence over the clergy. The clergy therefore had both less power and less inclination to disturb the state.
elegant: Before the Reformation, the papal claim to church appointments -- once powerful enough to overthrow sovereigns -- had been restrained or abandoned across much of Europe. As clerical influence over the people declined, state influence over clergy grew. The clergy had both less power and less desire to challenge the state.
summary: Even before the Reformation, the papal appointment power that had once toppled sovereigns was being curtailed across Europe. The declining influence of clergy over the people corresponded to rising state influence over the clergy, reducing both their capacity and their motivation to challenge civil authority.
distilled: Before the Reformation even began, the economic decline of clerical temporal power had already shifted the balance from papal to state control of church appointments across much of Europe.
notes: The summary of the pre-Reformation institutional shift: economic change (5.1.256-258) weakened clerical temporal power, which enabled sovereign recovery of appointment authority (5.1.259), which redirected clerical loyalty toward the state (5.1.260). The Reformation will exploit and accelerate these existing trends (5.1.262). The dual decline: less power (economic base gone) and less inclination (preferment now depends on the state). Cross-reference with 5.1.256-260 for the full causal chain.

refashioned: The authority of the Church of Rome was in this state of decline when the disputes that gave birth to the Reformation began in Germany, and soon spread throughout every part of Europe. The new doctrines were received everywhere with a high degree of popular favor. They were propagated with all the enthusiastic zeal that commonly animates the spirit of party when it attacks established authority. The teachers of these doctrines, though perhaps in other respects no more learned than many of the theologians who defended the established church, seem in general to have been better acquainted with ecclesiastical history and with the origin and development of the system of beliefs on which the church's authority was established, and they thereby had the advantage in almost every dispute. The austerity of their manners gave them authority with the common people, who contrasted the strict regularity of their conduct with the disorderly lives of most of their own clergy. They possessed, too, in a much higher degree than their adversaries, all the arts of popularity and of gaining converts -- arts that the lofty and dignified sons of the church had long neglected as largely useless to them. The reason of the new doctrines recommended them to some, their novelty to many, the hatred and contempt of the established clergy to a still greater number. But the zealous, passionate, and fanatical -- though frequently coarse and rustic -- eloquence with which they were almost everywhere preached recommended them to by far the greatest number.
elegant: The Reformation found the Church of Rome already in decline. The new doctrines succeeded through multiple advantages: better knowledge of church history, austere personal conduct that shamed the dissolute established clergy, mastery of popular persuasion arts that the established church had abandoned, and passionate eloquence. Different audiences responded to different appeals -- reason, novelty, anti-clerical sentiment -- but impassioned preaching recruited by far the most converts.
summary: The Reformation succeeded because the Church of Rome was already weakened and the reformers held multiple advantages: superior knowledge of ecclesiastical history, austere morals that contrasted with dissolute clergy, mastery of popular arts, and passionate preaching. Different elements appealed to different audiences, but zealous eloquence was the most powerful recruiting tool.
distilled: The Reformation succeeded not primarily through doctrinal superiority but because an already-declining church was challenged by reformers who mastered popular persuasion, exemplified austere morals, and preached with passionate eloquence.
notes: Smith's analysis of the Reformation is institutional, not theological. The reformers' advantages map onto his earlier analysis: (1) better historical knowledge (intellectual edge), (2) austere morals (the common people's preferred moral code from 5.1.233-234), (3) popular arts (the competitive skills the establishment had abandoned per 5.1.219-221), (4) passionate eloquence (the energy of competition-driven teachers per 5.1.218). The established church's decline (5.1.256-261) created the opportunity; the reformers' competitive advantages exploited it. Multiple recruitment channels: reason, novelty, anti-establishment sentiment, emotional preaching. Cross-reference with 5.1.219-221 on the arts of popularity and 5.1.233-234 on austere morality.

refashioned: The success of the new doctrines was almost everywhere so great that princes who happened to be on bad terms with the court of Rome were, through them, easily able to overturn the church in their own dominions. The church, having lost the respect and veneration of the lower ranks, could offer scarcely any resistance. The court of Rome had offended some of the smaller princes in the northern parts of Germany, whom it had probably considered too insignificant to be worth managing carefully. They universally established the Reformation in their own dominions. The tyranny of Christian II and of Troll, Archbishop of Uppsala, enabled Gustavus Vasa to expel them both from Sweden. The pope favored the tyrant and the archbishop, and Gustavus Vasa had no difficulty establishing the Reformation in Sweden. Christian II was afterwards deposed from the throne of Denmark, where his conduct had made him as odious as in Sweden. The pope was still disposed to favor him, and Frederick of Holstein, who mounted the throne in his place, revenged himself by following the example of Gustavus Vasa. The magistrates of Berne and Zurich, who had no particular quarrel with the pope, established the Reformation in their respective cantons with great ease, where just before some of the clergy had, through an imposture somewhat grosser than ordinary, made the whole order both odious and contemptible.
elegant: The Reformation's popular success gave hostile princes the means to overturn the church, which could barely resist having lost popular support. Northern German princes, offended by Rome's neglect, universally adopted it. Sweden's Gustavus Vasa used it to overthrow a papal-backed tyrant. Denmark followed Sweden's example. Even Berne and Zurich, with no papal grievance, adopted it easily after local clerical scandals had made the whole order contemptible.
summary: The Reformation's popular success enabled any prince with a grievance against Rome to easily overturn the church in his dominions. Northern German princes, Scandinavian monarchs, and Swiss magistrates all used the opportunity -- some from political rivalry with Rome, others simply because the established clergy had made themselves contemptible.
distilled: The Reformation spread wherever princes had political grievances against Rome or wherever local clergy had discredited themselves, because the church's loss of popular support left it unable to resist.
notes: The political economy of the Reformation: religious change followed political interests. Smith lists specific cases: northern German princes (neglected by Rome), Sweden (papal support for a tyrant), Denmark (same dynamic), Switzerland (local clerical scandal). Each case combines opportunity (popular Reformation sentiment) with political motive (grievance against Rome). The church's inability to resist confirms the loss of temporal power analyzed in 5.1.256-258. 'Too insignificant to be worth managing' -- Rome's strategic miscalculation with small German princes. Cross-reference with 5.1.258-261 on the church's declining power base.

refashioned: In this critical situation, the papal court took considerable pains to cultivate the friendship of the powerful sovereigns of France and Spain, the latter of whom was at that time also Emperor of Germany. With their assistance, it was able, though not without great difficulty and much bloodshed, either to suppress altogether or to greatly obstruct the progress of the Reformation in their dominions. It was willing enough to be accommodating to the King of England as well. But given the circumstances of the times, it could not do so without giving offense to an even greater sovereign, Charles V, King of Spain and Emperor of Germany. Henry VIII accordingly, though he did not himself embrace most of the doctrines of the Reformation, was yet enabled by their general popularity to suppress all the monasteries and abolish the authority of the Church of Rome in his dominions. That he went so far, though he went no further, gave some satisfaction to the supporters of the Reformation, who, having gained control of the government during the reign of his son and successor, completed without any difficulty the work that Henry VIII had begun.
elegant: Rome managed to preserve its position only where it had powerful allies -- France and Spain -- and even then only with great bloodshed. It could not simultaneously accommodate Henry VIII without offending Charles V, so Henry used the Reformation's popularity to suppress the monasteries and break with Rome without adopting Reformed doctrine. His son's government then completed the Reformation that Henry had begun.
summary: The papacy survived the Reformation only where powerful allies (France, Spain) fought to suppress it, and even then with difficulty and bloodshed. Henry VIII exploited the Reformation's popularity to break with Rome without embracing its theology, and the next reign completed the full transition.
distilled: The Reformation was suppressed only where great powers actively fought it, while Henry VIII demonstrated that even a theologically conservative monarch could exploit its popularity to break with Rome.
notes: Geopolitical analysis of the Reformation's spread: success depended on the local sovereign's political situation vis-a-vis Rome and other great powers. The Henry VIII case is particularly interesting: political use of the Reformation without theological commitment. The Charles V constraint -- Rome could not accommodate both England and the Habsburgs -- shows how international political dynamics shaped religious outcomes. 'Great difficulty and much bloodshed' in France and Spain versus ease elsewhere illustrates the role of state power in determining religious outcomes. Cross-reference with 5.1.263 on the political dynamics of Reformation adoption.

refashioned:
In some countries, as in Scotland, where the government was weak, unpopular, and not very firmly established, the Reformation was strong enough to overturn not only the church but the state as well, for attempting to support the church.

Among the followers of the Reformation, dispersed throughout Europe, there was no general tribunal that could, like the court of Rome or an ecumenical council, settle all disputes among them and prescribe to all the precise limits of orthodoxy with irresistible authority. When the followers of the Reformation in one country happened to differ from their brethren in another, since they had no common judge to appeal to, the dispute could never be decided. Many such disputes arose. Those concerning the government of the church and the right of appointing clergy were perhaps the most important for civil peace and welfare. They gave rise to the two principal parties or sects among the Reformation's followers: the Lutheran and Calvinistic sects -- the only sects among them whose doctrine and organization have ever been established by law in any part of Europe.
elegant: In Scotland, where the government was weak, the Reformation overthrew both church and state. Without a centralized authority like Rome to resolve disputes, the Reformation fractured. Disagreements over church governance and appointments -- the issues most critical to civil peace -- produced the two major Protestant sects: Lutheran and Calvinist, the only ones ever legally established in Europe.
summary: The Reformation could overthrow even the state itself where government was weak, as in Scotland. Without a central authority to resolve disputes, Protestantism fractured along lines of church governance and appointment rights -- producing Lutheranism and Calvinism, the two sects whose organization and doctrine were established by law.
distilled: Without a central authority like Rome, the Reformation split over church governance and clerical appointments into Lutherans and Calvinists -- a fracture driven by the same institutional questions about power and patronage that Smith has analyzed throughout.
notes: The Reformation's own institutional dynamics: without a pope, disputes cannot be authoritatively resolved, so fragmentation follows. The key disputes were institutional (church governance, appointment rights), not primarily theological -- consistent with Smith's institutional-interest framework. Scotland as the extreme case: a weak state overthrown by the Reformation shows the limits of sovereign power when facing religious movements. Lutheran vs. Calvinist split as an organizational rather than doctrinal distinction at its core. Cross-reference with 5.1.266-267 on the two systems' characteristics.

refashioned: The followers of Luther, together with what is called the Church of England, preserved more or less of the episcopal form of government, established a hierarchy among the clergy, gave the sovereign the disposal of all bishoprics and other major benefices within his dominions, and thereby made him the real head of the church. Without depriving the bishop of the right to fill the smaller positions within his diocese, they admitted and even favored the right of presentation -- both for the sovereign and for all other lay patrons. This system of church government was, from the beginning, favorable to peace, good order, and submission to the civil sovereign. It has never been the occasion of any tumult or civil commotion in any country where it has been established. The Church of England in particular has always valued herself, with good reason, on the unexceptionable loyalty of her principles. Under such a government, the clergy naturally try to recommend themselves to the sovereign, the court, and the nobility and gentry, whose influence they chiefly look to for advancement. They pay court to these patrons sometimes, no doubt, through the basest flattery, but frequently also by cultivating all those arts that best deserve, and are therefore most likely to earn, the esteem of people of rank and fortune -- through their knowledge of various branches of useful and ornamental learning, through the decent generosity of their manners, the social good humor of their conversation, and their open contempt for the absurd and hypocritical austerities that fanatics preach and pretend to practice in order to win the veneration of the common people and the abhorrence of most men of rank and fortune. Such a clergy, however, while they pay court in this manner to the higher ranks, are very apt to altogether neglect the means of maintaining their influence and authority with the lower. They are listened to, esteemed, and respected by their superiors, but before their inferiors they are frequently incapable of effectively defending their own sober and moderate doctrines against the most ignorant enthusiast who chooses to attack them.
elegant: The followers of Luther and the Church of England preserved episcopal hierarchy, established clerical subordination, and gave the sovereign control of all major appointments -- making him the real head of the church. Lay patrons' right to present candidates for smaller benefices was admitted and even favored. This system was from the start favorable to peace, good order, and civil obedience -- it has never caused a tumult or civil commotion anywhere it has been established. Clergy seeking preferment naturally court the sovereign, the court, and the gentry, cultivating learning, social refinement, decent manners, and open contempt for the hypocritical austerities of fanatics. This wins them the esteem of the upper ranks. But in courting the higher orders, such clergy entirely neglect the arts of maintaining influence with the common people. Before lower-class audiences, they prove incapable of defending their own sober and moderate doctrines against the most ignorant enthusiast who chooses to attack them.
summary: The Lutheran-Anglican church model creates peace by giving the sovereign control of appointments, directing clerical ambition toward pleasing the upper classes. But this produces clergy who, while cultivated and moderate, completely lose the ability to connect with or influence common people, leaving them defenseless against enthusiastic challengers.
distilled: The episcopal Protestant model produces political stability and cultivated clergy but at the cost of all popular influence -- moderate clergymen who cannot defend their own doctrines against passionate enthusiasts before common audiences.
notes: The trade-off of the episcopal-crown model: political stability purchased at the cost of popular influence. Clergy optimize for their actual incentive structure (preferment from the sovereign and aristocracy) and neglect what they are not rewarded for (popular engagement). This exactly parallels Smith's teacher analysis: people respond to the incentive structure they actually face. The Church of England's 'unexceptionable loyalty' is both a genuine virtue and a symptom of institutional capture by the state. The vulnerability to enthusiasts echoes 5.1.219-221. Cross-reference with 5.1.267 for the contrasting Calvinist model.

refashioned: The followers of Zwingli, or more properly those of Calvin, on the contrary, bestowed on the people of each parish, whenever the church became vacant, the right to elect their own pastor. They established at the same time the most perfect equality among the clergy. The former part of this arrangement, as long as it remained in force, seems to have produced nothing but disorder and confusion, and tended equally to corrupt the morals of both clergy and people. The latter part seems never to have had any effects but what were perfectly agreeable.
elegant: The Calvinist model gave each parish the right to elect its own pastor and established complete equality among clergy. Popular election produced disorder, confusion, and moral corruption. Clerical equality produced only beneficial effects.
summary: Calvinism's two key innovations were popular election of pastors and equality among clergy. The electoral system produced disorder and moral corruption, while clerical equality proved entirely beneficial.
distilled: Calvinist church governance split into two elements: popular election of pastors (which caused disorder) and clerical equality (which proved wholly beneficial).
notes: Smith separates the two components of the Calvinist model and evaluates them independently. Popular election fails because it creates the competitive dynamics Hume worried about (5.1.226) -- clergy competing for popular favor through fanaticism. Clerical equality succeeds because it prevents the ambition-driven court-paying that corrupts the episcopal model (5.1.266). The analytical separation allows Smith to endorse one element and reject the other. Cross-reference with 5.1.266 for the Lutheran-Anglican model and 5.1.268-270 for the problems with popular election.

refashioned: As long as the people of each parish retained the right to elect their own pastors, they almost always acted under the influence of the clergy, and generally of the most factious and fanatical of the order. The clergy, in order to preserve their influence in these popular elections, became -- or affected to become -- many of them, fanatics themselves. They encouraged fanaticism among the people and almost always gave preference to the most fanatical candidate. So small a matter as the appointment of a parish priest almost always caused a violent contest, not only in one parish but in all the neighboring parishes, which seldom failed to take sides in the quarrel.
elegant: Popular pastoral elections were dominated by the most fanatical clergy, who cultivated fanaticism to maintain their electoral influence. Even clergy who were not naturally fanatical adopted or feigned fanaticism to compete. Each parish appointment triggered violent contests that spread to neighboring parishes -- a trivial cause producing disproportionate disorder.
summary: Popular election of pastors was dominated by the most fanatical clergy, who encouraged fanaticism to win elections. Clergy either became or pretended to be fanatics to compete. Even routine parish appointments triggered violent contests that spread across multiple parishes.
distilled: Popular election of pastors created a race to fanaticism, as clergy competed for electoral influence by encouraging extremism and preferring the most fanatical candidates.
notes: The race-to-the-bottom dynamic in popular religious elections -- exactly what Hume predicted. The mechanism: electoral success rewards fanaticism, so clergy either become or simulate fanatics. Even moderate clergy must adopt fanatical postures to compete. This is the democratic equivalent of the monopoly problem -- concentrated electoral power in small parishes produces polarization. 'So small a matter' causing 'violent contest' -- disproportionate institutional friction. Cross-reference with 5.1.226 for Hume's prediction and 5.1.269-270 for the political consequences.

refashioned: When the parish happened to be situated in a great city, it divided all the inhabitants into two parties. When that city happened to constitute itself a little republic, or to be the head and capital of a little republic -- as was the case with many of the considerable cities of Switzerland and Holland -- every petty dispute of this kind, besides exasperating the hostility of all their other factions, threatened to leave behind it both a new schism in the church and a new faction in the state. In those small republics, therefore, the magistrate very soon found it necessary, for the sake of preserving public peace, to assume the right of presenting to all vacant benefices himself. In Scotland, the most extensive country in which this presbyterian form of church government has ever been established, the rights of patronage were effectively abolished by the act that established presbytery at the beginning of the reign of William III. That act at least put it in the power of certain classes of people in each parish to purchase, for a very small price, the right of electing their own pastor.
elegant: In cities that were also small republics -- as in Switzerland and Holland -- parish electoral disputes compounded existing political factions, creating new schisms in both church and state. Magistrates quickly assumed appointment power to preserve peace. In Scotland, William III's act establishing presbytery effectively abolished aristocratic patronage, allowing parish communities to purchase the right of electing their own pastors for a small sum.
summary: Popular pastoral elections proved especially dangerous in city-republics like those of Switzerland and Holland, where they created new political factions alongside religious schisms. Magistrates were forced to take over appointments. Scotland's presbyterian establishment initially transferred election rights to parish communities at a nominal price.
distilled: The political dangers of popular pastoral election were so severe in small republics that magistrates were forced to seize appointment power, demonstrating that democratic church governance produces factional disorder incompatible with civil peace.
notes: The urban-republic setting amplifies the factional dynamics: where church and state are tightly integrated in small communities, religious elections become political crises. The Swiss and Dutch examples show that even strongly republican governments had to centralize appointments for peace. Scotland's solution -- purchasable election rights -- was an intermediate approach. The key lesson: democratic institutions in religion produce worse outcomes than in secular politics because religious disputes are more easily inflamed. Cross-reference with 5.1.268 on the fanaticism dynamic and 5.1.270 on the Scottish outcome.

refashioned: The constitution that this act established was allowed to stand for about twenty-two years, but was abolished by the 10th of Queen Anne, chapter 12, on account of the confusions and disorders that this more popular mode of election had almost everywhere caused. In so extensive a country as Scotland, however, a tumult in a remote parish was not as likely to disturb the government as in a smaller state. The 10th of Queen Anne restored the rights of patronage. But although in Scotland the law gives the benefice without any exception to the person presented by the patron, the church sometimes requires -- for she has not been entirely consistent in her decisions on this point -- a certain agreement from the people before she will confer upon the nominee what is called the cure of souls, or ecclesiastical jurisdiction in the parish. She sometimes, at least from a professed concern for the peace of the parish, delays the settlement until this agreement can be obtained.
elegant: Scotland's experiment with popular election lasted only twenty-two years before the disorders it caused led to its repeal by the 10th of Queen Anne, which restored patronage rights. Scotland's size moderated the damage somewhat -- remote parish tumults disturbed government less than in small republics. Under the restored system, the law gives the benefice to the patron's nominee, but the church sometimes requires a degree of congregational consent before conferring spiritual jurisdiction -- occasionally delaying settlements under the pretext of parish peace.
summary: Scotland's experiment with popular pastoral election was abolished after twenty-two years due to widespread disorder. Patronage was restored, though the church retained some informal power to require congregational consent, creating an ongoing tension between legal appointment and popular acceptance.
distilled: Scotland's twenty-two-year experiment with popular pastoral election produced enough disorder to be repealed, but the restored patronage system retained a tension between legal appointment rights and the church's informal requirement of congregational consent.
notes: The Scottish natural experiment: popular election tried, produced disorder, was abolished. This empirical result supports Smith's theoretical analysis. The twenty-two-year duration is enough time to evaluate. The church's residual requirement of 'concurrence' creates ongoing friction between patronage law and ecclesiastical practice -- a compromise that satisfies neither principle fully. Scotland's size as a moderating factor -- an important variable Smith identifies: the same institutional design produces different outcomes at different scales. Cross-reference with 5.1.268-269 on the problems with popular election and 5.1.271 on the residual fanaticism.

refashioned: The private maneuvering of some neighboring clergy, sometimes to procure but more frequently to prevent this congregational consent, and the popular arts they cultivate in order to meddle more effectively on such occasions, are perhaps the principal causes that keep alive whatever remains of the old fanatical spirit, either in the clergy or in the people of Scotland.
elegant: Residual Scottish fanaticism is sustained mainly by clerical maneuvering around congregational consent, keeping alive the popular arts that feed the old spirit.
summary: The remaining fanaticism in Scottish religion is sustained primarily by clerical politicking around congregational consent requirements, which keeps alive the popular arts and factional dynamics that formal patronage was meant to eliminate.
distilled: Scotland's residual religious fanaticism persists because the informal congregational consent requirement preserves the factional dynamics and popular politicking that formal patronage was designed to eliminate.
notes: The unintended consequence of the compromise: the consent requirement, though weaker than full election, preserves enough of the popular-influence dynamic to sustain fanaticism. Even informal mechanisms can maintain the competitive-fanaticism cycle identified in 5.1.268. The 'popular arts' are exactly the skills that compete-for-followers dynamics reward. Smith's analysis suggests that only complete removal of popular election mechanisms would fully eliminate the fanaticism problem. Cross-reference with 5.1.268-270 on the election-fanaticism dynamic.

refashioned: The equality that the presbyterian form of church government establishes among the clergy consists, first, in equality of authority or ecclesiastical jurisdiction, and second, in equality of benefice. In all presbyterian churches, the equality of authority is perfect; that of benefice is not entirely so. The difference between one benefice and another, however, is seldom so considerable as to tempt even the possessor of the smaller one to pay court to his patron through the base arts of flattery and servility in order to get a better one. In all presbyterian churches where the rights of patronage are thoroughly established, it is by nobler and better means that the established clergy generally try to gain the favor of their superiors -- by their learning, by the irreproachable regularity of their life, and by the faithful and diligent discharge of their duty. Their patrons even frequently complain of the independence of their spirit, which they are apt to interpret as ingratitude for past favors, but which at worst is perhaps seldom more than the indifference that naturally arises from the awareness that no further favors of the kind are ever to be expected. There is scarcely to be found anywhere in Europe a more learned, decent, independent, and respectable set of men than the greater part of the presbyterian clergy of Holland, Geneva, Switzerland, and Scotland.
elegant: Presbyterian clerical equality operates on two levels: perfect equality of authority and near-equality of benefice. The small differences between benefices are insufficient to tempt clergy into servile flattery. Instead, they compete through learning, moral conduct, and diligent service. Their patrons complain of their independent spirit -- but this independence merely reflects the knowledge that no great advancement is available to chase. The result is that Presbyterian clergy across Europe are among the most learned, decent, independent, and respectable of any establishment.
summary: Presbyterian clerical equality -- in both authority and income -- eliminates the incentive for servile courtship of patrons. With little to gain from flattery, clergy compete through genuine merit: learning, moral conduct, and diligent service. This produces remarkably independent and respectable clergy, as seen in Holland, Geneva, Switzerland, and Scotland.
distilled: Near-equality of clerical income under presbyterianism eliminates servile ambition, causing clergy to compete through genuine merit -- learning, integrity, and diligence -- producing the most independent and respectable clergy in Europe.
notes: The beneficial effects of the Calvinist equality principle (separated from the harmful popular-election element in 5.1.267). Income equality removes the incentive for patronage-seeking that corrupts the episcopal model (5.1.266). When clergy cannot advance materially, they compete on character and competence. 'Indifference that naturally arises from the consciousness that no further favours are ever to be expected' -- a precise description of how limited upward mobility produces independence. The compliment to Presbyterian clergy is Smith's strongest endorsement of any religious establishment. Cross-reference with 5.1.266-267 on the two Protestant models and 5.1.273 on why modest benefices produce good character.

refashioned: Where church benefices are all nearly equal, none of them can be very great, and this mediocrity of benefice, though it can no doubt be carried too far, has some very agreeable effects. Nothing but exemplary morals can give dignity to a person of small fortune. The vices of levity and vanity necessarily make him ridiculous and are, besides, almost as ruinous to him as they are to the common people. In his own conduct, therefore, he is obliged to follow the system of morals that the common people most respect. He gains their esteem and affection by the plan of life that his own interest and situation naturally lead him to follow. The common people look upon him with the kindness they naturally feel toward someone who approaches their own condition but whom they think ought to be somewhat above it. Their kindness naturally calls forth his kindness in return. He becomes careful to instruct them, and attentive to assist and relieve them. He does not even despise the prejudices of people who are disposed to be so favorable to him, and never treats them with the contemptuous and arrogant airs we so often encounter in the proud dignitaries of wealthy and well-endowed churches. The presbyterian clergy accordingly have more influence over the minds of the common people than perhaps the clergy of any other established church. It is accordingly in presbyterian countries only that we ever find the common people converted, without persecution, completely and almost to a man, to the established church.
elegant: Nearly equal, modest benefices produce clergy of exemplary character because small fortunes demand moral dignity. Such clergy naturally align with common people in lifestyle and values, earning their affection and trust. This mutual sympathy -- impossible for the proud dignitaries of wealthy churches -- gives Presbyterian clergy unmatched influence. Only in Presbyterian countries have the common people been universally converted to the established church without persecution.
summary: Modest, nearly equal clerical incomes produce the best clergy because economic circumstances force moral excellence and natural alignment with common people. This creates genuine mutual sympathy that proud, wealthy clergy cannot achieve. The result is that only in presbyterian countries has an entire population been voluntarily converted to the established church.
distilled: Modest clerical incomes produce the best clergy and the greatest popular influence, because economic necessity aligns the clergyman's interests with the common people's values -- achieving through voluntary sympathy what wealthy establishments could never achieve through authority.
notes: The capstone of Smith's analysis of religious institutions -- and one of his most elegant arguments. The mechanism: modest income forces moral alignment with common people, which produces genuine sympathy, which produces real influence. The wealthy-church alternative produces arrogance, distance, and impotence with the lower orders. 'Nothing but exemplary morals can give dignity to a man of small fortune' -- a principle applying far beyond clergy. The empirical test: only Presbyterian countries achieved voluntary universal conversion. This closes the circle opened in 5.1.218: market-like incentive structures (modest income, competition on merit) produce the best religious outcomes. Cross-reference with 5.1.233 on class morality, 5.1.266 on the episcopal model's upper-class bias, and 5.1.272 on clerical equality.

refashioned: In countries where most church positions pay modestly, a university professorship is typically a better career than a church appointment. In such cases, universities get to select their faculty from the entire pool of clergymen -- who, in every country, form by far the largest class of educated men. Where church positions are instead very lucrative, the church naturally draws away the most distinguished scholars from the universities, as prominent intellectuals typically find some patron willing to advance their career by securing them a well-paid church appointment.
elegant: Where church positions pay poorly, universities attract the best scholars from the clergy. Where church positions pay well, the church poaches the best minds from universities through patronage.
summary: The relative pay of church versus university positions determines where the best scholars end up. Modest church salaries push talent toward universities, while generous ones pull talent away from academia.
distilled: The competition between church and university salaries determines which institution attracts the best intellectual talent.
notes: Institutional competition for talent -- labor market dynamics in intellectual professions -- church vs. university as employers of scholars -- patronage systems in academia

refashioned: In the first situation, we tend to find universities staffed by the country's most brilliant scholars. In the second, we find few distinguished minds among the faculty, and those few tend to be junior members who are likely to be lured away before they accumulate enough experience and knowledge to truly benefit the institution. Voltaire observed that Father Pore, a Jesuit of no great literary distinction, was the only professor France had ever produced whose works were worth reading. In a country that has produced so many eminent writers and thinkers, it seems remarkable that virtually none of them ever held a university professorship.
elegant: Where church pay exceeds university pay, universities lose their best minds. Voltaire noted that in all of France -- a nation rich in great thinkers -- virtually no eminent scholar had ever been a university professor. The few talented academics who do appear are quickly poached before they can contribute meaningfully.
summary: When church salaries exceed university ones, universities are left with mediocre faculty. Voltaire observed that France, despite its wealth of great thinkers, had produced almost no notable university professors -- they were all drawn into the church.
distilled: Generous church salaries drain universities of talent, explaining why a great intellectual nation like France produced almost no distinguished professors.
notes: Brain drain from universities to church -- Voltaire's observation on French academia -- experience and institutional knowledge lost through talent poaching -- systemic failure in intellectual institutions

refashioned: The famous Gassendi began his career as a professor at the University of Aix. As soon as his genius became apparent, he was advised that entering the church would provide a more comfortable living and a better environment for his studies -- and he immediately took the advice. Voltaire's observation applies, I believe, not only to France but to all Roman Catholic countries. We very rarely find an eminent scholar serving as a university professor in any of them, except perhaps in law and medicine -- professions from which the church is less likely to recruit. After the Roman Catholic Church, the Church of England is by far the richest and best-endowed in Christendom. In England, accordingly, the church continuously drains the universities of their best members, and an old college tutor recognized across Europe as a distinguished scholar is as rare there as in any Catholic country. In Geneva, the Protestant cantons of Switzerland, the Protestant states of Germany, Holland, Scotland, Sweden, and Denmark, by contrast, the greatest scholars those countries have produced have mostly been university professors. In those countries, the universities continuously drain the church of its most eminent intellectual talent.
elegant: Gassendi left his university chair at Aix for the better-paid church, illustrating a pattern across all Catholic countries: eminent scholars rarely remain professors. England's wealthy church similarly drains its universities of talent. But in Protestant countries -- Geneva, Switzerland, Germany, Holland, Scotland, Scandinavia -- where church pay is modest, the greatest scholars have mostly been university professors. The direction of the talent drain reverses entirely based on relative compensation.
summary: Across Catholic countries and England, where the church is wealthy, the best scholars leave universities for church careers. In Protestant countries with modest church salaries, the reverse occurs -- the most eminent thinkers become professors, and universities draw talent from the church.
distilled: Wealthy churches drain universities of talent in Catholic countries and England, while modest church pay in Protestant nations keeps the best scholars in academia.
notes: Gassendi as case study -- Catholic vs. Protestant institutional dynamics -- Church of England as talent competitor -- cross-national comparison of academic quality -- law and medicine as exceptions (church doesn't recruit from them)

refashioned: It is worth noting that, if we set aside the poets, a few orators, and a few historians, the vast majority of the other great scholars of Greece and Rome were either public or private teachers -- generally of philosophy or rhetoric. This holds true from the era of Lysias and Isocrates, Plato and Aristotle, through to the times of Plutarch and Epictetus, Suetonius and Quintilian. Requiring someone to teach a particular branch of knowledge year after year is in reality the most effective method for making him a complete master of it. By going over the same ground annually, any competent person inevitably becomes thoroughly familiar with every aspect of the subject. If he forms a hasty opinion one year, he is very likely to correct it when he revisits the same topic the next. Just as teaching is the natural occupation for a pure scholar, it is also perhaps the education most likely to produce a person of deep and solid learning. The modesty of church salaries naturally directs most scholars toward the profession where they can be most useful to the public, while simultaneously giving them the best education they could possibly receive. It tends to make their learning both as rigorous and as practical as possible.
elegant: Most great scholars of Greece and Rome -- from Plato and Aristotle to Plutarch and Quintilian -- were teachers. Teaching the same subject year after year is the most effective way to master it completely: repeated engagement corrects hasty judgments and deepens understanding. Modest church salaries naturally push scholars into teaching, the profession where they are most useful and where they receive the best continuing education themselves.
summary: The greatest ancient scholars were almost all teachers. Teaching year after year is the most effective path to mastery, as it forces constant revision and deepening of knowledge. Modest church pay naturally channels scholars into teaching, benefiting both their own learning and the public.
distilled: Teaching is the most effective route to scholarly mastery, and modest church salaries beneficially direct intellectuals toward this most publicly useful profession.
notes: Teaching as mastery -- classical precedent from Greece and Rome -- Lysias, Isocrates, Plato, Aristotle, Plutarch, Epictetus, Suetonius, Quintilian -- iterative learning through instruction -- incentive alignment between modest pay and public benefit

refashioned: The revenue of every established church -- excluding income from particular lands or estates -- is essentially a branch of the state's general revenue that has been diverted to a very different purpose than national defense. The tithe, for example, is effectively a land tax that reduces the ability of landowners to contribute to the defense of the state as much as they otherwise could. Land rent is, according to some theorists, the sole fund, and according to others, the principal fund from which the expenses of every great monarchy must ultimately be supplied.
elegant: Church revenue, apart from its own land holdings, is really state revenue diverted from defense. The tithe functions as a land tax, reducing what landowners can contribute to the state. Since land rent is widely regarded as the primary or sole fund for covering state expenses, church diversion of this fund weakens national capacity.
summary: Church revenue is essentially diverted state revenue. The tithe acts as a land tax that reduces landowners' ability to fund national defense, which is problematic since land rent is considered the primary source for covering state expenses.
distilled: Church tithes effectively divert land tax revenue from national defense, weakening the state's financial capacity.
notes: Church revenue as diverted state revenue -- tithes as implicit land tax -- Physiocratic influence (land rent as sole/principal fund) -- tension between ecclesiastical and state finance -- cross-reference to Book 2 on sources of revenue

refashioned: The more of this revenue that goes to the church, the less remains for the state. It can be stated as a firm principle that, all else being equal, the richer the church, the poorer either the sovereign or the people must necessarily be -- and in every case, the less able the state is to defend itself. In several Protestant countries, particularly in all the Protestant cantons of Switzerland, the revenue that formerly belonged to the Roman Catholic Church -- the tithes and church lands -- has proven sufficient not only to pay adequate salaries to the established clergy but also to cover, with little or no additional funding, all the other expenses of the state.
elegant: A firm principle: all else equal, the richer the church, the poorer the sovereign or the people, and the weaker the state's defenses. In Protestant Swiss cantons, former Catholic Church revenues -- tithes and church lands -- proved sufficient to fund both clergy salaries and nearly all other state expenses.
summary: Church wealth comes at the direct expense of state or popular wealth, weakening national defense. Protestant Swiss cantons demonstrated that former Catholic Church revenues could fund both the clergy and nearly all government expenses.
distilled: The richer the church, the poorer and weaker the state -- as Protestant Switzerland proved by funding government largely from repurposed Catholic Church revenues.
notes: Zero-sum relationship between church and state revenue -- Protestant vs. Catholic fiscal models -- Swiss cantons as empirical example -- church wealth and national defense capacity

refashioned: The magistrates of the powerful canton of Berne in particular have accumulated a very large sum from the savings of this fund, supposedly amounting to several millions. Part of this is held in a public treasury, and part is invested at interest in the public funds of various indebted European nations -- chiefly France and Great Britain. I do not claim to know the total expense of the church in Berne or any other Protestant canton. But by a very precise accounting, the entire revenue of the Scottish clergy in 1755 -- including their church lands and the estimated value of their dwelling-house rents -- amounted to only 68,514 pounds, 1 shilling, and 5-1/12 pence. This very modest revenue provides a decent living for 944 ministers.
elegant: The canton of Berne accumulated millions in savings from former church revenues, investing the surplus in French and British public funds. Scotland's entire clergy revenue in 1755 totaled just 68,514 pounds -- enough to decently support 944 ministers, demonstrating that modest church funding suffices.
summary: Berne accumulated millions from church revenue savings, investing the surplus abroad. Scotland's clergy in 1755 subsisted decently on a total of just 68,514 pounds for 944 ministers, showing that lavish church funding is unnecessary.
distilled: Berne grew wealthy investing surplus church funds, while Scotland proved that modest clergy pay of 68,514 pounds could adequately support 944 ministers.
notes: Canton of Berne as fiscal model -- sovereign wealth fund concept (investing surplus in foreign debt) -- Scottish church as example of frugal but effective establishment -- specific 1755 revenue data

refashioned: The total expense of the Scottish church, including occasional spending on building and repairing churches and ministers' residences, can hardly exceed eighty or eighty-five thousand pounds per year. Yet the most opulently funded church in Christendom does not do a better job of maintaining uniformity of faith, fervor of devotion, orderliness, regularity, and austere morals among the general population than this very modestly endowed Church of Scotland. Every beneficial effect, both civil and religious, that an established church could be expected to produce is achieved just as fully by this one.
elegant: Scotland's entire church costs under 85,000 pounds annually, yet outperforms the richest churches in Christendom at maintaining faith, devotion, and moral discipline. Every benefit an established church can deliver, Scotland's poorly endowed church delivers equally well.
summary: The Church of Scotland, spending under 85,000 pounds per year, maintains religious devotion, moral discipline, and social order as effectively as the wealthiest churches in Christendom. Lavish church funding produces no better results.
distilled: Scotland's modestly funded church achieves every civil and religious benefit as effectively as the richest churches, proving that generous endowment adds no value.
notes: Efficiency of modest church funding -- Church of Scotland as model -- diminishing returns on religious institutional spending -- moral outcomes independent of institutional wealth

refashioned: Most of the Protestant churches of Switzerland, which are generally no better endowed than Scotland's, produce these effects to an even greater degree. In most Protestant cantons, there is not a single person who does not belong to the established church. Anyone professing a different faith is legally required to leave the canton. But such a severe -- indeed oppressive -- law could never have been enforced in such free countries had the clergy not already converted essentially the entire population to the established church beforehand, with perhaps a few individual exceptions. In some parts of Switzerland, however, where the accidental union of a Protestant and Catholic territory meant the conversion was incomplete, both religions are not merely tolerated but legally established.
elegant: Swiss Protestant churches, funded no better than Scotland's, achieve even greater religious conformity -- in most cantons, literally everyone belongs to the established church. The severe law requiring dissenters to leave could only be enforced because the clergy had already converted nearly everyone. Where Protestant-Catholic territories merged and conversion was incomplete, both faiths are legally established.
summary: Swiss Protestant churches achieve near-total religious conformity despite modest funding. Laws requiring dissenters to leave only work because the diligent clergy had already converted virtually everyone. Where historical mergers left mixed populations, both faiths are legally established.
distilled: Modestly funded Swiss Protestant churches achieved near-total conformity through clerical diligence, not coercive law, proving generous endowment unnecessary for religious effectiveness.
notes: Religious conformity and institutional funding -- Swiss cantonal religious law -- coercion vs. persuasion in religious establishment -- dual-establishment model in mixed territories

refashioned: Proper performance in any profession seems to require that compensation be proportioned as closely as possible to the nature of the work. If a position is significantly underpaid, the quality of service suffers because mostly mediocre and incompetent people will fill it. If it is significantly overpaid, the quality may suffer even more from the negligence and idleness of its holders. A person with a large income, regardless of profession, tends to think he should live like other wealthy people -- spending much of his time in festivities, vanity, and self-indulgence. In a clergyman, however, this lifestyle not only consumes time that should be devoted to his duties, but in the eyes of ordinary people, it almost entirely destroys the sanctity of character that alone enables him to perform those duties with proper authority and moral weight.
elegant: Compensation should match the nature of the service. Underpayment attracts mediocrity; overpayment breeds negligence. A wealthy clergyman lives like other rich men -- in festivity and indulgence -- which consumes time meant for duties and, worse, destroys the sanctity of character essential to his moral authority in the eyes of ordinary people.
summary: Pay should be proportioned to the nature of the work. Underpayment attracts mediocrity while overpayment breeds negligence. For clergy especially, excessive wealth leads to a lifestyle that destroys the moral authority essential to their role.
distilled: Both underpayment and overpayment degrade professional performance, but overpaid clergy suffer uniquely because their lavish lifestyles destroy the sanctity that gives them moral authority.
notes: Optimal compensation theory -- incentive effects of under- and overpayment -- clergy as special case where wealth undermines professional effectiveness -- moral authority and perceived sanctity -- cross-reference to 5.1.274-277 on church endowment levels

refashioned:
Beyond the expenses needed for the sovereign to fulfill his various duties, a certain amount must be spent to maintain his dignity. This expense varies with both the stage of economic development and the form of government.

In a wealthy and advanced society, where all classes of people are spending more and more on their homes, furniture, dining, clothing, and carriages, the sovereign can hardly be expected to resist the trend alone. He naturally -- indeed necessarily -- becomes more expensive in all these areas as well. His very dignity seems to demand it.
elegant: Beyond the costs of governance, a sovereign must spend to maintain dignity -- and this expense grows as society grows richer. When all classes spend lavishly on homes, clothing, and carriages, the sovereign cannot resist the trend. His dignity demands he keep pace.
summary: Sovereigns must spend to maintain their dignity, and this expense rises as society becomes wealthier. When all classes increase their standard of living, the sovereign is naturally compelled to do the same.
distilled: As a society grows wealthier and all classes spend more lavishly, the sovereign must increase spending on dignity to keep pace.
notes: Cost of sovereign dignity -- conspicuous consumption and social expectations -- expense scaling with economic development -- government form affects dignity costs

refashioned:
Since a monarch stands far above his subjects in dignity -- more so than the chief magistrate of any republic stands above fellow citizens -- greater expense is needed to maintain that higher dignity. We naturally expect more splendor at the court of a king than at the residence of a doge or a burgomaster.

In conclusion: the expense of defending the society and the expense of maintaining the chief magistrate's dignity are both incurred for the general benefit of the whole society. It is therefore reasonable that they should be funded by the general contribution of the whole society, with all members contributing as nearly as possible in proportion to their respective abilities.
elegant: Monarchs require more splendor than republican magistrates, as their greater dignity demands greater expense. In conclusion: both national defense and the chief magistrate's dignity serve the whole society, so both should be funded by general contributions proportional to each member's ability to pay.
summary: Monarchies require more spending on dignity than republics. Both defense spending and maintaining the sovereign's dignity benefit all of society and should therefore be funded by proportional contributions from all citizens.
distilled: Defense and sovereign dignity both serve the general public and should be funded by proportional contributions from all members of society.
notes: Monarchy vs. republic -- cost of dignity -- proportional taxation principle -- ability to pay -- transition to Chapter 5.2 on revenue sources

refashioned: The expense of administering justice can also be considered as benefiting the whole society, so there is nothing improper about funding it from general taxation. However, the people who actually cause this expense are those whose wrongdoing makes it necessary for others to seek legal redress or protection. The people most directly benefited are those whose rights the courts either restore or defend. The cost of justice could therefore quite properly be covered by particular contributions from one or both of these groups -- that is, by court fees. General taxation need only cover the prosecution of criminals who lack the means to pay such fees themselves.
elegant: Justice benefits all society but is specifically caused by wrongdoers and specifically benefits those seeking legal redress. Court fees levied on these parties can properly fund the system, with general taxation needed only for prosecuting criminals too poor to pay fees.
summary: While justice benefits everyone, its costs are specifically caused by wrongdoers and benefit those seeking legal protection. Court fees from these parties can fund the system, with general taxation covering only the prosecution of impoverished criminals.
distilled: The administration of justice can be properly funded through court fees rather than general taxation, except for prosecuting criminals who cannot pay.
notes: User-pays principle in justice -- court fees vs. general taxation -- distinction between who causes expense vs. who benefits -- criminal prosecution as public good requiring general funding

refashioned: Local or provincial expenses whose benefits are confined to that locality -- such as the policing of a particular town or district -- should be funded by local or provincial revenue and should not burden the general revenue of the whole society. It is unjust to make the entire society contribute toward an expense whose benefits are limited to only part of it.
elegant: Local expenses with only local benefits -- like town policing -- should be funded locally. Making the whole society pay for benefits confined to one area is unjust.
summary: Expenses that benefit only a particular locality should be funded by that locality's own revenue, not by the general public. Universal contribution to local benefits is unjust.
distilled: Local benefits should be funded by local revenue, not general taxation, because making everyone pay for one area's benefits is unjust.
notes: Fiscal federalism -- benefit principle of taxation -- local vs. general revenue -- subsidiarity in public finance

refashioned: Maintaining good roads and communications undoubtedly benefits the whole society and can therefore justly be funded from general contributions. However, this expense most directly benefits those who travel or transport goods from place to place, and those who consume such goods. Turnpike tolls in England and similar road duties in other countries place the cost entirely on these two groups, thereby relieving the general revenue of a very considerable burden.
elegant: Road maintenance benefits all society but most directly benefits travelers, carriers, and consumers of transported goods. Turnpike tolls rightly place costs on these direct beneficiaries, relieving general revenue of a significant burden.
summary: Roads benefit everyone but especially travelers, carriers, and consumers. Turnpike tolls efficiently charge these direct beneficiaries, reducing the burden on general revenue.
distilled: Road costs can justly be charged to their direct beneficiaries through tolls rather than funded entirely from general taxation.
notes: User-pays principle for infrastructure -- turnpike tolls -- direct vs. indirect beneficiaries -- relieving general revenue through targeted charges -- cross-reference to 5.1.71-98 on roads and communications

refashioned: The expense of educational and religious institutions likewise benefits the whole society and can justly be funded from general contributions. However, this expense could perhaps equally properly -- and even advantageously -- be funded entirely by those who directly benefit from such education and instruction, or by voluntary contributions from those who believe they need either one.
elegant: Education and religious instruction benefit all society but could justly -- perhaps even advantageously -- be funded entirely by direct beneficiaries or by voluntary contributions from those who value the services.
summary: While education and religion benefit society broadly, their costs could properly be borne by direct beneficiaries or voluntary contributors rather than by general taxation.
distilled: Education and religious institutions could be funded by their direct beneficiaries or voluntary contributors rather than the general public.
notes: User-pays principle for education -- voluntary funding model for religion -- public vs. private benefit of education -- foreshadowing arguments for market-based education funding

refashioned: When institutions or public works that benefit the whole society cannot be fully maintained by the contributions of those who benefit most directly, the shortfall must generally be covered by the general contribution of the whole society. The state's general revenue, beyond funding national defense and the chief magistrate's dignity, must make up for deficiencies in many particular branches of revenue. I shall attempt to explain the sources of this general or public revenue in the following chapter.
elegant: When direct beneficiaries cannot fully fund public institutions, general taxation must cover the shortfall. The state's general revenue -- beyond defense and sovereign dignity -- must fill gaps across many revenue branches. The sources of this public revenue are the subject of the next chapter.
summary: When the direct beneficiaries of public works and institutions cannot fully fund them, general taxation must cover the gap. The next chapter examines the sources of this public revenue.
distilled: General taxation must fill the gap whenever direct beneficiary funding falls short of maintaining beneficial public institutions.
notes: Residual role of general taxation -- transition to Chapter 5.2 on public revenue -- hierarchy of funding: user fees first, general taxation as backup -- summary of Part 1 principles
