refashioned: The revenue needed to cover not only national defense and the chief magistrate's dignity, but all other necessary government expenses for which the constitution provides no dedicated funding, must come from one of two sources: either from some fund belonging specifically to the sovereign or commonwealth that is independent of the people's revenue, or from the revenue of the people themselves.
elegant: Government revenue beyond what dedicated funds cover must come either from the sovereign's own independent resources or from taxation of the people's revenue.
summary: All government expenses not covered by dedicated constitutional provisions must be funded either from the sovereign's own independent resources or from the people's revenue through taxation.
distilled: Government revenue must come either from the sovereign's own property and investments or from taxing the people.
notes: Two fundamental sources of public revenue -- sovereign's own funds vs. taxation -- opening framework for Chapter 5.2

refashioned:
The funds that may specifically belong to the sovereign or commonwealth must consist either of capital stock or of land.

The sovereign, like any other owner of capital, can earn revenue from it either by employing it directly or by lending it out. In the first case, the return is profit; in the second, it is interest.
elegant: The sovereign's own revenue sources are capital stock and land. Capital yields either profit (if employed directly) or interest (if lent out).
summary: A sovereign's independent revenue comes from two types of assets: capital stock and land. Capital generates either profits through direct employment or interest through lending.
distilled: The sovereign's own revenue derives from capital stock (yielding profit or interest) and from land.
notes: Classification of sovereign revenue -- profit vs. interest -- parallel between sovereign and private capital owner

refashioned: The revenue of a Tartar or Arabian chief consists of profit. It comes mainly from the milk and increase of his own herds and flocks, which he personally manages as the principal shepherd or herdsman of his tribe. However, it is only in this earliest and most primitive stage of civil government that profit has ever constituted the principal part of a monarchical state's public revenue.
elegant: A Tartar or Arabian chief's revenue is profit from personally managing his herds -- milk, breeding, and growth. But profit has served as the principal source of monarchical revenue only in this most primitive stage of government.
summary: In the earliest stage of government, a chief's public revenue comes from the profits of personally managing his herds. This is the only period in which profit has been the main source of monarchical state revenue.
distilled: Only in the most primitive stage of government has the sovereign's personal profit from herding served as the principal public revenue.
notes: Pastoral stage of government -- sovereign as herdsman-in-chief -- profit as primitive revenue source -- stages of economic development and governance

refashioned: Small republics have sometimes earned considerable revenue from commercial ventures. The Republic of Hamburg is said to derive revenue from the profits of a public wine cellar and apothecary shop. (This information comes from a work on European taxes and duties compiled by order of the French court for a commission studying financial reform. The account of French taxes, filling three quarto volumes, can be regarded as perfectly reliable. The accounts of other European nations' taxes were compiled from information gathered by French ministers at the various courts.
elegant: Small republics have sometimes profited from state-run commercial ventures -- Hamburg, for instance, from a public wine cellar and apothecary shop.
summary: Some small republics have generated significant revenue through government-operated commercial enterprises, such as Hamburg's public wine cellar and apothecary shop.
distilled: Small republics like Hamburg have sometimes earned considerable revenue from state-run commercial enterprises.
notes: State commercial enterprises -- Republic of Hamburg -- mercantile projects as public revenue -- French fiscal research as source material

refashioned: That state cannot be very powerful if its sovereign has time to run a wine shop or a pharmacy. Public banking has been a revenue source for more substantial states -- not only Hamburg but also Venice and Amsterdam. Some have even suggested this kind of revenue is not beneath a great empire like Britain's. Calculating the Bank of England's ordinary dividend at five and a half percent on its capital of 10,780,000 pounds, its net annual profit after management costs would be 592,900 pounds. If the government could borrow this capital at three percent interest and manage the bank itself, it could supposedly earn a clear profit of 269,500 pounds per year.
elegant: A state whose sovereign runs a wine shop cannot be very great. Public banking has generated revenue for more substantial states -- Hamburg, Venice, Amsterdam. Some proposed Britain nationalize the Bank of England: borrowing its 10.78 million pound capital at 3% while earning its 5.5% return would yield 269,500 pounds annually.
summary: While small states may run shops, more substantial governments have profited from public banks. It was proposed that Britain could earn 269,500 pounds annually by nationalizing the Bank of England -- borrowing its capital at 3% while capturing its 5.5% return.
distilled: Public banking has generated revenue for states like Hamburg, Venice, and Amsterdam, with some proposing Britain nationalize the Bank of England for a 269,500-pound annual profit.
notes: Public banking as revenue source -- Bank of England nationalization proposal -- spread between borrowing cost and bank returns -- Venice and Amsterdam as banking states

refashioned: The orderly, vigilant, and frugal administration of aristocracies like those of Venice and Amsterdam is extremely well suited, as experience shows, to managing commercial ventures of this kind. But whether a government like England's -- which, whatever its virtues, has never been famous for economy; which in peacetime has generally operated with the lazy, negligent extravagance that is perhaps natural to monarchies; and in wartime has consistently displayed the thoughtless overspending that democracies tend toward -- could be safely entrusted with such a venture must be considerably more doubtful.
elegant: Orderly, frugal aristocracies like Venice and Amsterdam can successfully manage state commercial ventures. But England's government -- characterized by monarchical negligence in peace and democratic extravagance in war -- is far less suited to such management.
summary: While disciplined aristocratic governments like Venice and Amsterdam have managed commercial ventures well, England's government lacks the economy and prudence needed. Its monarchical negligence in peacetime and democratic extravagance in wartime make it a poor candidate for such management.
distilled: Frugal aristocracies can manage state commercial ventures, but England's history of monarchical negligence and democratic extravagance makes it a poor candidate.
notes: Government type and commercial competence -- aristocratic vs. monarchical vs. democratic fiscal behavior -- Venice and Amsterdam as models -- England's fiscal character -- institutional capacity for commercial management

refashioned: The post office is essentially a commercial venture. The government invests in establishing offices and acquiring horses or carriages, then earns a substantial profit from postal charges. It is perhaps the only commercial enterprise that has been successfully managed by every type of government. The initial capital required is modest. The business involves no mystery. The returns are not only reliable but immediate.
elegant: The post office is the one commercial venture every type of government has managed successfully. It requires modest capital, involves no complexity, and generates certain, immediate returns.
summary: The post office is a rare example of a universally successful government commercial enterprise. Its success stems from requiring little capital, involving straightforward operations, and producing reliable, immediate returns.
distilled: The post office succeeds as a government enterprise universally because it requires little capital, is simple to operate, and generates immediate, certain returns.
notes: Post office as model government enterprise -- characteristics of successful state commercial ventures: low capital, simplicity, certain returns -- universal success across government types

refashioned: Princes, however, have frequently ventured into many other commercial enterprises, willing -- like private businessmen -- to improve their finances by becoming traders. They have almost never succeeded. The extravagance with which princes' affairs are always managed makes success nearly impossible. A prince's agents treat his wealth as inexhaustible: they are careless about purchase prices, careless about selling prices, and careless about transportation costs. These agents frequently live as extravagantly as princes themselves -- and sometimes, despite that extravagance, manage through creative accounting to amass princely fortunes of their own. This is how, as Machiavelli tells us, Lorenzo de' Medici's agents conducted his trade. The Republic of Florence was repeatedly forced to pay off the debts their extravagance had accumulated. Lorenzo eventually found it prudent to abandon the merchant trade -- the business to which his family originally owed its fortune -- and to devote both what remained of that fortune and the state revenue at his disposal to projects and expenditures more fitting for his station.
elegant: Princes have frequently attempted commerce but almost never succeeded. Their agents treat the prince's wealth as inexhaustible -- careless in buying, selling, and transporting goods -- often living extravagantly themselves and amassing fortunes through creative accounting. Machiavelli describes how Lorenzo de' Medici's agents operated this way until Florence had to cover the debts, prompting Lorenzo to abandon trade entirely.
summary: Princes almost always fail at commerce because their agents spend recklessly, treating royal wealth as infinite. Machiavelli's account of Lorenzo de' Medici illustrates the pattern: his agents' extravagance forced Florence to cover the debts, and Lorenzo abandoned trade for activities more suited to his station.
distilled: Princes fail at commerce because their agents spend recklessly, as illustrated by Lorenzo de' Medici, whose agents' extravagance forced Florence to cover the resulting debts.
notes: Principal-agent problem in sovereign commerce -- Machiavelli on Lorenzo de' Medici -- agent extravagance and creative accounting -- why government commercial ventures fail -- Medici family transition from merchants to rulers

refashioned: No two roles seem more incompatible than trader and sovereign. If the trading mentality of the English East India Company makes them very poor sovereigns, the sovereign mentality seems to have made them equally poor traders. When they were purely traders, they managed their business successfully and paid moderate dividends to shareholders. Since becoming sovereigns -- with a revenue originally exceeding three million sterling -- they have been forced to beg the government for assistance to avoid immediate bankruptcy. As mere traders, their employees in India saw themselves as clerks of merchants. As sovereigns, those same employees see themselves as ministers of state.
elegant: Trader and sovereign are incompatible roles. The East India Company succeeded as traders, paying decent dividends, but as sovereigns with revenues over three million sterling, they neared bankruptcy. Their Indian employees shifted from seeing themselves as merchant clerks to seeing themselves as ministers of state -- with corresponding extravagance.
summary: The East India Company demonstrates that trading and governing are incompatible. As traders they were successful, but acquiring sovereignty transformed their employees from frugal merchant clerks into extravagant would-be statesmen, driving the company toward bankruptcy despite enormous revenues.
distilled: The East India Company's decline from profitable trader to near-bankrupt sovereign proves that trading and governing are fundamentally incompatible roles.
notes: East India Company as case study -- incompatibility of commercial and sovereign roles -- employee identity shift from clerks to ministers -- principal-agent problem in hybrid commercial-sovereign entities

refashioned:
A state may sometimes derive part of its public revenue from interest on money as well as from profits on capital. If it has accumulated a treasury, it can lend part of it either to foreign states or to its own citizens.

The canton of Berne earns considerable revenue by lending part of its treasury to foreign states -- that is, by investing in the public debt of various European nations, mainly France and England. The security of this revenue depends, first, on the soundness of the funds in which it is invested and the good faith of the debtor government, and second, on the likelihood of continued peace with the debtor nation. In the event of war, the debtor nation's first hostile act might well be to seize the creditor's invested funds. This policy of lending money to foreign states is, as far as I know, unique to the canton of Berne.
elegant: States can earn revenue by lending accumulated treasury funds. Berne earns considerable income by investing in foreign government debt, mainly French and English. But this revenue depends on the debtor's good faith and continued peace -- in war, the debtor's first act might be to seize the invested funds. This foreign lending policy appears unique to Berne.
summary: States with accumulated treasuries can earn revenue through lending. Berne invests in French and English government debt, but this income is vulnerable to both debtor default and wartime seizure of funds -- a risk unique to its unusual policy of foreign sovereign lending.
distilled: Berne uniquely earns revenue by investing its treasury in foreign government debt, but this income is vulnerable to debtor default and wartime seizure.
notes: Sovereign wealth investment -- canton of Berne as pioneer -- risk of foreign sovereign lending -- wartime debt repudiation -- interest income as public revenue

refashioned: The city of Hamburg has established a kind of public pawnshop that lends money to citizens against pledges at six percent interest. This pawnshop, known as a lombard, reportedly generates revenue of 150,000 crowns for the state, which at four shillings sixpence per crown amounts to 33,750 pounds sterling.
elegant: Hamburg operates a public pawnshop (lombard) lending at 6% against pledges, reportedly earning the state 150,000 crowns -- about 33,750 pounds sterling.
summary: Hamburg's public pawnshop lends to citizens at six percent interest against collateral, generating approximately 33,750 pounds sterling annually for the state.
distilled: Hamburg earns state revenue of about 33,750 pounds annually through a public pawnshop lending at six percent interest.
notes: Public pawnshop (lombard) as revenue source -- Hamburg as financial innovator -- collateralized lending by government -- state as lender to citizens

refashioned: The government of Pennsylvania invented a way to lend not money itself, but something equivalent to money, to its citizens without first accumulating a treasury. By issuing paper bills of credit to private individuals at interest, secured by land worth double the loan value, redeemable after fifteen years, transferable like banknotes, and declared legal tender for all payments within the province, it raised a moderate revenue that went a considerable way toward covering annual expenses of about 4,500 pounds -- the total ordinary cost of that frugal government. The success of this scheme depended on three conditions: first, sufficient demand for a medium of exchange beyond gold and silver; second, the good credit of the government issuing the bills; and third, moderation in their issuance, with total paper never exceeding the gold and silver it replaced in circulation. Several other American colonies adopted the same approach, but lacking such moderation, most of them produced far more disorder than convenience.
elegant: Pennsylvania innovated by lending paper bills of credit -- land-secured, interest-bearing, transferable, and legal tender -- raising moderate revenue for its frugal government. Success required three conditions: demand for paper currency, government credibility, and moderation in issuance (never exceeding the gold and silver the paper replaced). Other colonies copied the scheme but, lacking moderation, caused more disorder than benefit.
summary: Pennsylvania raised revenue by issuing paper bills of credit secured by land, functioning as legal tender. This succeeded because of genuine demand for currency, government credibility, and disciplined issuance. Other colonies that imitated the scheme without restraint created financial disorder.
distilled: Pennsylvania successfully raised revenue through disciplined paper currency issuance, but other colonies that copied the scheme without moderation created financial chaos.
notes: Pennsylvania paper currency experiment -- early American monetary policy -- three conditions for successful paper money -- land-backed currency -- colonial fiscal innovation -- monetary discipline vs. excess

refashioned: The unstable and perishable nature of capital stock and credit, however, makes them unsuitable as the principal foundations of the reliable, steady, and permanent revenue that alone can give a government security and dignity. No great nation that had advanced beyond the pastoral stage has ever derived most of its public revenue from such sources.
elegant: Capital and credit are too unstable to serve as the principal foundation of government revenue, which requires permanence and reliability. No advanced nation has ever depended primarily on such sources.
summary: Capital stock and credit are too unstable to reliably fund government. No advanced nation has ever derived the majority of its public revenue from these sources.
distilled: Capital and credit are too unstable and perishable to serve as the primary source of reliable government revenue.
notes: Instability of capital-based revenue -- permanence requirement for government finance -- credit as unreliable revenue base -- transition to land as more stable source

refashioned: Land is a far more stable and permanent asset, and accordingly, the rent from public lands has been the principal source of public revenue for many great nations well beyond the pastoral stage. The ancient republics of Greece and Italy long derived most of their necessary government revenue from the produce or rent of public lands. Crown lands similarly constituted the greater part of revenue for the ancient European sovereigns.
elegant: Land provides the stable, permanent revenue base that capital cannot. Public land rents funded the ancient republics of Greece and Italy, and crown lands long constituted the principal revenue of European sovereigns.
summary: Land provides the stable revenue that capital cannot. Ancient Greek and Italian republics, along with early European monarchies, all relied primarily on public land rents to fund government.
distilled: Public land rent has historically been the most stable and widely used source of government revenue, from ancient Greece and Rome through medieval Europe.
notes: Land rent as stable revenue -- public lands in ancient republics -- crown lands in medieval Europe -- contrast with unstable capital-based revenue

refashioned: War and preparation for war are the two circumstances that, in modern times, account for most of a great state's necessary expenditure. But in the ancient republics of Greece and Italy, every citizen was a soldier who both served and prepared for service at his own expense. Neither circumstance, therefore, imposed any significant cost on the state. The rent from even a moderately sized public estate could have been fully sufficient to cover all other necessary government expenses.
elegant: War dominates modern state expenditure, but ancient Greek and Italian citizen-soldiers served at their own expense -- so military costs barely burdened the state. A moderate public estate's rent could cover all other government needs.
summary: Modern states spend most of their revenue on war and military preparation. Ancient republics avoided this burden because citizen-soldiers funded themselves, meaning even a modest public estate could cover all government costs.
distilled: Ancient republics needed little public revenue because citizen-soldiers bore their own military costs, unlike modern states where war consumes most government spending.
notes: Military expenditure ancient vs. modern -- citizen-soldier model -- self-funded military service -- minimal ancient government costs -- land rent sufficiency for small government

refashioned: In the ancient European monarchies, the customs and manners of the time sufficiently prepared the population for war, and under their feudal tenure obligations, soldiers maintained themselves at their own or their lords' expense without imposing any new charge on the sovereign. Most other government costs were very modest. The administration of justice, as we have seen, was a source of revenue rather than an expense. The labor of country people for three days before and after harvest was considered sufficient for building and maintaining all the roads, bridges, and other public works the country's commerce required. In those days, the sovereign's main expense was maintaining his own family and household. His household officers were therefore the great officers of state: the lord treasurer received rents, the lord steward and lord chamberlain managed household expenses, the lord constable and lord marshal oversaw the stables, and the keepers of his castle-houses served as a kind of military governor -- the only military officers it was necessary to maintain in peacetime. Under these circumstances, the rent from a great landed estate could ordinarily cover all necessary government expenses.
elegant: In feudal Europe, soldiers served at their own expense, justice generated revenue, public works were built by corvee labor, and the sovereign's main cost was his household. His household officers -- treasurer, steward, chamberlain, constable, marshal -- were the great officers of state. Castle keepers were the only standing military personnel. A great landed estate's rent could cover all government costs.
summary: Feudal European governments were cheap to run: soldiers funded themselves, justice earned revenue, corvee labor built roads, and the sovereign's household was the main expense. The household staff doubled as officers of state, and castle keepers were the only permanent military. Crown land rents easily covered everything.
distilled: Feudal European government was so inexpensive -- with self-funded soldiers, revenue-generating courts, and corvee labor -- that crown land rents alone could cover all state expenses.
notes: Feudal fiscal structure -- household officers as officers of state -- corvee labor for infrastructure -- justice as revenue source -- minimal standing military -- castle keepers as governors -- self-funding feudal military obligations

refashioned: In the current state of most civilized European monarchies, the rent from all the land in the country -- even if managed as well as it could be under a single owner -- would probably not equal the ordinary revenue these governments collect from the people, even in peacetime. Britain's ordinary revenue, for example, including not only current annual expenses but also interest on the public debt and sinking fund contributions, exceeds ten million pounds per year.
elegant: In modern European monarchies, even the total rent of all national land under ideal management would fall short of ordinary peacetime government revenue. Britain's ordinary revenue -- covering current expenses, debt interest, and debt reduction -- exceeds ten million pounds annually.
summary: Modern government has grown so expensive that even the total rent of all national land could not cover peacetime revenue needs. Britain alone requires over ten million pounds annually for current expenses, debt interest, and debt reduction.
distilled: Modern government expenses so far exceed what national land rents could produce that even Britain's peacetime revenue needs surpass ten million pounds annually.
notes: Growth of government expenditure beyond land-rent capacity -- Britain's fiscal position -- public debt service as major expense -- transition from land-rent to tax-based state finance

refashioned: Yet the land tax at four shillings in the pound falls short of two million pounds per year. This so-called land tax is supposed to represent one-fifth of the rent not only of all land but also of all houses and the interest on all capital stock in Great Britain -- excluding only capital lent to the government or employed as farming stock. A very considerable portion of this tax actually comes from house rents and capital stock interest rather than from land rent proper.
elegant: Britain's land tax at four shillings in the pound yields under two million pounds -- supposedly one-fifth of all land rents, house rents, and capital interest combined (excluding government loans and farming stock). Much of this actually comes from houses and capital, not land.
summary: Britain's land tax yields under two million pounds, nominally representing one-fifth of all land rents, house rents, and capital interest. In practice, much of the revenue comes from houses and capital rather than land rent itself.
distilled: Britain's land tax yields under two million pounds and actually taxes house rents and capital interest alongside land rent, despite its name.
notes: British land tax structure -- nominal vs. actual tax base -- four shillings in the pound rate -- tax on houses and capital disguised as land tax -- under two million pound yield

refashioned: The land tax of the City of London at four shillings in the pound amounts to 123,399 pounds; Westminster's to 63,092 pounds; Whitehall and St. James's palaces to 30,754 pounds. A similar proportion of land tax is assessed on all other cities and towns corporate in the kingdom, arising almost entirely from house rents or from the estimated interest on trading and capital stock. By this assessment, therefore, the entire mass of revenue from all land rents, all house rents, and all capital stock interest in Great Britain -- excluding only capital lent to the government or used in farming -- does not exceed ten million pounds per year: the ordinary revenue the government collects from the people even in peacetime.
elegant: London's land tax yields 123,399 pounds, Westminster's 63,092, and the palaces 30,754 -- all derived mainly from house rents and capital interest, not land. By this assessment, all land rents, house rents, and capital interest combined total only about ten million pounds -- exactly what the government already collects in peacetime revenue.
summary: Urban land taxes derive almost entirely from house rents and capital interest rather than land. By this assessment, the total of all British land rents, house rents, and capital interest barely equals the ten million pounds the government already collects in peacetime.
distilled: Britain's combined land rents, house rents, and capital interest total roughly ten million pounds -- the same amount the government already collects in ordinary peacetime revenue.
notes: Urban vs. rural land tax composition -- London, Westminster, palace assessments -- total national income approximation -- government revenue equals estimated national rent and interest income

refashioned: The assessment by which Great Britain is rated for the land tax is undoubtedly, taking the kingdom as a whole, far below the real value -- though in several particular counties and districts it is reportedly close to accurate. Land rent alone, excluding house rents and capital interest, has been estimated by many at twenty million pounds -- an estimate made largely at random that is as likely to be too high as too low. But even if Britain's lands do yield twenty million pounds in rent in their current state of cultivation, they could hardly produce half that -- probably not even a quarter -- if they all belonged to a single owner and were subjected to the negligent, expensive, and oppressive management of his agents and overseers.
elegant: Britain's land tax assessment is well below real values nationally, though accurate in some areas. Land rent alone is estimated at around twenty million pounds. But under single ownership with negligent agent management, these same lands would produce at most half -- probably a quarter -- of that rent. Private ownership and competition are essential for productive land management.
summary: Britain's land tax assessment falls well below actual values. While total land rent is estimated at twenty million pounds, the same land under single-owner management by negligent agents would yield at most half that amount, demonstrating the superiority of dispersed private ownership.
distilled: Britain's land tax vastly understates real values, and centralized ownership would reduce twenty million pounds in land rent to a fraction through negligent management.
notes: Land tax undervaluation -- estimated twenty million in land rent -- single-owner management inefficiency -- principal-agent problem in estate management -- argument against crown land consolidation

refashioned:
Britain's crown lands currently yield less than a quarter of the rent they could produce under private ownership. If the crown lands were more extensive, they would probably be even worse managed.

The revenue the general population derives from land is proportional not to the rent but to the total produce. The entire annual produce of a country's land, minus what is reserved for seed, is either consumed by the people or exchanged for other things they consume. Whatever suppresses land productivity below its potential reduces the people's revenue even more than it reduces the landlord's rent. If land yielding ten million pounds in rent in one state of cultivation could yield twenty million in another -- with rent being a third of total produce in both cases -- the landlords would lose ten million, but the people would lose thirty million in total produce (minus seed). The country's population would be smaller by the number of people that thirty million pounds of produce (minus seed) could support, distributed across the various ranks of society.
elegant: Crown lands yield under a quarter of their potential rent under private management. But the people's loss from poor land management exceeds the landlord's loss: since rent is roughly a third of produce, if poor management reduces rent by ten million, total produce falls by thirty million, reducing both the people's revenue and the population the land could support.
summary: Crown lands yield far below their potential. Poor land management harms the general population more than landlords because rent is only a third of total produce -- so a ten million pound rent reduction means a thirty million pound loss in total output, reducing both national revenue and supportable population.
distilled: Poor land management harms the general population three times more than landlords because rent is only a third of total produce, so lost rent implies triple the loss in total output.
notes: Crown land inefficiency -- rent vs. total produce distinction -- multiplier effect of land mismanagement on population -- argument for privatization of crown lands -- land productivity and population capacity

refashioned: Although no civilized European state currently derives most of its public revenue from state-owned land rents, all the great monarchies still possess many large tracts of crown land. These are generally forests -- often forests where you can travel several miles without finding a single tree -- representing a sheer waste of productive and population capacity. In every great European monarchy, selling the crown lands would raise an enormous sum. If applied to paying off public debts, this would free up far greater revenue than those lands have ever generated for the crown. In countries where well-cultivated land sells at thirty years' purchase of its rent, the unimproved, low-rented crown lands could easily sell at forty, fifty, or even sixty years' purchase. The crown could immediately enjoy the revenue this sale price would redeem from debt. Within a few years, it would gain additional revenue as newly privatized lands became well improved and cultivated. The increased production would grow the population by expanding the people's revenue and consumption. And the crown's revenue from customs and excise duties would necessarily rise alongside the people's revenue and consumption.
elegant: European monarchies hold vast crown lands -- often barren forests -- that waste productive capacity. Selling them to pay public debts would free far more revenue than these lands ever generated. Privatized crown lands would quickly improve, boosting production, population, consumption, and consequently customs and excise revenue. Unimproved crown lands could sell at 40-60 years' purchase, immediately redeeming debt and generating cascading economic benefits.
summary: Crown lands across Europe are mostly unproductive wastelands. Selling them to retire public debt would free more revenue than the lands ever produced, and privatization would trigger a virtuous cycle: improved cultivation would increase production, population, consumption, and tax revenue from customs and excise.
distilled: Selling unproductive crown lands to pay public debt would free more revenue than the lands ever generated, while privatization would boost production, population, and tax revenue.
notes: Crown land privatization argument -- land sale at years' purchase -- debt redemption through asset sale -- virtuous cycle of privatization: improvement, production, population, consumption, tax revenue -- crown forests as wasted land

refashioned: The revenue a civilized monarchy derives from crown lands, though it appears to cost individuals nothing, actually costs society more than perhaps any other equal amount of crown revenue. It would always be in society's interest to replace this revenue with some other equivalent source and to distribute the lands among the people -- which could be done best, perhaps, through public sale.
elegant: Crown land revenue appears costless but actually costs society more than any other equal revenue source. Society would benefit from replacing it with equivalent revenue and selling the lands to private buyers.
summary: Crown land revenue has a hidden cost to society greater than any other equal revenue source. The optimal solution is to sell crown lands publicly and replace the revenue through other means.
distilled: Crown land revenue appears free but imposes the highest hidden cost on society of any revenue source, making privatization through public sale the best policy.
notes: Hidden costs of crown land -- opportunity cost argument -- privatization advocacy -- public sale as optimal distribution method -- apparent vs. real cost of government revenue

refashioned:
Lands maintained for pleasure and display -- parks, gardens, public walks, and similar amenities that are everywhere considered sources of expense rather than revenue -- seem to be the only lands that should properly belong to the crown in a great civilized monarchy.

Since both public stock and public lands -- the two revenue sources that may specifically belong to the sovereign -- are both unsuitable and insufficient for funding a great civilized state's necessary expenses, most of that expense must be covered by taxes of various kinds: the people contributing part of their private revenue to create public revenue for the sovereign or commonwealth.
elegant: Only amenity lands -- parks, gardens, public walks -- should belong to the crown. Since the sovereign's own funds (stock and land) are both inadequate and ill-suited for funding a great state, most government revenue must come from taxation: citizens contributing part of their private income to fund public needs.
summary: Only ornamental lands should remain with the crown. Since sovereign-owned stock and land are insufficient to fund modern government, the bulk of public revenue must come from taxation of the people's private income.
distilled: Since the sovereign's own stock and land cannot fund modern government, most public revenue must come from taxes on private income, with only parks and gardens remaining as crown property.
notes: Crown property limited to amenities -- transition to taxation as primary revenue -- inadequacy of sovereign's own resources -- fundamental justification for taxation -- opening of tax theory section

refashioned: As shown in the first book of this work, the private revenue of individuals ultimately derives from three sources: rent, profit, and wages. Every tax must ultimately be paid from one or more of these three sources. I shall attempt to give the best account I can of, first, taxes intended to fall on rent; second, those intended to fall on profit; third, those intended to fall on wages; and fourth, those intended to fall on all three sources indiscriminately. These four categories will divide the second part of this chapter into four articles, three of which require further subdivisions. As the following review will show, many taxes are not ultimately paid from the source of revenue they were intended to target.
elegant: All private revenue comes from three sources: rent, profit, and wages. Every tax ultimately falls on one or more of these. The following analysis examines taxes targeting rent, profit, wages, and all three indiscriminately. Importantly, many taxes end up being paid from different sources than intended -- a key theme of the review that follows.
summary: All private income derives from rent, profit, or wages, and every tax must ultimately fall on one or more of these. The following analysis categorizes taxes by their intended target, but reveals that many taxes are ultimately paid from sources other than those originally intended.
distilled: Every tax ultimately falls on rent, profit, or wages, but many taxes end up being paid from different sources than their designers intended.
notes: Three sources of revenue: rent, profit, wages -- tax incidence vs. intent -- framework for tax analysis -- cross-reference to Book 1 on income sources -- tax shifting between sources

refashioned:
Before examining particular taxes, four general maxims about taxation must be established.

First: the citizens of every state should contribute to the support of government as nearly as possible in proportion to their respective abilities -- that is, in proportion to the income they enjoy under the state's protection. The cost of government to a nation's citizens is like the management fee charged to the joint tenants of a great estate, who all contribute in proportion to their respective interests. Whether this maxim is observed or neglected determines what is called the equality or inequality of taxation. Any tax that falls exclusively on just one of the three revenue sources is necessarily unequal insofar as it leaves the other two untouched. In the following analysis of different taxes, I shall generally not pursue this kind of inequality further, confining my observations mostly to the inequality that arises when a particular tax falls unevenly on the specific type of revenue it is supposed to affect.
elegant: Four maxims of taxation -- First: citizens should contribute in proportion to their ability, meaning in proportion to their income under state protection, like tenants of an estate paying proportional management fees. This is the principle of tax equality. Any tax hitting only one revenue source (rent, profit, or wages) is inherently unequal. The analysis that follows focuses on inequality within each targeted revenue source rather than across sources.
summary: Smith's first maxim of taxation: citizens should contribute proportionally to their income, like tenants sharing estate management costs. Taxes falling on only one of the three revenue sources are inherently unequal, but the analysis focuses primarily on whether taxes fall evenly within their targeted source.
distilled: Smith's first tax maxim: citizens should contribute to government in proportion to their income, establishing the principle of tax equality.
notes: Smith's four maxims of taxation -- first maxim: proportional contribution (ability to pay) -- equality of taxation -- estate management analogy -- inherent inequality of single-source taxes -- foundational principles of tax theory

refashioned: Second: the tax each person must pay should be certain, not arbitrary. The timing, method, and amount of payment should all be clear and transparent to the taxpayer and everyone else. Otherwise, every taxpayer is placed at the mercy of the tax collector, who can inflate the tax on anyone he dislikes or extort bribes by threatening to do so. Uncertainty in taxation encourages the arrogance and corruption of tax collectors -- a class of people who are naturally unpopular even when they are neither arrogant nor corrupt. The certainty of each person's tax obligation is so important that, as the experience of all nations seems to confirm, a considerable degree of inequality in taxation is far less harmful than even a small degree of uncertainty.
elegant: Second maxim: taxes must be certain, not arbitrary. Timing, method, and amount must be transparent. Otherwise, taxpayers are at the mercy of collectors who can inflate bills or extort bribes. Tax uncertainty breeds collector arrogance and corruption. Certainty matters so much that considerable inequality is less harmful than even slight uncertainty.
summary: Smith's second maxim: taxes must be certain and transparent in timing, method, and amount. Arbitrary taxation empowers corrupt collectors and harms taxpayers. Certainty is so important that significant inequality in taxation is preferable to even minor uncertainty.
distilled: Tax certainty -- in timing, method, and amount -- matters so much that considerable inequality is less harmful than even slight uncertainty.
notes: Second maxim: certainty over arbitrariness -- tax collector corruption -- certainty vs. equality trade-off -- transparency in taxation -- power dynamics between collector and taxpayer

refashioned: Third: every tax should be collected at the time and in the manner most convenient for the taxpayer. A tax on land or house rent, payable at the same time the rent is normally due, is collected when the taxpayer is most likely to have the means to pay. Taxes on luxury consumer goods are ultimately paid by the consumer in a particularly convenient way -- he pays them little by little as he buys the goods. Since he is free to buy or not as he chooses, any significant inconvenience from such taxes is his own fault.
elegant: Third maxim: taxes should be collected when and how it is most convenient for the taxpayer. Rent taxes timed to rent payments catch taxpayers when they have money. Luxury taxes are especially convenient -- paid gradually through purchases, and entirely voluntary since no one is forced to buy.
summary: Smith's third maxim: taxes should be levied at the most convenient time and in the most convenient manner for the taxpayer. Rent taxes timed to rent payments and luxury taxes paid through voluntary purchases exemplify this principle.
distilled: Taxes should be collected at the time and in the manner most convenient for the taxpayer, such as rent taxes timed to rent payments or luxury taxes paid through voluntary purchases.
notes: Third maxim: convenience of payment -- timing aligned to income receipt -- luxury taxes as voluntary and gradual -- consumer sovereignty in taxation

refashioned: Fourth: every tax should be designed to take and keep out of the people's pockets as little as possible beyond what it actually delivers to the public treasury. A tax can drain much more from the people than it delivers to the treasury in four ways. First, collection may require a large bureaucracy whose salaries consume most of the revenue, and whose additional demands impose a further burden on the people. Second, it may obstruct productive activity and discourage people from entering businesses that would provide employment and livelihoods for many, thus diminishing the very resources from which people could pay taxes. Third, through the fines and penalties imposed on those who unsuccessfully try to evade the tax, it may ruin individuals and destroy the economic benefit their capital would have provided the community. An unwise tax creates a powerful temptation to smuggle, and the penalties for smuggling must rise in proportion to that temptation. The law thus first creates the temptation and then punishes those who yield to it -- and typically makes the punishment harsher in exact proportion to the temptation, the very circumstance that should reduce it. Fourth, by subjecting people to frequent visits and intrusive examination by tax collectors, it exposes them to much needless trouble, harassment, and oppression. Though harassment is not technically an expense, it is certainly equivalent to the cost at which anyone would willingly purchase relief from it. It is through one or more of these four mechanisms that taxes are frequently far more burdensome to the people than they are beneficial to the sovereign.
elegant: Fourth maxim: taxes should minimize the gap between what leaves people's pockets and what reaches the treasury. Four mechanisms widen this gap: (1) costly collection bureaucracies, (2) discouragement of productive industry, (3) ruinous penalties for evasion that destroy useful capital -- with the law perversely creating temptation then punishing proportionally to it, and (4) harassment through intrusive tax collection. These inefficiencies make taxes far more burdensome to the people than beneficial to the sovereign.
summary: Smith's fourth maxim: taxes should minimize deadweight loss -- the gap between what taxpayers pay and what the treasury receives. Four mechanisms create waste: expensive collection bureaucracies, discouragement of productive activity, ruinous evasion penalties that destroy capital, and intrusive harassment by collectors.
distilled: Taxes should minimize the gap between what people pay and what the treasury receives, avoiding the four wastes of costly bureaucracy, discouraged industry, ruinous evasion penalties, and intrusive harassment.
notes: Fourth maxim: efficiency in taxation -- deadweight loss concept -- four sources of tax inefficiency -- smuggling as rational response to bad taxes -- perverse incentive structure in evasion penalties -- tax harassment as economic cost -- foundational public finance theory

refashioned: The obvious justice and usefulness of these maxims have commended them, to varying degrees, to all nations. Every nation has tried, to the best of its ability, to make its taxes as equal, as certain, and as convenient as possible in both timing and method of payment, and as efficient as possible relative to the revenue they produce. The following brief review of some principal taxes across different eras and countries will show that not all nations have been equally successful in these efforts.
elegant: All nations have recognized the justice of these four maxims and attempted to follow them -- pursuing equality, certainty, convenience, and efficiency in taxation. The following historical review shows that their success has varied greatly.
summary: Every nation has attempted to follow these four tax principles -- equality, certainty, convenience, and efficiency -- but with widely varying degrees of success, as the following historical review demonstrates.
distilled: All nations have aspired to the four tax maxims of equality, certainty, convenience, and efficiency, but their success has varied greatly across time and place.
notes: Universal recognition of tax principles -- gap between aspiration and achievement -- transition to historical survey of taxation -- comparative fiscal policy

refashioned:
ARTICLE I -- Taxes upon Rent -- Taxes upon the Rent of Land.

A tax on land rent can be imposed in one of two ways: according to a fixed assessment where each district is valued at a set rent that is never afterward changed, or in a manner that varies with every change in the actual rent, rising or falling with the land's improvement or decline in cultivation.
elegant: Land rent taxes come in two forms: a fixed assessment per district that never changes, or a variable tax that rises and falls with actual rent as cultivation improves or declines.
summary: Land rent can be taxed either at a fixed rate based on an unchanging valuation of each district, or at a variable rate that adjusts with actual changes in the rent as land is improved or neglected.
distilled: Land rent taxes are either fixed at an unchanging valuation or variable, adjusting with actual changes in rent as cultivation improves or declines.
notes: Two models of land taxation -- fixed vs. variable assessment -- introduction to detailed analysis of land tax systems -- Article I of tax analysis

refashioned: A land tax assessed on each district at an unchanging rate, like Britain's, may be equal when first established but necessarily becomes unequal over time as different areas improve or decline at different rates. In England, the valuation established under William and Mary's 4th-year statute was very unequal even at the start. This tax therefore violates the first of the four maxims but satisfies the other three perfectly. It is entirely certain. Its payment timing matches the rent, making it as convenient as possible. Though the landlord is always the true taxpayer, the tenant usually advances the payment and deducts it from the rent. The tax requires far fewer collection officers than any other yielding comparable revenue. Since the tax on each district does not rise with rising rents, the sovereign does not share in the landlord's improvements. Those improvements sometimes help relieve other landlords in the district from their share of the tax, but any resulting increase on a particular estate is always so small that it never discourages improvement or suppresses the land's productivity. Having no tendency to reduce output, it cannot raise the price of produce. It does not obstruct industry and imposes no inconvenience on the landlord beyond paying the tax itself. The landlord's advantage from the fixed valuation, however, has been mainly due to circumstances unrelated to the tax's nature.
elegant: Britain's fixed-rate land tax was unequal from the start and grows more so over time (violating maxim 1), but perfectly satisfies the other three maxims: it is certain, conveniently timed with rent, and efficiently collected with few officers. Since the tax does not rise with improvements, it neither discourages investment nor reduces output. The landlord's gain from the fixed valuation, however, owes more to fortunate circumstances than to the tax's design.
summary: Britain's fixed land tax violates equality (maxim 1) but excels at certainty, convenience, and efficiency (maxims 2-4). By not rising with improvements, it avoids discouraging investment, though its benefits to landlords stem mainly from fortunate external circumstances rather than good design.
distilled: Britain's fixed land tax fails on equality but succeeds on certainty, convenience, and efficiency, and its unchanging rate avoids discouraging land improvement.
notes: British land tax under William and Mary -- evaluation against four maxims -- fixed valuation advantages and disadvantages -- tax does not capture improvement value -- tenant advances tax deducted from rent -- efficient collection

refashioned: This has been partly due to the great prosperity of nearly every part of the country: rents on almost all British estates have been continuously rising since this valuation was first established, while hardly any have fallen. Landlords have therefore almost universally gained the difference between the tax they would pay on their current rents and what they actually pay under the old valuation. Had circumstances been different -- had rents been gradually falling due to declining cultivation -- landlords would have lost this difference instead. In the conditions that have happened to prevail since the Revolution, the fixed valuation has been advantageous to landlords and harmful to the sovereign. Under different conditions, it might have benefited the sovereign at the landlords' expense.
elegant: Britain's fixed valuation has benefited landlords because rents have risen continuously since it was established -- landlords pay tax on old, lower values. Had rents fallen, the fixed valuation would have harmed landlords and benefited the sovereign. The outcome depends entirely on whether rents rise or fall over time.
summary: The fixed land tax valuation has benefited British landlords because rents have risen steadily since it was set, meaning they pay tax on outdated low values. Had rents fallen instead, the fixed valuation would have worked against landlords and in the sovereign's favor.
distilled: Britain's fixed land tax valuation happened to benefit landlords because rents rose continuously, but the same system would have harmed them had rents fallen.
notes: Contingent benefit of fixed valuation -- rising rents since the Glorious Revolution -- distributional effects depend on economic trends -- landlord windfall from economic growth -- sovereign's loss from fixed assessment

refashioned: Since the tax is paid in money and the land valuation is expressed in money, the stability of silver's value and the consistency of the coinage standard have also mattered. Had silver risen considerably in value, as it apparently did during the two centuries before the discovery of American mines, the fixed valuation could have been very oppressive to landlords. Had silver fallen considerably, as it certainly did for at least a century after that discovery, the same fixed valuation would have greatly reduced this branch of sovereign revenue. Had there been any significant alteration to the monetary standard -- either debasing the coinage by putting the same amount of silver into a lower denomination, or raising it by putting that silver into a higher one -- it would have hurt the landlord in one case and the sovereign in the other.
elegant: The fixed money valuation also depends on monetary stability. Rising silver values (pre-American mines) would have crushed landlords under the fixed assessment; falling silver (post-discovery) would have eroded sovereign revenue. Any debasement or elevation of the coinage standard would similarly redistribute the burden between landlord and sovereign.
summary: A fixed money valuation of land tax depends on monetary stability. Changes in silver's value or the coinage standard would shift the tax burden unfairly between landlords and the sovereign, making the system unreliable over long periods.
distilled: Fixed money valuations for land tax are vulnerable to changes in silver's value and coinage standards, which redistribute the burden between landlord and sovereign.
notes: Monetary stability and tax design -- silver value fluctuations -- American silver discovery effects -- coinage debasement risk -- interaction between monetary policy and taxation -- real vs. nominal tax burden

refashioned: Under circumstances somewhat different from those that have actually occurred, this fixed valuation could have been a very serious problem for either taxpayers or the state. Over the course of centuries, such circumstances must eventually arise. But though empires, like all human creations, have all eventually proved mortal, every empire aspires to immortality. Any constitutional arrangement meant to last as long as the empire itself should be suitable not just to particular circumstances but to all circumstances -- suited not to conditions that are temporary, occasional, or accidental, but to those that are permanent and unchanging.
elegant: Under different historical circumstances, fixed valuation would have been seriously harmful. Over centuries, such circumstances must inevitably arise. Since empires aspire to permanence even though all prove mortal, constitutional arrangements should be designed for all circumstances -- not just current ones, but those that are permanent and inevitable.
summary: Fixed valuations work only under favorable circumstances that cannot last forever. Since empires aspire to permanence, their fiscal institutions should be designed for all possible conditions, not just those that happen to prevail at any given moment.
distilled: Fiscal institutions should be designed for permanent conditions, not transient ones, because the favorable circumstances sustaining fixed valuations cannot last forever.
notes: Constitutional design for permanence -- mortality of empires -- robustness of fiscal institutions -- contingency planning in tax design -- temporary vs. permanent institutional design

refashioned: A land tax that varies with every change in rent -- rising and falling with the improvement or neglect of cultivation -- is recommended by the French economists (who call themselves the Physiocrats) as the most equitable of all taxes. They argue that all taxes ultimately fall on land rent and should therefore be imposed directly on the fund that must finally bear them. That all taxes should fall as equally as possible on their ultimate source is certainly true. But without entering into the disagreeable metaphysical arguments supporting their ingenious theory, the following review will sufficiently show which taxes actually fall on land rent and which fall on some other fund.
elegant: The Physiocrats recommend a variable land tax -- one tracking actual rent -- as the most equitable, arguing all taxes ultimately fall on land rent. While taxes should indeed target their ultimate source, the following analysis will show empirically which taxes actually fall on rent and which do not, without engaging the Physiocrats' metaphysical theory.
summary: The Physiocrats argue that since all taxes ultimately fall on land rent, a variable tax tracking actual rent is most equitable. Smith accepts the principle of taxing the ultimate source but will demonstrate empirically which taxes actually fall on rent, without endorsing Physiocratic theory.
distilled: The Physiocrats advocate a variable land tax as most equitable since all taxes supposedly fall on rent, but empirical analysis reveals which taxes actually do so.
notes: Physiocratic tax theory -- variable land tax advocacy -- all taxes fall on rent (Physiocratic claim) -- Smith's empirical rather than theoretical approach -- equitable taxation debate

refashioned: In the Venetian territory, all leased arable land is taxed at one-tenth of the rent. Leases are recorded in a public register maintained by revenue officers in each province or district. When a proprietor cultivates his own land, it is valued by fair estimation and he receives a one-fifth deduction from the tax, so he pays only eight rather than ten percent of the estimated rent.
elegant: Venice taxes leased arable land at 10% of rent, with leases recorded publicly. Owner-cultivated land is fairly valued with a one-fifth tax discount -- paying 8% instead of 10% -- to encourage proprietor farming.
summary: Venice taxes leased farmland at 10% of rent recorded in public registers. Owner-cultivated land receives a discount, paying only 8% of estimated rent, encouraging landowners to farm their own property.
distilled: Venice taxes leased farmland at 10% of registered rent and owner-farmed land at 8% of estimated rent, incentivizing direct cultivation.
notes: Venetian land tax system -- lease registration requirement -- 10% rent tax -- owner-cultivation discount -- public register as administrative tool -- incentive design in taxation

refashioned:
A land tax of this kind is certainly more equitable than England's, though it might not be quite as certain, and the assessment process might cause the landlord considerably more trouble. It might also be more expensive to collect.

However, an administrative system could perhaps be devised that would largely prevent this uncertainty and moderate the expense.
elegant: A variable land tax like Venice's is more equitable than England's fixed tax but potentially less certain, more troublesome for landlords, and costlier to collect. Good administrative design could mitigate these drawbacks.
summary: A variable land tax is more equitable than a fixed one but introduces uncertainty, administrative burden, and collection costs. These downsides could be managed through careful institutional design.
distilled: Variable land taxes are more equitable but less certain and costlier than fixed ones, though good administrative design can mitigate these disadvantages.
notes: Trade-offs between equity and certainty in land taxation -- administrative design as solution -- variable vs. fixed land tax comparison -- collection costs

refashioned: For example, landlords and tenants could be jointly required to register their leases in a public record. Appropriate penalties could be imposed for concealing or misrepresenting any lease terms. If part of those penalties were payable to whichever party informed against and convicted the other of concealment or misrepresentation, this would effectively prevent them from colluding to defraud the public revenue. All the lease terms could be reliably known from such a register.
elegant: Requiring public registration of leases, with penalties for concealment split to reward informants, would prevent landlord-tenant collusion against the tax system. A public register would make all lease terms transparent.
summary: Public lease registration with penalties for concealment -- rewarding whichever party exposes the other's fraud -- would prevent collusion between landlords and tenants and ensure transparent tax assessment.
distilled: Public lease registration with whistle-blower incentives would prevent landlord-tenant collusion and ensure accurate tax assessment.
notes: Lease registration as administrative tool -- whistle-blower incentive mechanism -- anti-collusion design -- transparency in tax administration -- information asymmetry solution

refashioned: Some landlords, instead of raising the rent, charge a lump-sum fine for renewing a lease. This practice is usually the tactic of a spendthrift who sells a future revenue stream of much greater value for a sum of ready money. It is usually harmful to the landlord, frequently harmful to the tenant, and always harmful to the community. It often strips the tenant of so much capital that it impairs his ability to cultivate the land, making it harder for him to pay even a small rent than it would have been to pay a much larger one. Whatever reduces his ability to cultivate the land necessarily suppresses the most important part of the community's revenue. By taxing such lease-renewal fines more heavily than ordinary rent, this harmful practice could be discouraged -- to the considerable benefit of the landlord, the tenant, the sovereign, and the entire community.
elegant: Lease-renewal fines -- lump sums charged instead of raising rent -- are a spendthrift's tactic that harms landlords, tenants, and the community by stripping tenant capital and reducing cultivation. Taxing these fines more heavily than ordinary rent would discourage this practice, benefiting everyone.
summary: Charging lump-sum fines for lease renewal rather than raising rent is a harmful practice that strips tenant capital and reduces cultivation. Heavier taxation of such fines would discourage this practice, benefiting landlords, tenants, and the community alike.
distilled: Lease-renewal fines harm everyone by stripping tenant capital and reducing cultivation, and should be taxed more heavily than ordinary rent to discourage the practice.
notes: Lease-renewal fines as harmful practice -- present vs. future value trade-off -- tenant capital depletion -- impact on cultivation and community revenue -- differential taxation as behavioral incentive

refashioned: Some leases prescribe a specific mode of cultivation and crop rotation for the tenant during the entire lease term. This requirement, generally reflecting the landlord's misplaced confidence in his own superior agricultural knowledge -- a confidence usually quite unfounded -- should be treated as an additional rent: a rent paid in service rather than money. To discourage this generally foolish practice, such service-rents could be valued somewhat high and consequently taxed at a somewhat higher rate than ordinary money rents.
elegant: Leases prescribing cultivation methods reflect landlords' usually unfounded conceit about farming knowledge. Such requirements are effectively rent paid in service, and taxing them above ordinary money rents would discourage this generally foolish practice.
summary: When landlords dictate farming methods in leases, this reflects misplaced confidence in their own agricultural knowledge and functions as rent paid in service. Taxing such service-rents above ordinary money rents would discourage the practice.
distilled: Landlord-prescribed cultivation methods should be treated as service-rent and taxed above money-rent rates to discourage this typically misguided practice.
notes: Landlord interference in cultivation -- conceit of superior knowledge -- service-rent concept -- differential taxation as deterrent -- freedom of tenant management

refashioned: Some landlords require rent in kind -- corn, cattle, poultry, wine, oil, and the like -- while others require rent in labor. Such rents are always more harmful to the tenant than beneficial to the landlord: they either take more or keep more from the tenant's pocket than they put into the landlord's. In every country where such practices prevail, tenants are poor and wretched, roughly in proportion to the extent of the practice. By valuing such rents somewhat high and taxing them at a higher rate than ordinary money rents, this practice -- harmful to the entire community -- might perhaps be sufficiently discouraged.
elegant: Rents in kind (crops, livestock) or in labor always harm tenants more than they benefit landlords, and wherever they prevail, tenants are impoverished proportionally. Higher valuation and taxation of such rents compared to money rents could discourage this community-harming practice.
summary: Rents paid in kind or labor extract more from tenants than they deliver to landlords, impoverishing tenants wherever such practices prevail. Taxing these arrangements more heavily than money rents would discourage them.
distilled: Rents in kind or labor harm tenants more than they benefit landlords, and heavier taxation could discourage these practices that impoverish tenants everywhere they occur.
notes: In-kind and labor rent -- inefficiency of non-monetary rents -- tenant impoverishment -- differential taxation to discourage harmful practices -- monetization of rent as improvement

refashioned: When a landlord chooses to farm part of his own land, the rent could be estimated by fair arbitration among neighboring farmers and landlords, chosen equally by both parties, and a moderate tax abatement could be granted -- as in the Venetian territory -- provided the self-farmed land did not exceed a certain area. Encouraging landlords to cultivate some of their own land is important because their capital is generally larger than their tenants', and even with less skill, they can often raise more produce. Landlords can afford to experiment and are generally inclined to do so. Their failed experiments cause only moderate personal losses, while their successes contribute to the improvement and better cultivation of the whole country. However, the tax abatement should encourage self-cultivation only up to a point. If most landlords were tempted to farm all their own land, the country -- instead of having sober, industrious tenants bound by self-interest to cultivate as well as their capital and skill allow -- would be filled with idle and wasteful bailiffs whose mismanagement would soon degrade cultivation and reduce the annual produce, diminishing not only their masters' revenue but the most important part of the nation's income.
elegant: Landlords farming their own land should receive modest tax abatements, since their greater capital enables experimentation and improvement that benefits the whole country. But this should be limited: if most landlords farmed all their land, sober tenants would be replaced by idle bailiffs whose mismanagement would degrade cultivation, reducing both landlord revenue and national output.
summary: Tax abatements should encourage landlords to farm some of their own land, since their greater capital enables experimentation that benefits agriculture nationally. But excessive self-farming would replace industrious tenants with negligent bailiffs, degrading cultivation and reducing national output.
distilled: Limited tax abatements for landlord self-cultivation encourage beneficial agricultural experimentation, but must be capped to prevent the replacement of industrious tenants with negligent bailiffs.
notes: Landlord self-cultivation incentive -- Venetian model -- landlord capital advantage -- experimentation and agricultural innovation -- bailiff problem -- optimal scope of self-farming -- tenant vs. bailiff management quality

refashioned: Such an administrative system might eliminate any uncertainty from this kind of tax that could cause either oppression or inconvenience to the taxpayer, while simultaneously introducing into ordinary land management a policy framework that would contribute significantly to the general improvement and good cultivation of the country.
elegant: A well-designed administrative system could eliminate uncertainty from variable land taxes while simultaneously promoting better land management and national agricultural improvement.
summary: Proper administrative design can make variable land taxes both certain and beneficial, simultaneously eliminating taxpayer oppression and promoting national agricultural improvement.
distilled: Good administrative design can make variable land taxes both certain for taxpayers and beneficial for national agricultural improvement.
notes: Administrative design solving tax problems -- dual benefit: certainty plus agricultural improvement -- tax policy as agricultural policy -- institutional design as solution to trade-offs

refashioned: Collecting a variable land tax would undoubtedly cost somewhat more than one based on a fixed valuation. Additional expense would be incurred for both the register offices needed in each district and the occasional valuations of owner-occupied land. However, this additional cost could be quite moderate -- well below the collection costs of many other taxes that generate far less revenue than a well-designed variable land tax easily could.
elegant: Variable land taxes cost more to collect than fixed ones, requiring district register offices and periodic valuations. But these costs would be moderate and well below those of many other taxes that yield far less revenue.
summary: Though a variable land tax costs more to collect than a fixed one, the additional expense for register offices and valuations would be moderate and easily justified by the superior revenue it could generate.
distilled: The additional collection costs of a variable land tax are moderate and justified by its superior revenue potential compared to many other more expensive taxes.
notes: Collection costs of variable vs. fixed land tax -- register offices -- periodic valuations -- cost-benefit comparison with other taxes -- administrative expense as investment in revenue

refashioned: The most important objection to a variable land tax is that it might discourage land improvement. A landlord would naturally be less inclined to invest in improvements when the sovereign, who contributed nothing to the expense, would share in the profit. But even this objection could perhaps be addressed by allowing the landlord, before beginning improvements, to establish his land's current value jointly with revenue officers through fair arbitration by an equal number of landlords and farmers chosen by both sides. He would then be taxed at this valuation for enough years to fully compensate him for his investment. Directing the sovereign's attention toward land improvement -- through his interest in increasing his own revenue -- is one of the principal advantages proposed by this type of land tax.
elegant: The key objection to variable land taxes -- that they discourage improvement since the sovereign shares in profits without sharing costs -- can be addressed by fixing the tax at pre-improvement valuations for a sufficient indemnification period. This approach both protects the landlord's investment incentive and gives the sovereign a stake in promoting agricultural improvement.
summary: Variable land taxes risk discouraging improvement because the sovereign profits without investing. The solution is to freeze the tax at pre-improvement levels for a set period, protecting the landlord while aligning the sovereign's interest with agricultural progress.
distilled: The disincentive to improve land under variable taxation can be solved by freezing assessments at pre-improvement values for an indemnification period.
notes: Improvement disincentive in variable land taxes -- indemnification period as solution -- joint valuation mechanism -- sovereign's interest in land improvement -- aligning incentives between landlord and sovereign

refashioned: The indemnification period allowed the landlord should not be much longer than necessary for its purpose, lest the remoteness of future tax increases too greatly weaken the sovereign's incentive to promote improvement. It would be better, however, to err on the side of making it somewhat too long rather than too short. No incentive encouraging the sovereign's attention can ever compensate for even the slightest discouragement to the landlord's. The sovereign's attention can at best be only a very general and vague consideration of what is likely to improve cultivation across his dominions as a whole.
elegant: The indemnification period should not greatly exceed what is necessary, but it is better too long than too short. No sovereign incentive can compensate for even the slightest discouragement to the landlord, whose detailed local knowledge always trumps the sovereign's general, vague overview of national cultivation.
summary: The tax freeze for improvements should be long enough to fully protect the landlord but not so long as to eliminate the sovereign's interest in promoting agriculture. When in doubt, err on the side of the landlord, whose detailed attention to his land matters more than the sovereign's broad overview.
distilled: Indemnification periods should favor the landlord over the sovereign because the landlord's detailed attention to his land is always more valuable than the sovereign's general overview.
notes: Optimal indemnification period -- landlord attention vs. sovereign attention -- local knowledge superiority -- balancing incentives -- erring on side of private investment

refashioned: The landlord's attention is a particular, detailed consideration of the most advantageous use for every inch of ground on his estate. The sovereign's principal role should be to encourage both landlord and farmer by every means possible -- by allowing both to pursue their own interests in their own way and according to their own judgment, by providing the most complete security that they will enjoy the full reward of their own industry, and by creating the most extensive market for their produce through establishing the easiest and safest transport routes by both land and water throughout his dominions, along with the most unrestricted freedom of export to all other nations.
elegant: The landlord focuses on the best use of every inch of his estate. The sovereign's role is to enable this: secure property rights, freedom to pursue self-interest, and extensive markets through good transport infrastructure and unrestricted export freedom. The sovereign governs best by empowering private initiative.
summary: The landlord provides detailed management of his estate while the sovereign's role is to create enabling conditions: secure property rights, freedom to pursue self-interest, good transportation infrastructure, and unrestricted trade. The best governance empowers private initiative.
distilled: The sovereign should encourage agriculture not by managing land directly but by securing property rights, enabling free markets, building transport infrastructure, and allowing unrestricted exports.
notes: Division of roles: landlord (micro-management) vs. sovereign (enabling conditions) -- property rights security -- free trade advocacy -- transport infrastructure -- laissez-faire principles -- sovereign as enabler not manager

refashioned: If such an administrative system could manage this tax so as to provide not discouragement but actual encouragement to land improvement, it would seem unlikely to cause the landlord any other inconvenience beyond the unavoidable obligation of paying the tax. Through all variations in society's condition -- whether agriculture improves or declines -- and through all changes in silver's value and the coinage standard, such a tax would automatically adjust to actual conditions without any government intervention. It would be equally just and equitable across all such changes. It would therefore be far more suitable as a permanent and unalterable regulation -- what might be called a fundamental law of the commonwealth -- than any tax assessed according to a fixed valuation.
elegant: A well-administered variable land tax that encourages improvement would impose only the unavoidable burden of payment itself. It would automatically adjust to changing economic conditions -- agricultural shifts, silver value changes, coinage alterations -- remaining equitable without government intervention. This self-adjusting quality makes it ideal as a permanent fundamental law, unlike any fixed-valuation tax.
summary: A properly designed variable land tax would automatically adjust to all economic changes while encouraging improvement, requiring no government intervention to remain equitable. This self-adjusting nature makes it suitable as a permanent constitutional institution, unlike fixed-valuation taxes.
distilled: A well-designed variable land tax is self-adjusting across all economic conditions, making it uniquely suitable as a permanent constitutional institution.
