notes: Self-adjusting taxation -- variable tax as fundamental law -- automatic equity across economic changes -- permanent institutional design -- contrast with fixed valuation fragility -- constitutional tax design

refashioned: Some states, instead of the simple and obvious solution of registering leases, have resorted to the laborious and expensive alternative of actually surveying and valuing all the land in the country. They presumably suspected that landlords and tenants might collude to conceal the true lease terms in order to defraud the public revenue. The Domesday Book appears to have been the result of just such a thorough survey.
elegant: Some states have chosen the costly method of surveying and valuing all land rather than simply registering leases, fearing landlord-tenant collusion to conceal true rents. The Domesday Book was the product of one such comprehensive survey.
summary: Instead of simple lease registration, some states have conducted expensive comprehensive land surveys, fearing that landlords and tenants would collude to hide true lease terms. The Domesday Book is a historical example of this approach.
distilled: Some states chose comprehensive land surveys over simple lease registration to prevent landlord-tenant collusion, as exemplified by the Domesday Book.
notes: Domesday Book as land survey -- survey vs. registration approaches -- anti-collusion justification -- cost of comprehensive valuation -- historical land assessment methods

refashioned: In the ancient dominions of the king of Prussia, land tax is assessed according to an actual survey and valuation that is periodically reviewed and updated. Under this valuation, lay landowners pay twenty to twenty-five percent of their revenue, and church landowners pay forty to forty-five percent. The survey and valuation of Silesia was conducted under the present king's orders and is said to be very accurate. Under it, the bishop of Breslau's lands are taxed at twenty-five percent of rent, other ecclesiastical revenues at fifty percent, the estates of the Teutonic and Malta orders at forty percent, lands held by noble tenure at thirty-eight and one-third percent, and lands held by common tenure at thirty-five and one-third percent.
elegant: Prussia's land tax is based on surveys reviewed periodically. Lay proprietors pay 20-25% and church landowners 40-45% of revenue. Silesia's accurate survey under Frederick the Great sets differential rates: bishops at 25%, other clergy at 50%, military orders at 40%, noble lands at 38.3%, and common lands at 35.3%.
summary: Prussia taxes land based on regularly updated surveys, with church property taxed much more heavily than lay property. Silesia's detailed survey sets graduated rates from 25% for episcopal lands to 50% for general ecclesiastical revenue, with noble and common lands at intermediate rates.
distilled: Prussia's land tax uses regularly updated surveys with differential rates: church lands taxed at 40-50% of revenue versus 20-25% for lay landowners.
notes: Prussian land tax system -- actual survey and valuation -- periodic review -- differential rates by land tenure -- church taxed higher than laity -- Silesian survey under Frederick the Great -- Teutonic and Malta orders

refashioned: The survey and valuation of Bohemia is said to have taken more than a hundred years to complete. It was not finished until after the Peace of 1748, under orders from the current Empress Queen. The survey of the Duchy of Milan, begun under Charles VI, was not completed until after 1760 and is considered one of the most accurate ever conducted. The survey of Savoy and Piedmont was carried out under orders from the late King of Sardinia.
elegant: Major European land surveys took decades or longer: Bohemia's required over a century (completed after 1748), Milan's began under Charles VI and finished after 1760 (considered the most accurate ever), and Savoy-Piedmont's was ordered by the King of Sardinia.
summary: Comprehensive land surveys were enormous undertakings: Bohemia's took over a century, Milan's several decades, and Savoy-Piedmont's was a major royal project. Milan's survey was considered the most accurate ever produced.
distilled: Comprehensive land surveys were monumental projects -- Bohemia's took over a century and Milan's several decades -- demonstrating the enormous cost of this approach to tax assessment.
notes: Duration of comprehensive land surveys -- Bohemia (100+ years) -- Milan (most accurate) -- Savoy and Piedmont -- Empress Maria Theresa -- Charles VI -- enormous administrative undertaking

refashioned: In Prussia, church revenue is taxed much more heavily than that of lay landowners. Church revenue is for the most part a burden on land rent. It is seldom used to improve the land or employed in any way that increases the revenue of the general population. The Prussian king therefore probably considered it reasonable that the church should contribute substantially more toward relieving the state's financial needs. In some countries, church lands are entirely exempt from taxation. In others, they are taxed more lightly than other lands. In the Duchy of Milan, lands the church acquired before 1575 are rated at only one-third of their value for tax purposes.
elegant: Prussia taxes church revenue much more heavily than lay property because church income burdens land rent without contributing to improvement or popular revenue. Other countries vary: some exempt church lands entirely, some tax them lightly. Milan taxes pre-1575 church lands at only a third of their value.
summary: Prussia justifies heavy church taxation on the grounds that church revenue burdens land rent without contributing to national improvement. Other European approaches range from total church tax exemption to Milan's preferential rate for pre-1575 church acquisitions.
distilled: Prussia taxes church lands heavily because church revenue burdens land rent without contributing to improvement, while other countries range from total exemption to partial preference.
notes: Differential taxation of church property -- Prussian rationale for heavy church taxation -- church revenue as unproductive burden on land -- Milan's pre-1575 church land preference -- comparative church taxation across Europe

refashioned: In Silesia, lands held by noble tenure are taxed three percent higher than those held by common tenure. The Prussian king apparently reasoned that the honors and privileges attached to noble tenure would sufficiently compensate owners for this small additional tax, while the humiliating inferiority of common tenure would be somewhat offset by lighter taxation. In other countries, the tax system aggravates rather than alleviates this inequality. In the dominions of the King of Sardinia and in those French provinces subject to the real or predial taille, the tax falls entirely on lands held by common tenure, with noble lands completely exempt.
elegant: Prussia taxes noble lands 3% higher than common ones -- reasoning that noble privileges offset the extra tax while lighter taxation alleviates common tenure's inferiority. Other countries do the opposite: in Sardinia and parts of France, common lands bear the entire tax while noble lands are exempt, aggravating social inequality.
summary: Prussia taxes noble lands slightly more than common ones, using tax policy to offset social inequality. By contrast, Sardinia and parts of France exempt noble lands entirely and tax only common tenure holdings, worsening the disparity.
distilled: Prussia uses slightly higher taxes on noble lands to offset social inequality, while Sardinia and France aggravate it by exempting noble lands and taxing only common ones.
notes: Tax policy and social equity -- Prussian progressive approach -- Sardinian and French regressive approach -- noble vs. common tenure -- tax as tool for social justice or injustice -- predial taille

refashioned: A land tax based on a general survey and valuation, however equal it may be when first established, must inevitably become unequal over a fairly short period. Preventing this would require the government to constantly monitor variations in the condition and output of every farm in the country. The governments of Prussia, Bohemia, Sardinia, and the Duchy of Milan do actually attempt this kind of monitoring -- an attention so unsuited to the nature of government that it is unlikely to continue for long. If it does continue, it will probably cause far more trouble and harassment than any relief it provides to taxpayers.
elegant: Even the best survey-based land tax becomes unequal quickly. Preventing this requires government to monitor every farm's changing conditions -- attention fundamentally unsuited to government's nature. Prussia, Bohemia, Sardinia, and Milan attempt this, but such micromanagement is unsustainable and will likely cause more harassment than benefit.
summary: Survey-based land taxes inevitably become unequal over time. Maintaining equity requires government monitoring of every farm -- a task fundamentally unsuited to government that several states attempt but cannot sustain without creating more harassment than benefit.
distilled: Survey-based land taxes inevitably become unequal, and the government micromanagement needed to maintain them is unsustainable and creates more harassment than relief.
notes: Decay of survey-based assessments -- government unsuited to farm-level monitoring -- unsustainability of comprehensive reassessment -- Prussia, Bohemia, Sardinia, Milan as examples -- government overreach in taxation -- information problem in centralized assessment

refashioned: In 1666, the generality of Montauban was assessed for the real or predial taille according to a reportedly very exact survey and valuation. By 1727, this assessment had become completely unequal. To remedy this, the government imposed an additional tax of 120,000 livres on the entire generality. This additional tax was assessed on all districts according to the old valuation but collected only from those districts that were under-taxed relative to actual conditions. The revenue was then applied to relieve those districts that were over-taxed. For example, two districts -- one that should properly be taxed at 900 livres and another at 1,100 livres -- were both taxed at 1,000 livres under the old assessment. Under the additional tax, both are rated at 1,100 livres, but the additional tax is collected only from the under-charged district and applied entirely to relieve the over-charged one, which consequently pays only 900 livres. The government neither gains nor loses from the additional tax, which is used solely to correct the inequalities of the old assessment. The allocation is largely at the discretion of the regional intendant and must therefore be somewhat arbitrary.
elegant: Montauban's 1666 land survey became completely outdated by 1727. Rather than resurvey, the government imposed an additional 120,000 livres assessed on old valuations but collected only from under-taxed districts and redistributed to over-taxed ones -- a revenue-neutral correction. For example, districts that should pay 900 and 1,100 but both assessed at 1,000 are rebalanced through the additional levy. However, the allocation depends on the intendant's discretion, making it somewhat arbitrary.
summary: When Montauban's 1666 land survey became outdated by 1727, the government created a revenue-neutral additional tax collected from under-assessed districts and redistributed to over-assessed ones. While this corrected inequalities without new surveys, the allocation depended on the intendant's discretion, introducing arbitrariness.
distilled: France addressed outdated land valuations not through resurvey but through revenue-neutral redistribution from under-taxed to over-taxed districts, though this introduced arbitrary discretion.
notes: Montauban taille adjustment -- obsolescence of survey valuations -- revenue-neutral redistribution mechanism -- intendant discretion as source of arbitrariness -- alternative to resurvey -- French fiscal administration

refashioned:
Taxes proportioned not to rent but to the produce of land.

Taxes on the produce of land are in reality taxes on the rent, and though the farmer may initially pay them, the landlord ultimately bears the cost. When a certain portion of the crop must be surrendered as tax, the farmer estimates what that portion will be worth on average, year after year, and reduces the rent he agrees to pay accordingly. No farmer fails to calculate in advance what the church tithe -- a land tax of precisely this kind -- is likely to cost him on average.
elegant: Taxes on land produce are really taxes on rent. Though farmers initially pay them, they reduce their rent offers accordingly, passing the burden to landlords. Every farmer calculates the expected cost of the church tithe -- a classic produce tax -- and deducts it from the rent he offers.
summary: Taxes on land produce are effectively taxes on rent because farmers reduce their rent offers by the expected tax amount, ultimately shifting the burden to landlords. The church tithe is the classic example of this mechanism.
distilled: Taxes on land produce are really taxes on rent because farmers reduce their rent offers by the expected tax amount, shifting the ultimate burden to landlords.
notes: Tax incidence on land produce -- produce tax as disguised rent tax -- farmer's rent adjustment -- tithe as produce tax -- forward shifting of tax burden to landlord -- transition to produce-based taxation analysis

refashioned: The tithe and every other produce-based land tax, despite appearing perfectly equal, are actually very unequal taxes on rent. A fixed portion of produce represents very different proportions of rent depending on the land's productivity. On very rich land, the produce is so great that half of it suffices to repay the farmer's capital and normal profit, leaving the other half as potential rent. If a tenth is taken as tithe, the farmer must demand a one-fifth reduction in rent -- so the landlord's rent falls from five-tenths to four-tenths of produce. On poorer land, the produce may be so small and cultivation so expensive that four-fifths of produce is needed to repay the farmer's capital and profit. Without any tithe, the landlord could receive only one-fifth, or two-tenths, as rent. But if the farmer pays a tenth as tithe, he must demand an equal reduction in rent, cutting the landlord's share to just one-tenth. On rich land, the tithe may amount to a tax of only one-fifth of the rent, or four shillings in the pound. On poorer land, it may amount to a tax of one-half, or ten shillings in the pound.
elegant: The tithe appears equal -- everyone pays a tenth of produce -- but its impact on rent varies enormously. On rich land where half the produce is rent, a tenth reduces the landlord's share from 50% to 40% of produce (a 20% tax on rent). On poor land where only a fifth is rent, the same tithe halves it to a tenth (a 50% tax on rent). The same proportional produce tax becomes wildly disproportionate as a rent tax.
summary: The tithe appears equal at one-tenth of produce for everyone, but falls far more heavily on poor land's rent than rich land's. On rich land it represents about a 20% tax on rent; on poor land, about a 50% tax. Equal produce taxes create very unequal rent taxes.
distilled: The tithe appears equal as a produce tax but is deeply unequal as a rent tax -- falling as a 20% rent tax on rich land but a 50% rent tax on poor land.
notes: Tithe's hidden inequality -- produce tax vs. rent tax incidence -- rich land vs. poor land -- proportional produce tax becomes regressive rent tax -- apparent vs. real equality -- mathematical demonstration of tax incidence

refashioned: Just as the tithe is frequently a very unequal tax on rent, it is always a great discouragement to both the landlord's improvements and the farmer's cultivation. Neither dares undertake the most important improvements -- which are generally the most expensive -- nor grow the most valuable crops -- which are generally the most costly -- when the church, having invested nothing, takes such a large share of the profit. The cultivation of madder was long confined to the United Provinces, which as Presbyterian countries were exempt from this destructive tax and thus enjoyed a kind of monopoly in that useful dyeing plant over the rest of Europe. Recent attempts to grow madder in England were made possible only by a statute allowing a flat payment of five shillings per acre in place of all tithe on the crop.
elegant: The tithe discourages both landlord improvement and farmer cultivation: neither will invest in expensive improvements or valuable crops when the church claims a large share of profits without contributing to costs. Madder cultivation was long monopolized by tithe-free Presbyterian Netherlands; England could introduce it only after a statute replaced the tithe with a flat five-shillings-per-acre payment.
summary: The tithe discourages expensive improvements and valuable crops because the church takes profits without sharing costs. This drove madder cultivation exclusively to tithe-free Netherlands until England replaced the crop-specific tithe with a flat five-shilling payment per acre.
distilled: The tithe discourages agricultural improvement and valuable crop cultivation, as demonstrated by madder farming's confinement to tithe-free Netherlands until England adopted a flat alternative payment.
notes: Tithe as disincentive to improvement -- free-rider problem (church takes profit without cost) -- madder cultivation example -- Netherlands' competitive advantage from Presbyterian exemption -- flat-rate tithe substitutes -- tax reform enabling agricultural innovation

refashioned: Just as the church is mainly supported by a produce-based land tax in most of Europe, the state is similarly supported in many Asian countries. In China, the sovereign's principal revenue consists of a tenth of all the empire's land produce, though this tenth is reportedly assessed so moderately that in many provinces it amounts to no more than a thirtieth of ordinary output. The land tax or rent formerly paid to the Muslim government of Bengal before the English East India Company took control is said to have been about a fifth of produce. Ancient Egypt's land tax is also said to have been about a fifth.
elegant: While European churches live off produce tithes, Asian states do the same. China's sovereign takes a nominal tenth but in practice often only a thirtieth of produce. Pre-British Bengal under Muslim rule took about a fifth, as did ancient Egypt.
summary: Produce-based land taxes support the state in much of Asia just as they support the church in Europe. China's nominal tenth is often just a thirtieth in practice, while Bengal under Muslim rule and ancient Egypt both took approximately a fifth.
distilled: Produce-based land taxes support Asian states just as tithes support European churches, with rates ranging from China's effective thirtieth to Bengal's and Egypt's fifth.
notes: Comparative produce taxation: Europe vs. Asia -- China's moderate assessment -- Bengal under Muslim government -- ancient Egypt -- East India Company transition -- nominal vs. effective tax rates

refashioned: In Asia, this type of land tax is said to give the sovereign a direct interest in improving and cultivating the land. The sovereigns of China, of Bengal under Muslim rule, and of ancient Egypt were all reportedly extremely attentive to building and maintaining good roads and navigable canals, seeking to maximize both the quantity and value of every part of the land's produce by securing the most extensive possible market within their dominions. The church tithe, by contrast, is divided among so many small beneficiaries that none has any comparable incentive. The parish vicar could never justify building a road or canal to a distant region just to expand the market for his own parish's produce. When produce taxes fund the state, they have some advantages that may partly offset their drawbacks. When they fund the church, they bring nothing but disadvantages.
elegant: Produce-based state taxes give sovereigns a direct stake in land improvement -- explaining why Chinese, Bengali, and Egyptian rulers invested heavily in roads and canals to expand markets. The church tithe, divided among countless small beneficiaries, creates no such incentive: no vicar would build a road to expand his parish's market. Produce taxes for the state have offsetting advantages; for the church, only disadvantages.
summary: Produce taxes give sovereigns incentive to invest in infrastructure since their revenue grows with the land's productivity. This explains why Asian rulers built roads and canals. Church tithes, divided among many small recipients, create no such incentive. Produce taxes benefit the state but only burden the church.
distilled: Produce taxes incentivize state investment in infrastructure since sovereign revenue grows with agricultural output, but church tithes divided among many beneficiaries create no such improvement incentive.
notes: Sovereign incentive alignment through produce taxation -- infrastructure investment in China, Bengal, Egypt -- tithe division eliminates improvement incentive -- state vs. church produce taxation compared -- roads and canals as market expansion

refashioned:
Taxes on the produce of land may be collected either in kind or in money according to a set valuation.

A parish vicar or a small landowner may sometimes find it advantageous to receive his tithe or rent in kind. Since both the quantity collected and the collection area are small, each can personally oversee every aspect of collection and disposal. But a great landowner living in the capital would risk serious losses from the neglect and even more from the fraud of his agents if rents from a distant estate were paid in kind. The sovereign's losses from the abuse and theft of tax collectors would necessarily be even greater. A private person's servants are generally under closer supervision than even the most careful prince's, and a public revenue collected in kind would lose so much to collector mismanagement that very little of what was levied from the people would ever reach the treasury. Part of China's public revenue is reportedly still collected in kind, however. The tax collectors -- the mandarins and their subordinates -- naturally find it in their interest to maintain a payment method far more susceptible to abuse than any money payment.
elegant: Produce taxes can be collected in kind or in money. In-kind collection works only at small scale where personal oversight is possible. For large estates or the state, in-kind collection invites massive losses from agent negligence and fraud. Even careful princes cannot supervise as closely as private persons. China still collects some revenue in kind -- maintained by tax collectors who profit from a system more susceptible to abuse than money payments.
summary: Collecting taxes in kind works only at small scale with personal oversight. At state level, the negligence and fraud of collectors means very little reaches the treasury. China's continued in-kind collection persists because corrupt mandarins benefit from this abuse-prone system.
distilled: Collecting taxes in kind invites massive losses from collector fraud and negligence at any scale beyond personal oversight, as China's mandarin-maintained system demonstrates.
notes: In-kind vs. money tax collection -- scale and oversight -- principal-agent problem in tax collection -- China's in-kind collection -- mandarin corruption -- collector self-interest in maintaining abusive systems

refashioned: A produce tax collected in money can be assessed either according to a valuation that varies with market prices, or according to a fixed valuation where a bushel of wheat, for example, is always priced the same regardless of the actual market. A tax assessed at variable market prices will fluctuate only with the actual produce of the land -- its improvement or decline. A tax assessed at a fixed price will fluctuate not only with the land's produce but also with changes in the value of precious metals and changes in the amount of metal contained in coins of any given denomination. The first type will always bear the same proportion to the actual value of produce. The second may bear very different proportions at different times.
elegant: Money-based produce taxes can use variable market valuations or fixed prices. Variable valuations fluctuate only with actual production changes. Fixed-price valuations also fluctuate with metal values and coinage changes, making their real burden unpredictable. Only market-based valuations maintain a consistent relationship to actual produce value.
summary: Produce taxes collected in money can use either market-based or fixed valuations. Market-based valuations adjust only with production changes, maintaining consistent proportionality. Fixed valuations also shift with metal values and coinage changes, making the real tax burden unpredictable over time.
distilled: Market-based valuations for produce taxes maintain consistent proportionality to actual output, while fixed valuations create unpredictable burdens as metal values and coinage change.
notes: Variable vs. fixed money valuation of produce taxes -- market price assessment -- metal value fluctuations -- coinage standard changes -- proportionality and predictability in taxation

refashioned: When, instead of a portion of the produce or its price, a fixed sum of money is paid in full settlement of all tax or tithe, the tax becomes identical in nature to England's land tax. It neither rises nor falls with the rent. It neither encourages nor discourages improvement. The tithe in most parishes that pay a so-called modus in lieu of all other tithe is a tax of this kind. Under the Muslim government of Bengal, a modus -- reportedly a very moderate one -- was established in most districts instead of the fifth-part payment in kind. Some East India Company officials, claiming to restore the public revenue to its proper value, have in some provinces replaced this modus with payment in kind. Under their management, this change is likely both to discourage cultivation and to create new opportunities for collection abuses. Public revenue has fallen well below what it was reportedly generating when the Company first took over its management. The Company's agents may have personally profited from the change, but probably at the expense of both their employers and the country.
elegant: A fixed money payment replacing all tithe or produce tax functions identically to England's fixed land tax -- neutral toward improvement. Bengal's moderate modus under Muslim rule was replaced by East India Company officials with payment in kind, supposedly to restore revenue. Instead, this discouraged cultivation, invited collection abuse, and reduced total revenue. Company agents profited personally at the expense of both the Company and Bengal.
summary: Fixed money payments in lieu of produce taxes are neutral toward improvement, like England's land tax. The East India Company's reversal of Bengal's moderate modus to payment in kind discouraged cultivation, enabled corruption, and reduced revenue -- benefiting only the Company's own agents.
distilled: The East India Company's replacement of Bengal's fixed money tithe with payment in kind discouraged cultivation, enabled corruption, and reduced revenue while enriching its own agents.
notes: Modus as fixed payment -- neutral effect on improvement -- Bengal under East India Company -- reversion to in-kind collection -- cultivation discouragement -- agent self-enrichment at company and country expense -- colonial fiscal mismanagement

refashioned:
Taxes upon the Rent of Houses.

The rent of a house can be divided into two components: one properly called the building-rent, and the other commonly called the ground-rent.
elegant: House rent has two components: building-rent (return on construction investment) and ground-rent (payment for the land itself).
summary: House rent consists of two distinct elements: the building-rent, which is the return on the building investment, and the ground-rent, which is the payment for the land.
distilled: House rent comprises two components: building-rent (return on construction capital) and ground-rent (payment for land).
notes: Decomposition of house rent -- building-rent vs. ground-rent -- introduction to house rent taxation -- analytical framework for housing costs

refashioned: The building-rent represents the interest or profit on the capital invested in constructing the house. To keep building competitive with other trades, this rent must be sufficient, first, to pay the builder the same interest he could have earned by lending his capital on good security, and second, to cover the cost of keeping the house in constant repair -- or equivalently, to replace the construction capital within a certain number of years. The building-rent, or normal profit from building, is therefore everywhere governed by the ordinary rate of interest. Where market interest is four percent, a house rent yielding six or six and a half percent on total construction cost (over and above the ground-rent) may provide adequate builder profit. Where interest is five percent, seven or seven and a half percent may be needed. If building profits significantly exceed this level, capital will flow in from other trades until profits fall to their normal level. If profits fall significantly below it, capital will flow out until they recover.
elegant: Building-rent must cover both the opportunity cost of capital (matching prevailing interest rates) and depreciation. At 4% interest, builders need 6-6.5% return on construction cost; at 5% interest, 7-7.5%. Market competition automatically corrects deviations: excess profits attract capital from other trades, while insufficient profits drive capital away.
summary: Building-rent must provide a return matching the prevailing interest rate plus depreciation. Competition ensures automatic correction: above-normal building profits attract capital from other trades, while below-normal profits drive capital away, keeping builder returns at market equilibrium.
distilled: Building-rent is regulated by the market interest rate plus depreciation, with competition automatically correcting any deviation from normal builder profits.
notes: Building-rent as return on capital -- opportunity cost of capital -- depreciation component -- interest rate as regulator -- capital mobility between trades -- competitive equilibrium in construction -- profit equalization across sectors

refashioned: Whatever portion of a house's total rent exceeds what is needed to provide this reasonable profit on building naturally goes to the ground-rent. When the ground owner and building owner are different people, this surplus is typically paid entirely to the ground owner. This surplus rent is the price the occupant pays for some real or perceived advantage of location. In rural houses far from any town, ground-rent is negligible -- scarcely more than the land would earn if used for agriculture. In country villas near a large town, it is sometimes considerably higher, as the particular convenience or beauty of the location commands a premium. Ground-rents are generally highest in the capital city, and specifically in those neighborhoods where demand for houses is greatest -- whatever the reason for that demand, whether trade and business, pleasure and socializing, or mere vanity and fashion.
elegant: Whatever house rent exceeds the builder's reasonable return goes to the ground owner as ground-rent -- the price of location advantage. Ground-rent is negligible in remote areas, higher near towns, and highest in capital cities, especially in fashionable or commercially important neighborhoods. The premium reflects demand driven by trade, pleasure, or fashion.
summary: Ground-rent is the portion of house rent exceeding the builder's normal return, representing the value of location. It ranges from negligible in remote areas to very high in capital city neighborhoods where demand is greatest, driven by commerce, social life, or fashion.
distilled: Ground-rent represents the location premium in house rent -- negligible in rural areas but highest in capital city neighborhoods where demand is greatest.
notes: Ground-rent as location value -- decomposition of house rent -- urban vs. rural ground-rents -- demand drivers: commerce, society, fashion -- location premium concept -- precursor to modern location theory

refashioned: A tax on house-rent, paid by the tenant and proportional to the total rent, could not -- at least for any considerable time -- affect the building-rent. If the builder could not earn his reasonable profit, he would leave the trade, and the resulting increase in demand for building would soon restore his profit to its normal level relative to other trades. Nor would such a tax fall entirely on the ground-rent. It would instead divide itself, falling partly on the house's occupant and partly on the ground owner.
elegant: A proportional house-rent tax paid by tenants cannot permanently affect building-rent, since builders would leave the trade until profits recovered. Nor does it fall entirely on ground-rent. Instead, the burden splits between the occupant and the ground owner.
summary: A proportional house-rent tax cannot permanently reduce builder profits because builders would exit until profits recovered. The tax burden instead splits between the occupant, who accepts less convenience, and the ground owner, who receives less rent.
distilled: A proportional house-rent tax splits between occupant and ground owner because builder profits, protected by capital mobility, cannot be permanently reduced.
notes: Tax incidence on house rent -- building-rent protected by capital mobility -- split burden between occupant and ground owner -- builder exit mechanism -- short-run vs. long-run incidence

refashioned: Suppose a person judges he can afford sixty pounds per year for house rent, and a tax of four shillings in the pound -- one-fifth -- is imposed on the tenant. A house renting at sixty pounds would now cost him seventy-two pounds per year, twelve more than he thinks he can afford. He will therefore settle for a worse house at fifty pounds rent, which with the ten-pound tax brings his total to sixty pounds -- the amount he can afford. In order to pay the tax, he gives up part of the additional comfort he might have enjoyed from a house ten pounds dearer. I say part of the additional comfort, because he will seldom have to give up all of it. Since the tax removes him as a competitor for sixty-pound houses, it must also reduce competition for fifty-pound houses, and similarly for every other rent level except the very lowest, where competition would temporarily increase.
elegant: A one-fifth house-rent tax forces a person who can afford 60 pounds total to downgrade from a 60-pound house to a 50-pound one (50 + 10 tax = 60). But he only partially loses comfort: as the tax removes competitors from higher-rent houses, competition falls at every level, improving quality at lower price points. Only the lowest-rent houses face increased competition.
summary: A house-rent tax forces tenants to downgrade, but the resulting cascade of reduced competition at every rent level means they lose only part of the comfort they sacrifice. The tax shifts competition downward through all housing classes except the very lowest.
distilled: A house-rent tax forces tenants to downgrade, but cascading reductions in competition at each rent level mean they lose only part of the comfort they sacrifice.
notes: Tax incidence through housing market cascade -- budget constraint forcing downgrade -- competition reduction across rent levels -- partial comfort loss -- cascading market adjustment -- lowest-rent compression

refashioned: The rents of every class of houses where competition has been diminished would necessarily fall to some degree. Since no part of this reduction could permanently affect the building-rent, the entire decrease must ultimately fall on the ground-rent. The final burden of this tax would therefore fall partly on the house occupant, who must give up some convenience to pay his share, and partly on the ground owner, who must give up some revenue to pay his. The exact proportion in which this final burden would be divided between them is not easy to determine.
elegant: Since reduced competition lowers rents across all housing classes, and building-rent is protected by capital mobility, the entire rent reduction falls on ground-rent. The tax is thus ultimately split: occupants sacrifice some convenience, and ground owners sacrifice some revenue. The exact split is hard to determine.
summary: Reduced housing competition lowers rents across all classes, and since building-rent cannot be permanently reduced, all rent decreases fall on ground-rent. The tax burden splits between occupants (who lose convenience) and ground owners (who lose revenue), in proportions difficult to determine.
distilled: The house-rent tax ultimately falls on occupants (through reduced convenience) and ground owners (through reduced ground-rent), in proportions that are difficult to determine precisely.
notes: Final incidence of house-rent tax -- ground-rent bears rent reduction -- building-rent protected -- split burden: occupant convenience vs. ground-owner revenue -- indeterminate proportions

refashioned:
The division would likely differ greatly under different circumstances, and a tax of this kind might therefore affect the occupant and ground owner quite unequally.

The inequality in its impact on different ground-rent owners would arise entirely from the unpredictable way the burden happens to split in different cases. But the inequality in its impact on occupants of different houses would arise from an additional cause. The proportion of housing expense to total living costs varies with the level of wealth. It is probably highest among the very rich and decreases through lower income levels, being generally lowest among the poorest. Food is the main expense of the poor, who struggle to get enough, spending most of their small income on it. The rich spend mainly on luxuries and displays, and a magnificent house is the centerpiece that shows off all their other luxuries to greatest advantage. A tax on house rent would therefore generally fall most heavily on the rich -- and in this kind of inequality there would be nothing unreasonable. It is not unreasonable that the rich should contribute to public expenses not only in proportion to their income but somewhat more than proportionally.
elegant: The tax's division between occupant and ground owner varies unpredictably by circumstance. But a deeper inequality emerges: housing expense as a share of total spending rises with wealth. The poor spend mostly on food; the rich spend on luxuries, with a magnificent house as the centerpiece. House-rent taxes therefore fall most heavily on the wealthy -- a progressive outcome that is entirely reasonable, since the rich can fairly be asked to contribute more than proportionally.
summary: House-rent taxes are inherently progressive because housing costs consume a larger share of rich people's budgets than poor people's (who spend mostly on food). This means the tax falls most heavily on the wealthy -- a form of inequality Smith considers entirely reasonable and just.
distilled: House-rent taxes are naturally progressive because housing expense is a larger share of wealthy people's budgets, making it reasonable that the rich bear a disproportionate share.
notes: Progressive nature of house-rent tax -- housing as luxury good -- Engel's law precursor (food share decreases with income) -- ability-to-pay principle -- progressive taxation justified -- housing as display of wealth -- distributional effects of consumption taxes

refashioned: House rent, though resembling land rent in some ways, differs from it in one essential respect. Land rent is paid for the use of a productive asset: the land that pays it also produces it. House rent is paid for the use of an unproductive asset: neither the house nor the ground beneath it produces anything. The person paying rent must therefore draw it from some other, independent source of income. A house-rent tax, insofar as it falls on the occupant, must be paid from the same source as the rent itself -- whether that income comes from wages, profits, or land rent. To the extent it falls on the occupant, a house-rent tax is therefore one of those taxes that falls not on one revenue source alone but indiscriminately on all three, much like a tax on any other consumer good. In general, there is perhaps no single item of spending that better indicates a person's overall standard of living than his house rent. A proportional tax on housing might therefore produce more revenue than any tax yet drawn from this source in Europe. If the tax were very high, however, most people would try to evade it by settling for smaller houses and redirecting their spending elsewhere.
elegant: House rent differs fundamentally from land rent: land is productive (generating what pays the rent), but houses are unproductive (rent must come from other income). A house-rent tax on occupants therefore falls on all three revenue sources -- wages, profits, and land rent -- like any consumption tax. Since house rent is perhaps the best single indicator of a person's overall spending level, a proportional tax on it could yield more revenue than any housing tax yet tried in Europe, though very high rates would drive people toward smaller houses.
summary: Unlike productive land, houses produce nothing -- so house rent must come from wages, profits, or land rent, making a house-rent tax effectively a general consumption tax. Since house rent is the best indicator of overall living standards, a proportional housing tax could be Europe's most productive revenue source, though excessive rates would drive evasion through downsizing.
distilled: House-rent taxes function as general consumption taxes falling on all income sources, and since house rent is the best indicator of living standards, they could be Europe's most productive revenue source.
notes: Productive vs. unproductive assets -- house rent as consumption -- general incidence on wages, profits, and rent -- house rent as proxy for total spending -- revenue potential of housing tax -- behavioral response to high rates -- Laffer curve concept

refashioned: House rents could easily be determined with sufficient accuracy using a system similar to that needed for assessing ordinary land rents. Unoccupied houses should pay no tax -- a tax on them would fall entirely on the owner, who would be taxed on property yielding him neither convenience nor revenue. Owner-occupied houses should be rated not according to their construction cost but according to the rent that a fair arbitration might judge them likely to fetch if leased to a tenant. If rated by construction cost, a tax of three or four shillings in the pound, combined with other taxes, would ruin nearly all the rich and great families of this country -- and I believe of every other civilized country. Anyone who examines the town and country houses of Britain's wealthiest families will find that at just six and a half or seven percent on original construction cost, the implied house rent nearly equals the entire net rent from their landed estates. This represents the accumulated expenditure of several successive generations, invested in objects of great beauty and magnificence that, relative to their cost, have very little exchange value. (Since this book was first published, a tax largely based on these principles has been imposed.)
elegant: House rents could be assessed through arbitration, like land rents. Unoccupied houses should be tax-free (the burden would fall on owners gaining nothing). Owner-occupied houses must be rated by rental value, not construction cost -- the latter would ruin wealthy families, since their accumulated building expenditure implies rents equaling their entire estate income. Construction cost reflects generations of spending on beauty and magnificence with little exchange value. A tax on these principles has since been adopted.
summary: House-rent assessment should use estimated rental value, not construction cost. Taxing by construction cost would ruin wealthy families whose multi-generational building investments far exceed their properties' rental value. Unoccupied houses should be exempt, and the assessment method should mirror land rent arbitration. Such a tax has since been implemented.
distilled: Houses should be taxed on estimated rental value rather than construction cost, which would ruin wealthy families whose multi-generational building investments far exceed exchange value.
notes: Assessment by rental value vs. construction cost -- unoccupied house exemption -- arbitration-based assessment -- accumulated construction expenditure of wealthy families -- beauty vs. exchange value -- subsequent tax reform confirmation

refashioned: Ground-rents are an even more appropriate subject of taxation than house rents. A tax on ground-rents would not raise house rents; it would fall entirely on the ground-rent owner, who always acts as a monopolist, demanding the highest rent the market will bear for his land. How much can be extracted depends on whether the competing occupants are richer or poorer, and how much they are willing to pay for a particular location. In every country, the greatest concentration of wealthy competitors is in the capital, which is consequently where the highest ground-rents are found. Since a ground-rent tax would not increase these competitors' wealth, they would not pay more for the land. Whether the tax is formally paid by the occupant or the ground owner makes little practical difference: the more the occupant pays in tax, the less he will pay for the ground, so the final burden falls entirely on the ground owner. Ground-rents of unoccupied sites should pay no tax. Both ground-rents and ordinary land rents are a species of income that the owner often enjoys without any personal effort or attention. Even if part of this income is taken to fund the state, no productive activity will be discouraged. The annual output of the nation's land and labor -- the real wealth and revenue of the people -- would be the same after such a tax as before. Ground-rents and ordinary land rents are therefore perhaps the form of income best able to bear a dedicated tax.
elegant: Ground-rents are the ideal tax base. The ground owner is a monopolist who extracts the maximum the market will bear -- a tax cannot be passed on because it does not increase competitors' ability to pay. Whether formally charged to occupant or owner, the burden falls entirely on the owner, who would simply receive less ground-rent. Since ground-rent is unearned income requiring no effort, taxing it discourages no productive activity and leaves national output unchanged. Ground-rents and land rents are therefore the revenue best able to bear taxation.
summary: Ground-rents are the ideal tax target because the monopolist ground-owner cannot pass the tax on to tenants, the income is unearned, and the tax discourages no productive activity. National output remains unchanged. Both ground-rents and land rents are the forms of income best suited to taxation.
distilled: Ground-rents are the ideal tax base because the monopolist owner cannot shift the burden, the income is unearned, and taxing it discourages no productive activity whatsoever.
notes: Ground-rent as ideal tax base -- monopolist ground-owner -- tax cannot be shifted -- unearned income -- zero deadweight loss -- national output unaffected -- precursor to Georgist land value taxation -- capital city as highest ground-rent location -- unoccupied site exemption

refashioned: Ground-rents appear to be a more appropriate subject for special taxation than even the ordinary rent of land. Ordinary land rent is owed, at least in part, to the landlord's attentiveness and good management. An excessively heavy tax might discourage such diligent stewardship. Ground-rents, however, insofar as they exceed the ordinary rent of the land, owe their entire existence to good government -- a government that, by protecting the industry of the whole nation or of a particular locality, enables people to pay far more than the land's real value for the ground on which they build their houses, or to compensate the landowner far beyond any loss from that use. Nothing could be more reasonable than that a source of revenue which owes its very existence to good government should be taxed in a special way, or should contribute more than most other revenue sources toward supporting that government.
elegant: Ground-rents deserve special taxation more than ordinary land rent. Ordinary rent partly reflects the landlord's management, which heavy taxes would discourage. But ground-rents above ordinary land rent exist entirely because good government protects local industry, enabling people to pay premium prices for building land. It is perfectly reasonable that a revenue stream created by good government should contribute disproportionately to supporting it.
summary: Ground-rents are a better target for special taxation than ordinary land rents because they owe their existence entirely to good government, which protects industry and drives up the value of building land. Taxing ordinary rent risks discouraging landlord management.
distilled: Ground-rents, owing their existence to good government rather than landlord effort, are the most legitimate target for special taxation.
notes: Key distinction between ground-rent (location value created by society) and building-rent (created by investment). Anticipates Henry George's land value tax by a century. Cross-reference 5.2.67-74 on house rent taxation. The argument that government-created value should fund government is a foundational principle of public finance.

refashioned: Although taxes have been imposed on house rents in many different European countries, I am not aware of any in which ground-rents have been treated as a separate subject of taxation. Tax designers have probably found it difficult to determine precisely which portion of rent should be classified as ground-rent and which as building-rent. It should not, however, seem very difficult to distinguish these two components from one another.
elegant: Though many European countries tax house rents, none has separately taxed ground-rents. Tax designers have apparently found it hard to separate ground-rent from building-rent -- yet the distinction should not be that difficult.
summary: No European country has separately taxed ground-rents, apparently because of difficulty distinguishing ground-rent from building-rent, though Smith suggests this distinction is not actually hard to make.
distilled: Despite the theoretical case for taxing ground-rents separately, no European country has done so, likely due to the perceived difficulty of separating ground-rent from building-rent.
notes: Practical obstacle to land value taxation -- the appraisal problem. Smith dismisses this difficulty, suggesting it is more perceived than real. This administrative challenge remains central to modern debates about land value taxation.

refashioned: In Great Britain, house rents are supposed to be taxed in the same proportion as land rents through what is called the annual land tax. The valuation used to assess each parish and district to this tax is always the same. It was originally extremely unequal, and it remains so. Throughout most of the kingdom, this tax falls even more lightly on house rents than on land rents. Only in a few districts that were originally rated high, and where house rents have since fallen considerably, does the land tax of three or four shillings per pound amount to a fair proportion of the actual rent. Untenanted houses, though legally subject to the tax, are in most districts exempted by the favor of assessors, and this exemption sometimes causes slight variations in the rate on particular houses, even though the district rate stays constant. Improvements in rental income from new construction, repairs, and similar work go toward reducing the district's overall assessment, which creates further variations in the rate on individual houses.
elegant: Britain's annual land tax is supposed to tax house rents equally with land rents, but the unchanging valuation is extremely unequal. In most areas, houses are taxed more lightly than land. Only where original assessments were high and rents have since fallen does the tax approximate a fair proportion of actual rent. Assessors typically exempt untenanted houses, and rental improvements reduce district assessments, creating further rate variations.
summary: Britain's land tax assesses house rents alongside land rents using fixed, outdated valuations that are extremely unequal. Houses are generally taxed more lightly than land, untenanted houses are informally exempted, and improvements reduce district burdens.
distilled: Britain's land tax on houses is based on outdated, unequal valuations that tax houses more lightly than land and allow informal exemptions for vacant properties.
notes: Illustrates how fixed assessments become increasingly distorted over time as actual rents change. The informal exemption of untenanted houses shows administrative discretion undermining legislative intent. Cross-reference Smith's four maxims of taxation (5.2.3-6) -- this tax violates the equality principle.

refashioned: In the province of Holland, every house is taxed at two and a half percent of its value, regardless of what rent it actually pays or whether it is tenanted or untenanted. There seems to be a hardship in forcing a property owner to pay tax on an untenanted house from which he derives no revenue, especially so heavy a tax. In Holland, where the market interest rate does not exceed three percent, two and a half percent on the full value of a house must, in most cases, amount to more than a third of the building-rent -- perhaps of the entire rent. The valuations used for assessment, though very unequal, are said always to fall below actual value. When a house is rebuilt, improved, or enlarged, a new valuation is made and the tax adjusted accordingly.
elegant: Holland taxes every house at two and a half percent of its value, whether tenanted or not. This is harsh on owners of vacant houses earning no revenue. With interest rates at just three percent, this tax often exceeds a third of the building-rent. Valuations, though unequal, are reportedly always below real value, and reassessment occurs upon rebuilding or improvement.
summary: Holland taxes all houses at 2.5% of value regardless of occupancy, which is burdensome for vacant properties. With low interest rates, this amounts to over a third of building-rent, though valuations reportedly understate actual values.
distilled: Holland's 2.5% property tax on all houses regardless of tenancy is effectively very heavy, amounting to over a third of building-rent at prevailing low interest rates.
notes: Comparison of British and Dutch approaches to house taxation. Holland's approach is simpler but harsher, especially on vacant properties. The relationship between interest rates and effective tax burden is an important insight -- the same nominal rate becomes heavier when returns on capital are low. Reassessment upon improvement creates transparency but may discourage building investment.

refashioned: The designers of the various taxes imposed on houses in England at different times seem to have believed there was great difficulty in ascertaining, with reasonable accuracy, the actual rent of every house. They therefore based their taxes on some more visible characteristic that they imagined would, in most cases, bear some proportion to the rent.
elegant: English tax designers, believing it too difficult to ascertain actual house rents, instead based house taxes on visible physical characteristics they assumed would roughly correlate with rental value.
summary: English tax designers, deeming it impractical to assess actual house rents, relied instead on observable physical proxies they believed correlated with rental value.
distilled: England taxed houses based on visible physical characteristics rather than actual rents, using proxies assumed to correlate with value.
notes: Introduces the proxy-based taxation approach that led to hearth taxes and window taxes. The challenge of accurate assessment is a recurring theme in tax administration -- the tradeoff between precision and practicality.

refashioned: The first such tax was hearth-money -- a tax of two shillings on every hearth. To determine how many hearths were in a house, the tax collector had to enter every room. This intrusive visit made the tax hated. Soon after the Glorious Revolution, therefore, it was abolished as a badge of slavery.
elegant: The first proxy tax was hearth-money: two shillings per hearth. But counting hearths required tax collectors to enter every room, making the tax detested. It was abolished after the Revolution as a badge of slavery.
summary: England's hearth tax of two shillings per hearth required intrusive home inspections to count hearths, making it deeply unpopular. It was abolished after the Glorious Revolution as a symbol of tyranny.
distilled: The hearth tax was abolished after the Revolution because counting hearths required odious household inspections.
notes: Illustrates how administrative intrusiveness can doom an otherwise reasonable tax. The phrase 'badge of slavery' reflects the political context of the 1689 Revolution and its concern with individual liberty. Cross-reference Smith's fourth maxim -- taxes should minimize inconvenience to the contributor.

refashioned: The next house tax was a levy of two shillings on every inhabited dwelling-house. A house with ten windows paid an additional four shillings, and one with twenty or more windows paid an extra eight shillings. This tax was later modified so that houses with twenty to thirty windows paid ten shillings, and those with thirty or more paid twenty shillings. The number of windows can generally be counted from outside, and in all cases without entering every room. The tax collector's visit was therefore much less offensive under this tax than under the hearth-money.
elegant: The next house tax charged two shillings per dwelling, with surcharges scaled by window count. Since windows can be counted from outside without entering rooms, the tax collector's visit was far less intrusive than under the hearth tax.
summary: England replaced the hearth tax with a dwelling tax scaled by window count. Since windows could be counted from outside, the tax collector's visit was much less intrusive than room-by-room hearth inspections.
distilled: The window-based house tax was less intrusive than hearth-money because windows could be counted from outside without entering homes.
notes: Shows the evolution toward less intrusive tax proxies. Windows as a proxy for wealth -- larger, wealthier houses had more windows. The graduated rate structure represents an early attempt at progressive taxation on housing.

refashioned: This tax was later repealed and replaced by the window tax, which has undergone two subsequent alterations and increases. The window tax, as it stands at present (January 1775), in addition to a base duty of three shillings on every house in England and one shilling on every house in Scotland, imposes a duty on every window. In England, this duty rises gradually from twopence -- the lowest rate on houses with no more than seven windows -- to two shillings, the highest rate on houses with twenty-five windows or more.
elegant: The earlier tax was replaced by the window tax, which as of 1775 charges a base duty per house plus a graduated per-window duty -- from twopence on small houses to two shillings on houses with twenty-five or more windows.
summary: The window tax replaced earlier house taxes with a base duty per house plus a graduated per-window charge, ranging from twopence for small houses to two shillings for houses with twenty-five or more windows.
distilled: The window tax combined a flat base duty per house with a graduated per-window charge that increased with the number of windows.
notes: The window tax (1696-1851) became one of England's most famous taxes. The graduated structure attempted proportionality. Different base rates for England and Scotland reflect the union's fiscal asymmetries. Historical note: the window tax famously led to bricked-up windows, a classic example of tax-induced behavioral distortion.

refashioned: The principal objection to all such taxes is their inequality -- and inequality of the worst kind, since they frequently fall much more heavily on the poor than on the rich. A house renting for ten pounds in a country town may sometimes have more windows than a five-hundred-pound house in London. Though the country-town inhabitant is likely far poorer than the Londoner, the window tax requires him to contribute more to the support of the state. Such taxes therefore directly violate the first of the four maxims mentioned above. They do not, however, seem to offend much against the other three.
elegant: The chief objection to window taxes is their inequality -- the worst kind, falling harder on the poor than the rich. A modest country house may have more windows than an expensive London house, forcing a poorer person to pay more. This directly violates the first maxim of taxation, though it does not much offend the other three.
summary: Window taxes are fundamentally regressive: a modest country house may have more windows than an expensive London house, forcing poorer people to pay more. This violates the equality principle of taxation, though the tax otherwise performs reasonably well.
distilled: Window taxes are regressive because they tax a physical feature that does not reliably correlate with ability to pay.
notes: Direct application of Smith's first maxim -- taxes should be proportional to ability to pay (5.2.3). The London vs. country town example is powerful: urban density compresses windows while rural construction spreads them. The concession that the tax respects the other three maxims (certainty, convenience, efficiency) shows Smith's balanced analytical approach. Cross-reference the four maxims at 5.2.3-6.

refashioned: The natural tendency of the window tax, and of all other taxes on houses, is to lower rents. The more a person pays in tax, the less he can obviously afford to pay in rent. Since the window tax was imposed, however, house rents have generally risen in almost every town and village in Great Britain with which I am acquainted. The demand for houses has increased so much that it has raised rents more than the window tax could reduce them -- one of many proofs of the country's great prosperity and the rising incomes of its people. Had it not been for the tax, rents would probably have risen even higher.
elegant: House taxes naturally tend to lower rents, since tax payments reduce what tenants can pay in rent. Yet since the window tax was imposed, rents have risen almost everywhere in Britain -- demand has grown so strongly that it has more than offset the tax's downward pressure. Without the tax, rents would have risen even more.
summary: While house taxes naturally depress rents, Britain's house rents have risen despite the window tax because surging demand has overwhelmed its downward pressure. This demonstrates the country's growing prosperity.
distilled: The window tax's natural tendency to depress rents has been overwhelmed by Britain's rising prosperity and growing housing demand.
notes: Key insight on tax incidence versus market forces -- a tax can depress prices while overall market conditions push them higher. The counterfactual reasoning ('had it not been for the tax, rents would have risen higher') is analytically sophisticated. Smith reads the evidence as proof of prosperity rather than tax ineffectiveness.

refashioned:
ARTICLE II -- Taxes upon Profit, or upon Revenue Arising from Capital.

The revenue or profit arising from capital naturally divides itself into two parts: the portion that pays interest and belongs to the owner of the capital, and the surplus that remains after the interest has been paid.
elegant: Profit from capital has two components: the interest paid to the capital's owner, and the surplus remaining beyond that interest payment.
summary: Profit from capital divides into two parts: interest paid to the capital owner and the surplus beyond interest. This section heading introduces the analysis of taxes on profit.
distilled: Profit from capital splits into interest owed to the owner and the surplus remaining after interest is paid.
notes: Article II heading. Smith distinguishes between the return to capital ownership (interest) and the return to enterprise (surplus profit above interest). This decomposition is crucial to his tax incidence analysis -- each component has different taxability. Cross-reference Book I on the natural components of price.

refashioned: This surplus portion of profit is clearly not a proper subject for direct taxation. It is the compensation -- and in most cases only a very modest compensation -- for the risk and trouble of employing capital. The employer must receive this compensation, or he cannot rationally continue the business. If taxed directly on his entire profit, he would be forced either to raise his rate of profit or to charge the tax against the interest on money -- that is, to pay less interest. If he raised his profit rate proportionally to the tax, the whole tax, though he might advance it initially, would ultimately be paid by one of two different groups, depending on how he employed his capital. If he used it as farming capital to cultivate land, he could raise his profit only by keeping a larger share -- or the value of a larger share -- of the land's produce. Since this could only be done by reducing rent, the final payment would fall on the landlord. If he used it as commercial or manufacturing capital, he could raise his profit only by raising the price of his goods, in which case consumers would bear the final cost. If he did not raise his profit rate, he would have to charge the entire tax against the interest portion of his returns. He could afford to pay less interest on whatever capital he borrowed, and the full weight of the tax would fall on the interest of money. To whatever extent he could not relieve himself in one way, he would be compelled to relieve himself in the other.
elegant: The surplus profit beyond interest -- merely compensation for risk and trouble -- cannot bear direct taxation. If taxed on total profit, the employer must either raise his profit rate or pay less interest. Higher farming profits mean lower rents, falling on landlords. Higher commercial profits mean higher prices, falling on consumers. Lower interest payments fall on lenders. The tax is always shifted to someone else -- landlords, consumers, or capital owners.
summary: Surplus profit above interest merely compensates for business risk and cannot bear direct taxation. Any such tax would be shifted: onto landlords through reduced rents, onto consumers through higher prices, or onto lenders through lower interest rates.
distilled: Taxing business profits directly is futile because the tax will always be shifted onto landlords, consumers, or lenders.
notes: Central to Smith's tax incidence theory. The three channels of tax shifting -- rent reduction, price increases, interest reduction -- anticipate modern public finance analysis. The argument rests on the assumption that entrepreneurs require a minimum return for risk-bearing. Cross-reference Book I on profits as compensation for risk (1.9-1.10).

refashioned: At first glance, the interest of money seems equally suitable for direct taxation as the rent of land. Like land rent, interest is a net return remaining after fully compensating for all the risk and trouble of employing capital. Just as a tax on land rent cannot raise rents -- because the net produce remaining after replacing the farmer's capital and providing his reasonable profit cannot be greater after the tax than before it -- so, for the same reason, a tax on interest should not raise the interest rate, assuming the total quantity of capital in the country remains the same after the tax as before. The ordinary rate of profit, as I showed in the first book, is everywhere determined by the ratio of capital available for employment to the amount of business to be done. Neither the business to be done nor the capital available would be increased or decreased by a tax on interest, so the ordinary profit rate would remain unchanged. The portion of profit needed to compensate the employer for risk and trouble would also remain the same, since neither the risk nor the trouble is affected. The residue -- the portion belonging to the capital's owner that constitutes the interest of money -- would therefore necessarily remain unchanged as well. At first glance, then, interest appears to be just as fit a subject for direct taxation as land rent.
elegant: Interest on money appears equally taxable as land rent -- both are net returns after compensating for risk and effort. A tax on interest should not raise interest rates, since neither the supply of capital nor the demand for it changes. The profit rate, determined by the ratio of capital to business, stays the same. The risk-compensation portion stays the same. Therefore the residual interest portion should also stay the same. Interest seems, at first, a perfect tax base.
summary: Interest on money appears as suitable for taxation as land rent, since both are net returns. A tax on interest should not raise interest rates because it affects neither the supply of capital nor the volume of business requiring it.
distilled: Interest on money seems as taxable as land rent, since a tax on it should not change the interest rate when the supply of capital and demand for it remain constant.
notes: Smith constructs the theoretical parallel between land rent and interest as tax bases -- both are net surplus after costs. The 'at first sight' framing signals that objections will follow (5.2.88-89). The argument depends on capital immobility, which Smith will challenge. Cross-reference Book I on the determination of the profit rate.

refashioned:
There are, however, two circumstances that make interest on money a much less suitable subject for direct taxation than land rent.

First, the quantity and value of any person's land can never be kept secret and can always be determined with great accuracy. But the total amount of a person's capital is almost always a secret and can seldom be established with reasonable precision. It is also subject to nearly constant fluctuation. Rarely does a year pass -- frequently not a month, sometimes not a single day -- without it rising or falling. An inquiry into every person's private finances, one that would need to track all the fluctuations of his fortune in order to adjust the tax accordingly, would be a source of such continual and endless harassment that no one could endure it.
elegant: Two factors make interest a worse tax base than land rent. First, land holdings are public and easily valued, while capital holdings are nearly always secret and constantly fluctuating. An inquiry invasive enough to track every person's shifting fortune would impose intolerable harassment.
summary: Interest is harder to tax than land rent for two reasons. First, land is visible and stable in value, while capital is secret and constantly fluctuating, making accurate assessment impossibly intrusive.
distilled: Capital is a worse tax base than land because it is secret and constantly changing, making accurate assessment impossibly intrusive.
notes: First of two objections to taxing interest. The transparency/observability distinction between land and capital remains central to modern tax policy. The argument anticipates concerns about financial privacy and administrative feasibility. Cross-reference 5.2.89 for the second objection (capital mobility).

refashioned: Second, land is a subject that cannot be moved, whereas capital can be moved easily. The owner of land is necessarily a citizen of the particular country where his estate lies. The owner of capital is properly a citizen of the world, not necessarily tied to any particular country. He would be inclined to leave a country that subjected him to intrusive investigation and burdensome taxation, moving his capital to some country where he could conduct his business or enjoy his fortune more comfortably. By removing his capital, he would put an end to all the industry it had supported in the country he left. Capital cultivates land; capital employs labor. A tax that tends to drive capital away from any particular country would thereby tend to dry up every source of revenue, both for the sovereign and for society. Not only the profits of capital, but the rent of land and the wages of labor would all necessarily be diminished by its departure.
elegant: Second, land cannot move but capital can. The landowner is tied to his country; the capital owner is a citizen of the world who will flee intrusive taxes. His departure ends all the industry his capital supported -- for capital cultivates land and employs labor. A tax that drives away capital dries up every revenue source: profits, rents, and wages alike.
summary: Capital is mobile while land is not. Capital owners will flee countries with burdensome capital taxes, taking with them all the industry, employment, and revenue their capital supported.
distilled: Capital mobility makes capital taxes self-defeating -- owners will simply move their capital abroad, destroying domestic industry, employment, and revenue.
notes: Smith's most famous statement on capital mobility and tax competition. 'A citizen of the world' is a landmark phrase in the history of globalization. The argument that capital flight destroys wages and rents -- not just profits -- shows the interconnectedness of factor returns. Anticipates modern debates about corporate tax havens and the 'race to the bottom.' Cross-reference Book II on capital as the driver of productive employment.

refashioned: The nations that have attempted to tax the revenue from capital, therefore, instead of undertaking any rigorous investigation, have been forced to content themselves with very rough and consequently more or less arbitrary estimates. The extreme inequality and uncertainty of a tax assessed in this manner can only be tolerated because of the tax's extreme moderation. As a result, every person finds himself assessed so far below his actual income that he does not much trouble himself even if his neighbor is assessed somewhat lower still.
elegant: Nations that have tried to tax capital income have had to settle for rough, arbitrary estimates rather than rigorous assessment. The resulting inequality is tolerable only because the tax is kept very moderate -- everyone is rated so far below their real income that minor discrepancies between taxpayers cause little complaint.
summary: Countries taxing capital income have relied on rough, arbitrary estimates rather than precise assessment. This inequality is tolerable only because the tax rate is kept extremely low, so everyone is assessed far below their actual income.
distilled: Capital income taxes survive only by being kept so moderate that their inevitable inaccuracy and inequality cause little complaint.
notes: Practical resolution of the theoretical difficulties in 5.2.88-89. The tradeoff between accuracy and moderation is a fundamental insight -- imprecise taxes must be light to be politically sustainable. This logic applies to many modern tax compliance challenges.

refashioned: What is called the land tax in England was intended to tax capital in the same proportion as land. When the land tax was at four shillings per pound, or one-fifth of the supposed rent, capital was intended to be taxed at one-fifth of the supposed interest. When the current annual land tax was first imposed, the legal interest rate was six percent. Every hundred pounds of capital was accordingly supposed to be taxed at twenty-four shillings -- one-fifth of six pounds. Since the legal interest rate was reduced to five percent, every hundred pounds of capital is supposed to be taxed at only twenty shillings. The total sum to be raised by the land tax was divided between the countryside and the principal towns. The greater part was levied on the countryside, and of the portion levied on towns, most was assessed on houses. What remained to be assessed on the capital or trade of the towns -- since capital used on land was not meant to be taxed -- was far below the real value of that capital or trade. Whatever inequalities existed in the original assessment therefore caused little complaint. Every parish and district continues to be rated for its land, houses, and capital according to the original assessment, and the nearly universal prosperity of the country, which has greatly increased the value of all these in most places, has made those inequalities even less important. Moreover, since the rate on each district stays constant, the uncertainty of this tax, insofar as it applies to any individual's capital, has been greatly reduced. If most English land is not rated to the land tax at half its actual value, most English capital is probably rated at scarcely a fiftieth of its actual value. In some towns, the entire land tax is assessed on houses -- as in Westminster, where capital and trade are exempt. London is different.
elegant: England's land tax was meant to tax capital at the same rate as land -- one-fifth of supposed interest. But as prosperity increased values far beyond the original fixed assessments, capital became taxed at perhaps a fiftieth of its real value, compared to about half for land. The fixed assessment makes the tax predictable but increasingly disconnected from reality, though universal prosperity makes the inequality tolerable.
summary: England's land tax intended to tax capital and land equally, but fixed assessments mean capital is now taxed at perhaps a fiftieth of its true value while land is taxed at about half. Rising prosperity has made this inequality tolerable.
distilled: England's land tax on capital, based on frozen assessments, now captures perhaps a fiftieth of capital's true value compared to about half for land.
notes: Detailed case study of how fixed assessments create growing disconnects between tax liability and actual values. The fiftieth vs. half comparison dramatically illustrates capital's undertaxation. Westminster's exemption of capital and trade shows how political power shapes tax geography. Cross-reference 5.2.77 on the parallel problem with house assessments.

refashioned:
In all countries, severe investigation into private citizens' finances has been carefully avoided.

At Hamburg, every inhabitant is required to pay the state one-quarter of one percent of all he possesses. Since the wealth of Hamburg's people consists mainly of capital, this may be considered a tax on capital.
