Every person assesses himself and, in the presence of the magistrate, deposits annually into the public treasury a certain sum of money that he swears, under oath, to be one-quarter percent of everything he possesses -- without disclosing the total amount or being subject to any examination on the matter. This tax is generally believed to be paid with great honesty. In a small republic, where people have complete confidence in their magistrates, are convinced the tax is necessary for the state's support, and believe it will be faithfully applied to that purpose, such conscientious and voluntary payment may sometimes be expected. This is not unique to the people of Hamburg.
elegant: All countries have avoided severe investigation of private wealth. Hamburg requires each citizen to pay 0.25% of total wealth, self-assessed under oath without disclosure or examination. In a small republic where people trust their government and believe the tax necessary and fairly applied, such voluntary honesty can work.
summary: Hamburg taxes wealth at 0.25% through self-assessment under oath, without disclosure or investigation. This works because citizens of a small republic trust their government and believe the tax necessary and honestly administered.
distilled: Hamburg's self-assessed wealth tax succeeds through civic trust in a small republic, avoiding the intrusive investigations that larger states cannot.
notes: Illustrates how social trust substitutes for enforcement in small polities. The self-assessment model with oath but no audit is remarkable -- Smith treats it as evidence of civic virtue. Anticipates modern research on tax morale and voluntary compliance. The 0.25% rate exemplifies the moderation principle from 5.2.90.

refashioned: The canton of Unterwalden in Switzerland is frequently ravaged by storms and floods, exposing it to extraordinary expenses. On such occasions the people assemble, and every person is said to declare with the greatest frankness what he is worth, so he can be taxed accordingly. At Zurich, the law requires that in times of necessity, everyone should be taxed in proportion to his income, the amount of which he must declare under oath. They reportedly have no suspicion that any fellow citizen would deceive them. At Basel, the state's principal revenue comes from a small customs duty on exported goods. All citizens take an oath to pay every three months all legally imposed taxes. All merchants, and even all innkeepers, are entrusted with keeping their own accounts of goods sold within or outside the territory. At the end of every three months, they send this account to the treasurer, with the tax amount computed at the bottom. The revenue is not thought to suffer from this system of trust.
elegant: In Swiss cantons, self-assessment works through civic trust. In Unterwalden, citizens publicly declare their worth for emergency taxation. In Zurich, everyone declares income under oath with no suspicion of dishonesty. In Basel, merchants and innkeepers self-report their sales for customs duties. In all cases, the revenue is believed to suffer nothing from this honor system.
summary: Swiss cantons of Unterwalden, Zurich, and Basel all rely on self-reported wealth or income declarations under oath for taxation, and in each case, citizens are trusted to report honestly with apparently good results.
distilled: Swiss cantons successfully tax through self-assessment and public declaration, relying on civic trust rather than coercive investigation.
notes: Three Swiss case studies of trust-based taxation -- Unterwalden (emergency wealth declaration), Zurich (income oath), Basel (merchant self-reporting of sales). Smith presents small, homogeneous republics as environments where social capital replaces enforcement capital. Anticipates Elinor Ostrom's work on community governance.

refashioned: To require every citizen to publicly declare under oath the amount of his fortune is apparently not considered a hardship in those Swiss cantons. In Hamburg, it would be considered the greatest hardship imaginable. Merchants engaged in the risky ventures of trade all shudder at the thought of being forced to expose the true state of their affairs at all times. They foresee that the ruin of their credit and the failure of their ventures would too often be the consequence. A sober and thrifty people, strangers to such risky ventures, do not feel they have any need for such concealment.
elegant: Public wealth declarations are no hardship in the Swiss cantons, but would be intolerable in Hamburg. Merchants in hazardous trade fear that exposing their true finances would ruin their credit and destroy their ventures. A sober, thrifty people with no such risky enterprises feel no need for financial secrecy.
summary: Public wealth declaration works in simple, thrifty Swiss communities but would terrify Hamburg's merchants, whose risky ventures depend on credit that would collapse if their true financial position were publicly revealed.
distilled: Financial transparency in taxation is tolerable for simple, thrifty communities but destructive for trading societies where credit depends on financial secrecy.
notes: Explains why trust-based taxation cannot be universalized -- commercial societies require credit, and credit requires confidentiality. The sober/thrifty versus mercantile distinction maps onto the small republic vs. commercial state divide. Anticipates modern tensions between tax transparency and commercial privacy.

refashioned: In Holland, soon after the Prince of Orange was elevated to the stadtholdership, a tax of two percent -- the so-called fiftieth penny -- was imposed on the entire wealth of every citizen. Each citizen assessed himself and paid the tax in the same manner as at Hamburg, and it was generally believed to have been paid with great honesty. The people at that time had the greatest affection for their new government, which they had just established through a general insurrection. The tax was to be paid only once, to relieve the state in a particular emergency. It was indeed too heavy to be permanent. In a country where the market interest rate seldom exceeds three percent, a two percent tax amounts to thirteen shillings and fourpence per pound on the highest net income commonly drawn from capital. Very few people could pay such a tax without eating into their capital. In a specific emergency, people may, from great public spirit, make an extraordinary effort and even sacrifice part of their capital to relieve the state. But they cannot continue doing so for long. If they did, the tax would soon ruin them completely, making them entirely unable to support the state.
elegant: Holland once imposed a 2% wealth tax -- the 'fiftieth penny' -- during a patriotic emergency after the Prince of Orange's rise. Paid through self-assessment with apparent honesty, it was too heavy to sustain. With interest at 3%, a 2% wealth tax equates to two-thirds of capital income. Citizens may sacrifice capital once from patriotic zeal, but sustained capital consumption would ruin them and ultimately destroy the tax base.
summary: Holland's emergency 2% wealth tax succeeded through patriotic self-assessment but was too heavy to sustain. At 3% interest rates, it consumed two-thirds of capital income, meaning continued payment would destroy taxpayers' capital and ultimately the state's revenue base.
distilled: Holland's one-time 2% wealth tax worked through patriotic fervor but would have been ruinous as a permanent measure, consuming far more than capital income at prevailing interest rates.
notes: Historical case study showing the limits of even popular, trust-based taxation. The math is crucial: at 3% interest, a 2% wealth tax takes 67% of income -- clearly unsustainable. Distinguishes between what citizens will do once in emergency versus what they can sustain. The Laffer curve logic is implicit -- excessive taxation destroys the base.

refashioned: The tax on capital imposed by England's land tax bill, though proportioned to capital, is not intended to diminish or take away any part of that capital. It is meant only to be a tax on the interest of money, proportioned to the tax on land rent, so that when the latter is at four shillings per pound, the former is also at four shillings per pound. The Hamburg tax, and the still more moderate taxes of Unterwalden and Zurich, are similarly intended as taxes not on capital itself, but on the interest or net income from capital. Holland's tax, by contrast, was intended as a tax on capital itself.
elegant: England's land tax on capital, and the taxes at Hamburg, Unterwalden, and Zurich, are all intended as taxes on the interest from capital, not on capital itself. Only Holland's fiftieth penny was designed as an actual tax on capital.
summary: Most capital taxes in England, Hamburg, and the Swiss cantons are intended as taxes on capital income, not on capital itself. Only Holland's emergency tax was explicitly a tax on the capital stock.
distilled: Most so-called capital taxes are actually taxes on capital income; only Holland's fiftieth penny was truly a tax on the capital stock itself.
notes: Important conceptual distinction between taxing capital (the stock) and taxing capital income (the flow). This distinction remains central in modern tax policy -- wealth taxes vs. income taxes on investment returns. Cross-reference 5.2.95 on why taxing the stock is unsustainable.

refashioned:
Taxes upon the Profits of Particular Employments.

In some countries, special taxes are imposed on the profits of capital -- sometimes when employed in particular branches of trade, and sometimes when employed in agriculture.
elegant: Some countries impose special taxes on profits in specific trades or in agriculture.
summary: This section introduces taxes targeted at profits in specific industries or in agriculture, as distinct from general taxes on capital income.
distilled: Some countries tax profits in specific trades or agriculture rather than taxing capital income generally.
notes: Section heading introducing industry-specific profit taxes. The trade vs. agriculture distinction will be explored in detail -- taxes on commercial profits are shifted to consumers, while agricultural profit taxes fall on landlords. Cross-reference 5.2.98-112.

refashioned: Examples of taxes on specific trades in England include the tax on hawkers and peddlers, that on hackney coaches and chairs, and the licensing fee that alehouse keepers pay for the right to sell ale and spirits. During a recent war, another tax of the same kind was proposed on shops. The justification offered was that since the war had been undertaken to defend the country's trade, the merchants who stood to profit from it ought to contribute toward its cost.
elegant: English examples of trade-specific profit taxes include levies on hawkers, hackney coaches, and alehouse licenses. During a recent war, a shop tax was proposed on the grounds that merchants who benefited from the war should help pay for it.
summary: England taxes specific trades through levies on hawkers, hackney coaches, and alehouse licenses. A wartime shop tax was once proposed on the argument that merchants benefiting from the war should contribute to its costs.
distilled: England taxes specific trades through licenses on hawkers, hackney coaches, and alehouses, and once considered a wartime shop tax.
notes: Concrete examples of occupation-specific taxation. The war-justification for the shop tax illustrates benefit-based taxation -- those who gain from government action should pay for it. This anticipates modern arguments about industry-specific taxes and user fees.

refashioned: A tax on the profits of capital employed in any particular trade, however, can never ultimately fall on the dealers themselves -- who must in ordinary circumstances earn their reasonable profit, and where competition is free, can seldom earn more than that profit. The tax always falls on the consumers, who must pay, in the price of goods, the tax that the dealer has advanced, generally with some additional markup.
elegant: A tax on profits in any specific trade never ultimately falls on the dealers, who require their reasonable profit in competitive markets. It always falls on consumers through higher prices, typically with an additional markup beyond the tax itself.
summary: Taxes on profits in competitive trades are always passed through to consumers via higher prices, since dealers must earn their normal profit and cannot absorb the tax.
distilled: Taxes on trade profits are always shifted to consumers through higher prices because competitive dealers cannot absorb them.
notes: Fundamental tax incidence principle: in competitive markets, taxes on sellers are passed to buyers. The 'overcharge' beyond the tax amount is the dealer's profit on the capital tied up in advancing the tax -- an early recognition of gross-up effects. Cross-reference 5.2.86 on the shifting mechanisms.

refashioned: When such a tax is proportioned to the dealer's volume of trade, it is ultimately paid by the consumer without oppressing the dealer. When it is not proportioned but instead charged equally to all dealers, then although it is still ultimately paid by the consumer, it advantages the large dealer and creates some hardship for the small dealer. The tax of five shillings per week on every hackney coach and ten shillings per year on every hackney chair, insofar as it is advanced by the respective keepers, is appropriately proportioned to the scale of their businesses. It neither favors the large operator nor burdens the small one.
elegant: A trade tax proportioned to volume falls on consumers without oppressing dealers. A flat tax on all dealers also falls on consumers but favors the large over the small. The per-vehicle taxes on hackney coaches and chairs are properly proportioned to business scale, treating large and small operators fairly.
summary: Trade taxes proportioned to business volume treat large and small dealers fairly. Flat-rate taxes on all dealers, though still paid by consumers, advantage large operators who can more easily absorb and recover the fixed cost.
distilled: Proportional trade taxes treat all dealers fairly, while flat-rate taxes favor large operators over small ones, though consumers ultimately pay either way.
notes: Key distinction between proportional and flat-rate business taxes and their competitive effects. The regressive nature of flat fees on small businesses is a principle that remains central to modern tax design. The hackney coach example shows a naturally proportional tax (per vehicle). Cross-reference Smith's first maxim on proportionality (5.2.3).

refashioned: The tax of twenty shillings a year for a license to sell ale, forty shillings for a license to sell spirits, and forty shillings more for a license to sell wine, being the same for all retailers, necessarily gives some advantage to the large dealer and creates some hardship for the small one. The large dealer finds it easier to recover the tax in the price of his goods than the small dealer does. The moderation of the tax, however, makes this inequality less important, and many people may think it not unreasonable to somewhat discourage the proliferation of small alehouses.
elegant: Flat licensing fees for ale, spirits, and wine sellers advantage large retailers who more easily recover the cost. But the tax is moderate enough to make this inequality tolerable, and some may see merit in discouraging the proliferation of small alehouses.
summary: Flat licensing fees for alcohol retailers favor large dealers over small ones, but the tax is moderate enough to make the inequality tolerable and may usefully discourage the proliferation of small alehouses.
distilled: Flat alcohol licensing fees favor large retailers but are moderate enough that the inequality is tolerable and may usefully limit the number of small alehouses.
notes: Practical application of the proportional vs. flat tax principle. Smith's tolerance of the inequality here rests on two grounds: moderation of the tax, and a quasi-sumptuary purpose (limiting alehouses). This is one of Smith's concessions to social policy objectives in taxation. Cross-reference 5.2.100.

refashioned: The proposed shop tax was intended to be the same for all shops. It could scarcely have been otherwise. Proportioning the tax to the volume of trade in each shop, with any tolerable accuracy, would have required an investigation utterly insupportable in a free country. Had the tax been substantial, it would have crushed small retailers and driven virtually all retail trade into the hands of large dealers. With the competition of small retailers eliminated, the large dealers would have enjoyed a monopoly and, like all monopolists, would soon have conspired to raise their profits far beyond what was needed to pay the tax.
elegant: The shop tax had to be flat -- proportioning it to each shop's trade would have required intolerable investigation. But a substantial flat tax would have crushed small retailers, creating monopoly conditions in which large dealers would have conspired to raise prices far beyond the tax.
summary: A flat shop tax was the only practical option since proportional assessment would require intolerable investigation, but any substantial flat tax would destroy small retailers, create monopolies among large dealers, and lead to price gouging.
distilled: A flat shop tax would destroy small retailers and create monopolies, while a proportional shop tax would require intolerable government investigation.
notes: Classic dilemma between proportional and flat taxation when business volumes cannot be observed. Smith's anti-monopoly reasoning is characteristic -- eliminating small competitors leads to collusive pricing. The 'insupportable in a free country' standard shows his libertarian baseline for acceptable tax administration. Cross-reference 5.2.100-101.

refashioned:
The final burden, instead of falling on the shopkeeper, would have fallen on the consumer, with a considerable markup added to the shopkeeper's profit. For these reasons, the shop tax proposal was abandoned and replaced by the subsidy of 1759.

What in France is called the personal taille is perhaps the most important tax on the profits of capital employed in agriculture that is levied anywhere in Europe.
elegant: The shop tax would ultimately have burdened consumers with inflated monopoly prices, so the proposal was dropped in favor of the subsidy of 1759. France's personal taille is perhaps Europe's most significant tax on agricultural profits.
summary: The shop tax was abandoned because it would have created monopoly pricing harming consumers, replaced by the 1759 subsidy. France's personal taille is introduced as Europe's most important tax on agricultural profits.
distilled: The shop tax was abandoned to prevent monopoly pricing, and France's personal taille is introduced as Europe's chief agricultural profit tax.
notes: Transition from English trade taxes to the French taille. The shop tax episode illustrates how theoretical objections can kill tax proposals. The personal taille will be analyzed extensively as a case study in how agricultural profit taxes distort farming. Cross-reference 5.2.104-111.

refashioned: During the disorderly period of feudal government in Europe, the sovereign was forced to content himself with taxing those too weak to refuse. The great lords, though willing to assist him in particular emergencies, refused to submit to any regular tax, and he was not strong enough to compel them. The occupiers of land throughout Europe were, for the most part, originally bondmen. Across most of Europe, they were gradually emancipated. Some acquired landed property, which they held under base or ignoble tenure -- sometimes under the king, sometimes under another great lord, like the ancient copyholders of England. Others, without acquiring ownership, obtained leases for terms of years on the lands they occupied under their lord, and thus became less dependent on him.
elegant: Under feudalism, sovereigns could only tax the weak -- great lords refused regular taxation. Land occupiers, originally bondmen, gradually gained freedom: some acquired land under ignoble tenure, others obtained leases. Both paths reduced their dependence on the great lords.
summary: Feudal sovereigns could only tax the powerless, as great lords refused regular taxation. Agricultural workers, originally bondmen, gradually gained independence through either land ownership under base tenure or long-term leases.
distilled: Feudal taxation fell on the weak because great lords refused it, while agricultural workers gradually escaped bondage through land ownership or leases.
notes: Historical context for the personal taille -- explains why agricultural workers became the primary tax base. The emancipation narrative connects to Book III's account of feudal decline. The copyhold comparison links English and continental legal traditions. Cross-reference Book III on the liberation of serfs and the rise of tenant farming.

refashioned: The great lords appear to have viewed the growing prosperity and independence of this lower class of men with malicious and contemptuous resentment, and they willingly consented to let the sovereign tax them. In some countries, this tax was confined to lands held under ignoble tenure, and in this case the taille was called 'real.' The land tax established by the late King of Sardinia, and the taille in the provinces of Languedoc, Provence, Dauphine, and Brittany -- as well as in the generality of Montauban, the elections of Agen and Condom, and certain other French districts -- are taxes on lands held under ignoble tenure. In other countries, the tax was levied on the presumed profits of all those who farmed or leased lands belonging to others, regardless of the owner's tenure, and in this case the taille was called 'personal.'
elegant: Great lords, resenting the rising prosperity of lower classes, gladly let the sovereign tax them. Where the tax applied only to land held under ignoble tenure, it was called 'real' taille. Where it targeted the supposed profits of all tenant farmers regardless of the owner's tenure, it was called 'personal' taille.
summary: Resentful great lords consented to the sovereign taxing the increasingly prosperous lower classes. The 'real' taille taxed land held under ignoble tenure; the 'personal' taille taxed the presumed profits of all tenant farmers regardless of land tenure.
distilled: The taille emerged from feudal lords' willingness to let the sovereign tax their newly independent tenants, taking either a 'real' form based on land tenure or a 'personal' form based on estimated farming profits.
notes: The real vs. personal taille distinction is crucial for understanding French fiscal history. The 'malignant and contemptuous indignation' language is unusually emotional for Smith, revealing his sympathy for the emerging middle class. Geographic detail shows the taille was not uniform across France -- a theme of ancien regime fiscal fragmentation.

refashioned: In most of those French provinces known as the pays d'elections, the taille is of the personal kind. The real taille, being imposed on only part of the country's lands, is necessarily unequal, but it is not always arbitrary -- though it can be so on occasion. The personal taille, since it is intended to be proportioned to the profits of a certain class of people whose profits can only be guessed at, is necessarily both arbitrary and unequal.
elegant: In France's pays d'elections, the personal taille predominates. The real taille is unequal but not necessarily arbitrary. The personal taille, targeting profits that can only be guessed at, is inevitably both arbitrary and unequal.
summary: The personal taille, predominant in France's pays d'elections, is necessarily both arbitrary and unequal because it attempts to tax profits that can only be estimated. The real taille is unequal but not always arbitrary.
distilled: The personal taille is inherently both arbitrary and unequal because it taxes farming profits that can only be guessed at.
notes: Connects to Smith's general critique of profit taxation from 5.2.88 -- the impossibility of accurately assessing private incomes. The pays d'elections were provinces under direct royal tax administration, as opposed to pays d'etats which had their own assemblies. The distinction between unequal-but-certain and arbitrary-and-unequal reflects Smith's hierarchy of tax evils.

refashioned: In France, the personal taille currently (1775) imposes 40,107,239 livres and 16 sous annually on the twenty generalities called the pays d'elections. The proportion assessed on each province varies from year to year according to reports made to the king's council concerning crop quality and other circumstances that may increase or decrease their respective ability to pay. Each generality is divided into elections, and the sum imposed on the whole generality is divided among these elections, again varying annually according to similar reports. It seems impossible that the council, even with the best intentions, could ever proportion either of these assessments with tolerable accuracy to the real capacity of the province or district. Ignorance and misinformation must always, to some degree, mislead even the most well-meaning council.
elegant: France's personal taille raises over 40 million livres annually, allocated among provinces and districts by the king's council based on yearly reports about crops and local conditions. Even with the best intentions, the council cannot accurately proportion these assessments -- ignorance and misinformation inevitably distort the process.
summary: France's personal taille raises over 40 million livres, allocated among provinces based on annual crop reports. Even the most well-intentioned council cannot accurately proportion these assessments due to inevitable ignorance and misinformation.
distilled: France's annual taille allocation among provinces is inevitably inaccurate because the central council lacks the information needed to assess each district's true capacity.
notes: Information problem in centralized tax allocation -- the council lacks local knowledge to set accurate rates. This is essentially a Hayekian knowledge problem avant la lettre. The annual variation adds uncertainty for taxpayers. The specific figure (40+ million livres) gives concrete scale to the discussion.

refashioned: The share each parish should bear of the election's assessment, and each individual's share of the parish assessment, are both likewise varied from year to year according to supposed circumstances. In one case, these circumstances are judged by the election's officers; in the other, by parish officers -- and both are more or less under the direction and influence of the intendant. Not only ignorance and misinformation, but friendship, political animosity, and personal resentment are said frequently to influence such assessors. No person subject to such a tax can ever be certain, before being assessed, of what he will owe. He cannot even be certain after being assessed.
elegant: Parish and individual assessments also change yearly, judged by local and election officers under the intendant's influence. Beyond mere ignorance, friendship, faction, and personal grudges corrupt the process. No taxpayer can know what he owes -- not before assessment, and not even after.
summary: Individual taille assessments change yearly, determined by local officials subject to the intendant's influence and corrupted by favoritism, political grudges, and personal animosity. Taxpayers can never be certain what they owe.
distilled: The personal taille's yearly reassessment by corruptible local officials makes the tax radically uncertain for every taxpayer.
notes: Devastating critique of discretionary taxation. The corruption channels -- friendship, party animosity, private resentment -- show how arbitrary power invites abuse. 'Cannot even be certain after he is assessed' implies the assessment itself can be challenged or changed. Violates Smith's second maxim (certainty) catastrophically. Cross-reference 5.2.4.

refashioned: If someone has been taxed who should have been exempt, or taxed beyond his fair share, both must pay in the meantime. If they complain and prove their case, the entire parish is reimposed the following year to reimburse them. If any contributor goes bankrupt or becomes insolvent, the collector must advance his tax, and the whole parish is reimposed the next year to reimburse the collector. If the collector himself goes bankrupt, the parish that elected him must answer for his conduct to the receiver-general of the election. Since prosecuting an entire parish would be troublesome, the receiver-general typically selects five or six of the richest contributors and forces them to make up the loss caused by the collector's insolvency.
elegant: Wrongly assessed taxpayers must pay first and seek reimbursement later through reimposition on the whole parish. If contributors or collectors go bankrupt, the parish absorbs the loss. The receiver-general, rather than prosecuting the whole parish, typically forces five or six of the richest citizens to cover shortfalls.
summary: The taille system forces wrongly assessed taxpayers to pay first and seek parish-wide reimbursement later. Bankruptcies among taxpayers or collectors are covered by reimposing on the parish, with the richest members often forced to make up shortfalls.
distilled: The taille's correction mechanism is itself oppressive -- errors and bankruptcies are covered by reimposing costs on the parish, especially its wealthiest members.
notes: Illustrates cascading oppression in the taille system. The 'pay first, complain later' structure places all risk on the taxpayer. Collective liability for individual defaults creates perverse incentives. Targeting the five or six richest for shortfalls is a crude form of progressive liability that punishes success. Each correction mechanism generates new injustice.

refashioned:
The parish is then reimposed to reimburse those five or six wealthy contributors. Such reimpositions are always on top of the regular taille for that particular year.

When a tax is imposed on profits in a particular branch of trade, the dealers are all careful to bring no more goods to market than they can sell at a price sufficient to recoup the tax they have advanced. Some withdraw part of their capital from the trade, and the market is supplied more sparingly than before. Prices rise, and the final burden of the tax falls on the consumer. But when a tax is imposed on profits from agricultural capital, it is not in the farmers' interest to withdraw any capital from farming. Each farmer occupies a certain amount of land for which he pays rent. Proper cultivation requires a certain amount of capital, and by withdrawing any part of this necessary capital, the farmer is unlikely to become more able to pay either his rent or the tax. To pay the tax, it can never be in his interest to reduce his output, nor consequently to supply the market more sparingly. The tax will therefore never enable him to raise prices so as to shift the burden onto consumers. Yet the farmer must earn his reasonable profit like any other businessman, or he must quit the trade. After such a tax is imposed, he can obtain this reasonable profit only by paying less rent to the landlord. The more he pays in tax, the less he can afford in rent. Such a tax, imposed during an existing lease, may indeed ruin the farmer. But upon lease renewal, it must always fall on the landlord.
elegant:
Reimpositions to cover these corrections pile on top of the regular annual taille.

Trade taxes cause dealers to restrict supply, raising prices and shifting the burden to consumers. Agricultural taxes work differently: farmers cannot reduce capital without reducing output, and reduced output does not help them pay the tax. Unable to raise prices, farmers can only maintain their necessary profit by paying less rent. The tax therefore falls on landlords -- ruinously for farmers during existing leases, but permanently upon renewal.
summary: Trade taxes are shifted to consumers through reduced supply and higher prices. Agricultural profit taxes cannot be similarly shifted because farmers cannot profitably reduce their capital or output. Instead, the tax reduces what farmers can pay in rent, ultimately falling on landlords.
distilled: Agricultural profit taxes fall on landlords through reduced rents because farmers, unlike merchants, cannot restrict supply to raise prices.
notes: Critical distinction in tax incidence between trade and agriculture. In trade, supply is elastic -- dealers withdraw capital and prices adjust. In farming, capital is tied to fixed land commitments and cannot be withdrawn without self-harm. This is one of Smith's most important incidence arguments. The timing distinction (mid-lease ruin vs. renewal adjustment) shows how institutional rigidities affect tax burden distribution. Cross-reference 5.2.86 and 5.2.99.

refashioned: In countries where the personal taille is in force, the farmer is commonly assessed in proportion to the capital he appears to employ in cultivation. He is therefore frequently afraid to keep a good team of horses or oxen, and instead strives to cultivate with the most wretched and inferior equipment he can manage. So deep is his distrust of his assessors' fairness that he counterfeits poverty, wishing to appear barely able to pay anything, for fear of being forced to pay too much. By this miserable strategy, he does not necessarily serve his own best interest. He probably loses more from the reduction in his output than he saves from the reduction in his tax. Though this wretched cultivation does somewhat worsen the market's supply, the small price increase it causes is unlikely even to compensate the farmer for his lost output, much less to enable him to pay more rent to his landlord. The public, the farmer, and the landlord all suffer from this degraded cultivation. That the personal taille tends, in many ways, to discourage farming and thereby dry up the principal source of every great country's wealth is something I have already observed in the third book of this inquiry.
elegant: Under the personal taille, farmers are taxed on their apparent capital, so they deliberately use inferior equipment and counterfeit poverty to avoid assessment. This self-defeating strategy reduces output more than it saves in taxes -- the slight price increase from reduced supply cannot compensate. The public, the farmer, and the landlord all lose. The personal taille systematically discourages the cultivation that is every nation's chief source of wealth.
summary: The personal taille causes farmers to deliberately appear poor to avoid high assessments, using inferior equipment that reduces output more than it saves in taxes. Everyone loses -- farmers, landlords, and the public alike.
distilled: The personal taille's assessment on visible capital causes farmers to deliberately degrade their farming, destroying more wealth than the tax collects.
notes: Classic example of tax-induced behavioral distortion. The farmer rationally (but self-defeatingly) reduces visible investment to lower tax liability. This is an early description of what economists now call the 'excess burden' or deadweight loss of taxation. Cross-reference Book III on agriculture as the foundation of national wealth. The observation that everyone loses -- a negative-sum outcome -- is a powerful indictment.

refashioned: What are called poll-taxes in the southern provinces of North America and in the West Indian islands -- annual taxes of so much per head on every enslaved person -- are properly taxes on the profits of a particular kind of capital employed in agriculture. Since the planters are for the most part both farmers and landlords, the final payment of the tax falls on them in their capacity as landlords, without any compensation.
elegant: Poll taxes on enslaved workers in the American South and West Indies are effectively taxes on agricultural capital profits. Since planters are both farmers and landlords, the tax falls on them as landlords with no way to shift the burden.
summary: Per-head taxes on enslaved workers in the American colonies and West Indies are effectively taxes on agricultural capital that fall entirely on planters in their dual role as farmer-landlords.
distilled: Colonial poll taxes on enslaved workers are agricultural profit taxes that fall entirely on planters who serve as both farmers and landlords.
notes: Smith treats enslaved people as 'capital employed in agriculture' -- reflecting the horrific economic logic of slavery while analyzing its tax implications. The planter's dual role as farmer and landlord means there is no one to shift the tax to. Cross-reference 5.2.110 on why agricultural taxes fall on landlords.

refashioned: Per-head taxes on agricultural bondmen appear to have been common throughout ancient Europe. Such a tax currently exists in the Russian Empire. It is probably for this reason that poll-taxes of all kinds have often been characterized as badges of slavery. However, every tax is, to the person who pays it, a badge not of slavery but of liberty. It signifies that he is subject to government, certainly, but that since he has some property, he cannot himself be the property of a master. A poll-tax on slaves is an entirely different thing from a poll-tax on free men. The latter is paid by the persons on whom it is imposed; the former is paid by a different set of persons entirely. The latter is either completely arbitrary or completely unequal, and in most cases is both; the former, though somewhat unequal -- different slaves having different values -- is in no way arbitrary. Every master who knows the number of his own slaves knows exactly what he has to pay. Yet because these different taxes share the same name, they have been treated as though they were the same in nature.
elegant: Per-head taxes on bondmen were common in ancient Europe and still exist in Russia, which is why poll-taxes are called 'badges of slavery.' But paying tax is actually a badge of liberty -- it means one has property and cannot be property. A poll-tax on slaves is paid by the master and is certain; a poll-tax on freemen is paid by the person taxed and is arbitrary. They share a name but differ fundamentally in nature.
summary: Despite being called badges of slavery, poll-taxes on freemen actually signal liberty -- having property and not being property. Poll-taxes on slaves and on freemen are fundamentally different: the former is certain and paid by masters, the latter is arbitrary and paid by the taxed individuals themselves.
distilled: Poll-taxes on freemen are badges of liberty, not slavery -- being taxed means you have property and cannot be another's property -- though they differ fundamentally from poll-taxes on slaves.
notes: Striking philosophical reversal -- taxation as a marker of freedom rather than oppression. The distinction between taxes on free persons (arbitrary, unequal) and taxes on slaves (certain, paid by masters) reveals how the same label obscures different economic realities. Smith's analysis of Russian bondage connects to his broader theme of serfdom's persistence. Cross-reference 5.2.104 on feudal taxation of the weak.

refashioned: The taxes imposed in Holland on male and female servants are taxes not on capital but on personal expenditure, and thus resemble taxes on consumable goods. The tax of a guinea per head for every male servant recently imposed in Great Britain is of the same kind. It falls most heavily on the middle ranks of society. A man with two hundred pounds a year may keep a single manservant. A man with ten thousand pounds a year will not keep fifty. It does not affect the poor.
elegant: Taxes on servants in Holland and Britain are consumption taxes, not capital taxes. Britain's guinea-per-servant tax falls heaviest on the middle classes -- a man of modest income may keep one servant, while a wealthy man will not keep proportionally more. The poor are unaffected.
summary: Taxes on servants are consumption taxes that fall disproportionately on the middle classes, since modest households keep servants but wealthy ones do not keep proportionally more. The poor are unaffected.
distilled: Servant taxes are consumption levies that fall most heavily on the middle classes because servant-keeping does not scale proportionally with wealth.
notes: Illustrates how a per-unit tax on a consumption item can be regressive within the servant-keeping population -- middle-class households pay a higher proportion of income. The observation that servant counts do not scale linearly with wealth is an empirical insight about luxury consumption patterns. Cross-reference 5.2.147 on necessaries vs. luxuries.

refashioned: Taxes on the profits of capital in particular employments can never affect the interest rate. Nobody will lend money at lower interest to those in taxed trades than to those in untaxed ones. But taxes on the revenue from capital in all employments, where the government attempts to collect them with any accuracy, will in many cases fall on the interest of money. The vingtieme, or twentieth penny, in France is a tax of the same kind as England's land tax, assessed on the revenue from land, houses, and capital alike. Insofar as it applies to capital, it is assessed with considerably more accuracy than the corresponding part of England's land tax, though still not with great rigor. It often falls entirely on the interest of money. Money in France is frequently invested in what are called contracts for the constitution of a rent -- that is, perpetual annuities redeemable at any time by the debtor but not callable by the creditor except in particular cases. The vingtieme does not appear to have raised the rate of these annuities, despite being precisely levied upon them all.
elegant: Taxes on profits in specific trades cannot affect interest rates -- lenders will not accept less from taxed trades than untaxed ones. But general taxes on capital income, if accurately collected, fall on interest. France's vingtieme, assessed on capital income more accurately than England's land tax, often falls entirely on interest. It has not raised the rate on perpetual annuities despite being levied precisely upon them.
summary: Industry-specific profit taxes cannot affect interest rates, but general capital income taxes collected with accuracy do fall on interest. France's vingtieme, more accurately assessed than England's equivalent, falls on interest without raising annuity rates.
distilled: Specific trade taxes cannot touch interest rates, but accurately collected general capital income taxes like France's vingtieme fall directly on interest.
notes: Important distinction between partial and general capital taxation. A tax on one industry cannot lower interest because capital flows to untaxed alternatives; a tax on all capital income has nowhere to escape. The vingtieme's failure to raise annuity rates confirms Smith's theory that accurately assessed capital income taxes fall on the capital owner. Cross-reference 5.2.87 on the theoretical parallel between interest and rent.

refashioned:
APPENDIX TO ARTICLES I AND II -- Taxes upon the Capital Value of Lands, Houses, and Stock.

While property remains in the same person's possession, whatever permanent taxes may have been imposed upon it, they have never been intended to diminish or take away any part of its capital value -- only some part of the revenue arising from it. But when property changes hands, whether transmitted from the dead to the living or from the living to the living, taxes have frequently been imposed that necessarily take away some part of its capital value.
elegant: Taxes on property held by the same owner target only revenue, not capital value. But taxes on property transfers -- from the dead to the living, or between living persons -- inevitably reduce capital value itself.
summary: Permanent taxes on property are designed to take revenue, not capital. But transfer taxes on property changing hands -- through inheritance or sale -- necessarily reduce the capital value of the property transferred.
distilled: Transfer taxes on property changing hands, unlike ongoing property taxes, necessarily diminish the capital value of the property itself.
notes: Appendix heading introducing transfer taxes -- inheritance taxes, stamp duties, and registration fees. The revenue-vs.-capital distinction is crucial: ongoing taxes take from income, but transfer taxes take from the stock. This sets up the analysis of death duties and sale taxes in 5.2.117-131.

refashioned: The transfer of all sorts of property from the dead to the living, and the transfer of immovable property -- land and houses -- from the living to the living, are transactions that are either publicly known by their nature or cannot be concealed for long. Such transactions can therefore be taxed directly. The transfer of capital or movable property between living persons through lending money is frequently a secret transaction and can always be made so. It cannot easily be taxed directly. It has been taxed indirectly in two ways: first, by requiring that the loan agreement be written on paper or parchment that has paid a certain stamp duty, on pain of invalidity; and second, by requiring, under the same penalty, that it be recorded in either a public or secret register, with certain duties imposed on the registration. Stamp duties and registration duties have also frequently been imposed on deeds transferring property of all kinds from the dead to the living, and on those transferring immovable property between living persons -- transactions that could easily have been taxed directly instead.
elegant: Property transfers from the dead and sales of land or houses are inherently public and can be taxed directly. But money lending is easily kept secret, so it is taxed indirectly through stamp duties on loan documents and registration fees. These same indirect taxes have also been extended to inheritances and land sales -- transactions that could have been taxed directly.
summary: Inheritances and land sales are public enough to tax directly, but money lending is secret and can only be taxed indirectly through stamp duties and registration fees. These indirect methods have been extended to all types of property transfer.
distilled: Property transfers are taxed directly when public (inheritances, land sales) and indirectly through stamp duties and registration when secret (money lending).
notes: Taxonomy of transfer taxation methods based on observability. The stamp duty mechanism -- voiding unstamped documents -- is an ingenious enforcement device that enlists the parties themselves in compliance. The extension of indirect methods to easily observed transactions suggests administrative convenience or revenue-seeking beyond necessity.

refashioned: The vicesima hereditatum, or the twentieth penny of inheritances, imposed by Augustus on the ancient Romans, was a tax on the transfer of property from the dead to the living. Dion Cassius, the author who writes about it least unclearly, says it was imposed on all successions, legacies, and donations in case of death, except those to the nearest relations and to the poor.
elegant: Augustus imposed the vicesima hereditatum -- a 5% inheritance tax -- on all Roman successions, legacies, and death-time donations, exempting only close relatives and the poor.
summary: Augustus imposed a 5% inheritance tax on all Roman successions and death-time donations, with exemptions for close relatives and the poor.
distilled: Augustus's Roman inheritance tax of 5% exempted only close relatives and the poor, establishing an ancient precedent for death duties.
notes: Historical precedent for inheritance taxation stretching back to ancient Rome. The exemption for nearest relations acknowledges that family inheritance is not pure windfall. The exemption for the poor recognizes ability-to-pay concerns. Dion Cassius as source -- Smith notes the historical record is unclear.

refashioned: Of the same kind is the Dutch tax on successions. Collateral successions are taxed according to the degree of relation, from five to thirty percent on the total value of the succession. Testamentary donations or legacies to collateral relations are subject to the same rates. Transfers from husband to wife, or wife to husband, are taxed at the fiftieth penny. The luctuosa hereditas -- the mournful succession of parents inheriting from their children -- is taxed at only the twentieth penny. Direct successions, those of children inheriting from parents, pay no tax at all. A father's death, for children living in the same household, seldom brings any increase in income and frequently brings a considerable decrease -- through the loss of his industry, his office, or some life-rent estate he may have held. A tax that aggravated their loss by taking part of his succession would be cruel and oppressive. However, it may sometimes be different for those children who, in Roman legal terms, are 'emancipated' -- or in Scottish law, 'foris-familiated' -- that is, who have already received their portion, established their own families, and are supported by resources independent of their father's. Whatever part of his succession came to such children would be a genuine addition to their fortune and might perhaps, without more hardship than accompanies all such duties, be subject to some tax. The feudal casualties were taxes on the transfer of land, both from the dead to the living and between living persons. In ancient times, they constituted one of the principal branches of crown revenue throughout Europe.
elegant: Holland taxes successions progressively: collateral heirs pay 5-30% based on degree of relation; spousal transfers pay 2%; parents inheriting from children pay 5%; children inheriting from parents pay nothing -- since a parent's death typically reduces rather than increases household income. An exception might apply to emancipated children living independently, for whom an inheritance is a genuine windfall. The feudal casualties were an ancient precedent -- transfer taxes on land that once formed a principal branch of crown revenue.
summary: Holland's succession tax is graduated by family relationship, from zero for children inheriting from parents to 30% for distant collateral heirs. The exemption for direct heirs recognizes that a parent's death usually decreases rather than increases family income.
distilled: Holland's inheritance tax ranges from zero for direct heirs to 30% for distant relatives, calibrated to the likelihood that the inheritance represents a genuine windfall.
notes: Sophisticated graduated inheritance tax based on degree of relation -- closer heirs pay less because the death is more likely to represent a loss than a gain. The luctuosa hereditas (mournful inheritance) concept acknowledges the economic loss of a breadwinner. The emancipated vs. dependent child distinction is analytically sharp. Feudal casualties mentioned as historical precedent for transfer taxes.

refashioned: The heir of every immediate vassal of the crown paid a certain duty -- generally a year's rent -- upon receiving investiture of the estate. If the heir was a minor, the entire rents of the estate during the minority went to the feudal superior, with no other obligation beyond maintaining the minor and paying the widow's dower when there was a dowager on the land. When the minor came of age, another tax called 'relief' was still due to the superior, generally amounting likewise to a year's rent. A long minority, which in modern times so often frees a great estate from all its debts and restores the family to its former splendor, could have no such effect in those times. The waste of the estate, not its recovery, was the usual result of a long minority.
elegant: Under feudal law, heirs paid a year's rent upon inheriting, and minors' entire estate rents went to the feudal lord during minority. Coming of age required another year's rent in 'relief.' Unlike today, when a long minority frees estates from debt, feudal minorities resulted in waste -- lords exploited the property rather than preserving it.
summary: Feudal inheritance taxes included a year's rent on succession and full estate revenues during minorities. Unlike today's debt-clearing minorities, feudal minorities meant estate waste as lords exploited the property.
distilled: Feudal inheritance duties -- a year's rent on succession plus full revenue seizure during minorities -- typically resulted in estate waste rather than recovery.
notes: Illustrates how feudal transfer taxes were far more burdensome than modern inheritance taxes. The contrast between feudal and modern minorities is striking -- the same institutional arrangement (minority) produces opposite economic outcomes depending on the legal framework. Cross-reference Book III on feudal institutional decay.

refashioned: Under feudal law, a vassal could not sell his land without the lord's consent, and the lord generally extorted a fine or composition for granting it. This fine, originally arbitrary, came in many countries to be fixed at a certain proportion of the sale price. In some countries where most other feudal customs have fallen out of use, this tax on land sales still yields a very considerable portion of the sovereign's revenue. In the canton of Berne, it is as high as a sixth of the price for noble fiefs and a tenth for ignoble ones. In the canton of Lucerne, the tax on land sales is not universal but applies only in certain districts. However, if anyone sells his land in order to leave the territory, he pays ten percent on the entire sale price. Similar taxes on the sale of all lands, or of lands held by certain tenures, exist in many other countries and form a more or less significant branch of the sovereign's revenue.
elegant: Feudal law required the lord's consent for land sales, typically obtained through a fine that eventually became a fixed proportion of the price. This land transfer tax persists in many countries -- a sixth of the price in Berne for noble fiefs, a tenth for ignoble ones. Lucerne imposes a 10% exit tax on those selling land to leave the territory. Such taxes remain significant revenue sources.
summary: The feudal requirement of lordly consent for land sales evolved into fixed transfer taxes. These persist in Swiss cantons as significant revenue sources, ranging from a tenth to a sixth of the sale price, with special exit taxes for those leaving the territory.
distilled: Feudal land sale fines evolved into fixed transfer taxes that persist in many countries, including Swiss cantons charging up to a sixth of the sale price.
notes: Shows how feudal institutions transform into modern fiscal instruments. The Berne distinction between noble and ignoble fiefs preserves medieval status hierarchies in tax rates. Lucerne's exit tax is an early capital control -- penalizing emigration through asset taxation. Cross-reference Book III on feudal customs and their modern survivals.

refashioned:
Such transactions may be taxed indirectly through stamp duties or duties on registration, and those duties may or may not be proportioned to the value of the property transferred.

In Great Britain, stamp duties are graduated not so much by the value of the property transferred -- an eighteen-penny or half-crown stamp suffices for a bond of any size -- as by the nature of the deed. The highest duties do not exceed six pounds per sheet of paper or skin of parchment, and these high duties fall mainly on grants from the crown and certain legal proceedings, without regard to the property's value. There are in Great Britain no duties on the registration of deeds or writings, except the fees of the registry officers, which are seldom more than a reasonable payment for their labor. The crown derives no revenue from them.
elegant: Property transfers can be taxed indirectly through stamp duties or registration fees, proportioned or not to the property's value. In Britain, stamp duties vary by the nature of the deed rather than the property's value -- a bond for any amount requires only a small stamp. The highest duties fall on crown grants and legal proceedings. Registration fees merely cover the officers' costs and produce no crown revenue.
summary: Britain's stamp duties vary by type of legal document rather than property value, with the highest rates on crown grants and legal proceedings. Registration fees cover only administrative costs without generating crown revenue.
distilled: British stamp duties are graduated by type of document rather than property value, and registration fees merely cover administrative costs.
notes: Contrast between value-based and document-type-based stamp duties. Britain's approach is simple but violates proportionality -- the same stamp serves for a small or enormous bond. The absence of crown revenue from registration is notable and contrasts with other countries. Cross-reference 5.2.123-124 for Holland and France comparisons.

refashioned: In Holland, there are both stamp duties and registration duties, which in some cases are proportioned to the property's value and in some cases are not. All wills must be written on stamped paper, with stamp prices proportioned to the estate being disposed of -- ranging from three pence per sheet to three hundred florins (about twenty-seven pounds ten shillings). If the stamp is of a lower value than the testator should have used, his succession is confiscated. This is over and above all other succession taxes. Except for bills of exchange and some other commercial bills, all other deeds, bonds, and contracts are subject to stamp duty, though this duty does not rise in proportion to value. All sales of land and houses, and all mortgages on either, must be registered, and upon registration pay a duty of two and a half percent on the sale price or mortgage amount. This duty extends to the sale of all ships and vessels over two tons, whether decked or undecked -- these being considered, it seems, a sort of houses on the water. The court-ordered sale of movable property is also subject to the same two and a half percent duty.
elegant: Holland has both stamp duties and registration duties, some value-based, some not. Wills require stamps proportioned to the estate's value, with confiscation penalties for understamping. Land and house sales pay 2.5% registration duty, extended to ships over two tons ('houses on the water') and court-ordered sales of movables. Other deeds pay flat stamp duties regardless of value.
summary: Holland combines value-proportioned stamp duties (on wills) with flat stamp duties (on other deeds) and a 2.5% registration duty on all land, house, ship, and court-ordered movable property sales.
distilled: Holland's transfer tax system combines proportional stamp duties on wills, flat duties on other deeds, and a 2.5% registration duty on property sales.
notes: Holland's system is more comprehensive and value-proportioned than Britain's. The confiscation penalty for understamped wills is harsh but effective enforcement. Ships as 'houses on the water' is a charming legal fiction. The 2.5% registration duty on property transactions is substantial. Cross-reference 5.2.122 for the British comparison.

refashioned: In France, there are both stamp duties and registration duties. The former are considered a branch of the excise and, in provinces where those duties apply, are collected by excise officers. The latter are considered a branch of the crown's domain and are collected by a different set of officers.
elegant: France has both stamp duties (collected as excise by excise officers) and registration duties (collected as crown domain revenue by separate officers).
summary: France has stamp duties administered as excise and registration duties administered as crown domain revenue, each collected by different sets of officers.
distilled: France divides transfer taxation between stamp duties (excise branch) and registration duties (crown domain), each with separate collection agencies.
notes: Brief administrative note on France's dual system. The separation of collection between excise officers and domain officers creates complexity and potential for jurisdictional conflict. Cross-reference 5.2.130 on the controle system and its abuses.

refashioned: Stamp duties and registration duties are very modern inventions. In little more than a century, however, stamp duties have become nearly universal across Europe, and registration duties have become extremely common. There is no art that one government learns from another more quickly than that of draining money from the people's pockets.
elegant: Stamp duties and registration duties are recent innovations that have spread across Europe in barely a century. No art is learned faster between governments than that of extracting money from the people.
summary: Stamp duties and registration duties, though modern inventions, have spread rapidly across Europe because governments quickly learn from each other how to extract revenue from citizens.
distilled: Stamp duties spread across Europe in a century because governments rapidly copy each other's methods of extracting revenue.
notes: One of Smith's most quotable lines -- governments as fast learners in the art of taxation. The rapid diffusion of fiscal innovation across borders anticipates modern policy transfer literature. The cynical tone reveals Smith's skepticism about government revenue motives. 'Draining money from the pockets of the people' is characteristically blunt.

refashioned: Taxes on the transfer of property from the dead to the living fall finally, as well as immediately, on the persons receiving the property. Taxes on the sale of land fall entirely on the seller. The seller is almost always under the necessity of selling and must therefore accept whatever price he can get. The buyer is seldom under any necessity to buy and will therefore only offer a price he finds acceptable. He considers what the land will cost him in tax and price combined. The more he must pay in tax, the less he will be willing to offer in price.
elegant: Inheritance taxes fall on the recipient. Land sale taxes fall on the seller -- because sellers usually must sell and accept what they can get, while buyers, under no compulsion, simply deduct the tax from what they are willing to pay.
summary: Inheritance taxes fall on recipients. Land sale taxes fall on sellers because sellers are typically under pressure to sell while buyers can simply reduce their offer to account for the tax.
distilled: Inheritance taxes fall on heirs, while land sale taxes fall on sellers because buyers deduct the tax from their offer price.
notes: Tax incidence determined by relative bargaining power and necessity. The asymmetry between buyer and seller -- necessity to sell vs. freedom not to buy -- is a simple but powerful framework for incidence analysis. This insight applies broadly beyond land sales to any market with unequal urgency. Cross-reference 5.2.127-128 for extensions.

refashioned: Such taxes therefore almost always fall on a person in a difficult situation, and must frequently be quite cruel and oppressive. Taxes on the sale of newly built houses, where the building is sold without the land, generally fall on the buyer, because the builder must generally earn his profit -- otherwise he must abandon the trade. If he advances the tax, the buyer must generally repay him. Taxes on the sale of older houses, for the same reason as taxes on land sales, generally fall on the seller, whom either convenience or necessity compels to sell.
elegant: Land sale taxes cruelly burden sellers who are often in financial distress. New house sale taxes fall on buyers because builders require their profit and will pass the tax along. Old house sale taxes, like land taxes, fall on sellers who are typically compelled to sell.
summary: Land sale taxes are often cruel because they burden sellers already in difficult circumstances. New house taxes fall on buyers since builders must maintain their profit, while old house taxes fall on sellers driven by necessity.
distilled: Land and old house sale taxes cruelly burden necessitous sellers, while new house taxes fall on buyers because builders must maintain their profit margin.
notes: Extends the necessity-based incidence framework to different property types. The new vs. old house distinction turns on supply conditions: new houses can stop being built (elastic supply), but existing houses are a fixed stock. Builders' exit option (abandoning the trade) gives them bargaining power that distressed sellers of old houses lack. Cross-reference 5.2.126.

refashioned: The number of new houses brought to market each year is more or less regulated by demand. Unless demand is sufficient to give the builder his profit after all expenses, he will build no more. The number of existing houses that come to market at any time is determined by accidents, most of which have no connection to demand. Two or three major bankruptcies in a commercial town will bring many houses to sale, and they must be sold for whatever they can fetch. Taxes on the sale of ground-rents fall entirely on the seller, for the same reason as taxes on land sales. Stamp duties and duties on the registration of bonds and loan contracts fall entirely on the borrower and are in fact always paid by him. Similar duties on legal proceedings fall on the litigants. They reduce the capital value of the subject in dispute for both parties.
elegant: New houses are built to match demand -- if there is no profit, builders stop. But old houses come to market through accidents like bankruptcy, forcing fire sales. Ground-rent sale taxes fall on sellers (like land taxes), stamp duties on loans fall on borrowers, and duties on legal proceedings fall on litigants, reducing the disputed property's value for both sides.
summary: New house supply adjusts to demand, but old houses enter the market through accidents like bankruptcy. Various transfer taxes fall on sellers (ground-rents, land), borrowers (loan stamp duties), and litigants (legal proceedings duties).
distilled: New house supply is demand-driven while old houses enter the market through accidents, and transfer taxes fall variously on sellers, borrowers, and litigants depending on who faces the greater necessity.
notes: Elastic vs. inelastic supply as the key determinant of tax incidence. The bankruptcy example vividly illustrates involuntary supply. The point about legal proceeding duties reducing value for both parties is important -- litigation taxes are doubly destructive. Comprehensive summary of who bears different transfer taxes.

refashioned:
The more it costs to acquire any property, the less must be its net value once acquired.

All taxes on the transfer of property, insofar as they reduce the capital value of that property, tend to diminish the funds available for maintaining productive labor. They are all more or less wasteful taxes that increase the sovereign's revenue -- which seldom supports anyone but unproductive workers -- at the expense of the people's capital, which supports only productive workers.
elegant: Transfer taxes reduce the net value of acquired property. By diminishing capital, they shrink the funds available for productive labor. They are inherently wasteful -- transferring resources from the people's capital (which supports productive workers) to the sovereign's revenue (which mostly supports unproductive ones).
summary: Transfer taxes reduce property values and thereby diminish the capital available for productive employment. They are inherently wasteful, redirecting resources from productive private capital to the sovereign's typically unproductive spending.
distilled: All transfer taxes are wasteful because they divert capital from productive private employment to the sovereign's mostly unproductive expenditure.
notes: Strong normative judgment against transfer taxes based on the productive vs. unproductive labor distinction from Book II. Smith's assumption that sovereign revenue 'seldom maintains any but unproductive labourers' is debatable but reveals his skepticism about government spending. The capital-reduction argument applies to all transfer taxes as a class. Cross-reference Book II on productive vs. unproductive labor.

refashioned: Such taxes, even when proportioned to the value of the transferred property, are still unequal because the frequency of transfers is not the same for property of equal value. When they are not proportioned to value -- as is the case with most stamp duties and registration fees -- they are even more unequal. They are in no way arbitrary, however, and can in all cases be perfectly clear and certain. Though they sometimes fall on a person not well able to pay, the timing of payment is usually convenient enough. When payment comes due, the person generally has the means to pay. They are collected at very little expense and in general subject taxpayers to no inconvenience beyond the unavoidable one of paying. In France, stamp duties are not much complained about. Registration duties -- called the controle -- are. They reportedly create opportunities for considerable extortion by the officers of the tax-farmers, and the tax is in large measure arbitrary and uncertain. In the many pamphlets written against the current French financial system, abuses of the controle are a major theme. This uncertainty, however, is not inherent in such taxes. If the popular complaints are well-founded, the abuse must arise not from the nature of the tax but from the lack of precision and clarity in the laws that impose it.
elegant: Transfer taxes, even when value-proportioned, are unequal because transfer frequency varies among properties of equal value. Non-proportioned stamp duties are worse. But these taxes are at least clear, certain, and cheaply collected. In France, stamp duties are uncontroversial, but the controle (registration) system is widely condemned for extortion by tax-farm officers. This abuse stems not from the tax's nature but from vague, imprecise laws.
summary: Transfer taxes are inherently unequal because properties of equal value change hands at different rates. However, they are clear, certain, and cheap to collect. France's controle system is abused through extortion, but this reflects poorly drafted laws rather than any defect inherent in registration taxes.
distilled: Transfer taxes are inherently unequal but administratively efficient; abuses like France's controle stem from vague laws, not from the nature of registration duties themselves.
notes: Balanced assessment of transfer taxes against Smith's four maxims. They fail on equality (first maxim) but score well on certainty, convenience, and economy (maxims 2-4). The French controle critique distinguishes between structural tax defects and implementation failures. Smith defends the instrument while condemning the execution -- a nuanced position. Cross-reference 5.2.3-6.

refashioned: The registration of mortgages, and in general of all rights over immovable property, provides great security to both creditors and purchasers and is extremely advantageous to the public. Registration of most other kinds of deeds, however, is frequently inconvenient and even dangerous to individuals, without benefiting the public. All registers that are acknowledged as properly secret should certainly never exist. The credit of individuals should certainly never depend on so slender a security as the honesty and integrity of junior revenue officials. But where registration fees have become a source of revenue for the sovereign, registry offices have commonly been multiplied without limit -- for both the deeds that ought to be registered and those that ought not. In France there are several different kinds of secret registers. This abuse, though perhaps not a necessary consequence, is admittedly a very natural effect of such taxes.
elegant: Registering mortgages and property rights benefits creditors, purchasers, and the public. But registering other deeds often harms individuals without public benefit. Secret registers should not exist -- individual credit should not depend on junior officials' honesty. Yet when registration fees become revenue sources, registries multiply needlessly. France's proliferation of secret registers, while not inevitable, is the natural consequence of such taxes.
summary: Property registration benefits the public by securing creditors and purchasers, but revenue-motivated expansion of registration creates harmful secret registers that endanger individual privacy and credit.
distilled: Property registration is beneficial when limited to securing real rights, but revenue-driven expansion creates harmful secret registers that endanger individual privacy.
notes: Important distinction between registration as public good (mortgage security) and registration as revenue device (proliferating secret registers). The critique of secret registers anticipates modern concerns about government data collection and privacy. Smith identifies a general pattern: useful institutions become harmful when repurposed for revenue extraction.

refashioned: Stamp duties like those in England on cards and dice, newspapers, and periodical pamphlets are properly taxes on consumption; the final payment falls on the persons who use or consume such goods. Stamp duties like those on licenses to retail ale, wine, and spirits, though perhaps intended to fall on retailers' profits, are likewise ultimately paid by the consumers of those liquors. Such taxes, though called by the same name and collected by the same officers in the same manner as the stamp duties on property transfers mentioned above, are in fact of a quite different nature and fall on quite different funds.
elegant: Stamp duties on cards, dice, newspapers, and pamphlets are consumption taxes paid by users. License stamps for alcohol retailers, though nominally targeting profits, are also ultimately paid by consumers. Despite sharing a name and collection method with property transfer stamps, these are fundamentally different taxes falling on different revenue sources.
summary: Stamp duties on consumer goods and retail licenses are consumption taxes ultimately paid by consumers, fundamentally different from property transfer stamps despite sharing the same name and collection method.
distilled: Stamp duties on consumer goods and retail licenses are consumption taxes, not property transfer taxes, despite sharing the same administrative name and collection method.
notes: Important taxonomic clarification -- the same administrative instrument (stamps) serves radically different economic functions. Consumption stamps are analyzed separately from transfer stamps. This confusion of categories under a single name is a recurring source of policy error. Transition toward Article III and consumption taxation.

refashioned:
ARTICLE III -- Taxes upon the Wages of Labour.

The wages of the lower classes of workers, as I endeavored to show in the first book, are everywhere necessarily regulated by two distinct factors: the demand for labor and the ordinary or average price of basic necessities. The demand for labor -- according to whether it is increasing, stationary, or declining, and whether it requires a growing, stable, or shrinking population -- determines the worker's level of subsistence and whether it shall be generous, moderate, or meager. The average price of necessities determines the amount of money the worker must be paid to purchase this generous, moderate, or meager subsistence from year to year. So long as the demand for labor and the price of necessities remain unchanged, a direct tax on wages can have no effect other than to raise them somewhat above the tax. Suppose, for example, that in a particular place the demand and prices make ten shillings a week the ordinary wage, and a tax of one-fifth (four shillings per pound) is imposed on wages. If demand and prices stay the same, the worker must still earn a subsistence purchasable only for ten shillings a week, receiving ten shillings free and clear after paying the tax. To leave him such free wages after paying a one-fifth tax, the price of labor must soon rise not merely to twelve shillings but to twelve shillings and sixpence -- that is, to enable him to pay a one-fifth tax, his wages must rise not by one-fifth but by one-fourth. Whatever the proportion of the tax, wages must in all cases rise not just in that proportion but in a higher proportion. If the tax were one-tenth, wages must rise not by one-tenth but by one-eighth.
elegant: Wages are set by labor demand and the price of necessities. A direct wage tax cannot reduce what workers take home -- wages must rise to restore their purchasing power. But the math requires wages to rise by more than the tax rate: a one-fifth tax requires a one-fourth wage increase, a one-tenth tax requires a one-eighth increase. The gross-up always exceeds the tax itself.
summary: Wages are determined by labor demand and the cost of necessities. A direct tax on wages must raise wages above the tax rate to preserve workers' purchasing power -- a one-fifth tax requires a one-fourth wage increase.
distilled: Direct wage taxes are self-defeating because wages must rise by more than the tax rate to preserve workers' necessary subsistence.
notes: Article III heading. Smith's wage-floor theory means wage taxes cannot reduce workers' real income -- they are fully shifted. The mathematical gross-up effect (one-fifth tax requires one-fourth increase) is a subtle but important point about the difference between tax-inclusive and tax-exclusive rates. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 8 on wage determination. This analysis anticipates the modern concept of tax incidence on labor markets.

refashioned: A direct tax on wages, therefore, though the worker might initially pay it from his earnings, could not properly be said to be truly advanced by him -- at least not if the demand for labor and the average price of necessities remain unchanged after the tax. In all such cases, not only the tax itself but something more than the tax would in reality be advanced by his employer. The final burden would fall on different persons depending on the circumstances. The wage increase caused by such a tax in manufacturing would be advanced by the manufacturer, who would be both entitled and obliged to charge it, with a profit, onto the price of his goods. The final payment of this wage increase, along with the manufacturer's additional profit, would therefore fall on the consumer. The wage increase in agricultural labor would be advanced by the farmer, who, to maintain the same number of workers, would have to employ more capital. To recover this additional capital plus his normal profit, he would need to retain a larger portion of the land's produce, and consequently pay less rent to the landlord. The final burden of the agricultural wage increase would therefore fall on the landlord, together with the farmer's additional profit. In all cases, a direct wage tax must, in the long run, cause both a greater reduction in land rents and a greater rise in manufactured goods prices than would have resulted from simply dividing an equivalent tax between land rent and consumer goods.
