elegant: A wage tax is never truly borne by workers -- employers advance the tax and more. In manufacturing, the employer charges it with profit onto goods prices, burdening consumers. In agriculture, the farmer needs more capital to pay higher wages, retaining more produce and paying less rent, burdening the landlord. A wage tax thus causes greater damage to rents and prices than an equivalent tax split directly between land and consumption would.
summary: Wage taxes are never truly borne by workers. In manufacturing, they raise goods prices and burden consumers. In agriculture, they reduce rents and burden landlords. Both effects are amplified by employers' profit margins, making wage taxes more harmful than equivalent direct taxes on rent and consumption.
distilled: Wage taxes are borne by consumers (through higher goods prices) and landlords (through lower rents), with profit markups making them more damaging than equivalent direct taxes.
notes: Comprehensive tax incidence analysis of wage taxes. The amplification effect -- employers add profit markup when passing on the tax -- means the total burden exceeds the tax revenue collected. This is the excess burden or deadweight loss concept. The comparison with equivalent direct taxes shows wage taxes are an inefficient way to raise the same revenue. Cross-reference 5.2.86 on profit tax shifting and 5.2.110 on agricultural taxes falling on landlords.

refashioned: If direct taxes on wages have not always caused a proportional rise in those wages, it is because they have generally caused a considerable fall in the demand for labor. The decline of industry, the decrease of employment for the poor, the reduction of the country's annual output -- these have generally been the consequences of such taxes. As a result, however, the price of labor must always be higher than it would otherwise have been given the actual state of demand, and this elevated price, together with the profit of those who advance it, must always be ultimately paid by landlords and consumers.
elegant: When wage taxes fail to raise wages proportionally, it is because they have reduced labor demand itself -- causing industrial decline, unemployment, and lower national output. Even so, wages remain higher than they would be at the reduced demand level, and this cost, with markup, still falls on landlords and consumers.
summary: When wage taxes do not fully raise wages, it is because they have reduced labor demand and economic output. Even at lower demand levels, wages are higher than they would otherwise be, with the cost falling on landlords and consumers.
distilled: Wage taxes that fail to raise wages proportionally do so by destroying labor demand and economic output -- the worst possible outcome.
notes: The darker scenario -- when wage taxes cannot be fully shifted, it is because they have caused genuine economic damage. This is worse than successful shifting because output is destroyed. Smith identifies the deflationary spiral: tax raises wages, higher wages reduce employment, lower employment reduces output. Cross-reference 5.2.133-134.

refashioned:
A tax on the wages of agricultural labor does not raise the price of raw produce in proportion to the tax, for the same reason that a tax on the farmer's profit does not raise that price proportionally.

However absurd and destructive such taxes are, they exist in many countries. In France, that part of the taille charged on the earnings of rural workers and day-laborers is properly a tax of this kind. Their wages are calculated according to the prevailing local rate, and to minimize overcharging, their annual income is estimated based on no more than two hundred working days per year. Each individual's tax varies from year to year according to different circumstances, as judged by the collector or the commissary appointed by the intendant to assist him. In Bohemia, following fiscal reforms begun in 1748, a very heavy tax is imposed on the earnings of artisans. They are divided into four classes. The highest class pays a hundred florins a year (about nine pounds, seven shillings and sixpence). The second class pays seventy, the third fifty, and the fourth -- comprising village artisans and the lowest class in towns -- pays twenty-five florins.
elegant: Agricultural wage taxes, like farmer profit taxes, do not raise produce prices proportionally. Despite being absurd and destructive, such taxes exist widely. In France, the taille on rural workers is assessed on estimated wages based on 200 working days, varying yearly at the collector's discretion. In Bohemia, artisans are taxed in four classes ranging from 25 to 100 florins annually.
summary: Agricultural wage taxes do not raise produce prices proportionally. Despite being recognized as destructive, such taxes exist in France (taille on rural workers) and Bohemia (heavy graduated taxes on artisans).
distilled: Agricultural wage taxes fail to raise produce prices and are widely recognized as destructive, yet they persist in France and Bohemia.
notes: Connects agricultural wage tax incidence to the farmer profit tax analysis of 5.2.110. The 200-day estimation for French workers shows administrative approximation. Bohemia's four-class artisan tax is a rigid, class-based system. Smith's 'absurd and destructive' language is unusually strong, reflecting his view that wage taxes are the worst form of taxation. Cross-reference 5.2.111 on the taille's distortionary effects.

refashioned: The compensation of skilled artists and professionals, as I endeavored to show in the first book, necessarily maintains a certain proportion to the earnings of lower trades. A tax on this compensation could therefore have no effect other than to raise it somewhat beyond the tax. If it did not rise in this way, the skilled arts and liberal professions, being no longer on an equal footing with other trades, would be so heavily deserted that they would soon return to that equilibrium.
elegant: Professional and artistic compensation maintains a fixed premium over ordinary trades. A tax on professional earnings must raise them above the tax -- otherwise people would abandon these careers until equilibrium was restored.
summary: Professional compensation maintains a premium over ordinary trades, so a tax on professional earnings must raise them proportionally or professionals will desert until equilibrium is restored.
distilled: Taxes on professional earnings are fully shifted because compensation must maintain its premium over ordinary trades to prevent career desertion.
notes: Application of occupational equilibrium theory from Book I, Chapters 7 and 10. The compensating differentials framework means taxes on skilled professions are fully shifted -- they raise professional fees rather than reducing professional incomes. The adjustment mechanism is labor supply: overtaxed professions lose entrants until scarcity restores the pay premium.

refashioned: The pay of public officeholders, unlike the earnings from trades and professions, is not set by free market competition and does not therefore always bear a fair proportion to what the nature of the employment requires. In most countries, office pay is higher than necessary, since those who administer government are generally disposed to compensate themselves and their dependents rather more generously than needed. The pay of offices can therefore usually bear to be taxed. Besides, those who enjoy public offices, especially the most lucrative ones, are objects of general envy in all countries, and a tax on their pay -- even if somewhat higher than on any other kind of income -- is always a very popular tax. In England, for example, when every other income was supposedly assessed at four shillings in the pound by the land tax, it was very popular to impose an actual tax of five shillings and sixpence per pound on the salaries of offices exceeding a hundred pounds a year -- with exceptions for the pensions of younger members of the royal family, the pay of military and naval officers, and a few others less subject to envy. There are in England no other direct taxes on the wages of labor.
elegant: Government salaries, unlike market earnings, are not set by competition and are typically higher than necessary -- administrators tend to overpay themselves. Office pay can therefore bear taxation, and taxing it is always popular since officeholders attract envy. In England, office salaries above one hundred pounds were taxed at a higher rate than other income under the land tax, with exceptions for military pay and royal pensions.
summary: Government officials' pay is set by administrative discretion rather than market competition and is typically higher than necessary. Taxing office salaries is both economically sound and politically popular, as in England where they were taxed at higher rates than other income.
distilled: Government salaries can and should be taxed at higher rates than market earnings because they are set by discretion rather than competition and are typically excessive.
notes: Rare case where Smith endorses a higher tax rate on a specific income source. The logic is that office pay contains economic rent (above-market compensation), making it a good tax base. The popularity of taxing officeholders reflects both sound economics and political envy. The military and royal exceptions show the limits of even popular taxation. Cross-reference Book I on how competition regulates earnings.

refashioned:
ARTICLE IV -- Taxes Which Are Intended to Fall Indifferently upon Every Different Species of Revenue.

The taxes intended to fall equally on every type of revenue are capitation taxes and taxes on consumable commodities. These must be paid regardless of the contributor's revenue source -- whether from the rent of land, from profits on capital, or from the wages of labor.
elegant: Two types of taxes aim to fall on all revenue sources equally: capitation (poll) taxes and taxes on consumable goods. Both must be paid regardless of whether income comes from rent, profits, or wages.
summary: Article IV introduces taxes designed to burden all revenue sources equally: capitation taxes and consumption taxes, payable regardless of whether income derives from rent, profits, or wages.
distilled: Capitation taxes and consumption taxes are the two instruments designed to fall equally on all types of income -- rent, profit, and wages.
notes: Article IV heading. This completes the taxonomy: Articles I-III covered taxes on specific revenue sources (rent, profit, wages), while Article IV covers taxes intended to be universal. The two instruments -- poll taxes and consumption taxes -- have very different properties that will be analyzed separately. Cross-reference 5.2.140-165.

refashioned:
Capitation Taxes.

Capitation taxes, if anyone attempts to proportion them to each contributor's fortune or revenue, become entirely arbitrary. A person's fortune changes from day to day, and without an investigation more intolerable than any tax -- one that would need to be repeated at least once every year -- it can only be guessed at. The assessment must therefore depend, in most cases, on the good or bad temper of the assessors, and must consequently be entirely arbitrary and uncertain.
elegant: If capitation taxes are proportioned to individual fortune, they become entirely arbitrary. Wealth fluctuates daily and can only be guessed without intolerable annual investigation. Assessment inevitably depends on the assessors' moods, making the tax arbitrary and uncertain.
summary: Capitation taxes proportioned to individual wealth become entirely arbitrary because wealth fluctuates constantly and cannot be accurately assessed without intolerable investigation.
distilled: Capitation taxes proportioned to wealth are inevitably arbitrary because wealth fluctuates too rapidly for accurate annual assessment.
notes: Section heading for capitation taxes. Connects directly to the capital assessment problem from 5.2.88 -- the same information problem that plagues capital taxation also undermines proportional poll taxes. The 'good or bad humour of his assessors' echoes the taille critique from 5.2.108. Cross-reference Smith's second maxim on certainty (5.2.4).

refashioned:
Capitation taxes proportioned not to supposed fortune but to each contributor's social rank become entirely unequal, since the degrees of fortune are frequently very different within the same rank.

Such taxes, therefore, if one attempts to make them equal, become entirely arbitrary and uncertain; and if one attempts to make them certain and not arbitrary, they become entirely unequal. Whether the tax is light or heavy, uncertainty is always a serious grievance. A light tax may tolerate a considerable degree of inequality; a heavy one cannot tolerate inequality at all.
elegant: Capitation taxes based on rank are unequal because wealth varies greatly within ranks. The dilemma: proportioning to fortune makes them arbitrary; proportioning to rank makes them unequal. Uncertainty is always a grievance. Light taxes can tolerate inequality; heavy taxes cannot.
summary: Capitation taxes face an impossible dilemma: proportioning to fortune makes them arbitrary, while proportioning to rank makes them unequal. Light taxes can tolerate some inequality, but heavy taxes cannot.
distilled: Capitation taxes face an inescapable tradeoff: accuracy requires intolerable investigation while certainty requires accepting inequality.
notes: The equality-certainty tradeoff is a fundamental insight in tax design. Smith shows that the two desirable properties (equality and certainty) are in direct conflict for poll taxes. The light vs. heavy tax distinction is practical -- imperfect taxes are tolerable when rates are low. Cross-reference the four maxims (5.2.3-6) and the taille discussion (5.2.106-108).

refashioned: In the various poll-taxes levied during the reign of William III, most contributors were assessed by social rank -- dukes, marquises, earls, viscounts, barons, esquires, gentlemen, eldest and youngest sons of peers, and so on. All shopkeepers and tradesmen worth more than three hundred pounds -- that is, the more prosperous among them -- were subject to the same assessment regardless of how great the differences in their actual fortunes. Their rank was considered more important than their fortune. Several who had been assessed by supposed fortune in the first poll-tax were later assessed by rank instead. Sergeants, attorneys, and proctors at law, initially assessed at three shillings per pound of supposed income, were later assessed simply as gentlemen. In a tax that was not very heavy, a considerable degree of inequality had been found more tolerable than any degree of uncertainty.
elegant: Under William III's poll-taxes, most people were assessed by rank, not wealth -- all prosperous tradesmen paid the same regardless of fortune. Lawyers initially taxed on income were later reclassified as 'gentlemen' with a flat rate. Experience showed that in a moderate tax, inequality was more tolerable than uncertainty.
summary: England's poll-taxes under William III shifted from income-based to rank-based assessment, finding that moderate inequality was more tolerable than the uncertainty of estimating individual fortunes.
distilled: England's experience with poll-taxes proved that taxpayers prefer the inequality of rank-based assessment to the uncertainty of fortune-based assessment.
notes: Empirical evidence for the equality-certainty tradeoff from 5.2.141. The reclassification of lawyers from income-based to rank-based assessment is a telling practical compromise. 'A considerable degree of inequality had been found less insupportable than any degree of uncertainty' is one of Smith's most quotable tax policy insights.

refashioned: In the capitation levied in France without interruption since the beginning of the present century, the highest orders are assessed by rank according to a fixed, invariable schedule, while the lower orders are assessed according to supposed fortune through an assessment that varies from year to year. The officers of the king's court, judges and other officers in the superior courts, military officers, and similar persons are assessed in the first manner. The lower ranks in the provinces are assessed in the second. In France, the great submit readily to a considerable degree of inequality in a tax that, as far as it concerns them, is not very burdensome. But they could not tolerate the arbitrary assessment of an intendant.
elegant: France's capitation taxes the upper orders by fixed rank-based tariffs and the lower orders by annually varying fortune-based estimates. The great accept inequality in a light tax readily enough, but would never tolerate an intendant's arbitrary assessment of their wealth.
summary: France's capitation uses fixed rank-based rates for the upper classes and variable fortune-based assessments for the lower classes. The wealthy accept inequality but refuse arbitrary assessment.
distilled: France's capitation uses certainty (fixed rank rates) for the powerful and arbitrariness (variable fortune estimates) for the powerless.
notes: Reveals the political economy of tax design -- the powerful get the system they prefer (certain if unequal), while the powerless endure the system they cannot resist (uncertain and arbitrary). This is not merely an administrative convenience but a reflection of power relations. Cross-reference 5.2.108 on the intendant's arbitrary power and 5.2.142 on the English parallel.

refashioned:
The lower ranks of people must, in that country, patiently endure whatever treatment their superiors see fit to give them.

In England, the various poll-taxes never raised the expected revenue. In France, the capitation always does. England's mild government, when it assessed different ranks, contented itself with whatever the assessment happened to produce and demanded no compensation for shortfalls from those who could not pay or would not pay -- and there were many such -- who, thanks to lenient enforcement, were never compelled to pay. France's more severe government assesses each generality a fixed sum that the intendant must collect however he can. If any province complains of being overcharged, it may receive an adjustment the following year, but it must pay in full in the meantime. The intendant, to ensure he meets his target, was empowered to assess a sum larger than required so that the failure or inability of some contributors could be offset by overcharging others. Until 1765, setting this surplus was entirely at his discretion; that year the council took this power upon itself. In the provincial capitation, the well-informed author of the Memoirs on French Taxation observes that the share falling on the nobility and the privileged classes exempt from the taille is the smallest. The largest share falls on those subject to the taille, who are assessed for the capitation at a rate per pound of what they already pay in taille. Capitation taxes, insofar as they are levied on the lower ranks, are direct taxes on wages and carry all the disadvantages of such taxes.
elegant: In France, the lower orders must accept whatever treatment the powerful impose. England's lenient poll-taxes never met revenue targets because nonpayers were never compelled. France's severe system always meets targets -- intendants assess more than needed so others' overcharges cover shortfalls. The privileged pay the least capitation; those already burdened by the taille pay the most, assessed as a surcharge on their existing tax. For the lower classes, the capitation is effectively a wage tax with all its defects.
summary: England's lenient poll-tax collection never met targets, while France's harsh system always does by overcharging some to cover others' shortfalls. The privileged pay the least capitation while taille-payers are burdened most, making the capitation effectively a regressive wage tax on the poor.
distilled: France's capitation reliably meets revenue targets through coercive overcharging, with the privileged paying least and the poor -- already burdened by the taille -- paying most.
notes: Stark contrast between English lenience and French severity in tax collection. The overcharging mechanism -- assessing more than needed to cover defaults -- is systematically oppressive. The capitation as a surcharge on the taille is doubly regressive -- those already most burdened pay the most. Smith's implicit preference for the English system, even with its revenue shortfalls, is clear. Cross-reference 5.2.133-135 on wage tax incidence.

refashioned: Capitation taxes are collected at little expense and, when rigorously enforced, provide a very reliable revenue to the state. It is for this reason that in countries where the comfort, security, and welfare of the lower classes receive little attention, capitation taxes are very common. In general, however, only a small part of a great empire's public revenue has ever been raised through such taxes, and the largest sum they have ever produced could always have been raised in some other way far more convenient for the people.
elegant: Capitation taxes are cheap to collect and reliable when rigorously enforced, which is why they are common in countries that disregard the welfare of the poor. But they never raise much revenue, and whatever they produce could always be raised more conveniently by other means.
summary: Capitation taxes are cheap and reliable but only common where governments disregard the poor. They never raise much revenue, and what they produce could always be raised less oppressively through other tax methods.
distilled: Capitation taxes are administratively efficient but morally bankrupt -- cheap to collect, oppressive to the poor, and never necessary since other taxes could raise the same revenue.
notes: Summary judgment on capitation taxes -- administratively attractive but ethically and economically indefensible. The link between capitation taxes and indifference to the lower classes is a powerful political economy observation. Smith's conclusion that the revenue 'might always have been found in some other way much more convenient to the people' is a practical condemnation. Cross-reference 5.2.139-144.

refashioned:
Taxes upon Consumable Commodities.

The impossibility of taxing people in proportion to their income through any capitation seems to have given rise to the idea of taxing consumable commodities instead. The state, unable to tax people's income directly and proportionally, attempts to tax it indirectly by taxing their spending, which is assumed to be roughly proportional to their income in most cases. Spending is taxed by imposing duties on the consumable goods on which it is laid out.
elegant: The failure of capitation taxes to achieve proportional taxation led to consumption taxes. Unable to tax income directly, the state taxes spending instead -- assumed to roughly reflect income -- by taxing the goods people buy.
summary: Consumption taxes arose because capitation taxes could not proportionally tax income. The state instead taxes spending, which is assumed to roughly correlate with income, through duties on consumer goods.
distilled: Consumption taxes emerged as a practical alternative to the impossible task of proportionally taxing income through capitation.
notes: Section heading introducing consumption taxation. The logic is second-best: since income cannot be observed, tax its observable proxy (spending). The assumption that spending is proportional to income is approximately true for most of the population but breaks down for the very rich (who save more) and the very poor (who may spend more than they earn). This sets up the necessaries vs. luxuries distinction in 5.2.147.

refashioned:
Consumable commodities are either necessaries or luxuries.

By 'necessaries' I mean not only the things absolutely indispensable for sustaining life, but whatever the customs of the country make it indecent for respectable people, even of the lowest class, to go without. A linen shirt, for example, is not strictly necessary for survival. The Greeks and Romans lived comfortably enough without linen. But in modern Europe, a respectable day-laborer would be ashamed to appear in public without a linen shirt -- its absence would suggest the sort of disgraceful poverty that, it is assumed, no one falls into without extremely bad conduct. Similarly, custom has made leather shoes a necessity of life in England. The poorest respectable person of either sex would be ashamed to appear publicly without them. In Scotland, custom has made them a necessity for the lowest rank of men but not for women of the same rank, who may walk about barefoot without any loss of respectability. In France, leather shoes are necessary for neither sex; the lowest ranks of both appear in public, without disgrace, sometimes in wooden shoes and sometimes barefoot. Under 'necessaries,' therefore, I include not only what nature requires but what the established rules of decency have made necessary for the lowest rank of people. Everything else I call 'luxuries,' without meaning by this term to cast the slightest reproach on their moderate use. Beer and ale in Great Britain, and wine even in wine-producing countries, I classify as luxuries. A person of any rank may, without any discredit, abstain entirely from such drinks. Nature does not require them for survival, and custom nowhere makes it indecent to live without them.
elegant: Consumable goods are either necessaries or luxuries. Necessaries include not only what sustains life but what custom requires for respectability -- linen shirts in Europe, leather shoes in England (but not for Scottish women or the French poor). Everything else is luxury, including beer, ale, and wine, which no one need consume to maintain respectability. The boundary between necessity and luxury is culturally determined, not absolute.
summary: Smith defines necessaries as both biological needs and what custom requires for respectability, varying by country and class. Luxuries are everything else, including alcohol. The necessity-luxury boundary is culturally determined, not fixed by nature.
distilled: Necessaries include both survival requirements and culturally mandated respectability goods; everything else -- including alcohol -- is luxury, with the boundary varying across societies.
notes: One of Smith's most famous definitional passages. The social construction of necessity is a remarkably modern insight -- poverty is relative to cultural norms, not just biological survival. The cross-national comparisons (English shoes, Scottish gender differences, French barefooting) demonstrate cultural variability. This definition has profound tax implications: taxing necessaries raises wages, taxing luxuries does not. Cross-reference 5.2.148-154.

refashioned: Since wages are everywhere regulated partly by the demand for labor and partly by the average price of necessary goods, whatever raises this average price must necessarily raise wages, so that workers can still purchase the quantity of necessities that the state of labor demand -- whether increasing, stationary, or declining -- requires them to have. A tax on necessities necessarily raises their price somewhat above the amount of the tax, because the dealer who advances the tax must generally recover it with a profit. Such a tax must therefore cause a rise in wages proportional to this price increase.
elegant: Since wages are set by labor demand and the price of necessities, taxing necessities raises their price above the tax (dealers add profit), which forces wages up proportionally. The tax cascades: higher necessity prices lead to higher wages lead to higher costs throughout the economy.
summary: Taxes on necessities raise prices above the tax amount (because dealers add profit) and therefore force wages up proportionally, since workers must maintain their necessary standard of living.
distilled: Taxes on necessities raise prices, which raise wages, which raise costs throughout the economy -- a cascading effect exceeding the tax itself.
notes: Key mechanism connecting necessity taxes to wage inflation. The dealer's profit markup on the advanced tax is the amplification mechanism -- the total price increase exceeds the tax. This connects to the wage-floor theory from 5.2.133. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 8 on wage determination. The cascading cost increases foreshadow the analysis in 5.2.154.

refashioned: A tax on the necessaries of life therefore operates in exactly the same way as a direct tax on wages. The worker, though he may pay it from his earnings, cannot -- for any considerable time at least -- properly be said even to advance it. It must always, in the long run, be advanced to him by his employer through higher wages. If the employer is a manufacturer, he will add the wage increase plus a profit to the price of his goods, so the final payment along with this markup falls on the consumer. If the employer is a farmer, the final payment with a similar markup falls on the rent of the landlord.
elegant: A tax on necessaries works just like a direct wage tax. Workers cannot truly bear it -- employers must raise wages to compensate. Manufacturers pass the cost with profit onto consumers through higher prices. Farmers pass it onto landlords through lower rents. Either way, the worker is merely a conduit.
summary: Taxes on necessaries function identically to direct wage taxes: employers must raise wages, manufacturers pass costs to consumers, and farmers pass them to landlords. Workers are never the final bearers.
distilled: Taxes on necessaries are functionally identical to direct wage taxes, ultimately falling on consumers and landlords rather than workers.
notes: Establishes the economic equivalence of necessity taxes and wage taxes -- a powerful insight that collapses two apparently different tax categories into one. The symmetry between manufacturer (-> consumer) and farmer (-> landlord) channels mirrors the analysis in 5.2.134. Cross-reference 5.2.133-135.

refashioned: It is different with taxes on what I call luxuries, even luxuries of the poor. The price increase on taxed luxury goods does not necessarily cause any rise in wages. A tax on tobacco, for example -- a luxury of both poor and rich -- does not raise wages, even though in England it is taxed at three times its original price and in France at fifteen times. These heavy duties seem to have no effect on wages whatsoever. The same may be said of the taxes on tea and sugar, which in England and Holland have become luxuries of the lowest classes, and of those on chocolate, which in Spain is said to have become so as well.
elegant: Unlike necessity taxes, luxury taxes -- even on luxuries consumed by the poor -- do not raise wages. Tobacco, taxed at three times its price in England and fifteen times in France, has no effect on wages. Nor do taxes on tea, sugar, or chocolate, despite being consumed by the poorest classes.
summary: Taxes on luxury goods, even those consumed by the poor like tobacco, tea, and sugar, do not raise wages -- unlike taxes on necessaries. The distinction depends on whether the good is required for basic social respectability.
distilled: Luxury taxes, even on goods consumed by the poor, do not raise wages because workers can reduce consumption without losing social respectability.
notes: Critical practical consequence of the necessity-luxury distinction from 5.2.147. The empirical examples (tobacco at 3x-15x price with no wage effect) provide strong evidence. The key is that workers can abstain from luxuries without social harm, so the goods are not part of the subsistence floor that determines wages. Cross-reference 5.2.147 for the definitions and 5.2.148 for the necessity mechanism.

refashioned: The various taxes imposed on spirits in Great Britain during the present century are not thought to have had any effect on labor wages. The rise in the price of porter caused by an additional three-shilling tax on a barrel of strong beer has not raised the wages of common labor in London. Those wages were about eighteen pence or twenty pence a day before the tax, and they are no more now.
elegant: British taxes on spirits and the additional tax on strong beer have not raised London wages. Common laborers earned eighteen to twenty pence a day before the beer tax and earn no more after it.
summary: Taxes on spirits and beer in Britain have not raised wages, with London common laborers earning the same eighteen to twenty pence per day before and after the beer tax increase.
distilled: British alcohol taxes provide empirical proof that luxury taxes do not raise wages, with London labor rates unchanged after beer tax increases.
notes: Direct empirical evidence supporting the luxury tax theory. The before-and-after wage comparison is a rudimentary natural experiment. Porter (strong beer) was a staple drink of London's working class, yet its taxation had no wage effect -- confirming its classification as luxury rather than necessity. Cross-reference 5.2.150.

refashioned: The high price of luxury goods does not necessarily diminish the lower classes' ability to raise families. For the sober and industrious poor, taxes on such goods act as sumptuary laws, encouraging them either to moderate or to entirely forgo the use of luxuries they can no longer easily afford. Their ability to support families, as a result of this forced frugality, is frequently increased rather than decreased by the tax. It is the sober and industrious poor who generally raise the largest families and who principally supply the demand for useful labor. Not all poor people, of course, are sober and industrious. The dissolute and disorderly might continue to indulge in these goods after the price increase, just as before, disregarding the hardship this self-indulgence might bring on their families. Such disorderly persons, however, seldom raise large families -- their children generally dying from neglect, mismanagement, and inadequate or unwholesome food. If by constitutional strength they survive the hardships inflicted by their parents' bad conduct, the example of that conduct commonly corrupts their morals, so that instead of being useful to society through their industry, they become public burdens through their vices and disorders. Though higher luxury prices might somewhat increase the distress of such disordered families and reduce their ability to raise children, they would probably not much diminish the country's useful population.
elegant: Luxury taxes do not reduce the poor's ability to raise families -- for the sober and industrious, forced frugality actually increases it. These are the families that raise the most children and supply the most useful labor. The dissolute poor, who continue indulging despite higher prices, rarely raise large families anyway -- their children die from neglect or grow up corrupted. Higher luxury prices may worsen their situation but would not significantly reduce the country's productive population.
summary: Luxury taxes act as beneficial sumptuary laws for the sober poor, whose forced frugality actually increases their ability to raise families. The dissolute poor, who ignore price increases, rarely raise productive children regardless.
distilled: Luxury taxes benefit the industrious poor through forced frugality while having little effect on the dissolute poor's already low contribution to productive population.
notes: Controversial passage reflecting 18th-century moral distinctions between 'deserving' and 'undeserving' poor. The economic logic is that luxury taxes redirect spending toward family support. The claim that forced frugality increases family-raising capacity is the positive case for consumption taxes as social policy. The harsh treatment of 'disorderly' poor reflects prevailing attitudes. Cross-reference 5.2.147 on the necessity-luxury boundary.

refashioned: Any rise in the average price of necessaries, unless compensated by a proportional rise in wages, must necessarily diminish, to some degree, the ability of the poor to raise large families and consequently to supply the demand for useful labor -- whatever the state of that demand may be, whether increasing, stationary, or declining.
elegant: Uncompensated increases in necessity prices reduce the poor's ability to raise families and supply labor, regardless of whether labor demand is growing, stable, or falling.
summary: Rising prices of necessaries, without matching wage increases, reduce the poor's capacity to raise families and supply the labor force, regardless of labor market conditions.
distilled: Uncompensated necessity price increases reduce the labor supply by undermining the poor's ability to raise families.
notes: Restates the necessity tax mechanism from the population side -- necessity taxes that somehow fail to raise wages (perhaps through demand destruction as in 5.2.135) directly reduce population growth and long-term labor supply. This connects Smith's tax analysis to his population theory. Cross-reference 5.2.148-149.

refashioned: Taxes on luxuries have no tendency to raise the price of any other commodities beyond the ones taxed. Taxes on necessaries, by raising wages, necessarily tend to raise the price of all manufactured goods and consequently to reduce the extent of their sale and consumption. Taxes on luxuries are ultimately paid by consumers of the taxed goods, without any ripple effects. They fall equally on every type of income -- wages, profits, and rent. Taxes on necessaries, insofar as they affect the laboring poor, are ultimately paid partly by landlords through reduced rents and partly by wealthier consumers through higher manufactured goods prices -- always with a considerable markup. The increased price of manufactures that are themselves necessaries for the poor, such as coarse woolens, must be compensated by a further wage increase. The middle and upper classes, if they understood their own interest, ought always to oppose all taxes on the necessaries of life, as well as all taxes on wages. The final payment of both falls entirely on them, always with a considerable markup. These taxes fall hardest on landlords, who always pay in a double capacity: as landlords, through reduced rents, and as wealthy consumers, through higher prices. The observation of Sir Matthew Decker -- that certain taxes are sometimes repeated and accumulated four or five times in the price of certain goods -- is perfectly accurate regarding taxes on necessaries. In the price of leather, for example, you pay not only for the tax on the leather in your own shoes, but for part of the tax on the leather in the shoemaker's and tanner's shoes. You pay also for the tax on the salt, soap, and candles those workers consume, and for the tax on the leather consumed by the salt-maker, soap-maker, and candle-maker in their own work.
elegant: Luxury taxes affect only the taxed goods. Necessity taxes cascade throughout the economy: they raise wages, which raise all manufacturing costs, which raise all prices, with profit markups compounding at every stage. The middle and upper classes bear the final cost -- landlords doubly so, through both reduced rents and higher prices. Sir Matthew Decker correctly observed that necessity taxes accumulate four or five times in the price of a single good, as each worker's taxed necessities add cost to the next product in the chain.
summary: Luxury taxes affect only the taxed goods, but necessity taxes cascade through the entire economy: raising wages, manufacturing costs, and all prices with compounding markups. The wealthy and landlords bear the ultimate cost, and a single necessity tax can accumulate four or five times in any product's final price.
distilled: Necessity taxes cascade through the economy with compounding markups, ultimately falling on landlords and the wealthy, while luxury taxes affect only the taxed goods.
notes: One of Smith's most analytically important passages. The cascading effect of necessity taxes -- each stage adds cost and markup -- is an early description of what modern economists call tax pyramiding or cumulative turnover tax effects. Sir Matthew Decker's observation about four-to-five-fold accumulation is quantitatively plausible. The leather example traces the tax through multiple production stages. The policy advice to the wealthy is shrewd: opposing necessity taxes serves their self-interest. Cross-reference 5.2.148-149.

refashioned:
In Great Britain, the principal taxes on necessaries are those on the four commodities just mentioned: salt, leather, soap, and candles.

Salt has been taxed since ancient times and is taxed nearly universally today. The quantity consumed annually by any individual is so small, and may be purchased so gradually, that even a fairly heavy tax on it was presumably thought to be barely noticeable. In England it is taxed at three shillings and fourpence per bushel -- about three times the commodity's original price. In some other countries the tax is even higher. Leather is a true necessity of life. The use of linen makes soap one as well. In countries with long winter nights, candles are a necessary tool of trade. Leather and soap are taxed in Great Britain at three halfpence per pound; candles at one penny -- amounting to about eight to ten percent of leather's original price, about twenty to twenty-five percent of soap's price, and about fourteen to fifteen percent of candle prices. Though lighter than the salt tax, these are still very heavy duties. Since all four commodities are genuine necessaries, such heavy taxes must somewhat increase the expenses of the sober and industrious poor and consequently must raise, more or less, the wages of their labor.
elegant: Britain's main necessity taxes fall on salt, leather, soap, and candles. Salt is taxed at three times its price; leather and soap at 3 halfpence per pound (8-25% of price); candles at a penny (14-15%). All four are genuine necessaries, so these heavy duties must increase the poor's expenses and consequently raise wages.
summary: Britain's principal necessity taxes fall on salt (taxed at 3x its price), leather, soap, and candles (taxed at 8-25% of their prices). As genuine necessities, these taxes raise the cost of living for the poor and push up wages.
distilled: Britain's heavy taxes on salt, leather, soap, and candles -- all genuine necessaries -- raise the cost of living and consequently wages.
notes: Concrete application of the necessity tax theory to four specific British commodities. The tax rates are substantial -- salt at 300% is particularly striking. Smith's classification of these as genuine necessaries (not luxuries) triggers the full cascading mechanism from 5.2.148-154. The 'gradually purchased' observation about salt explains why heavy taxes on small individual purchases may go unnoticed. Cross-reference 5.2.147 for necessity definitions.

refashioned: In a country with winters as cold as Great Britain's, fuel is, in the strictest sense, a necessity of life -- not only for cooking but for the comfortable survival of the many workers who labor indoors. Coal is the cheapest fuel. The price of fuel so powerfully influences the cost of labor that throughout Britain, manufactures have concentrated principally in the coal-producing counties; other regions, burdened by the high cost of this necessity, cannot manufacture as cheaply. In some industries, moreover, coal is a necessary tool of production -- as in glass-making, ironworking, and all other metalworking. If a subsidy could ever be justified, it might perhaps be for transporting coal from where it is abundant to where it is scarce. But the legislature, instead of a subsidy, has imposed a tax of three shillings and threepence per ton on coastwise coal shipments -- which, for most types of coal, exceeds sixty percent of the original pithead price. Coal carried by land or inland waterway pays no duty. Where coal is naturally cheap, it is consumed duty-free; where it is naturally expensive, it is burdened with a heavy duty.
elegant: Coal is a strict necessity in Britain's cold climate -- for heating, cooking, and manufacturing. Its price determines where industry locates: manufactures cluster in coal counties because other regions cannot compete. Yet instead of subsidizing coal transport to coal-poor areas, the legislature imposes a 60%+ tax on coastwise shipment. Coal is duty-free where cheap and heavily taxed where expensive -- exactly backwards.
summary: Coal is a fundamental necessity in Britain's cold climate, determining where industry can affordably locate. Yet the legislature taxes coastwise coal transport at over 60% of pithead price, making coal most expensive precisely where it is most needed.
distilled: Britain perversely taxes coastwise coal shipment at 60%+ of pithead price, making coal most expensive where it is most needed and cheapest where it is already abundant.
notes: Powerful critique of a specific policy that contradicts Smith's general principles. The coal tax violates logic by burdening the good where it is scarcest. Smith's suggestion of a coal transport subsidy is unusual -- he rarely endorses subsidies. The observation that industry clusters around cheap coal anticipates industrial location theory (Alfred Weber). Cross-reference 5.2.154 on cascading necessity taxes.

refashioned: Such taxes, though they raise the price of subsistence and consequently wages, still provide considerable government revenue that might not be easy to raise any other way. There may therefore be good reasons for keeping them. The bounty on corn exports, insofar as it tends to raise the price of that necessity in the current state of farming, produces all the same harmful effects -- and instead of providing revenue, frequently causes very great government expense. The high duties on imported foreign corn, which in years of moderate abundance amount to a prohibition, and the absolute prohibition on importing either live cattle or salt provisions under normal circumstances -- currently suspended for a limited time for Ireland and the British plantations because of scarcity -- have all the harmful effects of taxes on necessaries and produce no revenue for the government. To repeal such regulations, nothing seems necessary except to convince the public of the futility of the system that established them.
elegant: Necessity taxes at least generate revenue that may be hard to replace. But export bounties on corn, import prohibitions on grain and cattle, and bans on salt provisions produce all the same harmful effects as necessity taxes -- higher subsistence costs, higher wages, distorted production -- while generating no revenue at all, and sometimes costing the government money. Repealing these requires only convincing the public of the system's futility.
summary: While necessity taxes at least produce hard-to-replace revenue, corn bounties, grain import duties, and livestock import bans cause the same economic damage without generating any revenue -- and sometimes at great public expense.
distilled: Corn bounties and import prohibitions cause all the harm of necessity taxes while producing no revenue, making them purely destructive policies.
notes: Brilliant comparative argument: necessity taxes are bad but produce revenue; mercantile protections are worse because they produce the same harm with no offsetting revenue. The corn bounty and import prohibitions are Smith's standard targets for anti-mercantilist critique. The 'convince the public of the futility' line shows Smith believes the obstacle is intellectual, not political. Cross-reference Book IV on mercantilism and the corn trade.

refashioned: Taxes on necessaries are much higher in many other countries than in Great Britain. Duties on flour and meal at the mill, and on bread at the oven, exist in many countries. In Holland, these taxes are said to double the money-price of bread consumed in towns. In lieu of part of these taxes, country dwellers pay an annual per-head charge according to the type of bread they are presumed to consume: those eating wheat bread pay three guilders fifteen stivers (about six shillings ninepence halfpenny). These and similar taxes, by raising the price of labor, are said to have ruined most of Holland's manufactures. Similar taxes, though not quite as heavy, exist in the Milanese, the states of Genoa, the duchy of Modena, the duchies of Parma, Piacenza, and Guastalla, and the Papal States. A French author of some note has even proposed reforming his country's finances by replacing most other taxes with this most ruinous of all taxes. As Cicero observed, there is nothing so absurd that some philosopher has not asserted it.
elegant: Necessity taxes are much heavier abroad than in Britain. Holland's bread taxes reportedly double bread prices and have ruined most Dutch manufactures. Similar taxes exist across Italy. One French writer even proposed replacing most taxes with a bread tax -- the most destructive tax of all. As Cicero said, no absurdity lacks a philosophical defender.
summary: Many European countries impose far heavier necessity taxes than Britain. Holland's bread taxes double bread prices and have reportedly ruined Dutch manufacturing. A French author even proposed a bread tax as the primary revenue source -- a proposal Smith considers absurd.
distilled: Holland's bread tax, which doubled bread prices and ruined manufactures, demonstrates the destructive extremes of necessity taxation that some theorists incredibly still advocate.
notes: International comparison showing Britain's necessity taxes are moderate by European standards. The Holland case is the strongest evidence of necessity taxes destroying manufacturing competitiveness. The Cicero quotation deployed against the French author (likely Le Reformateur) is a devastating put-down. The Italian examples show how widespread such taxes are despite their known harm. Cross-reference 5.2.154 on cascading effects.

refashioned: Taxes on butcher's meat are even more common than those on bread. It may indeed be questioned whether butcher's meat is a necessity of life anywhere. Grain and other vegetables, supplemented by milk, cheese, and butter -- or oil where butter is unavailable -- can, as experience shows, provide the most plentiful, wholesome, nourishing, and invigorating diet without any meat at all. Social custom nowhere requires that a person eat butcher's meat in the way that it requires him, in most places, to wear a linen shirt or leather shoes.
elegant: Meat taxes are even more common than bread taxes. But meat may not be a necessity at all -- a vegetable, dairy, and oil diet is fully adequate. Unlike linen shirts or leather shoes, no social custom requires meat consumption.
summary: Meat taxes are widespread, but Smith questions whether meat is a true necessity, since a vegetarian diet with dairy is fully adequate and no social custom requires meat consumption.
distilled: Butcher's meat may not be a true necessity, since a vegetarian diet is fully adequate and no social custom demands meat consumption.
notes: Interesting application of the necessity-luxury framework. By Smith's own definition (5.2.147), necessity includes socially required goods, and he argues meat fails this test. The pro-vegetarian argument is remarkable for the 18th century. If meat is a luxury, meat taxes would not raise wages -- a significant policy implication. Cross-reference 5.2.147 on the social construction of necessity.

refashioned: Consumable goods, whether necessaries or luxuries, may be taxed in two different ways. The consumer may pay an annual sum for the right to use or consume a certain kind of good, or the goods may be taxed while still in the dealer's hands, before delivery to the consumer. Durable goods that last a considerable time before being fully consumed are most suitably taxed in the first way; goods consumed immediately or quickly are most suitably taxed in the second. The coach tax and plate tax are examples of the first method; most excise duties and customs duties are examples of the second.
elegant: Consumer goods can be taxed two ways: an annual user fee paid by the consumer (best for durables like coaches and silver plate), or a duty paid by the dealer before delivery (best for perishables and quickly consumed goods, as with most excise and customs duties).
summary: Durable consumer goods are best taxed through annual user fees, while perishable or quickly consumed goods are best taxed through dealer-paid duties before delivery to the consumer.
distilled: Durable goods suit annual consumer taxes while perishable goods suit dealer-paid excise duties -- the optimal method depends on consumption speed.
notes: Practical taxonomy of consumption tax methods based on product durability. The annual license approach for durables (coaches, silverware) spreads the tax over the good's useful life. The dealer-stage approach for perishables captures the tax at a convenient chokepoint. This framework remains relevant to modern excise tax design. Cross-reference 5.2.161-165 for applications and critique.

refashioned: A coach may, with good maintenance, last ten or twelve years. It could be taxed once when it leaves the coachmaker's shop. But it is certainly more convenient for the buyer to pay four pounds a year for the privilege of keeping a coach than to pay forty or forty-eight pounds as an additional lump sum to the coachmaker -- an amount equivalent to the tax's likely lifetime cost. Silverware, similarly, may last more than a century. It is certainly easier for the consumer to pay five shillings a year for every hundred ounces of plate, nearly one percent of its value, than to pay the equivalent of twenty-five or thirty years' purchase of that annuity upfront, which would raise the price by at least twenty-five or thirty percent. The various taxes on houses are likewise more conveniently paid through moderate annual installments than as a single heavy tax on the initial construction or sale of the house.
elegant: Spreading consumption taxes over a durable good's life is more convenient than taxing all at once. Paying four pounds yearly for a coach is easier than forty-eight pounds upfront. Five shillings yearly per hundred ounces of silver is easier than a 25-30% price increase. House taxes work the same way -- annual payments are less burdensome than lump sums at purchase.
summary: Taxing durable goods through annual payments rather than lump sums at purchase is more convenient for consumers, whether for coaches, silverware, or houses.
distilled: Annual consumption taxes on durables like coaches, silverware, and houses are more convenient than equivalent lump-sum taxes at purchase.
notes: Time-value-of-money argument for annual versus lump-sum taxation. Spreading payments over a good's useful life reduces the cash-flow burden on the buyer. The specific rates (4 pounds/year for coaches, 5 shillings/100oz for plate) are period details. The 25-30 year capitalization of the silver annuity shows Smith's financial sophistication. Cross-reference 5.2.160 for the general framework.

refashioned: It was the well-known proposal of Sir Matthew Decker that all commodities -- even those consumed immediately or quickly -- should be taxed in this manner, with the dealer advancing nothing and the consumer paying an annual sum for a license to consume certain goods. His aim was to promote all branches of foreign trade, especially the carrying trade, by abolishing all import and export duties and thereby allowing merchants to devote their entire capital and credit to purchasing goods and chartering ships, with no portion diverted to advancing taxes. However, the proposal of taxing immediately or quickly consumed goods through annual licenses seems liable to four very important objections. First, the tax would be more unequal, or less well proportioned to each contributor's actual consumption, than under the standard method of taxation.
elegant: Sir Matthew Decker proposed taxing all goods -- even perishables -- through annual consumer licenses, eliminating dealer-advanced duties to free up merchant capital for trade. But applying annual licenses to quickly consumed goods faces four major objections. First, the tax would be less proportional to actual consumption than traditional methods.
summary: Sir Matthew Decker proposed replacing all trade duties with annual consumer licenses to free merchant capital, but Smith raises four objections, beginning with the point that license fees would poorly correspond to actual consumption levels.
distilled: Decker's proposal to replace all duties with annual consumer licenses would poorly match tax burden to actual consumption and faces four serious objections.
notes: Critique of a specific reform proposal. Decker's free-trade motivation (eliminating duties to free merchant capital) is sympathetic to Smith, but the implementation is flawed. The first objection -- proportionality failure -- is central: a flat license fee taxes moderate consumers as heavily as heavy consumers. Cross-reference 5.2.163-165 for the remaining three objections.

refashioned: The taxes on ale, wine, and spirits, advanced by dealers, are ultimately paid by each consumer in exact proportion to his consumption. But if the tax were paid through a license to drink those liquors, the moderate drinker would, in proportion to his consumption, be taxed much more heavily than the heavy drinker. A family that entertained lavishly would be taxed much more lightly than one that entertained fewer guests. Second, this method of taxation through annual, semi-annual, or quarterly licenses to consume certain goods would greatly diminish one of the principal advantages of taxes on quickly consumed goods: the piecemeal nature of payment.
elegant: Current excise duties are perfectly proportional -- each consumer pays per unit consumed. A license system would overtax moderate consumers relative to heavy ones, and undertax lavish entertainers. Second, licenses eliminate the key advantage of excise taxes: piecemeal payment that matches ability to pay moment by moment.
summary: Excise duties tax consumption proportionally, but annual licenses would overtax moderate consumers and undertax heavy ones. Additionally, licenses eliminate the valuable piecemeal payment feature of excise taxes.
distilled: Annual consumption licenses would destroy both the proportionality and the convenient piecemeal payment that make excise duties effective.
notes: Two of four objections to Decker's proposal. The proportionality objection is intuitive: a flat license overtaxes light users. The piecemeal payment advantage is a key insight -- small, frequent payments embedded in purchase prices are less burdensome than periodic lump sums. Cross-reference 5.2.164 for the piecemeal payment argument developed further.

refashioned: In the price of three and a half pence currently paid for a pot of porter, the various taxes on malt, hops, and beer, together with the extra profit the brewer charges for having advanced them, may amount to about three halfpence. If a worker can conveniently spare those three halfpence, he buys a pot of porter. If he cannot, he makes do with a pint and, since a penny saved is a penny earned, gains a farthing by his temperance. He pays the tax in small installments as he can afford to, and when he can afford to, and every act of payment is perfectly voluntary -- something he can avoid entirely if he chooses.
elegant: In a pot of porter costing three and a half pence, about three halfpence goes to taxes and brewer's markup. A worker buys a pot if he can spare it, or a pint if he cannot -- saving a farthing by his restraint. The tax is paid piecemeal, voluntarily, and only when affordable. Each purchase is a free choice.
summary: The beauty of excise taxes on beverages is that workers pay them piecemeal, voluntarily, and only when they can afford to -- buying a pot of porter when flush and a pint when tight, with every payment a free choice.
distilled: Excise taxes on beer are ideal because they are paid piecemeal, voluntarily, and only when the worker can afford them.
notes: One of Smith's most vivid illustrations. The porter example makes the piecemeal payment principle concrete and human. The 'penny saved is a penny got' proverb adds warmth. The voluntary, self-regulating nature of excise taxes contrasts sharply with the coercive taille. This passage implicitly argues for consumption taxes over income or poll taxes. Cross-reference 5.2.163.

refashioned: Third, such taxes would be less effective as sumptuary laws. Once the license was purchased, whether the buyer drank much or little, his tax would be the same. Fourth, if a worker had to pay all at once -- in yearly, half-yearly, or quarterly installments -- a tax equal to what he currently pays with little or no hardship on all the pots and pints of porter he drinks over that period, the lump sum might cause him serious distress. This method of taxation therefore could clearly never, without the most severe oppression, produce a revenue anywhere near what the current method yields without any oppression at all. In several countries, however, goods of immediate or very rapid consumption are indeed taxed this way. In Holland, people pay a per-head charge for a license to drink tea. I have already mentioned a tax on bread that, insofar as it is consumed in farmhouses and country villages, is collected in the same manner.
elegant: Third, licenses would weaken sumptuary effects -- drinkers pay the same whether they consume much or little. Fourth, lump-sum payments for consumption that currently costs little spread across many small purchases would cause real financial distress. This system could never match current excise revenue without severe oppression. Yet some countries use it -- Holland charges a per-head tea license, and bread in rural areas is taxed similarly.
summary: Licenses would weaken the sumptuary effect of alcohol taxes and cause financial distress through lump-sum payments that current piecemeal excise taxes avoid. This system could never match excise revenue without oppression, though some countries like Holland use it for tea and bread.
distilled: Annual consumption licenses would eliminate both the sumptuary restraint and the painless piecemeal payment that make excise taxes superior, producing less revenue with more oppression.
notes: Completes the four objections to Decker's proposal: (1) proportionality failure, (2) loss of piecemeal payment, (3) reduced sumptuary effect, (4) distress from lump-sum payment. The Holland tea-license example shows the system does exist despite its defects. Smith's overall conclusion is that traditional excise duties are vastly superior to annual licenses for quickly consumed goods. Cross-reference 5.2.162-164 for the complete argument.

refashioned: Excise duties are levied mainly on domestically produced goods intended for domestic consumption. They apply to only a limited number of widely used goods. There is never any ambiguity about which goods are subject to these duties or what rate applies to each. They fall almost entirely on what I consider luxuries, with the exception of the four duties already mentioned -- those on salt, soap, leather, candles, and perhaps on green glass.
elegant: Excise duties target a narrow range of domestically produced goods for home consumption. Their scope and rates are always clear. They fall almost entirely on luxuries, excepting those on salt, soap, leather, candles, and perhaps green glass.
summary: Excise duties are simple, transparent taxes on a small number of domestic luxury goods. The only exceptions to their luxury focus are duties on a few necessities like salt, soap, leather, and candles.
distilled: Excise duties are clear, limited taxes on domestic luxury goods, with few exceptions for necessities.
notes: Excise vs. customs distinction -- clarity and simplicity of excise administration -- taxation of luxuries vs. necessities -- Smith's four maxims of taxation (certainty principle)

refashioned: Customs duties are far older than excise duties. They appear to have been called 'customs' because they were customary payments of immemorial origin. They seem to have been initially conceived as taxes on merchants' profits. During the violent disorder of feudal times, merchants -- like other town dwellers -- were regarded as barely above freed serfs, their persons looked down upon and their earnings resented. The great nobles who had agreed to let the king tax the profits of their own tenants were equally willing to let him tax those of a class they had little interest in protecting. In those ignorant times, people did not understand that merchant profits cannot be taxed directly, or that the final burden of all such taxes must fall on consumers, along with a considerable additional charge.
elegant: Customs duties predate excise duties, originating as customary payments taxing merchant profits. In feudal times, merchants were despised as near-serfs whose gains could be freely taxed. The nobility consented to this, having little interest in protecting merchants. What was not understood then is that merchant profits cannot be directly taxed -- the final burden always falls on consumers, with a significant markup.
summary: Customs duties originated in feudal times as taxes on merchant profits, when merchants were looked down upon and the nobility saw no reason to protect them. The fundamental misunderstanding was that such taxes cannot really target merchant profits -- they ultimately fall on consumers with an added surcharge.
distilled: Customs duties began as feudal-era taxes on despised merchants, but their true burden always falls on consumers.
notes: History of customs duties -- feudal social hierarchy -- tax incidence theory -- merchants as despised class -- indirect taxation and consumer burden -- tallage

refashioned: The profits of foreign merchants were viewed even more unfavorably than those of English merchants. It was natural, therefore, that foreign merchants should be taxed more heavily. This distinction between duties on foreign and English merchants, which began from ignorance, has been maintained out of a spirit of monopoly -- to give domestic merchants an advantage in both the home and foreign markets.
elegant: Foreign merchants' profits were viewed more unfavorably than English ones, so they were taxed more heavily. This distinction, born from ignorance, has been preserved to give domestic merchants a monopolistic advantage at home and abroad.
summary: Higher customs duties on foreign merchants originated from prejudice but have been maintained deliberately to give English merchants a competitive advantage in both domestic and foreign markets.
distilled: Discriminatory duties against foreign merchants, born of prejudice, persist as tools of trade monopoly.
notes: Protectionism -- discriminatory tariffs -- monopoly spirit in trade policy -- mercantile system bias against foreign traders -- cross-reference Book IV on mercantilism

refashioned: Apart from this distinction between foreign and domestic merchants, the ancient customs duties were imposed equally on all types of goods -- necessities as well as luxuries, exports as well as imports. The reasoning was simple: why should dealers in one kind of goods be favored over dealers in another? And why should the exporting merchant be treated more favorably than the importing merchant?
elegant: The ancient customs applied equally to all goods -- necessities and luxuries, exports and imports alike. The logic was straightforward: no reason to favor one type of dealer or trade direction over another.
summary: Originally, customs duties were applied uniformly to all goods regardless of type or trade direction, reflecting a principle of equal treatment among merchants.
distilled: Ancient customs duties applied equally to all goods and all merchants without discrimination.
notes: Original uniformity of customs duties -- equal treatment principle -- contrast with later mercantile-era discrimination favoring exports over imports

refashioned: The ancient customs were divided into three branches. The first, and perhaps oldest, was the duty on wool and leather -- primarily an export duty. When the woolen manufacturing industry established itself in England, a similar duty was placed on woolen cloth to prevent the king from losing customs revenue through the export of finished goods rather than raw wool. The other two branches were: first, a duty on wine, charged at a fixed rate per ton and therefore called tonnage; and second, a duty on all other goods, charged at a fixed rate per pound of their estimated value, and therefore called poundage.
elegant: Ancient customs had three branches. First was the export duty on wool and leather, later extended to woolen cloth to protect royal revenue. Second was tonnage -- a per-ton duty on wine. Third was poundage -- a per-pound-of-value duty on all other goods.
summary: The ancient customs system comprised three duties: a wool and leather export duty (later extended to cloth), tonnage on wine, and poundage as an ad valorem tax on all remaining goods.
distilled: Ancient customs consisted of duties on wool/leather exports, tonnage on wine, and poundage on everything else.
notes: Origins of tonnage and poundage -- wool export duty -- English woolen manufacture -- ad valorem vs. specific duties -- revenue protection through tax extension

refashioned: In the forty-seventh year of Edward III's reign, a duty of sixpence per pound was imposed on all exported and imported goods, except wool, wool-felts, leather, and wines, which were subject to their own specific duties. Under Richard II, this was raised to one shilling per pound, but three years later reduced back to sixpence. It was raised to eightpence in the second year of Henry IV, and to one shilling in the fourth year of his reign. From that point until the ninth year of William III, this duty remained at one shilling per pound.
elegant: Under Edward III, a sixpence-per-pound duty covered all goods except those already specifically taxed. It fluctuated between sixpence and one shilling across several reigns before settling at one shilling from Henry IV through William III -- a period of nearly three centuries.
summary: The general poundage duty varied between sixpence and one shilling per pound across medieval and early modern reigns, finally stabilizing at one shilling from Henry IV until William III.
distilled: The general poundage duty fluctuated for centuries before settling at one shilling per pound under Henry IV.
notes: Historical poundage rates -- Edward III, Richard II, Henry IV, William III -- long stability of one-shilling rate -- medieval English fiscal history

refashioned: The duties of tonnage and poundage were usually granted to the king by a single act of Parliament and were known collectively as the subsidy of tonnage and poundage. Because the poundage subsidy had remained at one shilling per pound -- or five percent -- for so long, the word 'subsidy' came to mean, in customs terminology, a general duty of five percent. This original subsidy, now called the old subsidy, continues to be levied according to the schedule of rates established under Charles II. The practice of determining goods' values through an official book of rates is believed to predate the reign of James I.
elegant: Tonnage and poundage, granted together by Parliament, became known as the subsidy. Since poundage held at five percent for so long, 'subsidy' came to mean any general five-percent customs duty. The old subsidy still follows Charles II's book of rates, a valuation method predating James I.
summary: The long-standing five-percent poundage rate caused 'subsidy' to become synonymous with a five-percent customs duty. The original old subsidy persists under Charles II's rate schedule, while the book-of-rates valuation method dates back before James I.
distilled: The term 'subsidy' became shorthand for a five-percent customs duty due to poundage's long stability at that rate.
notes: Parliamentary grants of tonnage and poundage -- 'old subsidy' terminology -- book of rates under Charles II -- customs terminology evolution -- ad valorem assessment

refashioned: The new subsidy imposed under William III added another five percent on most goods. The one-third and two-third subsidies together constituted yet another five percent. The subsidy of 1747 added a fourth five percent on most goods, and that of 1759 a fifth on certain specific goods. Beyond these five subsidies, a wide variety of additional duties have been imposed on particular goods at various times -- sometimes to meet urgent government expenses, and sometimes to regulate trade according to mercantile system principles.
elegant: Successive subsidies under William III and later monarchs stacked additional five-percent layers onto customs duties. Beyond these, numerous ad hoc duties were imposed to address fiscal emergencies or to regulate trade along mercantilist lines.
summary: From William III onward, customs duties accumulated through successive five-percent subsidies, supplemented by numerous special duties imposed for either revenue or mercantilist trade regulation.
distilled: Customs duties grew through stacked five-percent subsidies and ad hoc duties driven by revenue needs and mercantilism.
notes: Layering of customs subsidies -- William III fiscal policy -- mercantilist trade regulation through tariffs -- distinction between revenue duties and regulatory duties

refashioned: The mercantile system has gradually become more fashionable. The old subsidy applied equally to exports and imports. But the four subsequent subsidies, along with most other duties imposed on particular goods, have been levied almost entirely on imports, with few exceptions. Most ancient export duties on domestic goods have been reduced or eliminated entirely. Bounties have even been granted to encourage certain exports. Drawbacks -- refunds of part or all of the import duties -- have been allowed when foreign goods are re-exported. Only half of the old subsidy's import duties are refunded on re-export, but the full duties from later subsidies are generally refunded. This growing favoritism toward exports and discouragement of imports has only a few exceptions, mainly concerning manufacturing materials. Merchants and manufacturers want raw materials to be as cheap as possible for themselves and as expensive as possible for foreign competitors. Foreign materials like Spanish wool, flax, and raw linen yarn are sometimes imported duty-free. Meanwhile, exports of domestic raw materials and colonial products have sometimes been prohibited or subjected to higher duties. English wool exports have been banned outright. Exports of beaver skins, beaver wool, and gum senegal have faced higher duties, since Britain's conquests of Canada and Senegal gave it near-monopoly control of those commodities.
elegant: The mercantile system's growing influence shifted customs from balanced import-export duties to a regime favoring exports through bounties and drawbacks while discouraging imports. Exceptions exist for raw materials: manufacturers want cheap inputs for themselves and expensive ones for competitors. Foreign raw materials sometimes enter duty-free, while exports of domestic materials are restricted -- especially where Britain holds monopoly power, as with Canadian beaver products and Senegalese gum.
summary: Under mercantilism, customs policy shifted from equal treatment of imports and exports to systematic encouragement of exports through bounties and drawbacks, and discouragement of imports. The main exceptions concern raw manufacturing materials, where policy aims to keep inputs cheap domestically while restricting their export to maintain competitive advantage.
distilled: Mercantilism transformed customs from balanced duties into a system favoring exports and restricting imports, with exceptions for raw materials.
notes: Evolution of customs policy under mercantilism -- export bounties and import drawbacks -- raw material trade policy -- colonial monopolies (Canada, Senegal) -- wool export prohibition -- cross-reference Book IV

refashioned: I have attempted to show in the fourth book of this work that the mercantile system has not served the revenue of the general population well -- that is, it has not benefited the annual output of the nation's land and labor. It appears to have been equally unhelpful to the sovereign's revenue, at least insofar as that revenue depends on customs duties.
elegant: As argued in Book IV, the mercantile system has harmed both national output and the sovereign's customs revenue.
summary: The mercantile system has failed both the public at large, by reducing national output, and the sovereign, by diminishing customs revenue.
distilled: The mercantile system has damaged both national prosperity and government customs revenue.
notes: Cross-reference Book IV -- mercantile system critique -- customs revenue vs. national output -- double failure of protectionism

refashioned: Under the mercantile system, the importation of several types of goods has been completely prohibited. This has in some cases entirely prevented, and in others greatly reduced, the importation of those goods by forcing importers to resort to smuggling. It has completely prevented the importation of foreign woolens and greatly reduced that of foreign silks and velvets. In both cases, it has entirely eliminated the customs revenue that such imports would have generated.
elegant: Import prohibitions under the mercantile system have eliminated or reduced imports of goods like foreign woolens, silks, and velvets -- partly by encouraging smuggling. In every case, the customs revenue those imports would have produced has been destroyed.
summary: Mercantile import prohibitions have either eliminated legal imports entirely or driven them underground through smuggling, destroying the customs revenue those goods would have generated.
distilled: Import prohibitions destroy customs revenue by eliminating legal trade and encouraging smuggling.
notes: Import prohibition effects -- smuggling as unintended consequence -- wool and silk import bans -- lost customs revenue -- mercantile system self-defeating nature

refashioned: The high duties imposed on many imported goods to discourage their consumption in Britain have often served only to encourage smuggling, and in every case have reduced customs revenue below what more moderate duties would have produced. As Dr. Swift aptly put it, in the arithmetic of customs, two and two sometimes make only one instead of four. This holds perfectly true for such excessive duties, which would never have been imposed had the mercantile system not taught us to use taxation as a tool of monopoly rather than revenue.
elegant: High import duties meant to curb consumption have instead encouraged smuggling and reduced revenue below what moderate duties would yield. As Swift observed, in customs arithmetic, two and two sometimes make one. Such duties exist only because mercantilism taught us to use taxation for monopoly, not revenue.
summary: Excessively high import duties defeat their own purpose by encouraging smuggling and reducing revenue below what moderate rates would produce. This perverse outcome reflects the mercantile system's misuse of taxation as a tool of monopoly rather than revenue generation.
