distilled: Excessive import duties encourage smuggling and yield less revenue than moderate ones -- using taxation for monopoly rather than revenue.
notes: Laffer curve logic avant la lettre -- Swift quotation on customs arithmetic -- smuggling incentives -- optimal tax rate for revenue maximization -- mercantilism critique

refashioned: The bounties sometimes given on exports of domestic goods and the drawbacks paid on re-exports of foreign goods have created opportunities for widespread fraud and a particularly destructive form of smuggling. To claim the bounty or drawback, goods are shipped and sent to sea, only to be secretly landed again elsewhere in the country. The revenue loss from bounties and drawbacks -- much of it obtained fraudulently -- is enormous. In the year ending January 5, 1755, gross customs revenue was 5,068,000 pounds. Bounties paid from this (even without any corn bounty that year) came to 167,806 pounds. Drawbacks on debentures and certificates amounted to 2,156,800 pounds. Together, bounties and drawbacks totaled 2,324,600 pounds. After these deductions, customs revenue was only 2,743,400 pounds. Subtracting 287,900 pounds for administrative costs, net customs revenue was just 2,455,500 pounds. Administrative expenses thus ran between five and six percent of gross revenue, and more than ten percent of revenue after bounties and drawbacks.
elegant: Export bounties and import drawbacks have spawned a destructive form of fraud: goods are shipped to sea then secretly re-landed to claim refunds. In 1755, gross customs of 5,068,000 pounds were reduced by 2,324,600 in bounties and drawbacks (much of it fraudulent), leaving only 2,743,400 -- and after 287,900 in administrative costs, net revenue was just 2,455,500 pounds. Administration consumed over ten percent of post-deduction revenue.
summary: Export bounties and drawbacks have enabled massive fraud through fake shipments, draining customs revenue. In 1755, bounties and drawbacks consumed nearly half of gross customs revenue, while administrative costs took another significant share, leaving net revenue far below the gross figure.
distilled: Export bounties and drawbacks enable massive fraud, consuming nearly half of gross customs revenue.
notes: Customs fraud through re-landing schemes -- 1755 revenue data -- bounties and drawbacks as revenue drain -- administrative costs of customs collection -- net vs. gross revenue distinction

refashioned: Because heavy duties are imposed on nearly all imported goods, our merchant importers smuggle as much as they can and declare as little as possible. Our merchant exporters, by contrast, declare more than they actually export -- sometimes out of vanity, wanting to appear as major dealers in goods that carry no duty, and sometimes to claim a bounty. As a result of these opposing frauds, our exports appear in the customs records to greatly exceed our imports, to the immense satisfaction of those politicians who measure national prosperity by the so-called balance of trade.
elegant: Heavy import duties incentivize importers to underreport through smuggling, while exporters overreport out of vanity or to claim bounties. The result: customs records show a flattering but fictitious trade surplus, delighting politicians obsessed with the balance of trade.
summary: Systematic fraud distorts trade statistics: importers underreport to avoid duties while exporters overreport to claim bounties or status. The resulting fictitious trade surplus misleads politicians who equate the balance of trade with national prosperity.
distilled: Import smuggling and export fraud create a fictitious trade surplus that misleads balance-of-trade politicians.
notes: Systematic distortion of trade statistics -- smuggling incentives from high duties -- balance of trade fallacy -- mercantile system critique -- customs fraud on both import and export sides

refashioned: All imported goods are liable to some customs duty unless specifically exempted, and such exemptions are not numerous. Goods not listed in the book of rates are taxed at four shillings and ninepence three-farthings per twenty shillings of value, as sworn by the importer -- roughly equivalent to five subsidies or five poundage duties. The book of rates is extremely comprehensive, listing a vast variety of articles, many rarely used and therefore poorly understood. This frequently creates uncertainty about how a particular type of goods should be classified and what duty it should pay. Such mistakes sometimes ruin the customs officer and regularly cause considerable trouble, expense, and frustration for the importer. In terms of clarity, precision, and consistency, customs duties are therefore far inferior to excise duties.
elegant: All imports face customs duties unless specifically exempted. Unlisted goods are taxed at roughly five subsidies based on the importer's sworn valuation. The book of rates is comprehensive but confusing, covering many obscure items. Classification disputes routinely cause trouble for importers and sometimes ruin customs officers. In clarity and precision, customs duties are far inferior to excise duties.
summary: Nearly all imports face customs duties, but the system's complexity creates constant classification disputes. The comprehensive but confusing book of rates leads to errors that harm both importers and customs officers, making customs duties far less clear and precise than excise duties.
distilled: The complexity and ambiguity of customs classifications make them far inferior to the clarity of excise duties.
notes: Book of rates complexity -- customs classification uncertainty -- excise vs. customs clarity -- Smith's certainty maxim of taxation -- administrative burden on importers and officers

refashioned: To ensure that most members of society contribute to public revenue in proportion to their spending, it is not necessary to tax every single item of expenditure. The revenue from excise duties is thought to fall as equally on contributors as that from customs duties, yet excise applies to only a few articles of the most general use and consumption. Many people have argued that customs duties could similarly be confined to just a few articles, without any loss of public revenue and with great benefit to foreign trade.
elegant: Proportional contribution to public revenue does not require taxing every item of expenditure. Excise duties, applied to only a few widely consumed goods, fall as equally on contributors as customs duties do. Many argue customs could likewise be confined to a few key articles, maintaining revenue while benefiting trade.
summary: Taxing every item is unnecessary for proportional revenue contribution. Since excise duties achieve equitable collection by targeting just a few widely consumed goods, many argue customs could be similarly simplified without revenue loss and with significant trade benefits.
distilled: Customs duties could be simplified to cover only a few key goods, matching excise efficiency without losing revenue.
notes: Tax simplification argument -- excise as model for customs reform -- proportionality in taxation -- broad-base vs. narrow-base tax debate -- trade liberalization through customs reform

refashioned: The most widely used and consumed foreign goods in Britain today appear to be chiefly: foreign wines and brandies; certain American and West Indian products such as sugar, rum, tobacco, and cocoa; and certain East Indian products such as tea, coffee, chinaware, spices of all kinds, and various piece-goods. These articles probably generate the bulk of current customs revenue. Most existing taxes on foreign manufactures -- apart from those on the goods just listed -- have been imposed not for revenue but to create monopoly advantages for domestic merchants in the home market. By removing all import prohibitions and subjecting all foreign manufactures to moderate taxes set at whatever rate experience shows yields the greatest revenue, our own workers could still retain a considerable home-market advantage. Meanwhile, many goods that currently produce no revenue at all, or very little, could generate substantial income for the government.
elegant: Britain's customs revenue comes mainly from duties on a few widely consumed imports: wines, brandies, sugar, rum, tobacco, tea, coffee, spices, and textiles. Most other import duties exist for monopoly protection, not revenue. Replacing prohibitions with moderate revenue-maximizing tariffs would maintain domestic advantage while turning currently unproductive duties into significant revenue sources.
summary: Most customs revenue comes from a handful of widely consumed imports. Other import duties serve monopoly rather than revenue purposes. Replacing prohibitions with moderate, revenue-optimizing tariffs would preserve domestic advantage while generating new government income from currently unproductive categories.
distilled: Most customs revenue comes from a few key imports; replacing protectionist duties with moderate revenue-maximizing tariffs would increase total income.
notes: Revenue concentration in few import categories -- colonial goods as revenue base (sugar, tea, tobacco) -- protectionist duties vs. revenue duties -- revenue-maximizing tariff rates -- import prohibition as lost revenue

refashioned:
High taxes sometimes reduce government revenue by diminishing consumption of the taxed goods, and sometimes by encouraging smuggling. Both effects frequently yield less revenue than more moderate taxes would have produced.

When revenue falls because consumption declines, there is only one remedy: lower the tax. When revenue falls because smuggling increases, there are two possible remedies: reduce the incentive to smuggle by lowering the tax, or increase the difficulty of smuggling by establishing a more effective administrative system.
elegant: High taxes reduce revenue either by shrinking consumption or encouraging smuggling -- both yield less than moderate rates would. Falling consumption has one remedy: lower the tax. Rising smuggling has two: lower the tax to reduce temptation, or improve administration to increase the difficulty of smuggling.
summary: Excessive taxes reduce revenue through two channels: reduced consumption and increased smuggling. Lower consumption can only be addressed by lowering the tax; smuggling can be combated by either lowering the tax or improving enforcement administration.
distilled: Excessive taxes lose revenue through reduced consumption or smuggling, each requiring different remedies.
notes: Revenue-maximizing tax rate -- two channels of revenue loss (consumption decline, smuggling) -- tax administration as anti-smuggling tool -- Laffer curve reasoning

refashioned: Experience shows that excise laws obstruct and frustrate smugglers far more effectively than customs laws do. By adopting an administrative system for customs that resembles the excise system as closely as the nature of the different duties permits, the difficulty of smuggling could be greatly increased. Many people believe this change could be implemented quite easily.
elegant: Excise laws are far more effective against smuggling than customs laws. Adopting excise-style administration for customs could greatly increase the difficulty of smuggling -- a reform many consider straightforward.
summary: The excise system's administrative methods are far more effective at preventing smuggling than customs procedures. Reforming customs administration along excise lines would significantly reduce smuggling.
distilled: Adopting excise-style administration for customs would greatly reduce smuggling.
notes: Excise vs. customs enforcement effectiveness -- administrative reform proposal -- smuggling prevention through institutional design

refashioned: Under this proposed system, an importer of goods subject to customs duties could choose either to store them in his own private warehouse or to lodge them in a public warehouse -- maintained at his own or the public's expense -- kept under the customs officer's lock and opened only in his presence. If the merchant chose his private warehouse, duties would be paid immediately with no drawback allowed later, and the warehouse would remain subject to customs inspection to verify that its contents matched what duties had been paid on. If he chose the public warehouse, no duty would be owed until the goods were removed for domestic consumption. Goods taken out for export would be duty-free, provided proper security was given to guarantee actual exportation. All dealers in those goods, wholesale or retail, would remain subject to customs inspection and required to prove by proper certificates that duties had been paid on everything in their shops or warehouses. The excise duties on imported rum already work this way, and the same system could perhaps be extended to all import duties -- provided those duties were, like excise duties, confined to a few widely consumed goods. If extended to nearly all goods as at present, public warehouses of sufficient size could not easily be provided, and delicate goods requiring careful storage could not safely be trusted to any warehouse but the merchant's own.
elegant: Importers could choose between a private warehouse (duties paid immediately, no drawback, subject to inspection) or a public bonded warehouse (duties deferred until goods enter domestic consumption, duty-free if re-exported). All dealers would face inspection requirements. This system already applies to imported rum and could extend to all customs -- but only if duties were confined to a few major goods. Applying it to nearly all goods, as now, would make bonded warehousing impractical.
summary: A proposed bonded warehouse system would let importers defer duties until goods are sold domestically, while re-exports go duty-free. This already works for imported rum. However, it requires confining customs duties to a few major goods, since extending it to all goods would create impossible warehousing demands.
distilled: A bonded warehouse system could reform customs by deferring duties until domestic sale, but only if duties were confined to a few key goods.
notes: Bonded warehouse proposal -- duty deferral until consumption -- duty-free re-export -- excise-style customs administration -- rum import precedent -- practical limits of universal bonded warehousing

refashioned: If such an administrative system could effectively prevent large-scale smuggling even under fairly high duties, and if every duty rate were periodically adjusted up or down to maximize state revenue -- with taxation always used as an instrument of revenue rather than monopoly -- it seems quite possible that revenue at least equal to current net customs revenue could be collected from duties on just a few widely consumed imports. Customs duties could thus achieve the same simplicity, certainty, and precision as excise duties. The revenue currently lost to drawbacks on re-exported foreign goods that are secretly re-landed and consumed domestically would be entirely saved. If this saving were combined with the abolition of all export bounties -- except those that are genuinely refunds of excise duties already paid -- there can be little doubt that net customs revenue after such reform would at least equal what it had been before.
elegant: If effective anti-smuggling administration allowed duties to be set purely for maximum revenue rather than monopoly, net customs revenue could be maintained while taxing only a few key imports. Customs would gain the simplicity of excise. Revenue lost to fraudulent drawbacks would be saved, and abolishing non-refund export bounties would further ensure that net revenue matched or exceeded current levels.
summary: An effective anti-smuggling system focused on revenue maximization rather than monopoly could maintain customs revenue while taxing only a few widely consumed imports. Additional savings from eliminating drawback fraud and unnecessary export bounties would ensure no revenue loss from simplification.
distilled: Revenue-focused customs reform taxing only a few key imports could match current net revenue while gaining excise-level simplicity.
notes: Customs simplification proposal -- revenue-maximizing tax rates vs. monopoly duties -- drawback fraud elimination -- export bounty reform -- Smith's four maxims applied to customs

refashioned: If such a reform caused no loss of public revenue, trade and manufacturing would certainly gain enormous advantages. Trade in the untaxed goods -- by far the largest category -- would be completely free, conducted to and from all parts of the world under the most favorable conditions. These untaxed goods would include all necessities of life and all manufacturing materials. Insofar as free importation of necessities reduced their average money price in the home market, it would reduce the money price of labor -- but without reducing labor's real compensation in any way.
elegant: If revenue were maintained, trade and manufacturing would benefit enormously. The vast majority of goods, now untaxed, would trade freely worldwide -- including all necessities and raw materials. Free importation of necessities would lower their money price and thus money wages, but without reducing workers' real purchasing power.
summary: Customs reform maintaining revenue would free the vast majority of goods from duties, enabling unrestricted global trade in necessities and manufacturing materials. Lower money prices for necessities would reduce money wages without harming workers' real incomes.
distilled: Customs reform would free most goods for unrestricted trade, lowering money wages without reducing real purchasing power.
notes: Free trade benefits from customs simplification -- nominal vs. real wages distinction -- free importation of necessities and raw materials -- trade liberalization without revenue loss

refashioned: The value of money is determined by the quantity of necessities it can buy. The value of necessities, however, is entirely independent of how much money they sell for. A reduction in the money price of labor would necessarily produce a proportional reduction in the money price of all domestically manufactured goods, giving them a competitive advantage in foreign markets. For some manufactures, the price reduction would be even greater due to the free importation of raw materials. If raw silk could be imported duty-free from China and India, English silk manufacturers could greatly undersell their French and Italian competitors. There would be no need to prohibit the importation of foreign silks and velvets.
elegant: Money's value depends on the necessities it buys, not vice versa. Lower money wages would proportionally reduce domestic manufacturing costs, boosting competitiveness abroad. Free importation of raw materials would amplify this effect -- duty-free raw silk from China and India would let English manufacturers undersell French and Italian competitors, making import prohibitions on silks unnecessary.
summary: Lower money wages from free importation of necessities would reduce domestic manufacturing costs and boost export competitiveness. Free raw material imports would amplify this advantage further, potentially making protectionist import bans unnecessary.
distilled: Free imports of necessities and raw materials would lower manufacturing costs, making protectionist import bans unnecessary.
notes: Nominal vs. real value of money -- money wage reduction and manufacturing competitiveness -- raw material imports and cost advantage -- silk trade example (China, India, France, Italy) -- natural competitiveness vs. artificial protection

refashioned: The cheapness of domestic goods would secure for our workers not only the home market but also significant command of the foreign market. Even trade in the taxed goods would be conducted more advantageously than at present. If taxed goods were removed from the public warehouse for export, they would be entirely tax-free, making that trade perfectly free. The carrying trade in all goods would enjoy every possible advantage under this system. If taxed goods were removed for domestic consumption, the importer -- not having to pay the tax until he found a buyer, whether a dealer or consumer -- could always afford to sell cheaper than if he had been required to pay the duty at the moment of importation. Even under the same tax rates, the foreign trade in taxed goods could thus be conducted much more advantageously than it is now.
elegant: Cheap domestic goods would secure both home and foreign markets. Even taxed goods would trade more advantageously: exports from bonded warehouses would be duty-free, and importers selling domestically could defer tax payment until finding a buyer, enabling lower prices. The carrying trade would benefit maximally. Under identical tax rates, foreign trade would improve simply through better administration.
summary: Under the reformed system, domestic competitiveness would dominate both home and foreign markets. Even taxed goods would benefit: duty-free re-export from bonded warehouses and deferred domestic duty payment would lower costs and improve trade conditions without changing tax rates.
distilled: Bonded warehouse reform would improve trade even in taxed goods by enabling duty-free exports and deferred domestic payment.
notes: Carrying trade advantages -- bonded warehouse benefits -- duty deferral and cash flow for importers -- export competitiveness through lower domestic costs -- tax administration reform vs. rate changes

refashioned: Sir Robert Walpole's famous excise scheme aimed to establish a system for wine and tobacco very similar to what I have proposed here. Although the bill introduced to Parliament covered only those two goods, it was widely assumed to be the beginning of a broader reform along the same lines. Political faction, combined with the self-interest of smuggling merchants, raised such a violent -- though unjust -- outcry against the bill that the minister thought it prudent to withdraw it. Out of fear of provoking a similar uproar, none of his successors have dared revive the project.
elegant: Walpole's excise scheme proposed a similar system for wine and tobacco, but was seen as the start of broader reform. Political factions allied with smuggling merchants raised such an unjust outcry that Walpole withdrew the bill. No successor has dared revive it since.
summary: Walpole attempted a similar customs-to-excise reform for wine and tobacco, but an alliance of political opponents and smuggling interests forced him to abandon it. Fear of similar opposition has prevented any successor from reviving the idea.
distilled: Walpole's excise reform for wine and tobacco was killed by political factions and smuggling interests, deterring all successors.
notes: Walpole's excise scheme (1733) -- political economy of tax reform -- smuggling merchants as reform opponents -- interest group politics blocking efficient reform -- historical precedent for customs-to-excise conversion

refashioned:
Duties on imported foreign luxuries for domestic consumption, though they sometimes affect the poor, fall mainly on people of middling or greater fortune. Examples include duties on foreign wines, coffee, chocolate, tea, and sugar.

Duties on cheaper domestically produced luxuries for home consumption fall fairly equally on people of all income levels, in proportion to their spending. The poor pay the duties on malt, hops, beer, and ale through their own consumption; the wealthy pay on both their own consumption and that of their servants.
elegant: Import duties on foreign luxuries like wine, coffee, tea, and sugar fall mainly on the middling and wealthy. Duties on cheaper domestic luxuries like beer and ale fall more equally across all income levels in proportion to spending -- the poor pay on their own consumption, the rich on theirs and their servants'.
summary: Import duties on foreign luxuries primarily burden the middle and upper classes. Domestic excise duties on cheaper goods like beer and ale are more broadly shared across all income levels proportional to consumption.
distilled: Foreign luxury duties fall on the wealthy; domestic excise on cheaper goods like beer falls proportionally on all classes.
notes: Tax incidence by income class -- foreign luxury duties vs. domestic excise -- progressive vs. proportional taxation -- beer and ale as broadly consumed goods -- servant consumption included in wealthy household spending

refashioned: It must be noted that the total consumption of the lower classes -- those below the middling rank -- is in every country much greater, not only in quantity but in value, than that of the middle and upper classes combined. The total spending of the lower classes far exceeds that of the upper classes. First, nearly all of a country's capital is distributed annually among the lower classes as wages for productive labor. Second, a large share of the revenue from both land rent and stock profits is distributed among the same class as wages and maintenance for household servants and other unproductive workers.
elegant: The lower classes' total consumption exceeds that of the middle and upper classes, both in quantity and value. Nearly all national capital flows to them annually as productive wages, and a large portion of rent and profit income also reaches them as payment for domestic service and other unproductive labor.
summary: The aggregate consumption of the lower classes exceeds that of the upper classes because nearly all national capital reaches them as wages, and much rent and profit income flows to them as payment for service work.
distilled: Lower classes consume more in aggregate than upper classes because most national capital flows to them as wages.
notes: Aggregate consumption by class -- productive vs. unproductive labor -- wage distribution of national capital -- rent and profit redistribution through employment -- cross-reference Book II on productive labor

refashioned: Third, some portion of stock profits belongs to the lower classes as well, arising from the employment of their small capitals. The profits earned annually by small shopkeepers, tradesmen, and retailers of all kinds are everywhere very substantial and constitute a significant share of annual national output. Fourth and finally, even some land rent belongs to the lower classes: a considerable portion to those somewhat below the middling rank, and a small part even to the very lowest rank, since common laborers sometimes own an acre or two of land.
elegant: The lower classes also receive some profits from their small capitals -- shopkeepers, tradesmen, and retailers earn a significant share of national output. Even some land rent accrues to them: a considerable share to those just below middling rank, and a small part to the lowest laborers who sometimes own a little land.
summary: Beyond wages, the lower classes earn profits from small businesses and even some land rent, with common laborers sometimes owning small plots. These additional income sources further increase the lower classes' share of total national consumption.
distilled: Lower classes also receive small-business profits and some land rent, further increasing their aggregate spending share.
notes: Multiple income sources for lower classes -- small shopkeeper profits -- land ownership among laborers -- distribution of national output across classes -- four channels of income to lower classes

refashioned: Although each lower-class individual's spending is quite small, their collective spending always constitutes by far the largest share of total national expenditure. What remains of the annual output of land and labor for upper-class consumption is always much less, both in quantity and value. Taxes on spending that fall mainly on the upper classes -- targeting the smaller share of annual output -- will therefore produce much less revenue than taxes falling equally on all classes or even those falling mainly on the lower classes. Taxes targeting the larger share of annual output will always be more productive than those targeting the smaller share.
elegant: Though individually small, lower-class spending collectively dwarfs upper-class spending. Taxes falling mainly on upper-class expenditure -- the smaller share of national output -- therefore produce less revenue than those falling on all classes or even primarily on the lower classes.
summary: Because the lower classes' collective spending far exceeds that of the upper classes, taxes targeting upper-class expenditure alone generate less revenue than broader taxes or even those primarily affecting lower-class consumption.
distilled: Taxes on upper-class spending alone yield less revenue than broader taxes because lower-class aggregate spending is much larger.
notes: Tax base and revenue productivity -- aggregate spending by class -- regressive taxes as revenue-maximizers -- distributional paradox of consumption taxes -- revenue implications of targeting different income groups

refashioned: The excise on domestically produced fermented and spirituous liquors is accordingly the most productive of all consumption taxes by far, and this branch of the excise falls heavily -- perhaps primarily -- on ordinary people's spending. In the year ending July 5, 1775, the gross revenue from this branch of the excise amounted to 3,341,837 pounds, nine shillings, and ninepence.
elegant: The excise on domestic beer and spirits is by far the most productive consumption tax, falling heavily on common people's spending. In 1775, it grossed over 3.3 million pounds.
summary: The excise on domestic alcoholic beverages is the most revenue-productive of all consumption taxes, largely because it falls on the spending of ordinary people, whose aggregate consumption is the largest.
distilled: The excise on domestic alcohol is the most productive consumption tax because it targets the largest spending base -- ordinary people.
notes: Alcohol excise as top revenue source -- 1775 revenue figures (3.34 million pounds) -- regressive tax incidence -- broad consumption base drives revenue productivity

refashioned: It must always be remembered, however, that it is the luxury spending of the lower classes, not their necessary spending, that should be taxed. A tax on their necessities would ultimately fall on the upper classes -- on the smaller portion of annual output, not the larger. Such a tax must either raise wages or reduce the demand for labor. If it raises wages, the final payment falls on the upper classes. If it reduces labor demand, it shrinks the annual output of land and labor -- the very fund from which all taxes must ultimately be paid. Whatever state of labor demand such a tax might produce, it must always push wages higher than they would otherwise be in that state, and the final cost of this wage increase must in every case fall on the upper classes.
elegant: Only luxuries of the lower classes should be taxed, never necessities. Taxing necessities must either raise wages -- shifting the burden to upper classes -- or reduce labor demand, shrinking the national output that funds all taxes. Either way, the tax ultimately falls on the upper classes and harms the broader economy.
summary: Taxing the necessities of the poor is counterproductive: it either raises wages (shifting the burden to the wealthy) or reduces labor demand (shrinking national output). Only luxury consumption of the lower classes should be taxed.
distilled: Taxing lower-class necessities is self-defeating because the burden ultimately shifts to upper classes or reduces national output.
notes: Tax incidence on necessities vs. luxuries -- wage effects of necessity taxation -- labor demand and national output -- final burden always falls on upper classes -- cross-reference wage theory in Book I

refashioned: In Great Britain, beer brewed and spirits distilled for private use rather than for sale are exempt from excise duties. This exemption, intended to spare private families from intrusive visits by tax collectors, causes these duties to fall much more lightly on the wealthy than on the poor. Private distilling is uncommon, though it does occur. But in the countryside, many middling families and nearly all wealthy and great families brew their own beer. Their strong beer therefore costs them eight shillings per barrel less than it costs the commercial brewer, who must earn a profit on the tax as well as on all his other expenses. Such families can therefore drink their beer at least nine or ten shillings per barrel cheaper than any beer of equal quality available to ordinary people, who find it more convenient to buy by the small measure from a brewery or alehouse. Similarly, malt made for private use is exempt from tax inspection, though such families must pay a flat composition of seven shillings and sixpence per head. This equals the excise on ten bushels of malt -- roughly what all members of any moderate family, men, women, and children, would consume on average. But in wealthy households practicing country hospitality, the family's own consumption is only a small fraction of the household's total. Whether because of this composition arrangement or for other reasons, private malting is far less common than private brewing. It is difficult to see any fair reason why those who brew or distill for private use should not pay a similar composition.
elegant: The excise exemption for privately brewed beer and distilled spirits -- meant to spare families from tax inspectors -- causes these duties to fall much lighter on the wealthy than on the poor. Wealthy families brew their own beer at eight shillings per barrel less than commercial brewers charge. While private malting requires a per-head composition payment, private brewing does not. In grand households with extensive hospitality, the flat-rate composition captures only a fraction of actual consumption. There is no fair reason why private brewers and distillers should not pay a similar composition.
summary: The excise exemption for privately brewed beer creates an unfair advantage for wealthy families, who avoid duties that commercial brewers pass to ordinary consumers. While private malting requires a composition payment, private brewing does not, and there is no equitable justification for this distinction.
distilled: Excise exemptions for private brewing unfairly benefit the wealthy while ordinary consumers bear the full tax burden.
notes: Regressive effect of private brewing exemption -- composition payments for malt -- wealthy household hospitality and consumption -- equity in excise administration -- tax avoidance by upper classes

refashioned: It has frequently been argued that greater revenue than is currently drawn from all the heavy taxes on malt, beer, and ale could be raised by a much lighter tax on malt alone. The opportunities for defrauding the revenue are much greater in a brewery than in a malt-house, and those who brew for private use are exempt from all duties or composition, whereas those who malt for private use are not.
elegant: A lighter tax on malt alone could yield more revenue than the current heavy taxes on malt, beer, and ale combined, since breweries offer more opportunities for fraud than malt-houses, and private brewers enjoy duty exemptions that private maltsters do not.
summary: Consolidating all malt liquor taxes into a single malt tax could increase revenue by reducing fraud opportunities in breweries and eliminating the inequitable exemption enjoyed by private brewers.
distilled: A single malt tax could raise more revenue than current combined duties by reducing fraud and closing the private brewing exemption.
notes: Malt tax consolidation proposal -- fraud opportunities in brewing vs. malting -- private brewing exemption as loophole -- tax simplification for higher revenue

refashioned: In London's porter breweries, a quarter of malt is typically brewed into more than two and a half barrels, sometimes three barrels of porter. The various malt taxes amount to six shillings per quarter; the taxes on strong beer amount to eight shillings per barrel. In porter breweries, therefore, the combined taxes on malt, beer, and ale come to between twenty-six and thirty shillings per quarter of malt. In country breweries producing for local sale, a quarter of malt is rarely brewed into less than two barrels of strong beer and one barrel of small beer, often into two and a half barrels of strong beer. The small beer tax is one shilling and fourpence per barrel. In country breweries, the combined taxes therefore rarely fall below twenty-three shillings and fourpence, and frequently reach twenty-six shillings per quarter of malt. Across the whole kingdom, the average combined duties on malt, beer, and ale cannot be less than twenty-four or twenty-five shillings per quarter of malt. But by abolishing all separate duties on beer and ale and tripling the malt tax from six to eighteen shillings per quarter, it is argued that this single tax could raise more revenue than all those heavier taxes combined.
elegant: Combined taxes on malt and beer currently amount to twenty-four to thirty shillings per quarter of malt depending on location. London porter breweries pay twenty-six to thirty shillings; country breweries pay twenty-three to twenty-six. Tripling the malt tax from six to eighteen shillings while abolishing beer duties would, it is argued, raise more revenue through a single simpler tax.
summary: Current combined taxes on malt and beer average twenty-four to twenty-five shillings per quarter of malt across the kingdom. Consolidating them into a single tripled malt tax of eighteen shillings per quarter could raise more revenue through simplified administration and reduced fraud.
distilled: Tripling the malt tax while abolishing beer duties could generate more revenue than the current complex system.
notes: Porter brewery vs. country brewery tax burden -- London vs. provincial production ratios -- malt tax consolidation arithmetic -- six to eighteen shilling reform proposal -- strong beer vs. small beer duties

refashioned: The malt tax revenues from 1772 to 1775 were as follows: In 1772, the old malt tax produced 722,023 pounds and the additional tax 356,776 pounds. In 1773, the old tax produced 561,627 pounds and the additional 278,650 pounds. In 1774, the old tax produced 624,614 pounds and the additional 310,745 pounds. In 1775, the old tax produced 657,357 pounds and the additional 323,785 pounds. The four-year total was 3,835,580 pounds, giving an annual average of 958,895 pounds.
elegant: Malt tax revenues from 1772-1775 averaged 958,895 pounds annually, combining the old and additional malt taxes across four years of fluctuating yields.
summary: The combined old and additional malt taxes averaged about 959,000 pounds per year over the 1772-1775 period, providing the baseline for calculating whether a consolidated malt tax could match total alcohol duty revenue.
distilled: Malt tax revenue averaged roughly 959,000 pounds annually from 1772 to 1775.
notes: Malt tax revenue data 1772-1775 -- old vs. additional malt tax -- annual fluctuations in tax yield -- baseline for consolidation proposal

refashioned: The beer and ale excise revenues from 1772 to 1775 were as follows: In 1772, the country excise produced 1,243,120 pounds and the London brewery 408,260 pounds. In 1773, the country excise produced 1,245,808 pounds and the London brewery 405,406 pounds. In 1774, the country excise produced 1,246,373 pounds and the London brewery 320,601 pounds. In 1775, the country excise produced 1,214,583 pounds and the London brewery 463,670 pounds. The four-year total was 6,547,832 pounds, giving an annual average of 1,636,958 pounds. Adding the average malt tax of 958,895 pounds gives the combined total.
elegant: Beer and ale excise averaged 1,636,958 pounds annually from 1772-1775 (combining country excise and London brewery revenues). Adding the 958,895-pound malt tax average provides the total revenue baseline for comparison with the proposed reform.
summary: The beer and ale excise averaged about 1.64 million pounds per year over 1772-1775, which when added to the malt tax average of about 959,000 pounds, establishes the total revenue that a consolidated malt tax would need to match.
distilled: Beer and ale excise averaged 1.64 million pounds annually from 1772-1775, to be combined with malt tax data for reform comparison.
notes: Beer and ale excise revenue data 1772-1775 -- country excise vs. London brewery -- revenue baseline for malt tax consolidation -- four-year averaging method

refashioned:
The total combined duties on malt, beer, and ale averaged 2,595,835 pounds annually.

By tripling the malt tax from six to eighteen shillings per quarter, that single tax would produce 2,876,685 pounds -- exceeding the combined total by 280,832 pounds. Admittedly, the old malt tax includes a four-shilling duty on cider per hogshead and a ten-shilling duty on mum per barrel. In 1774, the cider tax produced only 3,083 pounds, probably below its usual yield since all cider taxes underperformed that year. The mum duty, though heavier, produces even less revenue due to lower consumption. However, to offset these, the country excise includes its own duties: an old excise of six shillings and eightpence on cider per hogshead, a similar duty on verjuice, eight shillings and ninepence on vinegar per hogshead, and elevenpence per gallon on mead or metheglin. The revenue from these duties would likely more than counterbalance the cider and mum duties included in the malt tax.
elegant: Combined malt, beer, and ale duties averaged 2,595,835 pounds. A tripled malt tax would yield 2,876,685 pounds -- a surplus of 280,832 pounds. Minor complications from cider and mum duties included in the malt tax are offset by corresponding excise duties on cider, verjuice, vinegar, and mead within the country excise.
summary: The tripled malt tax would raise about 281,000 pounds more than the combined existing duties. Technical complications involving minor duties on cider, mum, verjuice, vinegar, and mead roughly cancel each other out between the two systems.
distilled: A tripled malt tax would exceed current combined alcohol duties by about 281,000 pounds, with minor cross-duty complications roughly canceling out.
notes: Revenue comparison showing malt tax consolidation surplus -- cider, mum, verjuice, vinegar, and mead as minor complicating duties -- 280,832-pound net revenue gain from reform

refashioned: Malt is consumed not only in brewing beer and ale but also in manufacturing low wines and spirits. If the malt tax were raised to eighteen shillings per quarter, it might be necessary to reduce some of the excise duties on those spirits that use malt as an ingredient. In malt spirits, malt typically constitutes only about a third of the raw materials, with the remainder being either raw barley alone or a mixture of barley and wheat. In malt spirit distilleries, both the opportunity and temptation to smuggle are much greater than in either a brewery or a malt-house -- the opportunity because of the smaller bulk and greater value of the product, the temptation because of the much higher duty rates, which amounted to three shillings and ten and two-thirds pence per gallon of spirits. (Though the duties directly imposed on proof spirits amount to only two shillings and sixpence per gallon, these combined with the duties on the low wines from which they are distilled total three shillings and ten and two-thirds pence. Both low wines and proof spirits are now measured according to their wash content to prevent fraud.)
elegant: Malt is also used in distilling spirits, where it typically makes up only a third of the ingredients. Raising the malt tax might require offsetting reductions in spirit excise duties. Distilleries face much greater smuggling risks than breweries due to spirits' higher value-to-bulk ratio and heavier duty burden -- over three shillings and tenpence per gallon when low wine duties are included.
summary: A tripled malt tax would need to be offset by reduced spirit excise duties, since malt is a key distilling ingredient. Distilleries face greater smuggling temptation than breweries because spirits combine high value, small bulk, and heavy duty burdens.
distilled: Raising the malt tax would require offsetting reductions in spirit duties, given the already high smuggling incentives in distilling.
notes: Malt in distilling vs. brewing -- spirit duty rates (3s 10 2/3d per gallon) -- smuggling incentives: bulk-to-value ratio -- malt as one-third of spirit ingredients -- wash measurement as anti-fraud measure

refashioned:
By increasing the malt duty while reducing spirit excise duties, both the opportunity and temptation to smuggle would diminish, potentially producing a further increase in revenue.

British policy has long aimed to discourage the consumption of spirits because of their supposed tendency to ruin public health and corrupt morals. Under this policy, the excise reduction should not be so large as to actually reduce spirit prices. Spirits could remain as expensive as ever while beer and ale became considerably cheaper. The public could thus be partly relieved of one of the burdens they most complain about, while government revenue increased at the same time.
elegant: Shifting tax burden from spirits to malt would reduce smuggling incentives and potentially increase revenue. Since policy aims to discourage spirit consumption, the spirit duty reduction need not lower spirit prices. Instead, beer and ale prices would fall, relieving a major public grievance while maintaining or increasing total revenue.
summary: Restructuring duties to tax malt more heavily while slightly reducing spirit duties would reduce smuggling without making spirits cheaper. Beer and ale prices would fall, simultaneously relieving public burden and potentially increasing government revenue.
distilled: Shifting the tax burden from spirits to malt would reduce smuggling, lower beer prices, and maintain government revenue.
notes: Tax restructuring to reduce smuggling -- public health policy on spirits -- beer price reduction as public benefit -- simultaneous revenue increase and tax relief -- alcohol policy objectives

refashioned: Dr. Davenant's objections to this proposed change in the excise system appear to be without foundation. He objects that the tax, instead of being distributed as it is now among the maltster's, brewer's, and retailer's profits, would fall entirely on the maltster's profit; that the maltster could not as easily recover the tax through higher malt prices as the brewer and retailer can through higher liquor prices; and that such a heavy tax on malt might reduce the rent and profit of barley-growing land.
elegant: Davenant objected that a consolidated malt tax would concentrate the burden on maltsters rather than spreading it across maltsters, brewers, and retailers, and that it might reduce barley land rents. These objections are unfounded.
summary: Davenant argued that consolidating all alcohol taxes onto malt would unfairly burden maltsters who could not pass on the cost, and would depress barley land values. Smith considers these objections groundless.
distilled: Davenant's objections that a consolidated malt tax would burden maltsters and depress barley land values are unfounded.
notes: Davenant's objections to malt tax reform -- tax incidence across supply chain (maltster, brewer, retailer) -- barley land rent concerns -- Smith's rebuttal of anti-reform arguments

refashioned: No tax can reduce the profit rate in a particular trade for long, because profits must stay level with those in neighboring trades. Current duties on malt, beer, and ale do not affect dealer profits -- they all pass the tax on to consumers through higher prices. A tax may make goods so expensive that consumption declines, but malt is consumed as beer and ale, and an eighteen-shilling malt tax could hardly make these drinks more expensive than the current combined duties of twenty-four or twenty-five shillings already do. In fact, these drinks would probably become cheaper, and their consumption would be more likely to increase than decrease.
elegant: Profit rates equalize across trades, so no tax can permanently reduce profits in one sector. Current duties totaling twenty-four or twenty-five shillings per quarter of malt are fully passed to consumers. An eighteen-shilling malt tax would actually lower the total burden, making beer and ale cheaper and likely increasing consumption.
summary: Since profit rates equalize across industries, the malt tax cannot permanently depress maltster profits. Moreover, the proposed eighteen-shilling malt tax is actually lower than current combined duties, so beer and ale would likely become cheaper, boosting consumption.
distilled: The consolidated malt tax would be lower than current combined duties, making beer cheaper and likely increasing consumption.
notes: Profit equalization across trades -- tax pass-through to consumers -- eighteen vs. twenty-four-plus shillings comparison -- consumption increase from lower effective tax -- rebuttal of Davenant

refashioned: It is not easy to understand why it should be harder for the maltster to pass on eighteen shillings in higher malt prices than it currently is for the brewer to pass on twenty-four, twenty-five, or sometimes thirty shillings in higher liquor prices. The maltster would indeed have to advance a tax of eighteen shillings instead of six per quarter of malt. But the brewer currently advances twenty-four, twenty-five, or even thirty shillings per quarter brewed. It could not be more inconvenient for the maltster to advance a lighter tax than for the brewer to advance a heavier one. The maltster does not typically hold malt stocks any longer than the brewer holds stocks of beer and ale, so the maltster can recover his money just as quickly. But even if advancing the heavier tax did cause the maltster some inconvenience, this could easily be remedied by granting him a few months longer credit than is currently given to the brewer.
elegant: The maltster advancing eighteen shillings faces less burden than the brewer currently advancing twenty-four to thirty shillings per quarter. Malt inventory turns over no slower than beer inventory, so cost recovery is comparable. Any remaining inconvenience could be solved by extending the maltster's payment credit by a few months.
summary: The maltster's burden under the proposed system would actually be lighter than the brewer's current burden, since eighteen shillings is less than the twenty-four to thirty shillings brewers already advance. Any cash-flow difficulty could be solved with extended credit terms.
distilled: Maltsters would advance a lighter tax than brewers currently do, and any cash-flow difficulty could be resolved with extended credit.
notes: Rebuttal of tax-advancement objection -- comparative burden: maltster vs. brewer -- inventory turnover and cost recovery -- credit extension as practical remedy

refashioned: Nothing could reduce the rent and profit of barley land unless it reduced the demand for barley. But a reform that lowered the total duty on a quarter of malt brewed into beer from twenty-four or twenty-five shillings to eighteen shillings would more likely increase barley demand than reduce it. Besides, the rent and profit of barley land must always be roughly equal to those of other equally fertile and well-cultivated land. If returns from barley were lower, some barley land would be converted to other uses; if they were higher, more land would be planted with barley.
elegant: Barley land values would only fall if barley demand fell. Since the reform lowers the effective tax burden, barley demand would more likely increase. Moreover, barley land rents must stay in line with other equally productive land -- market forces ensure reallocation if returns diverge.
summary: The malt tax reform would likely increase barley demand by reducing the total tax burden, not decrease it. And barley land rents are kept in equilibrium with other agricultural land through natural market adjustment.
distilled: The reform would increase barley demand by lowering total duties, and market forces would maintain barley land rents at equilibrium.
notes: Barley demand and land rent -- tax burden reduction stimulating demand -- agricultural land rent equalization -- market-driven land allocation -- rebuttal of Davenant's barley land objection

refashioned: When the ordinary price of a particular agricultural product is at what may be called a monopoly price, a tax on it necessarily reduces the rent and profit of the land producing it. A tax on the output of those precious vineyards whose wine falls so far short of demand that its price permanently exceeds what comparably fertile land would normally yield would necessarily reduce vineyard rents and profits. Since the wine price is already the highest obtainable for the quantity typically brought to market, it could not be raised further without reducing that quantity. And the quantity could not be reduced without even greater loss, because the land could not be turned to any equally valuable alternative use.
elegant: When a product already commands a monopoly price, a tax on it cannot be passed to consumers -- it must fall on the producer's rent and profit. Precious vineyard wines that perpetually exceed demand cannot be priced higher or their land repurposed, so any tax reduces the landowner's returns directly.
summary: Taxes on goods already at monopoly prices cannot be passed on to consumers. The entire burden falls on rents and profits because prices cannot rise further and the land cannot be redirected to equally valuable alternative uses.
distilled: Taxes on monopoly-priced goods fall entirely on producers because the price cannot rise further and the land has no better alternative use.
notes: Monopoly price and tax incidence -- inelastic supply and tax burden -- precious vineyard example -- land rent reduction from taxation at monopoly price -- contrast with competitive-price goods

refashioned: The full weight of the tax would therefore fall on rent and profit -- specifically on the vineyard rent. When new taxes on sugar have been proposed, sugar planters have frequently complained that the entire burden falls on the producer rather than the consumer, claiming they were never able to raise sugar prices after a tax was imposed. It seems the price was already a monopoly price before the tax. The arguments planters used to show that sugar was an improper subject for taxation actually demonstrated it was a proper one -- for the profits of monopolists, whenever they can be reached, are certainly the most appropriate subjects for taxation of all.
elegant: When sugar planters complained that taxes fell entirely on producers rather than consumers, they inadvertently proved sugar was already at a monopoly price -- making it an ideal tax target. Monopoly profits, whenever they can be accessed, are the most proper subject for taxation.
summary: Sugar planters' complaints that they could not pass tax increases to consumers revealed that sugar was already monopoly-priced. This actually made it an ideal subject for taxation, since monopoly profits are the most appropriate targets for the tax collector.
distilled: Monopoly profits that cannot be passed to consumers are the most proper subject for taxation, as sugar planters inadvertently demonstrated.
notes: Sugar planters and tax incidence -- monopoly pricing revealed by inability to pass on tax -- monopoly profits as ideal tax base -- ironic reversal of planters' argument -- colonial sugar monopoly

refashioned: But the ordinary price of barley has never been a monopoly price, and the rent and profit of barley land have never exceeded their natural proportion to those of other equally fertile and well-cultivated land. The various taxes imposed on malt, beer, and ale have never lowered barley prices or reduced barley land rents and profits. The price of malt to the brewer has consistently risen in proportion to the taxes imposed on it, and those taxes, along with the separate duties on beer and ale, have consistently either raised the price or -- what amounts to the same thing -- reduced the quality of those beverages for the consumer.
elegant: Barley has never been monopoly-priced, so malt and beer taxes have never depressed barley land rents. Instead, malt prices have risen proportionally with taxes, and those taxes have either raised consumer prices or reduced beverage quality. The burden falls on consumers, not producers.
summary: Unlike monopoly-priced goods, barley is competitively priced, so all malt and beer taxes are passed through to consumers via higher prices or lower quality. Barley land rents have never been affected.
distilled: Because barley is competitively priced, all malt and beer taxes are passed to consumers, leaving barley land rents unaffected.
notes: Barley as competitive-price good vs. monopoly-price good -- full tax pass-through to consumers -- price increase or quality reduction as tax effects -- contrast with sugar/vineyard examples

refashioned:
The final payment of these taxes has always fallen on the consumer, not the producer.

The only people likely to suffer from the proposed reform are those who brew for their own private use. But the exemption that this privileged class currently enjoys from very heavy taxes paid by poor laborers and artisans is surely most unjust and unequal, and ought to be removed even if no other reform were undertaken. It has probably been the self-interest of this privileged class that has so far prevented a reform that could hardly fail to both increase revenue and relieve the general population.
elegant: Consumers have always borne these taxes, not producers. The only losers from reform would be wealthy private brewers, whose current exemption from duties paid by poor laborers is deeply unjust. Their self-interest has likely blocked a reform that would both increase revenue and relieve the public.
summary: The malt tax reform would only disadvantage wealthy private brewers whose current exemption from duties paid by ordinary workers is unjust. Their political influence has likely blocked a reform that would simultaneously increase government revenue and reduce the tax burden on the poor.
distilled: Wealthy private brewers' unjust tax exemption and political influence have blocked a reform that would benefit both revenue and the poor.
notes: Tax equity argument -- private brewing exemption as class privilege -- political economy of reform blockage -- self-interest preventing beneficial change -- revenue increase and popular relief as dual benefits

refashioned: Beyond customs and excise duties, there are several other taxes that affect goods prices more unevenly and indirectly. Among these are duties known in French as peages and in old Saxon times as passage duties, originally established for the same purpose as turnpike tolls or canal tolls -- to maintain roads or waterways. When applied to their intended purpose, these are most properly levied according to the bulk or weight of goods. Being originally local and provincial duties for local purposes, their administration was usually entrusted to the particular town, parish, or lordship where they were collected, which was in some way accountable for the funds. The sovereign, who is entirely unaccountable, has in many countries taken over the administration of these duties. Though he has usually raised the rates substantially, he has in many cases entirely neglected the maintenance they were meant to fund. If Britain's turnpike tolls ever became a general government revenue source, the experience of other nations shows what would likely follow. Such tolls are ultimately paid by the consumer, but the consumer is not taxed in proportion to spending when charges are based on bulk or weight rather than value. When passage duties are imposed not according to bulk or weight but according to estimated value, they become effectively a type of internal customs or excise, which severely obstructs the most important branch of commerce -- the country's internal trade.
elegant: Passage duties, originally local tolls for road and waterway maintenance levied by bulk or weight, have in many countries been seized by the sovereign, who raises rates while neglecting the infrastructure. Such duties tax consumers but not proportionally to spending. When levied by value instead of weight, they become internal customs that severely obstruct domestic commerce -- the most important branch of trade.
summary: Passage duties were originally local tolls for infrastructure maintenance, but sovereigns have taken them over, raising rates while neglecting upkeep. When levied by value rather than weight, they function as internal customs that obstruct the vital interior commerce of a country.
distilled: Passage duties, when seized by sovereigns and levied by value, become internal customs that obstruct domestic commerce.
notes: Passage duties (peages) -- turnpike tolls -- local vs. sovereign administration -- infrastructure maintenance neglect -- internal trade obstruction -- weight-based vs. value-based tolls -- interior commerce as most important trade

refashioned: In some small states, duties similar to passage duties are imposed on goods passing through the territory between two foreign countries by land or water. These are called transit duties. Some of the small Italian states along the Po and its tributaries derive revenue from such duties, which are paid entirely by foreigners and are perhaps the only duties one state can impose on another's subjects without obstructing its own industry or commerce. The most important transit duty in the world is that levied by the King of Denmark on all merchant ships passing through the Sound.
elegant: Transit duties on goods passing through a territory between foreign countries are paid entirely by foreigners -- perhaps the only tax one state can impose on another's subjects without harming its own commerce. The most significant example is Denmark's Sound Toll on all passing merchant ships.
summary: Transit duties, levied on goods passing through a state's territory between foreign countries, are unique in being borne entirely by foreigners without obstructing the levying state's own commerce. Denmark's Sound Toll is the world's most important example.
distilled: Transit duties are unique taxes borne entirely by foreigners without harming the levying state's own commerce.
notes: Transit duties -- Italian states on the Po -- Denmark's Sound Toll -- taxation of foreign subjects -- non-distortionary international taxation -- small state revenue strategy

refashioned: Taxes on luxuries, such as most customs and excise duties, fall indiscriminately on every type of income and are paid without reimbursement by whoever consumes the taxed goods. Yet they do not always fall equally or proportionally on every individual's income. Since each person's spending reflects personal temperament, everyone contributes according to their habits rather than their income. The extravagant contribute more than their fair share, the frugal less. During a wealthy person's minority, they contribute very little through consumption to the state that protects their large income. Those who live abroad contribute nothing through consumption to the government of the country where their income originates.
elegant: Luxury taxes fall on all income types and are paid by consumers, but not proportionally to income. People contribute according to temperament -- the extravagant overpay, the frugal underpay. Minors with large fortunes contribute little, and absentees living abroad contribute nothing to the country providing their income.
summary: Luxury taxes are paid by consumers regardless of income source but are not proportional to income -- they reflect individual spending habits. This creates inequities: the frugal underpay, minors with inherited wealth barely contribute, and absentee landowners contribute nothing to the source country of their income.
distilled: Luxury taxes reflect spending habits rather than income, creating inequities for the frugal, wealthy minors, and absentees.
notes: Consumption tax proportionality problems -- spending habits vs. income -- absentee landowner tax avoidance -- minor's exemption from consumption taxes -- voluntary nature of consumption taxation

refashioned: If the country where income originates has no land tax and no significant property transfer duties -- as is the case in Ireland -- such absentees may derive a large revenue from governmental protection without contributing a single shilling to its support. This inequality is greatest when a country's government is subordinate to and dependent on another. People with the most extensive property in the dependent country will generally choose to live in the governing country. Ireland is precisely in this situation, which explains why a tax on absentees is so popular there. It might, however, be somewhat difficult to define exactly what kind or degree of absence should trigger liability, or precisely when such a tax should begin or end.
elegant: Where no land tax or property transfer duties exist -- as in Ireland -- absentees enjoy governmental protection while contributing nothing. This problem is worst when the country is politically subordinate, since wealthy property owners prefer living in the governing country. A tax on absentees is popular in Ireland, though defining its precise terms would be challenging.
summary: In countries without land taxes, particularly those subordinate to another power like Ireland, wealthy absentees extract income while contributing nothing to the government that protects their property. An absentee tax is popular but practically difficult to define.
distilled: Wealthy absentees in dependent countries like Ireland benefit from governmental protection while contributing nothing to its support.
notes: Absentee landowner problem -- Ireland's subordinate political status -- absentee tax proposal -- definitional challenges of absentee taxation -- absence of land tax in Ireland -- colonial governance and tax equity

refashioned: Setting aside this very particular situation, any inequality arising from luxury taxes is more than compensated by the very circumstance that causes it: namely, that each person's contribution is entirely voluntary. Everyone has the power to consume or not consume the taxed commodity. When such taxes are properly designed and applied to appropriate goods, they are paid with less complaint than any other tax. When collected through the merchant or manufacturer, the consumer who ultimately pays them soon confuses them with the price of the goods and practically forgets that any tax is being paid at all.
elegant: The inequality of luxury taxes is offset by their voluntary nature -- no one is forced to buy taxed goods. Properly designed and applied, they provoke less complaint than any other tax. When collected through merchants, consumers confuse the tax with the price and barely notice they are paying it.
summary: Luxury taxes compensate for their inherent inequality through voluntary participation -- consumers choose whether to buy. When well-designed and collected through intermediaries, they are the least resented of all taxes because consumers forget they are paying them.
distilled: The voluntary nature of luxury taxes makes them the least resented, especially when embedded invisibly in prices.
notes: Voluntary contribution principle -- consumer perception of embedded taxes -- price confusion as political advantage -- proper commodity selection for consumption taxes -- Smith's convenience maxim

refashioned: Such taxes are, or can be made, perfectly certain. They can be designed so that there is no doubt about what should be paid or when it should be paid -- neither the amount nor the timing of payment. Whatever uncertainty sometimes exists in customs duties in Britain or similar taxes elsewhere arises not from the nature of such duties themselves, but from the careless or unskillful way the laws imposing them are drafted.
elegant: Consumption taxes can be made perfectly certain in both amount and timing. Any uncertainty in customs duties arises not from the nature of the tax but from poorly drafted legislation.
summary: Consumption taxes can achieve perfect certainty regarding both payment amounts and timing. Existing uncertainties in customs duties reflect poor legislation, not any inherent flaw in this type of taxation.
distilled: Consumption taxes can be perfectly certain; any customs uncertainty reflects bad legislation, not the tax's nature.
notes: Smith's certainty maxim of taxation -- legislative drafting quality -- inherent certainty of consumption taxes -- customs uncertainty as administrative failure

refashioned: Taxes on luxuries are generally paid, and can always be paid, in small installments as contributors buy the taxed goods. In their timing and mode of payment, they are, or can be, the most convenient of all taxes. On the whole, luxury taxes are perhaps as consistent with the first three of the four general maxims of taxation as any other form of tax. They offend, however, against the fourth maxim in every respect.
elegant: Luxury taxes are paid piecemeal as goods are purchased, making them the most convenient of all taxes. They satisfy the first three maxims of taxation well but violate the fourth -- economy of collection -- in every respect.
summary: Luxury taxes score well on three of Smith's four tax maxims -- equality, certainty, and convenience -- since they are paid in small, predictable installments at the point of purchase. They fail, however, on the fourth maxim: economy of collection.
distilled: Luxury taxes satisfy the first three tax maxims but violate the fourth maxim of economy of collection.
notes: Smith's four maxims of taxation -- equality, certainty, convenience, economy -- consumption taxes scoring well on three of four -- economy of collection as weakness -- piecemeal payment advantage

refashioned:
Such taxes, relative to what they bring into the public treasury, always extract from the public more than almost any other tax. They do this in all four possible ways.

First, levying these taxes, even when done most judiciously, requires a large number of customs and excise officers whose salaries and perquisites are themselves a real tax on the public that brings nothing into the treasury. This expense, it must be acknowledged, is more moderate in Britain than in most countries. In the year ending July 5, 1775, the gross product of excise duties managed by the excise commissioners in England was 5,507,308 pounds, collected at a cost of little more than five and a half percent. After deducting bounties and drawbacks on exported excisable goods, however, the net product falls below five million pounds. The net excise revenue after all deductions was 4,975,652 pounds. The customs are far more expensive to collect. Net customs revenue does not reach two and a half million pounds, yet the salaries of officers and other costs exceed ten percent of that amount. But customs officers' perquisites are everywhere much greater than their salaries -- at some ports more than double or triple. If salary costs alone exceed ten percent of net revenue, total collection costs including perquisites may reach twenty or thirty percent. Excise officers, by contrast, receive few or no perquisites, and the excise administration, being of more recent establishment, is generally less corrupted than customs, where long practice has introduced and sanctioned many abuses. By consolidating all malt and malt liquor revenue into a single malt tax, an estimated saving of more than 50,000 pounds per year could be achieved in excise expenses alone. Confining customs duties to a few goods and collecting them under excise-style rules could yield an even larger saving in customs expenses.
elegant: Consumption taxes extract far more from the public than they deliver to the treasury, through four channels. First, collection requires vast numbers of officers whose costs are themselves a tax yielding no revenue. In 1775, excise collection cost about five and a half percent, but customs cost over ten percent in salaries alone -- and with perquisites, possibly twenty to thirty percent. Customs administration is far more corrupt than the newer excise system. Consolidating malt taxes could save over 50,000 pounds annually, and applying excise methods to customs could save even more.
summary: Consumption taxes are costly to collect. Excise collection costs about five and a half percent of gross revenue, while customs collection may cost twenty to thirty percent when perquisites are included. Consolidating malt taxes and applying excise-style administration to customs could yield major savings.
distilled: Customs collection costs far exceed excise costs, and administrative reform could save significantly through consolidation and excise-style methods.
notes: Fourth maxim violation: economy of collection -- excise vs. customs collection costs -- officer perquisites as hidden costs -- 1775 revenue and cost data -- 50,000-pound savings estimate from malt tax consolidation -- customs corruption from long establishment

refashioned: Second, such taxes necessarily obstruct and discourage certain branches of industry. By raising the price of taxed goods, they reduce consumption and consequently production. If the taxed goods are domestically produced, less labor is employed in making them. If they are foreign goods made more expensive by the tax, domestic alternatives may gain an advantage in the home market, redirecting some industry toward producing them. But while this price increase may encourage one particular domestic industry, it necessarily discourages almost every other. The more a Birmingham manufacturer pays for foreign wine, the less his hardware is worth in exchange -- so he has less incentive to produce it. The more consumers in one country pay for another country's surplus, the less their own surplus is worth, and the less incentive they have to increase it. All taxes on consumable goods therefore tend to reduce productive labor below its natural level -- either in producing the taxed goods (if domestic) or in producing the goods exchanged for them (if foreign). Such taxes also always distort the natural direction of national industry, diverting it into channels that are different from, and generally less advantageous than, those it would naturally follow.
elegant: Consumption taxes discourage industry in two ways. They reduce consumption and production of taxed goods directly. They also distort trade: when foreign goods become more expensive, domestic alternatives gain an artificial advantage in one sector while every other sector loses competitiveness. The higher cost of imports reduces the value of exports exchanged for them. All consumption taxes thus reduce productive labor and divert industry from its natural, most advantageous channels.
summary: Consumption taxes harm industry by reducing demand for taxed goods and distorting trade patterns. While they may benefit one domestic sector competing with taxed imports, they disadvantage all other sectors by reducing the exchange value of their output. The net effect is reduced productive labor and misdirected national industry.
distilled: Consumption taxes reduce productive labor and distort industry away from its naturally most advantageous channels.
notes: Second cost of consumption taxes -- industry distortion -- Birmingham hardware/wine trade-off example -- consumption tax and productive labor -- natural direction of industry -- general equilibrium effects of tariffs

refashioned: Third, the hope of evading these taxes through smuggling frequently leads to forfeitures and penalties that entirely ruin the smuggler -- a person who, though clearly guilty of violating his country's laws, is often incapable of violating natural justice, and who would have been an excellent citizen in every respect had the law not made criminal what nature never intended to be. In corrupt governments where public revenue is widely suspected of being wasted and misapplied, revenue laws are little respected. Few people scruple about smuggling when they can do it easily and safely without perjury. Claiming to have scruples about buying smuggled goods, though it obviously encourages revenue law violations and the perjury that accompanies them, would in most countries be regarded as a piece of pedantic hypocrisy that, far from earning respect, only raises suspicion of being a greater rogue than one's neighbors. Encouraged by public tolerance, the smuggler comes to consider his trade partly innocent. When the law's severity threatens to fall on him, he often defends with violence what he has come to regard as his rightful property. Starting as merely imprudent rather than criminal, he too often becomes one of the most hardened and determined violators of social law. When the smuggler is ruined, his capital -- previously maintaining productive labor -- is absorbed by either the state revenue or the revenue officer, employed in maintaining unproductive workers, thereby diminishing the general capital of society and the useful industry it might otherwise have supported.
elegant: Smuggling, provoked by high consumption taxes, ruins people who would otherwise be excellent citizens. In corrupt governments, smuggling is socially tolerated and the smuggler considers himself partly innocent. When the law threatens, he turns to violence. Starting as imprudent, he becomes a hardened criminal. His ruin destroys productive capital, which is absorbed by the state or its officers and redirected to unproductive uses -- diminishing society's useful industry.
summary: High consumption taxes create smugglers out of otherwise law-abiding citizens. Social tolerance of smuggling in corrupt governments encourages escalation from minor evasion to violent criminality. When smugglers are ruined, their productive capital is destroyed and redirected to unproductive state or enforcement uses.
distilled: Excessive consumption taxes transform citizens into smugglers and criminals, destroying productive capital in the process.
notes: Third cost of consumption taxes -- smuggler as sympathetic figure -- natural justice vs. positive law -- social tolerance of smuggling -- escalation from evasion to violence -- productive vs. unproductive capital destruction -- moral corruption by bad laws

refashioned: Fourth, such taxes subject at least the dealers in taxed goods to frequent visits and intrusive examinations by tax collectors, exposing them sometimes to genuine oppression and always to considerable trouble and annoyance. Though vexation is not strictly an expense, it is certainly equivalent to whatever amount a person would pay to be free of it. Excise laws, though more effective for their intended purpose, are more vexatious in this respect than customs laws. Once a merchant has imported goods, paid the customs duties, and stored them in his warehouse, he is generally free from further customs harassment. This is not the case with excisable goods: dealers face continuous visits and examinations from excise officers. Excise duties are therefore more unpopular than customs duties, and so are the excise officers who collect them.
