These officers, it is claimed, though they generally perform their duties as well as customs officers, inevitably develop a certain hardness of character because their work requires them to be frequently troublesome to their neighbors. This observation, however, may simply be the complaint of fraudulent dealers whose smuggling is either prevented or detected by excise officers' diligence.
elegant: Consumption taxes subject dealers to intrusive, vexatious inspections. Excise laws are worse than customs in this regard: customs harassment ends once goods are warehoused and duties paid, while excise officers conduct continuous inspections. This makes excise duties and their officers more unpopular, though complaints about officers' hardness may reflect fraudulent dealers' resentment of effective enforcement.
summary: The fourth cost of consumption taxes is the vexation of constant tax inspections. Excise duties impose ongoing surveillance on dealers, unlike customs duties which end at importation. While excise officers are criticized for their harshness, this may simply reflect the frustration of those whose smuggling they successfully detect.
distilled: Consumption taxes impose ongoing vexation through inspections, with excise duties being more intrusive than customs but also more effective.
notes: Fourth cost of consumption taxes -- vexation as equivalent to expense -- excise vs. customs intrusiveness -- officer character shaped by enforcement role -- fraudulent dealers' complaints as unreliable testimony

refashioned: The drawbacks of consumption taxes, though perhaps inseparable from them to some degree, fall as lightly on the British public as on any country with a government of comparable expense. Our system is not perfect and could be improved, but it is as good as, or better than, that of most of our neighbors.
elegant: Britain's consumption tax drawbacks, though unavoidable, are lighter than in most comparably governed countries. The system is imperfect but as good as or better than most neighbors'.
summary: Despite the inherent costs of consumption taxes, Britain's system imposes them more lightly than most comparable countries.
distilled: Britain's consumption tax system, while imperfect, is as good as or better than most comparable nations'.
notes: Comparative assessment of British tax system -- relative advantage over neighbors -- concession that perfection is unattainable -- balanced evaluation of consumption taxation

refashioned: Based on the mistaken belief that duties on consumable goods were taxes on merchant profits, these duties have in some countries been levied repeatedly at every successive sale. If the importing or manufacturing merchant's profits were taxed, equality seemed to require taxing the profits of every middleman between them and the consumer as well. Spain's notorious alcavala was established on this principle. Originally a ten percent tax, later raised to fourteen percent, and currently at six percent, it applies to the sale of every type of property, movable or immovable, and is repeated every time the property changes hands. Collecting this tax requires a multitude of revenue officers to monitor the transport of goods not just between provinces but between shops. It subjects not just some dealers but all -- every farmer, manufacturer, merchant, and shopkeeper -- to continual tax inspector visits. Throughout most of the country where such a tax exists, nothing can be produced for distant sale; production in each area must be limited to local consumption. It is to the alcavala that Ustaritz attributes the ruin of Spanish manufacturing. He might equally have attributed the decline of agriculture to it, since it is imposed not only on manufactures but on raw agricultural produce.
elegant: The misconception that consumption duties tax merchant profits led some countries to impose them at every sale. Spain's alcavala -- originally ten percent, now six, on every sale of any property -- is repeated at each transaction, requiring a vast enforcement apparatus. It subjects every farmer, manufacturer, and dealer to constant inspection and confines production to local markets, ruining both manufacturing and agriculture.
summary: Spain's alcavala, based on the flawed idea that consumption duties tax merchant profits, imposes a turnover tax on every sale of every type of property. This cascading tax requires massive enforcement, confines production to local markets, and is credited with ruining Spanish manufacturing and agriculture.
distilled: Spain's cascading alcavala turnover tax on every sale destroyed manufacturing and agriculture by confining production to local markets.
notes: Alcavala as cascading turnover tax -- Spain's economic decline -- Ustaritz attribution -- tax on every transaction -- enforcement burden -- destruction of long-distance trade -- manufacturing and agricultural ruin

refashioned: In the Kingdom of Naples, a similar but lighter tax of three percent is imposed on the value of all contracts, including all sales. Being lighter than the Spanish tax, and with most towns and parishes allowed to pay a lump-sum composition instead, it is far less destructive. These communities levy the composition however they choose, generally in a way that does not interrupt local commerce. The Neapolitan tax is therefore far less ruinous than the Spanish one.
elegant: Naples imposes a similar three-percent contract tax, but allows most towns to pay a lump-sum composition instead, levied without disrupting local commerce. This makes it far less destructive than Spain's alcavala.
summary: Naples has a three-percent transaction tax similar to Spain's alcavala but much less harmful because most communities can pay a composition in lieu, collected without disrupting internal trade.
distilled: Naples mitigates its transaction tax through local composition payments that avoid disrupting commerce, unlike Spain's destructive alcavala.
notes: Neapolitan contract tax -- composition payment as alternative -- comparison with Spanish alcavala -- local administration reducing economic disruption -- lighter rate (3% vs. 6-14%)

refashioned: The uniform tax system that, with a few minor exceptions, applies throughout the United Kingdom of Great Britain leaves domestic commerce -- both inland and coastal trade -- almost entirely free. Inland trade is nearly perfectly free: most goods can be carried from one end of the kingdom to the other without any permit, pass, or inspection by revenue officers. The few exceptions are too minor to interrupt any important branch of domestic trade. Coastal goods do require certificates or coast-cockets, but apart from coal, nearly all are duty-free. This freedom of internal commerce, the result of tax system uniformity, is perhaps one of the principal causes of Britain's prosperity, since every great country is necessarily the best and largest market for most of its own products. If the same freedom, achieved through the same uniformity, could be extended to Ireland and the colonies, both the greatness of the state and the prosperity of every part of the empire would probably increase further still.
elegant: Britain's uniform tax system leaves internal trade almost perfectly free -- goods move end to end without permits or inspections, with few exceptions. This freedom of interior commerce, born of tax uniformity, is perhaps a principal cause of British prosperity. Extending the same uniformity to Ireland and the colonies would likely enhance both imperial power and universal prosperity.
summary: Britain's uniform tax system enables nearly unrestricted internal trade, which is a major source of national prosperity. Extending this tax uniformity to Ireland and the colonies could further enhance the prosperity of the entire empire.
distilled: Britain's uniform tax system enables free internal trade, a principal cause of its prosperity that could benefit the whole empire if extended.
notes: Tax uniformity and free internal trade -- British prosperity from domestic commerce -- coast-cockets for coastal trade -- proposal to extend uniformity to Ireland and colonies -- interior commerce as most important trade branch

refashioned: In France, the different revenue laws in different provinces require a multitude of revenue officers to patrol not only the kingdom's external borders but the boundaries of nearly every individual province, either to prevent certain imports or to levy duties on them. This severely disrupts the country's internal commerce. Some provinces are allowed to pay a lump sum in lieu of the gabelle, or salt tax, while others are exempt from it entirely. Some provinces are exempt from the exclusive tobacco sale enjoyed by the tax farmers throughout most of the kingdom.
elegant: France's patchwork of provincial revenue laws requires armies of officers guarding not just national borders but internal provincial boundaries, severely disrupting domestic commerce. Provinces differ in their liability for the gabelle and tobacco monopoly, creating a fragmented fiscal landscape.
summary: France's different tax laws across provinces require extensive internal border enforcement, severely obstructing domestic commerce. Provincial variations in salt tax liability and tobacco monopoly exemptions create a fragmented and inefficient fiscal system.
distilled: France's fragmented provincial tax system requires internal border enforcement that severely obstructs domestic commerce.
notes: French provincial tax fragmentation -- gabelle (salt tax) -- tobacco farm -- internal customs barriers -- contrast with British tax uniformity -- revenue officer proliferation

refashioned: The aides, which correspond to English excise duties, vary greatly among French provinces. Some provinces are exempt and pay a composition instead. Where aides are in force and farmed out, many local duties exist that apply only within a particular town or district. The traites, corresponding to English customs, divide the kingdom into three great regions. First are the provinces subject to the tariff of 1664, called the provinces of the five great farms, including Picardy, Normandy, and most interior provinces. Second are the provinces subject to the tariff of 1667, called the provinces reckoned foreign, comprising most frontier provinces. Third are those treated as foreign -- Alsace, the three bishoprics of Metz, Toul, and Verdun, and the three cities of Dunkirk, Bayonne, and Marseilles -- which enjoy free trade with foreign countries but face the same duties as foreign nations in their trade with the rest of France. Both in the provinces of the five great farms (named for an ancient division of customs into five branches, each originally a separate tax farm though now united) and in those reckoned foreign, there are many local duties that extend no further than a particular town or district.
elegant: French aides (excise) and traites (customs) vary enormously by province. The traites divide France into three zones: the five great farms (interior provinces, 1664 tariff), provinces reckoned foreign (frontier, 1667 tariff), and provinces treated as foreign (Alsace, certain bishoprics and cities), which trade freely abroad but face customs within France. Within each zone, numerous local duties add further fragmentation.
summary: France's excise and customs systems are fragmented across three tariff zones and countless local duties. Some provinces trade freely with foreign nations but face customs when trading with the rest of France, creating a deeply complex and internally obstructive fiscal landscape.
distilled: France's three-zone tariff system, combined with countless local duties, creates an internally fragmented and commerce-obstructing fiscal landscape.
notes: French tariff zones -- five great farms -- provinces reckoned foreign -- provinces treated as foreign -- Alsace, Dunkirk, Bayonne, Marseilles -- aides and traites -- 1664 and 1667 tariffs -- local duty proliferation

refashioned: Such local duties exist even in provinces treated as foreign, particularly in the city of Marseilles. It hardly needs stating how greatly both the restrictions on internal commerce and the number of revenue officers must multiply in order to guard the borders of all these different provinces and districts, each subject to its own system of taxation.
elegant: Even provinces treated as foreign, like Marseilles, have their own local duties. The resulting need to guard the borders of every province and district with its own tax system multiplies both trade restrictions and revenue officers enormously.
summary: The proliferation of distinct tax jurisdictions down to the city level in France, even in nominally free-trading provinces, requires massive enforcement and severely restricts internal commerce.
distilled: France's tax system extends internal border enforcement down to the city level, multiplying trade barriers and revenue officers.
notes: Marseilles' local duties -- tax jurisdiction proliferation -- enforcement multiplication -- internal commerce restrictions -- administrative burden of fragmented taxation

refashioned: Beyond the general restrictions from this complicated revenue system, the wine trade -- perhaps the most important French product after grain -- is in most provinces subject to additional restrictions arising from favoritism shown to certain vineyards and districts over others. The provinces most famous for their wines are, I believe, those where the wine trade faces the fewest such restrictions. The extensive market these provinces enjoy encourages good management both in cultivating their vineyards and in preparing their wines.
elegant: France's wine trade, arguably its second most important product, faces additional provincial restrictions favoring certain vineyards over others. The most renowned wine provinces are typically those with the fewest trade restrictions, since open markets encourage better vineyard management and winemaking.
summary: The French wine trade suffers from provincial favoritism that restricts competition. Provinces with the fewest trade restrictions tend to produce the most famous wines, because open markets incentivize better cultivation and production.
distilled: French provinces with the fewest wine trade restrictions produce the most famous wines, because open markets encourage quality.
notes: Wine trade restrictions in France -- favoritism toward specific vineyards -- market access and quality incentives -- wine as France's second product after grain -- free trade encouraging good management

refashioned: Such complicated and varied revenue laws are not unique to France. The small Duchy of Milan is divided into six provinces, each with a different tax system for several types of consumable goods. The even smaller territories of the Duke of Parma are divided into three or four districts, each with its own system. Under such absurd management, only the great fertility of the soil and the favorable climate could prevent these countries from sinking into the deepest poverty and barbarism.
elegant: Tax fragmentation is not uniquely French: the small Duchy of Milan has six different provincial tax systems, and Parma has three or four. Only natural fertility and climate prevent such absurdly governed territories from collapsing into poverty.
summary: Even small Italian states like Milan and Parma maintain multiple incompatible tax systems within their tiny territories. Only favorable natural conditions prevent this absurd fiscal fragmentation from causing economic ruin.
distilled: Even tiny Italian states fragment their tax systems into multiple incompatible jurisdictions, prevented from ruin only by natural advantages.
notes: Milan's six provincial tax systems -- Parma's fragmented taxation -- absurdity of small-state tax complexity -- natural endowments compensating for poor policy -- comparative fiscal administration

refashioned: Taxes on consumable goods may be collected in two ways: either by a government administration with appointed officers directly accountable to the state, in which case revenue varies year to year with the tax's actual yield; or the taxes may be farmed out for a fixed rent, with the farmer appointing his own officers who, though bound to collect according to law, are under his supervision and accountable to him. The best and most economical method of collecting a tax is never through farming it out. Beyond what is needed to pay the agreed rent, officer salaries, and all administrative expenses, the farmer must always extract from the tax's proceeds a profit proportional to his capital advance, the risk he bears, the trouble he undertakes, and the knowledge and skill required to manage such a complex enterprise. The government, by establishing its own administration of the same kind, could at least save this profit, which is almost always exorbitant. Farming out any significant branch of public revenue requires either great capital or great credit, restricting competition to very few people. Of those few with sufficient capital or credit, even fewer have the necessary expertise, further limiting competition. The very small number who qualify find it more profitable to combine as partners rather than compete, and when the farm is auctioned, to offer far below its real value. In countries where public revenues are farmed, the tax farmers are generally the wealthiest people. Their wealth alone would excite public outrage, and the vain, foolish ostentation with which they typically display it inflames that outrage further.
elegant: Taxes are best collected by government administration, never by tax farming. Tax farmers must extract profit beyond all expenses -- profit that is almost always exorbitant. The high capital requirements restrict competition to a tiny pool who combine rather than compete, bidding far below true value at auction. In countries with tax farming, the farmers become the wealthiest citizens, exciting public outrage through their ostentatious display of ill-gotten wealth.
summary: Tax farming is always more expensive than direct government collection because farmers must earn exorbitant profits. High barriers to entry create a small cartel that colludes to underbid at auction. Tax farmers become the wealthiest and most resented class wherever the system exists.
distilled: Tax farming is inefficient because high entry barriers create colluding cartels that extract exorbitant profits at public expense.
notes: Tax farming vs. direct administration -- farmer's exorbitant profit -- barriers to entry (capital, credit, expertise) -- cartel formation at auction -- public resentment of tax farmers -- collection cost efficiency

refashioned: Tax farmers never consider the laws too severe that punish attempts to evade taxes. They have no sympathy for the contributors, who are not their subjects, and whose total bankruptcy the day after the farm expires would barely affect their interests. In the state's greatest emergencies, when the sovereign's anxiety about revenue collection is most intense, tax farmers rarely fail to complain that without even more severe laws than currently exist, they cannot pay even the standard rent. In these moments of public distress, their demands cannot be refused. Revenue laws therefore become progressively more severe. The harshest laws are always found in countries where most public revenue is farmed out; the mildest, where it is collected under direct government oversight. Even a bad sovereign feels more compassion for his people than can ever be expected from tax farmers. He knows that his family's enduring greatness depends on his people's prosperity and will never knowingly destroy it for short-term gain. Tax farmers are different: their wealth may be the result of the people's ruin, not their prosperity.
elegant: Tax farmers lack compassion for taxpayers and constantly demand harsher laws. In emergencies, their demands for severity cannot be refused, making revenue laws progressively more punitive. The cruelest laws exist where tax farming prevails; the mildest where government collects directly. Even a bad sovereign, knowing his dynasty depends on popular prosperity, shows more restraint than farmers whose wealth often comes from the people's ruin.
summary: Tax farmers demand increasingly severe enforcement because they have no stake in the population's long-term welfare. Unlike even bad sovereigns, whose dynastic interests align with public prosperity, tax farmers may profit from the people's ruin. Countries with tax farming therefore develop the harshest revenue laws.
distilled: Tax farmers demand harsh laws because, unlike sovereigns, their wealth may come from the people's ruin rather than their prosperity.
notes: Tax farmer incentives vs. sovereign incentives -- progressive severity of revenue laws -- farmers' indifference to taxpayer welfare -- dynastic interest in public prosperity -- political economy of enforcement escalation

refashioned: Sometimes a tax is not only farmed out for a fixed rent but the farmer also receives a monopoly on the taxed commodity. In France, the duties on tobacco and salt are collected this way. The farmer thus levies two exorbitant profits from the public: the tax farmer's profit and the monopolist's profit, which is even more exorbitant. Since tobacco is a luxury, individuals may choose whether to buy it. But salt is a necessity, and everyone is required to buy a certain quantity from the farmer -- the presumption being that otherwise they would buy from smugglers. The taxes on both commodities are exorbitant, making the temptation to smuggle irresistible for many, while the law's severity and the farmer's vigilance make yielding to that temptation almost certainly ruinous. Salt and tobacco smuggling sends several hundred people to the galleys each year, and a considerable number to the gallows. Yet these taxes yield substantial revenue: in 1767, the tobacco farm was let for over twenty-two and a half million livres per year, and the salt farm for over thirty-six and a half million livres, both commencing in 1768 for six-year terms. Those who consider the people's blood as nothing compared to the prince's revenue may perhaps approve of this method. Similar tax-and-monopoly systems for salt and tobacco have been established in many other countries, particularly in the Austrian and Prussian dominions and most Italian states.
elegant: When tax farming combines with monopoly, as with French salt and tobacco, the farmer extracts two exorbitant profits. Tobacco buyers can abstain, but salt is a necessity everyone must buy from the farmer. Exorbitant taxes make smuggling irresistible yet the consequences are ruinous -- hundreds are sent to galleys or the gallows annually. The system yields enormous revenue (59 million livres combined in 1767), but only for those who value the prince's revenue above the people's blood. Similar systems exist across Austria, Prussia, and Italy.
summary: France's combined tax farming and monopoly on salt and tobacco extracts double profits while driving hundreds of people to the galleys or gallows annually for smuggling. The system yields vast revenue but at tremendous human cost, and has been replicated across European states.
distilled: France's combined tax farming and monopoly on salt and tobacco yields vast revenue but sends hundreds to galleys and gallows for smuggling.
notes: Tax farming plus monopoly -- French gabelle and tobacco farm -- forced salt purchases -- smuggling penalties (galleys, gallows) -- 1767 farm values (22.5M and 36.5M livres) -- Austrian, Prussian, Italian parallels -- human cost of revenue extraction

refashioned: In France, the crown's actual revenue comes chiefly from eight sources: the taille, the capitation, the two vingtiemes, the gabelles, the aides, the traites, the domaine, and the tobacco farm. The last five are mostly farmed out in most provinces. The first three are collected everywhere by a direct government administration under immediate sovereign oversight. It is universally acknowledged that the three directly administered taxes, in proportion to what they take from the people, deliver more to the treasury than the five farmed taxes, whose administration is far more wasteful and expensive.
elegant: France's eight main revenue sources include three collected by direct government administration (taille, capitation, vingtiemes) and five mostly farmed out (gabelles, aides, traites, domaine, tobacco). The directly administered taxes universally deliver more revenue per unit extracted from the public, confirming that tax farming is wasteful and expensive.
summary: Of France's eight main revenue sources, the three collected by direct government administration are universally acknowledged to deliver more revenue to the treasury relative to what they extract from the public than the five that are farmed out.
distilled: France's directly administered taxes deliver more revenue per unit extracted than its five farmed-out taxes.
notes: Eight French revenue sources -- taille, capitation, vingtiemes as direct taxes -- gabelles, aides, traites, domaine, tobacco farm as farmed taxes -- direct administration efficiency vs. tax farming waste

refashioned: French finances seem to admit three obvious reforms. First, by abolishing the taille and capitation and increasing the vingtiemes to produce equivalent revenue, total revenue could be maintained while greatly reducing collection costs and eliminating the vexation these taxes inflict on the lower classes. The upper classes would be no more burdened than at present, since the vingtieme is essentially the same as England's land tax, and the burden of the taille and much of the capitation ultimately falls on landowners anyway. However, since any reform would benefit some individuals and disadvantage others due to the taille's unequal assessment, those currently favored would oppose the change. Second, by making the gabelle, aides, traites, tobacco taxes, and all customs and excises uniform throughout the kingdom, collection costs could be greatly reduced and internal commerce freed to match England's. Third, by bringing all farmed taxes under direct government administration, the exorbitant profits of the farmers-general could be added to state revenue. Private interests are as likely to block the second and third reforms as the first.
elegant: France needs three reforms: replace the taille and capitation with increased vingtiemes (maintaining revenue, reducing costs and lower-class vexation); unify all excise, customs, and monopoly taxes across provinces (freeing internal commerce); and replace tax farming with direct administration (capturing farmers-general's exorbitant profits). Each reform is blocked by private interests that benefit from the current system.
summary: Smith proposes three reforms for France: consolidate direct taxes into the vingtieme, unify indirect taxes across provinces to free internal commerce, and replace tax farming with government administration. All three are blocked by vested interests benefiting from the status quo.
distilled: Three French fiscal reforms -- tax consolidation, provincial uniformity, and ending tax farming -- are all blocked by private interests.
notes: Three proposed French fiscal reforms -- taille and capitation replacement -- vingtieme as French land tax equivalent -- provincial tax uniformity -- abolition of tax farming -- farmers-general profits -- political economy of reform blockage by vested interests

refashioned: France's tax system appears inferior to Britain's in every respect. In Britain, ten million pounds sterling are raised annually from fewer than eight million people without any particular class being oppressed. According to the Abbe Expilly and other analysts, France, including Lorraine and Bar, contains about twenty-three or twenty-four million people -- roughly three times Britain's population. France has better soil and climate, has been cultivated longer, and is better stocked with accumulated capital such as great cities and well-built houses. With these advantages, one might expect France to raise thirty million pounds as easily as Britain raises ten. Yet in 1765 and 1766, total French treasury receipts typically ran between 308 and 325 million livres -- under fifteen million pounds sterling, not even half the expected amount given relative population. The French people are generally acknowledged to be more oppressed by taxes than the British, despite this lower yield. France is, however, after Britain, the great European empire with the mildest and most lenient government.
elegant: Britain raises ten million pounds from eight million people without oppressing any class. France, with three times the population, better soil, longer cultivation, and more accumulated wealth, should raise thirty million -- yet collects under fifteen million while oppressing its people far more. France's tax system is inferior in every respect, though its government is the second mildest in Europe after Britain's.
summary: Despite having three times Britain's population and superior natural advantages, France raises less than half the proportional revenue while imposing far greater tax oppression. This demonstrates the comprehensive inferiority of the French tax system, even though France otherwise has Europe's second mildest government.
distilled: France raises less than half Britain's proportional tax revenue while imposing far greater oppression, proving its fiscal system's comprehensive inferiority.
notes: British vs. French fiscal comparison -- population estimates (8M vs. 23-24M) -- revenue yield (10M vs. under 15M sterling) -- tax oppression inversely proportional to revenue -- Abbe Expilly population data -- soil and climate advantages -- 1765-1766 French treasury figures

refashioned: In Holland, heavy taxes on necessities have reportedly ruined its principal manufactures and are gradually threatening even its fisheries and shipbuilding trade. In Britain, taxes on necessities are modest, and no manufacture has yet been ruined by them. The British taxes most harmful to manufacturing are certain import duties on raw materials, particularly raw silk. The revenue of the States-General and the various Dutch cities reportedly exceeds five and a quarter million pounds sterling. Since the United Provinces' population is probably no more than a third of Britain's, the Dutch must be taxed far more heavily in proportion to their numbers.
elegant: Holland's heavy taxes on necessities have ruined its manufactures and threaten its fisheries and shipbuilding. Britain's modest necessity taxes have ruined no industry -- only raw material import duties, especially on silk, harm manufacturing. The Dutch, with roughly a third of Britain's population, raise over five and a quarter million pounds -- a far heavier proportional burden.
summary: Holland's heavy necessity taxes have destroyed its manufacturing and threaten other industries, while Britain's modest approach has preserved its industries. The Dutch bear a far heavier proportional tax burden than the British despite having only a third of the population.
distilled: Holland's heavy necessity taxes have ruined its manufactures, while Britain's lighter approach has preserved its industries.
notes: Dutch tax burden and industrial decline -- necessity taxes vs. luxury taxes -- raw silk import duties in Britain -- States-General revenue (5.25M pounds) -- proportional tax comparison -- fisheries and shipbuilding threatened

refashioned: Once all proper subjects of taxation have been exhausted, if the state still needs additional revenue, taxes must be imposed on improper subjects. Holland's taxes on necessities may therefore not impugn that republic's wisdom, since maintaining its independence required fighting expensive wars that forced heavy borrowing, despite great frugality. The unique geography of Holland and Zealand also demands considerable expense simply to prevent the sea from reclaiming the land, further adding to the tax burden. The republican form of government appears to be the principal support of Holland's current prosperity. The great mercantile families who own the largest capitals generally have either direct participation or indirect influence in the government. For the respect and authority this position brings, they are willing to live in a country where their capital earns less profit, where loans earn less interest, and where their moderate incomes buy less than anywhere else in Europe. The presence of such wealthy people inevitably sustains a degree of industry despite all disadvantages. Any catastrophe that destroyed the republican government -- throwing administration to nobles and soldiers and ending the importance of wealthy merchants -- would soon make the country intolerable for them. They would relocate both themselves and their capital elsewhere, and Holland's industry and commerce would quickly follow the capital that supported them.
elegant: Holland's necessity taxes reflect unavoidable circumstance rather than poor judgment: independence required expensive wars, and the sea itself demands costly defense. The republican government sustains prosperity by keeping great mercantile families invested despite low returns. These families stay for political influence and respect. Any revolution replacing republican government with aristocratic or military rule would drive out these merchants, their capital, and all the industry that depends on it.
summary: Holland's heavy taxes are justified by unavoidable defense costs, and its republican government sustains prosperity by giving wealthy merchants political influence that keeps them and their capital in the country. Destroying republican governance would trigger capital flight and economic collapse.
distilled: Holland's republican government sustains prosperity by retaining wealthy merchants who would flee -- with their capital -- under any other system.
notes: Dutch necessity taxes as pragmatic choice -- geographic defense costs (sea reclamation) -- republican government and capital retention -- merchant political participation -- capital flight risk from regime change -- independence wars and debt -- link between political system and economic prosperity

refashioned: In the primitive state of society that precedes the development of commerce and manufacturing -- when the expensive luxuries that only commerce and manufacturing can provide are entirely unknown -- a person with a large revenue, as I showed in the third book of this work, can spend or enjoy that revenue only by maintaining nearly as many people as it can support. A large revenue can always be understood as command over a large quantity of life's necessities. In that primitive condition, revenue is typically paid in kind: in the raw materials of plain food and coarse clothing, in grain and cattle, in wool and raw hides.
elegant: Before commerce and manufacturing, the wealthy could only spend their revenue by maintaining dependents, since expensive luxuries did not exist. Large revenue meant command over necessities -- grain, cattle, wool, and hides -- paid in kind.
summary: In pre-commercial societies, wealth could only be spent by supporting dependents, since luxury goods did not yet exist. Revenue was paid and measured in basic necessities like grain, cattle, and raw materials.
distilled: Before commerce, the wealthy could only spend their revenue by maintaining dependents, as luxury goods did not exist.
notes: Pre-commercial society and spending patterns -- revenue as command over necessities -- payment in kind -- cross-reference Book III -- transition to Chapter 5.3 on public debt

refashioned: When neither commerce nor manufacturing offers anything for which landowners can exchange their surplus production beyond what they personally consume, they have no option but to feed and clothe nearly as many people as the surplus will support. A hospitality without luxury, and a generosity without ostentation, are the principal expenses of the rich and powerful in this situation. But as I also showed in the same book, these are expenses by which people rarely ruin themselves.
elegant: Without commerce to absorb surplus production, the wealthy can only spend it on maintaining dependents through simple hospitality and unpretentious generosity -- expenses that rarely lead to financial ruin.
summary: When no market exists for surplus production, landowners spend it on maintaining dependents through plain hospitality and generosity. These non-ostentatious forms of spending rarely cause financial ruin.
distilled: Pre-commercial surplus spending on plain hospitality and generosity rarely ruins the wealthy.
notes: Hospitality vs. luxury spending -- sustainability of non-ostentatious expenditure -- surplus without markets -- cross-reference Book III on feudal spending patterns

refashioned: There is perhaps no selfish pleasure so trivial that its pursuit has not sometimes ruined even sensible people. A passion for cockfighting has ruined many. Yet the instances of people ruined by plain hospitality or generosity are, I believe, not very numerous -- though the hospitality of luxury and the generosity of ostentation have ruined many. Among our feudal ancestors, the fact that estates remained in the same families for very long periods sufficiently demonstrates the general tendency of people to live within their incomes. Though the constant rustic hospitality of great landowners may not seem, to modern eyes, consistent with what we consider essential to good economy, we must admit they were at least frugal enough not to habitually spend their entire income. They generally had some opportunity to sell part of their wool and raw hides for money. Some of this money they probably spent on the few objects of vanity and luxury the times could provide, but they seem usually to have hoarded the rest. They could hardly do anything else with their savings. Trade was considered beneath a gentleman, and lending money at interest -- then regarded as usury and forbidden by law -- would have been even more disgraceful. Besides, in those violent and disorderly times, it was practical to keep a hoard of money on hand so that if driven from home, they would have something of known value to carry to safety.
elegant: Trivial passions can ruin people, but plain hospitality and generosity rarely do -- only their luxurious and ostentatious versions are ruinous. Feudal estates stayed in families for generations, proving landowners generally lived within their means. They sold some wool and hides for money, spent a little on available luxuries, and hoarded the rest -- trade and lending being beneath a gentleman's dignity, and violent times making portable wealth prudent.
summary: Feudal landowners lived within their means, as shown by estates remaining in families for generations. Unable to trade or lend at interest, and needing portable wealth for dangerous times, they hoarded their modest cash savings while spending their surplus production on sustainable plain hospitality.
distilled: Feudal landowners hoarded savings because trade and lending were beneath them, and violent times demanded portable wealth.
notes: Feudal frugality -- estate longevity as evidence of living within means -- hoarding vs. investment -- usury prohibition -- social stigma of trade for gentlemen -- portable wealth as insurance against violence -- cross-reference Book III

refashioned: The same violence that made hoarding practical also made it necessary to conceal the hoard. The frequency of treasure trove -- discovered treasure with no known owner -- sufficiently demonstrates how common both hoarding and concealment were in those times. Treasure trove was then considered an important branch of the sovereign's revenue. All the treasure trove in the kingdom today would scarcely constitute an important branch of revenue for a single prosperous private gentleman.
elegant: The violence that encouraged hoarding also demanded secrecy. The frequency of treasure trove -- ownerless buried wealth -- shows how common both practices were. Treasure trove was once significant royal revenue; today all such finds would barely matter to a wealthy private individual.
summary: Feudal violence drove both hoarding and concealment of wealth, as evidenced by the frequency of treasure trove discoveries, once an important revenue source for sovereigns but now insignificant.
distilled: Feudal violence drove hoarding and concealment, as shown by frequent treasure trove discoveries that were once significant royal revenue.
notes: Treasure trove as evidence of hoarding practices -- concealment driven by violence -- sovereign's right to treasure trove -- declining significance of found treasure -- feudal insecurity and wealth management

refashioned: The same tendency to save and hoard prevailed among sovereigns as among their subjects. Among nations with little commerce or manufacturing, the sovereign -- as I observed in the fourth book -- is naturally disposed toward the frugality needed for accumulation. In that situation, even a sovereign's expenses cannot be directed by the vanity that delights in a court's gaudy display, because the times offer few of the trinkets such display requires. Standing armies are not yet necessary, so a sovereign's spending, like any other great lord's, can go to little besides generosity toward tenants and hospitality toward retainers. But generosity and hospitality very rarely lead to extravagance, though vanity almost always does. Accordingly, as previously noted, all the ancient European sovereigns had treasuries. Every Tartar chief today is said to have one.
elegant: Sovereigns in pre-commercial societies were as inclined to save and hoard as their subjects. Without luxury goods to buy or standing armies to fund, royal spending went to generosity and hospitality -- which rarely cause extravagance, unlike vanity. Ancient European sovereigns and modern Tartar chiefs alike accumulated treasuries.
summary: Before commerce, sovereigns naturally saved and hoarded because their spending was limited to generosity and hospitality, which rarely lead to extravagance. This explains why all ancient European sovereigns and modern Tartar chiefs have maintained treasuries.
distilled: Pre-commercial sovereigns naturally hoarded wealth because their limited spending options -- generosity and hospitality -- rarely caused extravagance.
notes: Sovereign frugality in pre-commercial societies -- generosity vs. vanity as spending motives -- absence of standing armies -- Tartar chiefs as contemporary parallel -- cross-reference Book IV -- royal treasuries as norm

refashioned: In a commercial country full of expensive luxuries, the sovereign -- like nearly all the great proprietors in his realm -- naturally spends much of his revenue purchasing those luxuries. His own and neighboring countries supply him abundantly with the costly ornaments that constitute the splendid but meaningless pageantry of a court. For the sake of similar if lesser display, his nobles dismiss their retainers, make their tenants independent, and gradually become as insignificant as most wealthy town merchants. The same frivolous passions that govern the nobles govern the sovereign. How can we expect him to be the only rich man in his realm immune to such pleasures? If he does not -- as is very likely -- spend so much on them as to seriously weaken the state's defenses, we can hardly expect him not to spend on them everything beyond what defense requires. His ordinary spending comes to equal his ordinary revenue, and it is fortunate if it does not frequently exceed it. Accumulating a treasury becomes impossible, and when extraordinary emergencies require extraordinary expenses, he must call on his subjects for extraordinary aid. Of the great European princes, only the present and late kings of Prussia, since the death of Henry IV of France in 1610, are believed to have amassed any considerable treasure. The frugality that leads to accumulation has become almost as rare in republics as in monarchies. The Italian republics and the United Provinces of the Netherlands are all in debt. The canton of Berne is the only European republic to have accumulated a significant treasury. The other Swiss republics have not. The taste for pageantry, at least for splendid buildings and public ornaments, often prevails as strongly in the apparently sober senate-house of a small republic as in the most extravagant royal court.
elegant: In commercial societies, sovereigns and nobles alike spend their revenues on luxuries, pageantry, and display. Nobles dismiss retainers and become insignificant; sovereigns spend up to or beyond their income, making treasure accumulation impossible. Since Henry IV's death in 1610, only Prussia's kings have saved significantly. Republics fare no better -- all except Berne are in debt. The taste for splendid buildings afflicts sober senates as much as extravagant courts.
summary: Commercial society makes both sovereigns and nobles spend their income on luxuries rather than saving. Treasure accumulation has become nearly impossible in both monarchies and republics, with only Prussia and Berne as exceptions. The desire for display is universal across forms of government.
distilled: Commercial society's luxuries prevent treasure accumulation by sovereigns and republics alike, with only Prussia and Berne as rare exceptions.
notes: Commercial society and sovereign spending -- pageantry as fiscal drain -- noble decline through luxury spending -- impossibility of treasure accumulation -- Henry IV of France (1610) as watershed -- Prussian fiscal discipline -- Berne as sole republican saver -- republics and monarchies equally profligate

refashioned: The failure to save during peacetime imposes the necessity of borrowing during war. When war comes, the treasury holds only what is needed for ordinary peacetime operations. War requires an establishment three or four times larger and therefore revenue three or four times greater. Even if the sovereign could immediately increase revenue proportionally -- which he almost never can -- the proceeds of new taxes would not begin arriving for perhaps ten or twelve months. But the moment war begins, or even appears likely, the army must be expanded, the fleet fitted out, garrisons fortified, and all must be supplied with arms, ammunition, and provisions. Enormous expense must be incurred at the very moment of danger, an expense that cannot wait for the slow, gradual returns of new taxes. In this emergency, government has no resource but borrowing.
elegant: Peacetime extravagance makes wartime borrowing inevitable. War requires three to four times peacetime spending, but new tax revenue takes months to arrive. The immediate need for army expansion, fleet preparation, and garrison supply cannot wait -- leaving borrowing as the only option.
summary: Government failure to save during peace makes borrowing inevitable during war, because military expansion requires immediate massive spending while new tax revenues take months or years to materialize.
distilled: Peacetime spending leaves no reserves, forcing governments to borrow when war demands immediate massive expenditure that new taxes cannot quickly fund.
notes: Peacetime profligacy and wartime borrowing -- fiscal gap between immediate military needs and delayed tax revenue -- three-to-four-fold wartime spending increase -- origins of public debt -- emergency finance

refashioned:
The same commercial society that, through moral causes, drives government into the necessity of borrowing also gives its citizens both the ability and the willingness to lend. Commercial society brings both the need for borrowing and the means to do it.

A country full of merchants and manufacturers necessarily contains many people through whose hands -- not only their own capital but the capital of everyone who lends to them or trusts them with goods -- passes as frequently, or more frequently, than the income of a private person living on his revenues passes through his hands. A private person's income passes through his hands only once a year. But a merchant in a quick-turnover trade may see the full amount of his capital and credit pass through his hands two, three, or four times annually. A country of merchants and manufacturers therefore necessarily contains a large class of people with the means to advance very large sums to the government at any time. This is the source of a commercial state's ability to lend.
elegant: Commercial society creates both the need to borrow and the ability to lend. Merchants and manufacturers constantly cycle capital through their hands -- two to four times annually, versus once for a private income earner. This gives commercial nations a large class of people able to advance substantial sums to government at any time.
summary: The same commercial development that forces governments to borrow also creates a class of citizens able to lend. Merchants' rapid capital turnover means they always have large sums available, giving commercial states a ready source of government loans.
distilled: Commercial society simultaneously creates government borrowing needs and a merchant class with the capital turnover to fund those needs.
notes: Dual effect of commercial society on public debt -- merchant capital turnover as lending capacity -- ability to lend from rapid business cycles -- link between commerce and government borrowing -- private income vs. merchant capital flow

refashioned: Commerce and manufacturing can rarely flourish in any state that lacks regular justice administration, where people feel insecure about their property, where contracts are not enforced by law, or where the state is not believed to regularly enforce debt payment from those able to pay. Commerce and manufacturing, in short, require a certain degree of confidence in government justice. The same confidence that leads great merchants and manufacturers to trust their property to a particular government's protection also leads them, in extraordinary circumstances, to trust that government with the use of their property. By lending to the government, they do not even momentarily reduce their ability to trade and manufacture -- on the contrary, they typically increase it. The state's needs make it willing to borrow on terms very favorable to lenders. The security it provides to the original creditor is transferable to any other buyer, and because of universal confidence in the state's justice, this security generally sells in the market for more than was originally paid. The merchant or moneyed man profits by lending to the government and increases rather than diminishes his trading capital. He generally considers it a favor when the government admits him to a share in the initial subscription for a new loan. This is the source of the willingness to lend in a commercial state.
elegant: Commerce requires confidence in government justice. That same confidence makes merchants willing to lend to the state, especially since government loans do not reduce but actually increase their trading capital. Favorable lending terms, transferable securities that appreciate in value, and the prestige of participating in new subscriptions make government lending attractive. This creates the willingness to lend in commercial states.
summary: The confidence in government justice that enables commerce also makes merchants willing to lend to the state. Government borrowing actually increases merchants' capital by offering favorable terms and transferable securities that appreciate, making loan subscriptions a sought-after privilege.
distilled: Confidence in government justice makes merchants willing to lend because government securities are profitable and transferable, actually increasing their trading capital.
notes: Rule of law and commercial confidence -- government lending as profitable for merchants -- transferable securities and market appreciation -- subscription privilege -- willingness to lend in commercial states -- property rights as foundation for public borrowing

refashioned:
A commercial state's government is very apt to rely on its subjects' ability and willingness to lend. Foreseeing the ease of borrowing, it exempts itself from the duty of saving.

In a primitive society, there are no great mercantile or manufacturing capitals. Individuals who hoard and conceal their savings do so from distrust of government justice -- fearing that a known hoard would quickly be seized. In such conditions, few people are able and no one is willing to lend to the government in emergencies. The sovereign, recognizing the absolute impossibility of borrowing, understands that he must save for emergencies himself. This foresight further strengthens his natural inclination to save.
elegant: Commercial governments rely on borrowing capacity and neglect saving. In primitive societies, by contrast, distrust of government drives hoarding and concealment, making lending impossible. Recognizing this, primitive sovereigns save out of necessity, reinforcing their natural frugality. Easy borrowing destroys the discipline that difficult borrowing imposes.
summary: The ease of borrowing in commercial states encourages governments to neglect saving, while in primitive societies the impossibility of borrowing forces sovereigns to save. The availability of credit undermines fiscal discipline.
distilled: Easy borrowing in commercial states destroys fiscal discipline, while the impossibility of borrowing in primitive societies forces sovereign frugality.
notes: Moral hazard of easy borrowing -- fiscal discipline vs. credit availability -- primitive hoarding from government distrust -- sovereign saving from necessity -- public debt as substitute for saving -- anticipation of modern fiscal discipline debates

refashioned: The growth of the enormous debts that now oppress and will likely eventually ruin all the great nations of Europe has followed a fairly uniform pattern. Nations, like individuals, have generally begun by borrowing on personal credit without pledging any specific revenue source to repay the debt. When this resource was exhausted, they progressed to borrowing against specific assigned or mortgaged revenue funds.
elegant: European national debts, which will likely ruin all great nations, have grown in a uniform pattern: first borrowing on general credit, then when that was exhausted, borrowing against specific pledged revenue sources.
summary: European national debts have grown through two stages: first borrowing on general credit, then on pledged specific revenues. These debts now threaten to ruin every major European nation.
distilled: European nations progressed from borrowing on general credit to pledging specific revenues, accumulating debts that threaten their ruin.
notes: Two stages of public borrowing -- personal credit then mortgaged funds -- national debt as existential threat -- uniform pattern across European nations -- Smith's pessimism about sovereign debt

refashioned: What is called the unfunded debt of Great Britain was contracted in the first of these two ways. It consists partly of debt bearing no interest, resembling what a private person owes on open account, and partly of interest-bearing debt, resembling personal bills or promissory notes. The first type includes amounts owed for extraordinary services, or for services not budgeted for or not paid when performed -- parts of the army, navy, and ordnance extraordinaries, arrears of subsidies to foreign princes, seamen's wage arrears, and similar obligations. The second type consists of Navy and Exchequer bills, issued sometimes to pay such debts and sometimes for other purposes. Exchequer bills bear interest from the date of issue; Navy bills from six months after issue. The Bank of England, by either voluntarily discounting these bills at their current value or by agreeing with the government to circulate Exchequer bills at par while paying their accrued interest, maintains their value and facilitates their circulation, frequently enabling the government to contract a very large debt of this kind. In France, where no central bank exists, state bills have sometimes traded at sixty and seventy percent discount. During the great recoinage under William III, when the Bank of England suspended its normal operations, Exchequer bills and tallies reportedly traded at twenty-five to sixty percent discount -- partly from doubts about the new revolutionary government's stability, but partly from the loss of the Bank's support.
elegant: Britain's unfunded debt takes two forms: non-interest-bearing obligations (unpaid military and diplomatic expenses) and interest-bearing bills (Exchequer and Navy bills). The Bank of England supports these bills' value by discounting or circulating them at par. Without such support, government paper loses value dramatically -- French state bills have traded at 60-70% discount, and during William III's recoinage, even British bills fell to 25-60% discount when the Bank suspended operations.
summary: Britain's unfunded debt consists of unpaid government obligations and interest-bearing bills whose value the Bank of England maintains through discounting and circulation. Without central bank support, government paper collapses in value, as demonstrated by French state bills and British bills during the William III recoinage crisis.
distilled: The Bank of England sustains the value of Britain's unfunded debt; without central bank support, government paper collapses in value.
notes: Unfunded vs. funded debt -- Exchequer and Navy bills -- Bank of England as market-maker for government debt -- French state bills at deep discount -- William III recoinage crisis -- central bank role in sovereign debt markets -- revolutionary government credit risk

refashioned: When borrowing on general credit is exhausted and money must be raised by assigning or mortgaging a specific branch of public revenue, the government has historically done this in two ways. Sometimes the assignment is for a short period -- a year or a few years -- with the fund expected to pay both principal and interest within that time. Sometimes the assignment is perpetual, with the fund expected to pay only the interest or an equivalent perpetual annuity, while the government retains the right to redeem the annuity at any time by repaying the principal. When money was raised the first way, it was called raising by anticipation. When raised the second way, it was called perpetual funding, or simply funding.
elegant: When general credit is exhausted, governments borrow against specific revenues in two ways: by anticipation, pledging revenue for a limited term to cover both principal and interest; or by funding, pledging revenue to pay interest perpetually while retaining the right to redeem by repaying principal.
summary: Governments that exhaust general credit borrow against specific revenues either through short-term anticipation (pledging revenue to cover both principal and interest) or through perpetual funding (pledging revenue for interest only, with optional principal repayment).
distilled: Governments borrow against specific revenues through either short-term anticipation or perpetual funding of interest payments.
notes: Anticipation vs. perpetual funding -- two methods of secured government borrowing -- principal repayment vs. perpetual annuity -- funded debt terminology -- evolution of public borrowing techniques

refashioned: In Great Britain, the annual land and malt taxes are regularly anticipated each year through a borrowing clause routinely inserted into the acts imposing them. The Bank of England typically advances the expected tax revenue at interest rates that have varied since the Revolution from eight to three percent, receiving repayment as the taxes gradually come in. Any shortfall -- and there always is one -- is covered from the following year's budget. The only significant branch of public revenue that remains unpledged is thus regularly spent before it arrives. Like an improvident spendthrift whose urgent needs prevent him from waiting for his regular income, the state constantly borrows from its own agents and pays interest for the use of its own money.
elegant: Britain's land and malt taxes are annually anticipated -- the Bank of England advances the expected revenue at interest, with any shortfall covered by next year's budget. The only major unpledged revenue stream is thus spent before it arrives. Like a spendthrift borrowing from his own servants, the state pays interest on its own money.
summary: Britain routinely spends its land and malt tax revenue before collecting it, borrowing from the Bank of England at interest and covering inevitable shortfalls from future budgets. The state effectively pays interest to use its own money.
distilled: Britain borrows against its own tax revenue before collection, paying the Bank of England interest on what is effectively its own money.
notes: Tax anticipation borrowing -- Bank of England as government lender -- interest rates 3-8% since Revolution -- annual shortfalls and budget carry-forwards -- spendthrift analogy -- last unpledged revenue being pre-spent

refashioned: During the reign of William III and much of Queen Anne's reign, before perpetual funding became as familiar as it is now, most new taxes were imposed for only short periods -- four, five, six, or seven years -- and much of each year's borrowing consisted of loans against the anticipated revenue from those temporary taxes. The revenue frequently proved insufficient to pay both principal and interest within the limited term, creating deficiencies that required extending the term.
elegant: Before perpetual funding became routine, taxes under William III and Anne were imposed for limited terms of four to seven years, with borrowing based on anticipated revenue. Revenues frequently fell short, creating deficiencies that forced term extensions.
summary: Early modern British borrowing relied on short-term taxes whose revenues consistently fell short of loan repayment needs, forcing repeated extensions and paving the way for perpetual funding.
distilled: Short-term tax revenues under William III and Anne consistently fell short, forcing term extensions that led to perpetual funding.
notes: Transition from anticipation to perpetual funding -- William III and Queen Anne fiscal policy -- short-term tax impositions -- revenue deficiencies and term extensions -- evolution of public debt structure

refashioned: In 1697, under the eighth year of William III (chapter 20), the deficiencies of several taxes were charged upon what was then called the first general mortgage or fund. This consisted of an extension to August 1, 1706, of several different taxes that would have expired sooner, with their revenues pooled into a single general fund. The deficiencies charged upon this extended term amounted to 5,160,459 pounds, fourteen shillings, and ninepence halfpenny.
elegant: In 1697, multiple tax deficiencies totaling over 5.16 million pounds were consolidated onto the first general mortgage fund -- created by extending several expiring taxes to 1706 and pooling their revenues.
summary: The first general mortgage fund of 1697 consolidated over 5.16 million pounds in tax deficiencies by extending and pooling several expiring tax revenues, marking an early step in the evolution of Britain's funded national debt.
distilled: The 1697 first general mortgage fund consolidated 5.16 million pounds in tax deficiencies by extending and pooling expiring tax revenues.
notes: First general mortgage fund (1697) -- 8 William III c.20 -- consolidation of tax deficiencies -- 5,160,459 pounds -- tax extension to 1706 -- pooled revenue funds -- early funded debt structure

refashioned: In 1701, these duties, along with some others, were extended again for similar purposes until August 1, 1710, and were called the Second General Mortgage or Fund. The deficiencies charged against it amounted to 2,055,999 pounds, 7 shillings, 11.5 pence. In 1707, these same duties were extended yet again as a fund for new loans until August 1, 1712, and were called the Third General Mortgage or Fund. The sum borrowed against it was 983,254 pounds, 11 shillings, 9.25 pence.
elegant: In 1701, these duties were extended to 1710 as the Second General Mortgage, covering deficiencies of over two million pounds. In 1707, they were extended again to 1712 as the Third General Mortgage, raising nearly one million pounds in new loans.
summary: The various customs and excise duties were repeatedly extended and renamed as successive 'general mortgages' to cover government deficiencies and fund new borrowing, with the second and third funds raising roughly three million pounds combined.
distilled: Government duties were repeatedly extended and relabeled as successive mortgage funds to cover growing deficiencies and new borrowing.
notes: Perpetual funding -- anticipation of revenue -- Second and Third General Mortgages -- escalating public debt under William III and Anne -- see 5.3.15-16 for First General Mortgage

refashioned: In 1708, all these duties -- except for the old subsidy of tonnage and poundage (of which only half was included) and a duty on Scottish linen imports (removed by the Articles of Union) -- were extended again as a fund for new loans until August 1, 1714. This was called the Fourth General Mortgage or Fund. The sum borrowed against it was 925,176 pounds, 9 shillings, 2.25 pence.
elegant: In 1708, nearly all existing duties were extended to 1714 as the Fourth General Mortgage, raising over 925,000 pounds. The old tonnage and poundage subsidy was only partially included, and a Scottish linen duty was dropped following the Act of Union.
summary: The Fourth General Mortgage of 1708 extended most existing duties to 1714, with exceptions made for the tonnage and poundage subsidy and Scottish linen duties eliminated by the Union. It raised over 925,000 pounds.
distilled: The Fourth General Mortgage of 1708 extended nearly all existing duties to fund another 925,000 pounds in government borrowing.
notes: Fourth General Mortgage -- Articles of Union 1707 -- Scottish linen duty exemption -- tonnage and poundage -- continuing pattern of debt accumulation

refashioned: In 1709, all these duties -- except the old subsidy of tonnage and poundage, which was now entirely excluded -- were extended for the same purpose until August 1, 1716, and were called the Fifth General Mortgage or Fund. The sum borrowed against it was 922,029 pounds, 6 shillings. In 1710, these duties were extended again to August 1, 1720, and were called the Sixth General Mortgage or Fund. The sum borrowed against it was 1,296,552 pounds, 9 shillings, 11.75 pence.
elegant: In 1709, the duties (now fully excluding the old tonnage and poundage subsidy) were extended to 1716 as the Fifth General Mortgage, raising 922,029 pounds. In 1710, a further extension to 1720 created the Sixth General Mortgage, raising nearly 1.3 million pounds.
summary: The Fifth and Sixth General Mortgages extended duties to 1716 and 1720 respectively, raising over two million pounds combined. The old tonnage and poundage subsidy was now entirely excluded from these funds.
distilled: The Fifth and Sixth General Mortgages extended revenue duties further into the future, raising over two million pounds in additional borrowing.
notes: Fifth and Sixth General Mortgages -- tonnage and poundage fully excluded -- escalating borrowing under Queen Anne -- War of the Spanish Succession financing

refashioned: In 1711, these same duties -- which by now were subject to four different anticipations simultaneously -- along with several additional taxes, were made permanent and designated as the fund for paying interest on the capital of the South Sea Company. That year, the South Sea Company had advanced to the government the sum of 9,177,967 pounds, 15 shillings, 4 pence, for paying debts and covering deficiencies. This was the largest single loan ever made to the government up to that time.
elegant: In 1711, these duties -- now under four overlapping anticipations -- were made perpetual as the fund backing the South Sea Company, which advanced over 9.1 million pounds to the government, the largest single loan in British history to that point.
summary: In 1711, the repeatedly extended duties were made permanent to service the South Sea Company's unprecedented loan of over nine million pounds to the government. This marked a pivotal shift from temporary anticipations to perpetual funding.
distilled: The 1711 creation of the perpetual South Sea Fund, backed by the largest government loan yet, marked the decisive shift from temporary to permanent debt financing.
notes: South Sea Company -- perpetual funding -- 9.1 million pound loan -- transition from anticipation to permanent debt -- see 5.3.24 on perpetual funding consequences

refashioned: Before this point, the only taxes that had been made perpetual to pay interest on government debt -- as far as I can determine -- were those funding the Bank of England and the East India Company, along with a projected land bank that was expected but never actually made its advance. The Bank fund at this time stood at 3,375,027 pounds, 17 shillings, 10.5 pence, paying an annuity of 206,501 pounds, 15 shillings, 5 pence. The East India fund stood at 3,200,000 pounds, paying an annuity of 160,000 pounds. The Bank fund paid six percent interest; the East India fund paid five percent.
elegant: Before the South Sea Fund, the only perpetual taxes for debt service funded the Bank of England (about 3.4 million at six percent) and the East India Company (3.2 million at five percent). A projected land bank was expected to contribute but never actually advanced any money.
summary: Prior to the South Sea Company arrangement, only the Bank of England and East India Company had perpetual tax funding for their government loans. The Bank fund was about 3.4 million pounds at six percent, and the East India fund was 3.2 million at five percent.
distilled: Before the South Sea Fund, only the Bank of England and East India Company enjoyed perpetual tax revenues to service their government loans.
notes: Bank of England fund -- East India Company fund -- projected land bank (never realized) -- interest rates: 6% Bank, 5% East India -- early perpetual debt instruments

refashioned: In 1715, under the first act of George I (chapter 12), the various taxes that had been earmarked for paying the Bank annuity, together with several other taxes that were also made perpetual by this act, were consolidated into a single common fund called the Aggregate Fund. This fund was responsible not only for the Bank annuity but also for several other annuities and obligations of various kinds. The Aggregate Fund was later enlarged by additional acts under George I, and the new duties added to it were likewise made perpetual.
elegant: In 1715, the taxes backing the Bank annuity were consolidated with other newly perpetuated taxes into the Aggregate Fund, which covered the Bank annuity plus various other obligations. Subsequent acts under George I further enlarged this fund.
summary: The Aggregate Fund of 1715 consolidated multiple previously separate tax streams into a single perpetual fund covering the Bank annuity and other government obligations, and was subsequently expanded by further legislation.
distilled: The 1715 Aggregate Fund consolidated multiple perpetual taxes into a single fund servicing the Bank annuity and other government debts.
notes: Aggregate Fund -- consolidation of perpetual taxes -- George I legislation -- institutional framework of national debt -- see 5.3.23 for General Fund

refashioned: In 1717, under another act of George I, several additional taxes were made perpetual and consolidated into a separate common fund called the General Fund, designated for paying annuities totaling 724,849 pounds, 6 shillings, 10.5 pence per year. As a result of these various acts, the great majority of taxes that had previously been anticipated only for short terms of years were now made perpetual -- not as a fund for repaying the principal of government borrowing, but solely for paying the interest on money that had been borrowed through successive anticipations.
elegant: In 1717, more taxes were made perpetual under the General Fund to cover annuities of nearly 725,000 pounds per year. The cumulative effect of these acts was transformative: taxes once anticipated for short terms were now permanent, dedicated not to repaying debt principal but merely to servicing its interest.
summary: The 1717 General Fund made additional taxes perpetual to cover annual annuities. The broader consequence was that most temporarily anticipated taxes had now become permanent fixtures, dedicated solely to interest payments rather than debt repayment.
distilled: The 1717 General Fund completed the transformation of temporarily anticipated taxes into permanent revenue streams dedicated solely to paying debt interest.
notes: General Fund -- perpetual taxation -- interest-only payments -- structural shift from debt repayment to perpetual debt service -- three great funds: Aggregate, South Sea, General

refashioned: Had money only ever been raised through temporary anticipation, the public revenue would have been freed within a few years, requiring nothing more from the government than the discipline not to overload any fund with more debt than it could repay within the set term, and not to anticipate again before the first anticipation expired. But most European governments have been incapable of such restraint. They have frequently overloaded funds even on the first anticipation, and when that was not the case, they made sure to overload them by anticipating a second and third time before the first term expired. Once a fund became wholly insufficient to pay both principal and interest, it became necessary to charge it with interest payments only -- a perpetual annuity. Such reckless anticipations inevitably gave rise to the far more destructive practice of perpetual funding. Though this practice delays the liberation of public revenue from a fixed deadline to one so indefinite that it may never arrive, a larger sum can always be raised through perpetual funding than through temporary anticipation. Once governments grew accustomed to it, they universally preferred it during major crises. Relieving the present emergency is always the primary concern of those running public affairs. They leave the future liberation of public revenue to posterity.
elegant: Had governments limited themselves to temporary anticipations and shown fiscal discipline, public revenues would have been freed within years. But most European governments overloaded their funds repeatedly, making it impossible to repay both principal and interest. This forced them to charge interest only -- perpetual annuities -- giving birth to perpetual funding. Though this practice postpones debt liberation indefinitely, it raises more money in the short term and became universally preferred in emergencies. Those managing public affairs always prioritize the present crisis, leaving debt repayment to future generations.
summary: Temporary anticipation of revenue would have freed public finances within years if governments had shown discipline. Instead, repeated overloading of funds made perpetual funding necessary, which raises more money but postpones debt repayment indefinitely. Governments universally prefer it because it solves immediate crises, leaving the burden to posterity.
distilled: Governments' inability to restrain borrowing transformed temporary revenue anticipations into perpetual funding, prioritizing present needs over any prospect of future debt liberation.
notes: Anticipation vs. perpetual funding -- moral hazard of government borrowing -- intergenerational debt transfer -- short-term bias in public finance -- key structural argument of Book 5 Chapter 3

refashioned: During Queen Anne's reign, the market interest rate fell from six to five percent, and in the twelfth year of her reign, five percent was declared the legal maximum for private loans. Soon after most of Britain's temporary taxes had been made perpetual and distributed among the Aggregate, South Sea, and General Funds, public creditors were persuaded to accept five percent interest instead of six. This saved one percent on the capital of most perpetually funded debts -- equivalent to one-sixth of the annuities paid from the three great funds. The savings created a substantial surplus in these tax funds beyond what was needed to pay the annuities now charged against them, and this surplus became the foundation of what has since been called the Sinking Fund. In 1717, it amounted to 523,454 pounds, 7 shillings, 7.5 pence. In 1727, interest on most public debts was further reduced to four percent, and in 1753 and 1757 to three and a half and then three percent, each reduction further enlarging the Sinking Fund.
elegant: As market interest rates fell from six to five percent under Queen Anne, public creditors were induced to accept lower returns, saving one percent on most perpetually funded debt -- one-sixth of the annuities paid from the three great funds. This surplus became the Sinking Fund, reaching over 523,000 pounds by 1717. Further interest reductions to four percent in 1727 and down to three percent by 1757 progressively enlarged it, as each reduction freed additional revenue beyond what was needed to service existing annuities.
summary: Falling interest rates allowed the government to reduce payments to public creditors, creating surplus revenue that became the Sinking Fund. Starting at over 523,000 pounds in 1717, the fund grew as interest rates were progressively cut from six percent down to three percent by 1757.
distilled: Declining interest rates created surplus revenue from the great funds, establishing the Sinking Fund that grew with each successive reduction in public debt interest.
notes: Sinking Fund origins -- interest rate reductions (6% to 3%) -- Aggregate, South Sea, General Funds -- Queen Anne era fiscal policy -- see 5.3.26-37 on sinking fund misuse

refashioned: A sinking fund, though established to pay off existing debts, greatly facilitates the creation of new ones. It serves as a reserve fund, always available to be pledged in support of any other uncertain fund against which money is proposed to be raised during a state emergency. Whether Great Britain's Sinking Fund has more often been used to pay off old debts or to support new borrowing will become sufficiently clear shortly.
elegant: A sinking fund meant to retire old debt actually makes new borrowing easier by providing a ready reserve that can be pledged to support fresh loans during emergencies. Whether Britain's Sinking Fund has served more to reduce debt or to enable new borrowing will soon become apparent.
summary: The Sinking Fund, though designed to retire old debt, paradoxically facilitates new borrowing by providing a ready reserve to back additional loans during emergencies.
distilled: A sinking fund designed to pay off old debts ironically makes it easier to contract new ones by serving as collateral for fresh borrowing.
notes: Sinking fund paradox -- moral hazard -- debt enables more debt -- perverse incentive structure in public finance -- foreshadows 5.3.37 on misapplication
