refashioned: Besides the two methods of borrowing already discussed -- anticipation and perpetual funding -- there are two others that occupy a middle ground: borrowing upon annuities for terms of years, and borrowing upon annuities for lives. During the reigns of William and Anne, large sums were frequently borrowed on annuities for various terms. In 1695, an act authorized borrowing one million pounds at an annuity of fourteen percent (140,000 pounds per year) for sixteen years. In 1691, an act authorized borrowing a million on life annuities at terms that would seem very favorable today, but the subscription was not filled. The following year, the shortfall was covered by borrowing on life annuities at fourteen percent -- barely more than seven years' purchase. In 1695, holders of these life annuities were allowed to exchange them for ninety-six-year annuities upon paying sixty-three pounds per hundred into the exchequer. In other words, the difference between fourteen percent for life and fourteen percent for ninety-six years was valued at only four and a half years' purchase -- so little confidence existed in government stability that even these terms attracted few buyers. Under Queen Anne, money was borrowed on annuities for lives and for terms of thirty-two, eighty-nine, ninety-eight, and ninety-nine years. In 1719, holders of the thirty-two-year annuities were persuaded to accept South Sea stock worth eleven and a half years' purchase plus stock equal to their arrears. In 1720, most of the other term annuities were subscribed into the same fund. The long annuities at that time totaled 666,821 pounds, 8 shillings, 3.5 pence per year. By January 5, 1775, the remainder -- what had not been subscribed -- amounted to only 136,453 pounds, 12 shillings, 8 pence.
elegant: Beyond anticipation and perpetual funding, governments also borrowed through annuities for terms of years and for lives. Under William and Anne, such annuities carried rates as high as fourteen percent, reflecting deep distrust of government stability. Life annuities sold at barely seven years' purchase, and the conversion premium from life to ninety-six-year annuities was valued at only four and a half years' purchase -- so little confidence existed that even these terms attracted few buyers. Under Anne, annuities for terms of thirty-two to ninety-nine years were issued, most of which were eventually absorbed into the South Sea fund during 1719-1720, with long annuities declining from 666,821 pounds to only 136,453 pounds by 1775.
summary: Annuities for terms of years and for lives represented a middle ground between temporary anticipation and perpetual funding. High rates of fourteen percent and low purchase prices reflected profound distrust of government. Most term annuities were eventually absorbed into the South Sea fund between 1719 and 1720.
distilled: Term and life annuities offered a middle path between anticipation and perpetual funding, but high rates and low confidence eventually led most to be absorbed into the South Sea fund.
notes: Annuities for years vs. lives -- government credit risk -- South Sea fund absorption 1719-1720 -- years' purchase valuation -- political instability premium in debt pricing

refashioned: During the wars that began in 1739 and 1755, little money was borrowed through annuities for terms of years or for lives. An annuity for ninety-eight or ninety-nine years is worth nearly as much as a perpetual annuity, and should therefore, one would think, serve as a fund for raising nearly as much money. However, investors who buy into public stocks to make family settlements and provide for the distant future do not want to purchase something whose value is constantly diminishing -- and such people make up a very significant proportion of both stockholders and stock purchasers. A long-term annuity, therefore, though its intrinsic value may be nearly identical to a perpetual annuity, will not attract nearly as many buyers. Subscribers to a new loan, who generally intend to sell their subscription as soon as possible, strongly prefer a perpetual annuity redeemable by Parliament to an irredeemable annuity for a long term at the same amount. The perpetual annuity's value can be assumed to remain essentially constant, making it a far more convenient tradeable asset.
elegant: During the wars of 1739 and 1755, little was borrowed via term or life annuities. Though a ninety-nine-year annuity is worth nearly as much as a perpetual one, it attracts far fewer buyers. Long-term investors dislike assets whose value constantly diminishes, and short-term speculators prefer perpetual annuities because their stable value makes them easier to resell. Perpetual annuities thus became the preferred instrument despite having no fixed repayment date.
summary: Long-term annuities fell out of favor because their diminishing value made them unattractive to both long-term family investors and short-term speculators. Perpetual annuities, with their stable transferable value, became the dominant instrument for government borrowing.
distilled: Perpetual annuities dominated government borrowing because their stable value made them far more liquid and attractive to both investors and speculators than depreciating term annuities.
notes: Liquidity preference -- transferability of debt instruments -- perpetual vs. term annuities -- investor behavior -- market preference for stable-value securities -- capital markets development

refashioned: During the last two wars mentioned, annuities for terms of years or for lives were seldom granted on their own. Instead, they were offered as bonuses to subscribers of new loans, in addition to the redeemable annuity or interest on which the loan was officially based. They served not as the primary security for the borrowed money, but as an extra incentive for lenders.
elegant: In the later wars, term and life annuities were no longer the basis for borrowing but were offered as sweeteners -- bonuses to entice subscribers to new loans beyond the standard redeemable annuity.
summary: Term and life annuities shifted from being primary borrowing instruments to serving as bonus incentives offered to subscribers of new perpetual-annuity-based loans.
distilled: Term and life annuities were reduced to premium sweeteners for new loan subscribers rather than serving as primary borrowing instruments.
notes: Evolution of debt instruments -- annuities as premiums -- loan subscription incentives -- shift toward perpetual funding dominance

refashioned: Life annuities have been granted in two ways: upon individual lives, or upon groups of lives -- the latter called tontines, after their inventor. With individual life annuities, the public revenue is relieved each time an annuitant dies. With tontines, relief does not begin until every person in a group -- sometimes twenty or thirty people -- has died, with survivors inheriting the annuities of those who die before them and the last survivor receiving the entire group's payments. More money can always be raised through tontines than through individual life annuities, because an annuity with survivorship rights is genuinely worth more than one for a single life. Furthermore, because every person naturally overestimates their own good fortune -- the same principle that makes lotteries successful -- such annuities typically sell for somewhat more than their actuarial value. In countries where governments routinely raise money through annuities, tontines are generally preferred to individual life annuities. The method that raises the most money is almost always chosen over the one most likely to free public revenue quickly.
elegant: Life annuities come in two forms: individual (where each death relieves the public) and tontines (where survivors inherit until the last person in a group dies). Tontines raise more money because survivorship rights add real value, and because people's natural overconfidence in their own longevity -- the same psychology driving lotteries -- makes them pay more than the actuarial worth. Governments therefore prefer tontines, choosing the method that maximizes revenue over the one that would retire debt fastest.
summary: Tontines, where survivors inherit annuities within a group, raise more money than individual life annuities because survivorship adds real value and human overconfidence in personal longevity inflates their market price. Governments consistently prefer the method that maximizes immediate revenue over faster debt retirement.
distilled: Tontines raise more money than individual life annuities because survivorship rights and human overconfidence in longevity inflate their price above actuarial value.
notes: Tontines vs. individual life annuities -- optimism bias and lottery psychology -- behavioral economics of government debt -- revenue maximization vs. debt liberation -- actuarial mispricing

refashioned: In France, a much larger share of public debt consists of life annuities than in England. According to a report presented by the Parliament of Bordeaux to the king in 1764, France's total public debt was estimated at 2.4 billion livres, of which the capital represented by life annuities was approximately 300 million livres -- one-eighth of the total. The annuity payments themselves were estimated at 30 million livres per year, one-quarter of the 120 million livres in total interest on the whole debt. I am well aware these figures are not exact, but since they were presented by such a respected body as reasonable approximations, they may be treated as such. The difference between French and English borrowing methods does not stem from different degrees of concern for liberating public revenue; it arises entirely from the different views and interests of the lenders in each country.
elegant: France relied far more heavily on life annuities than England -- by 1764 estimates, life annuity capital comprised one-eighth of total French debt (300 million of 2.4 billion livres) but consumed one-quarter of annual interest payments (30 of 120 million livres), reflecting the higher cost of life-contingent borrowing. The difference between French and English borrowing methods reflected not different government fiscal philosophies but entirely different characteristics of their respective lending classes.
summary: France's public debt relied much more heavily on life annuities than England's, with life annuity capital comprising one-eighth of total debt but one-quarter of interest costs. This reflected differences in lender preferences, not government fiscal philosophy.
distilled: France's heavier reliance on life annuities compared to England reflected the different investment preferences of French and English lenders, not different government fiscal philosophies.
notes: French vs. English public debt structure -- life annuities as proportion of debt -- Parliament of Bordeaux 1764 report -- lender preferences shape borrowing methods -- see 5.3.32-33 for explanation

refashioned: In England, the seat of government being in the world's greatest commercial city, merchants are generally the people who lend money to the government. By lending, they do not intend to reduce their trading capital but to increase it -- they would never subscribe to a loan unless they expected to sell their share at a profit. But if lending meant purchasing life annuities rather than perpetual ones -- whether on their own lives or others' -- they could not always expect to resell at a profit. Annuities on their own lives would always sell at a loss, because no one will pay the same price for an annuity on another person's life (of similar age and health) as for one on their own. An annuity on a third person's life is of equal value to buyer and seller, but its real value begins declining from the moment it is granted and continues falling for its entire duration. It can therefore never serve as a convenient tradeable asset in the way a perpetual annuity can, whose real value may be assumed to remain essentially constant.
elegant: English government lenders are mainly London merchants seeking to expand, not diminish, their capital. They subscribe to loans intending to resell at a profit -- which works with perpetual annuities whose value stays constant but not with life annuities, which lose value from the moment of issue. Self-life annuities always sell at a loss since no buyer pays the same for another's life risk, and third-party life annuities steadily depreciate. Perpetual annuities thus dominate because they are liquid.
summary: English merchants lend to the government to grow their capital, expecting to resell loan subscriptions at a profit. Life annuities, which depreciate from the moment of issue, cannot serve this purpose, making perpetual annuities the preferred instrument due to their constant value and easy tradability.
distilled: English merchants prefer perpetual annuities because their stable value enables profitable resale, whereas life annuities depreciate continuously and cannot serve as convenient tradeable assets.
notes: London capital markets -- merchant lenders -- liquidity and transferability -- perpetual vs. life annuities -- self-selection of debt instruments by lender type -- see 5.3.33 for French contrast

refashioned: In France, the seat of government not being in a great commercial city, merchants do not make up as large a share of government lenders. Instead, the principal lenders are people connected to the financial system: the farmers-general who collect taxes, the receivers of taxes not farmed out, court bankers, and similar figures. These are typically men of humble birth but great wealth, and frequently great pride. Too proud to marry their social equals yet scorned by women of higher rank, they often choose to remain bachelors. Having neither families of their own nor much affection for their relatives -- whom they are not always eager to acknowledge -- they wish only to live splendidly during their own lifetimes and are perfectly content for their fortunes to die with them. The number of wealthy people in France who are either unwilling or unable to marry is also much greater than in England. For such people, who care little about posterity, nothing is more convenient than exchanging their capital for an income that lasts exactly as long as they wish it to.
elegant: In France, government lenders are not merchants but financiers -- tax farmers, tax receivers, and court bankers. These men of humble origin but great wealth often remain unmarried, too proud for their equals and rejected by the nobility. Having no families and little concern for posterity, they happily exchange capital for life annuities that end when they do. France's larger class of wealthy bachelors explains its greater reliance on life annuities compared to England.
summary: France's government lenders are wealthy financiers rather than merchants. Often unmarried men of humble birth but great pride, they have no concern for posterity and prefer life annuities that convert capital into personal income ending at death, explaining France's heavier reliance on this borrowing method.
distilled: French government lending is dominated by wealthy, unmarried financiers who prefer life annuities because they have no interest in preserving capital for posterity.
notes: French financier class -- farmers-general, court bankers -- social dynamics of lending -- life annuities for childless wealthy -- contrasts with English merchant lenders (5.3.32) -- sociology of public debt

refashioned: The ordinary peacetime expenses of most modern governments are equal, or nearly equal, to their ordinary revenue. When war comes, they are both unwilling and unable to raise revenue proportionally to their increased spending. They are unwilling because they fear that a sudden, large tax increase would turn the people against the war. They are unable because they do not know which taxes would produce the revenue needed. The ease of borrowing rescues them from the difficulty that this fear and inability would otherwise create. Through borrowing, they can raise sufficient war funding each year with only a very moderate tax increase. Through perpetual funding specifically, they can raise the largest possible sums with the smallest possible tax increases. In great empires, people living in the capital and in provinces far from the fighting feel barely any hardship from the war. They enjoy the comfort of reading about the exploits of their fleets and armies in the newspapers, and this entertainment compensates for the small difference between wartime and peacetime taxes. They are commonly disappointed by the return of peace, which ends their amusement and extinguishes a thousand fantasies of conquest and national glory.
elegant: Most governments spend their full peacetime revenue, so when war arrives they are both unwilling and unable to raise taxes proportionally -- unwilling for fear of public backlash, unable from ignorance of what taxes would suffice. Borrowing, especially perpetual funding, solves both problems by enabling maximum war spending with minimal tax increases. Citizens far from the fighting barely notice the cost, entertaining themselves with newspaper accounts of military exploits. They often resent peace for ending the excitement and their fantasies of glory.
summary: Governments enter wars unable to match spending with revenue, so they borrow. Perpetual funding enables maximum spending with minimal tax increases. Citizens distant from combat barely feel the burden and often prefer war's excitement to peace, making borrowing politically easy.
distilled: Perpetual funding allows governments to wage expensive wars with minimal tax increases, insulating citizens from war's true cost and making borrowing politically painless.
notes: War finance and fiscal illusion -- perpetual funding enables warfare -- citizen disconnect from war costs -- psychological appeal of wartime nationalism -- political economy of military spending -- key argument for pay-as-you-go war finance

refashioned: The return of peace, in fact, rarely brings relief from most wartime taxes. These taxes are now pledged to pay interest on the debt incurred to fight the war. If the old revenue plus new taxes produce any surplus beyond debt interest and ordinary government expenses, it may be directed into a sinking fund to pay down the debt. But this sinking fund, even if used exclusively for debt repayment, is generally far too small to repay the full war debt within any reasonable period of expected peace. And in the second place, it is almost always diverted to other purposes.
elegant: Peace rarely brings relief from wartime taxes, since these are now pledged to pay interest on the war debt. If any surplus remains beyond debt interest and ordinary expenses, it may be directed into a sinking fund. But this fund is generally far too small to repay the full war debt within any reasonable period of expected peace, and it is almost always diverted to other purposes anyway.
summary: Wartime taxes persist into peacetime because they are committed to servicing war debt. Any surplus directed to a sinking fund is typically both inadequate for meaningful debt repayment and almost inevitably diverted to other purposes.
distilled: Wartime taxes persist after peace because they service war debt, and any sinking fund surplus is invariably too small and too easily diverted to achieve meaningful repayment.
notes: Ratchet effect of wartime taxes -- sinking fund inadequacy -- debt persistence across peace and war cycles -- fiscal asymmetry -- see 5.3.36-37 for elaboration

refashioned: The new taxes were imposed solely to pay interest on the money borrowed against them. If they happen to produce more than that, the surplus is generally unintended and unexpected, and therefore seldom very large. Sinking funds have typically arisen not so much from taxes producing more than needed for their original interest charges, but from subsequent reductions in that interest rate -- as with Holland's sinking fund in 1655 and the Papal States' in 1685. This explains why such funds are usually insufficient.
elegant: New taxes were designed only to cover interest on borrowing, so any surplus was incidental. Sinking funds have mainly grown not from tax surpluses but from interest rate reductions, as in Holland (1655) and the Papal States (1685). This is why they remain chronically insufficient.
summary: Sinking funds are typically inadequate because new taxes were calibrated only to cover debt interest. Fund growth has depended mainly on subsequent interest rate reductions rather than tax surpluses.
distilled: Sinking funds remain insufficient because they depend on incidental interest rate reductions rather than deliberate tax surpluses.
notes: Sinking fund inadequacy -- interest rate reductions as primary source -- Holland 1655 and Papal States 1685 examples -- structural design flaws in public debt management

refashioned: Even during the most profound peace, various events demand extraordinary spending, and governments always find it more convenient to cover these costs by raiding the sinking fund than by imposing new taxes. Every new tax is immediately felt by the people, always provoking some complaint and opposition. The more taxes have already been multiplied and raised, the louder the public protests against any additional one, and the harder it becomes to find new subjects for taxation or to raise existing taxes further. A momentary suspension of debt repayment, by contrast, goes unnoticed by the people and provokes neither complaint nor protest. Borrowing from the sinking fund is always the obvious and easy way out of present difficulties. The more public debt has accumulated -- the more necessary it becomes to reduce it, the more dangerous and ruinous it is to misuse any part of the sinking fund -- the less likely the debt is to be significantly reduced, and the more certain the sinking fund is to be raided for every extraordinary peacetime expense. When a nation is already overburdened with taxes, only the pressures of a new war -- national vengeance or national security -- can persuade the people to accept additional taxation with tolerable patience. This is why sinking funds are habitually misapplied.
elegant: In peacetime, governments invariably raid the sinking fund for unexpected expenses rather than impose unpopular new taxes. Every new tax is immediately felt and provokes complaint; suspending debt repayment goes entirely unnoticed by the public. The more taxes have already been multiplied and raised, the harder it becomes to find new subjects of taxation or raise existing ones further. Paradoxically, the greater the accumulated debt and the more urgent the need for its reduction, the more certainly the sinking fund will be diverted to other purposes. Only the extreme pressures of a new war -- national vengeance or national security -- can overcome public resistance to additional taxation.
summary: Governments consistently raid sinking funds during peacetime because suspending debt repayment is invisible to the public while new taxes provoke immediate opposition. The greater the debt burden, the more certainly the sinking fund will be misapplied, since only war can force new taxation on an already overburdened population.
distilled: Sinking funds are invariably raided in peacetime because diverting debt repayment is politically invisible while new taxes provoke immediate resistance.
notes: Political economy of sinking funds -- asymmetric visibility of taxes vs. debt -- political path of least resistance -- war as only catalyst for new taxation -- ratchet effect in public finance

refashioned: In Great Britain, ever since the country first adopted the ruinous practice of perpetual funding, the reduction of public debt during peacetime has never come close to matching its growth during wartime. The foundation of Britain's present enormous debt was first laid during the war that began in 1688 and concluded with the Treaty of Ryswick in 1697.
elegant: Since Britain adopted perpetual funding, peacetime debt reduction has never matched wartime accumulation. The current enormous national debt began with the war of 1688-1697.
summary: Britain's adoption of perpetual funding ensured that peacetime debt reduction would never keep pace with wartime accumulation, a pattern established from the 1688-1697 war onward.
distilled: Since adopting perpetual funding, Britain's peacetime debt reduction has never matched its wartime debt accumulation.
notes: Debt ratchet -- Treaty of Ryswick 1697 -- origins of British national debt -- asymmetry between peacetime savings and wartime spending -- see 5.3.39-45 for detailed accounting

refashioned: On December 31, 1697, Great Britain's public debts -- both funded and unfunded -- totaled 21,515,742 pounds, 13 shillings, 8.5 pence. A large portion had been contracted on short anticipations and some on life annuities, so that by December 31, 1701 -- in less than four years -- some 5,121,041 pounds, 12 shillings, 0.75 pence had been partly paid off and partly reverted to the public. This was the greatest debt reduction ever achieved in so short a time. The remaining debt therefore stood at only 16,394,701 pounds, 1 shilling, 7.25 pence.
elegant: By the end of 1697, Britain's total public debt stood at over 21.5 million pounds. By 1701, over 5.1 million had been paid off or reverted -- the largest reduction in so short a period -- leaving roughly 16.4 million.
summary: Britain's total public debt of 21.5 million pounds in 1697 was reduced by over 5.1 million within four years, the greatest short-term debt reduction in British history to that point, leaving about 16.4 million.
distilled: Britain achieved its greatest short-term debt reduction between 1697 and 1701, paying off over five million of its 21.5 million pound debt.
notes: Post-Ryswick debt reduction -- 21.5 million total debt 1697 -- 5.1 million reduction by 1701 -- short anticipations and life annuities expiring -- brief success before next war

refashioned: The War of the Spanish Succession, which began in 1702 and ended with the Treaty of Utrecht, accumulated public debts even further. By December 31, 1714, they totaled 53,681,076 pounds, 5 shillings, 6.5 pence. The subscription of short and long annuities into the South Sea Fund increased the debt capital so that by December 31, 1722, it stood at 55,282,978 pounds, 1 shilling, about 4 pence. Debt reduction began in 1723 but proceeded so slowly that by December 31, 1739 -- after seventeen years of deep peace -- only 8,328,554 pounds had been paid off, leaving the public debt at 46,954,623 pounds.
elegant: The War of the Spanish Succession (1702-1713) drove public debt to nearly 54 million pounds. South Sea Fund conversions pushed it above 55 million by 1722. Despite seventeen years of peace, only 8.3 million was paid off by 1739, leaving the debt at nearly 47 million.
summary: The War of the Spanish Succession tripled public debt to 54 million pounds. After South Sea Fund conversions raised it further, seventeen years of peace managed to reduce it by only 8.3 million, leaving nearly 47 million outstanding.
distilled: The War of the Spanish Succession tripled public debt, and seventeen subsequent years of peace reduced it by less than one-sixth.
notes: Treaty of Utrecht 1713 -- South Sea Fund conversions -- 17 years of peace, only 8.3 million repaid -- debt tripled from ~16 to ~54 million -- demonstrates peacetime repayment inadequacy

refashioned: The Spanish war beginning in 1739, followed by the French war, further increased the debt. By December 31, 1748, after peace was concluded at Aix-la-Chapelle, it stood at 78,293,313 pounds, 1 shilling, 10.75 pence. The most profound peace of seventeen years had removed only 8,328,354 pounds from the debt. A war lasting less than nine years had added 31,338,689 pounds to it.
elegant: The wars of 1739-1748 pushed public debt to over 78 million pounds. Seventeen years of peace had reduced it by only 8.3 million, while less than nine years of war added over 31 million.
summary: The wars of 1739-1748 increased public debt to over 78 million pounds, with less than nine years of war adding four times more debt than seventeen years of peace had managed to repay.
distilled: Less than nine years of war added four times more debt than seventeen years of peace had repaid, pushing total public debt past 78 million pounds.
notes: War of Austrian Succession -- Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle 1748 -- 4:1 ratio of wartime accumulation to peacetime reduction -- debt ratchet accelerating -- see Postlethwaite's History of Public Revenue

refashioned: Under the administration of Mr. Pelham, steps were taken to reduce public debt interest from four to three percent, the sinking fund was increased, and some debt was actually paid off. In 1755, before the Seven Years' War, Britain's funded debt stood at 72,289,675 pounds. By January 5, 1763, at the war's conclusion, the funded debt had reached 122,603,336 pounds, 8 shillings, 2.25 pence, with unfunded debt estimated at 13,927,589 pounds. But war expenses did not end with the peace treaty. By January 5, 1764, the funded debt had grown to 129,586,789 pounds (through new loans and funding of previously unfunded debt), with an additional 9,975,017 pounds in unfunded debt still being accounted for. Thus in 1764, Britain's total funded and unfunded debt amounted to 139,561,807 pounds. On top of this, life annuities granted as loan premiums in 1757 were valued at 472,500 pounds (at fourteen years' purchase), and long-term annuities granted in 1761 and 1762 were valued at 6,826,875 pounds (at twenty-seven and a half years' purchase). During about seven years of peace, Mr. Pelham's prudent and genuinely patriotic administration had been unable to pay off more than six million pounds of old debt. During a war of nearly the same length, more than seventy-five million pounds of new debt was created.
elegant: Under Pelham's prudent administration, debt interest was cut from four to three percent and some principal repaid. In 1755, funded debt stood at 72 million. But by 1764, after the Seven Years' War, total funded and unfunded debt had reached nearly 140 million pounds, plus annuity obligations valued at over 7 million. Life annuities granted as loan premiums in 1757 and long-term annuities granted in 1761-1762 added further liabilities. During seven peacetime years of truly patriotic administration, only six million was paid off. During a war of nearly the same length, more than seventy-five million in new debt was contracted -- revealing the devastating asymmetry between peacetime repayment and wartime borrowing.
summary: Pelham's prudent administration managed to pay off only six million pounds of debt in seven years of peace. The subsequent Seven Years' War added over seventy-five million in new debt, demonstrating the overwhelming asymmetry between peacetime repayment capacity and wartime borrowing.
distilled: Seven years of prudent peacetime administration paid off six million pounds; a war of similar length created over seventy-five million in new debt.
notes: Pelham administration -- Seven Years' War debt -- 6 million repaid vs. 75 million borrowed -- interest reduction 4% to 3% -- life annuity premiums -- total debt approaching 150 million by 1764

refashioned: By January 5, 1775, Great Britain's funded debt stood at 124,996,086 pounds, 1 shilling, 6.25 pence. The unfunded debt, excluding a large civil list debt, was 4,150,236 pounds, 3 shillings, nearly 12 pence. Together they totaled 129,146,322 pounds, 5 shillings, 6 pence. According to these figures, the total debt repaid during eleven years of deep peace amounted to only 10,415,476 pounds. Even this modest reduction was not entirely achieved through savings from ordinary state revenue. Several extraordinary and independent sources contributed, including an additional shilling in the pound land tax for three years, two million pounds received from the East India Company as compensation for its territorial acquisitions, and 110,000 pounds from the Bank for the renewal of its charter. Additional sums arising from the late war should perhaps also be counted.
elegant: By 1775, Britain's total public debt stood at 129 million pounds after eleven years of peace had reduced it by only 10.4 million. Even this modest reduction relied partly on extraordinary windfalls -- extra land tax, East India Company compensation, Bank charter renewal fees -- rather than ordinary revenue savings alone.
summary: Eleven years of peace reduced Britain's public debt by only 10.4 million pounds to 129 million, and even this modest achievement depended partly on extraordinary windfalls rather than ordinary revenue savings.
distilled: Eleven years of peace reduced public debt by only 10.4 million pounds, and much of that came from extraordinary windfalls rather than ordinary revenue.
notes: 1775 debt figures -- 129 million total -- 10.4 million repaid in 11 years -- East India Company territorial compensation -- Bank charter renewal -- extraordinary vs. ordinary revenue sources

refashioned: The proceeds from French prizes amounted to 690,449 pounds, 18 shillings, 9 pence. Compositions for French prisoners yielded 670,000 pounds. Revenue from the sale of ceded islands came to 95,500 pounds.
elegant: War-related revenue included 690,449 pounds from French prizes, 670,000 pounds from French prisoner compositions, and 95,500 pounds from the sale of ceded islands.
summary: Specific war-related revenues included nearly 1.5 million pounds from French prizes, prisoner compositions, and sales of ceded islands.
distilled: War-related windfalls from prizes, prisoner compositions, and island sales contributed nearly 1.5 million pounds toward debt reduction.
notes: French prizes -- prisoner composition payments -- ceded island sales -- war-related windfall revenue -- see 5.3.45 for total accounting

refashioned: These items totaled 1,455,949 pounds, 18 shillings, 9 pence. Adding the balances from the Earl of Chatham's and Mr. Calcraft's accounts, other army savings, and the receipts from the Bank, the East India Company, and the additional land tax, the total comes to well over five million pounds. The debt actually paid from ordinary revenue savings since the peace has therefore averaged less than half a million pounds per year. The sinking fund has certainly grown since the peace -- augmented by the debt already paid off, by the conversion of redeemable four percent debt to three percent, and by life annuities that have lapsed. If peace continued, perhaps a million per year could now be spared for debt repayment. Another million was indeed paid last year, but at the same time a large civil list debt was left unpaid, and we are now involved in a new war that may prove as expensive as any previous one. (It has proven more expensive than any former war, involving us in additional debt exceeding one hundred million pounds. During eleven years of deep peace, barely ten million was repaid; during seven years of war, more than one hundred million was contracted.) The new debt likely to be created before the end of the next campaign may nearly equal all the old debt repaid from ordinary revenue savings. It would therefore be entirely fanciful to expect that public debt could ever be fully repaid from savings on ordinary revenue as it currently stands.
elegant: After accounting for all extraordinary windfalls totaling over five million, ordinary revenue savings since the peace barely averaged half a million pounds annually toward debt. The sinking fund has grown through interest reductions and lapsed annuities, and might now spare a million per year in continued peace. But a new war has begun -- one ultimately more expensive than any before, adding over one hundred million in new debt against barely ten million repaid during eleven years of deep peace. One campaign's new debt may equal all prior peacetime repayment. Complete debt repayment from ordinary revenue is a total impossibility.
summary: Ordinary peacetime revenue savings averaged less than half a million pounds per year toward debt. The new war ultimately proved the most expensive ever, adding over one hundred million pounds in debt. Complete repayment of public debt from ordinary revenue savings is therefore an impossibility.
distilled: Ordinary peacetime revenue savings are wholly inadequate for debt repayment, a reality made undeniable by each new war adding far more debt than any peace can retire.
notes: Ordinary vs. extraordinary revenue -- half million annual savings -- American Revolutionary War costs -- 100+ million new debt -- complete impossibility of debt liberation -- climax of fiscal pessimism

refashioned: The public funds of various indebted European nations, particularly England, have been portrayed by one author as a great accumulation of additional capital, layered on top of the country's existing capital, by which trade is expanded, manufacturing multiplied, and land cultivated and improved far beyond what would be possible with existing capital alone. This author fails to recognize that the capital which the original public creditors advanced to the government was, from the moment it was lent, a certain portion of the annual product turned away from serving as productive capital to serve instead as revenue -- diverted from maintaining productive workers to maintaining unproductive ones, to be spent and wasted over the course of the year without any hope of future reproduction. In return for the capital they advanced, creditors did indeed receive a public fund annuity, usually of at least equal value. This annuity undoubtedly replaced their capital and allowed them to carry on their trade and business at the same level or even greater -- either by borrowing new capital on the credit of this annuity or by selling it to obtain equivalent funds from other people. However, this new capital that they obtained by borrowing or purchasing from others must have already existed in the country, and must already have been employed, as all capitals are, in maintaining productive labor. When it came into the hands of those who had lent their money to government, though it was in some respects a new capital to them personally, it was not new capital to the country as a whole. It was merely capital withdrawn from certain employments to be redirected toward others. Though it replaced what these individuals had advanced to the government, it did not replace it for the country. Had they never lent this capital to the government, there would have been two separate portions of the annual product -- two capitals -- employed in maintaining productive labor, instead of only one.
elegant: Some claim public funds represent additional national capital that expands trade and industry. This is wrong. Capital lent to the government is immediately redirected from productive to unproductive uses -- turned away from maintaining productive laborers to maintaining unproductive ones, spent and wasted within the year without hope of reproduction. Creditors receive annuities that restore their personal capital, enabling them to borrow or buy replacement funds from others. But this replacement capital already existed in the economy and was already productively employed. It is simply shifted from one private employment to another, not created anew. Had creditors never lent to the government, the country would have had two productive capitals instead of one.
summary: The claim that public debt creates additional productive capital is a fallacy. Capital lent to the government is consumed unproductively. Creditors restore their personal positions through annuities, but only by drawing on capital that already existed elsewhere in the economy, resulting in a net reduction of productive capital.
distilled: Public debt does not create new capital; it diverts existing productive capital to unproductive government spending, leaving the nation with less total productive capital.
notes: Crowding out -- public debt as capital destruction -- productive vs. unproductive labor -- fallacy of public funds as additional capital -- displacement effect of government borrowing -- core theoretical argument

refashioned: When government spending is financed by current-year taxes on unmortgaged revenue, a portion of private income is merely redirected from supporting one kind of unproductive activity to supporting another. Some of the tax revenue might otherwise have been saved and accumulated as capital for productive employment, but most would probably have been spent on unproductive purposes anyway. Financing government through current taxation therefore hinders the further accumulation of new capital to some degree, but it does not necessarily destroy any capital that already exists.
elegant: Financing government through current taxes diverts private income from one form of unproductive spending to another. While this somewhat hinders new capital accumulation, it does not destroy any existing capital -- most of the taxed income would have been consumed rather than saved anyway.
summary: Pay-as-you-go taxation redirects private income from one unproductive use to another without destroying existing capital, though it does somewhat slow the accumulation of new capital.
distilled: Current taxation hinders new capital accumulation but does not destroy existing capital, since most taxed income would have been consumed rather than saved.
notes: Pay-as-you-go vs. funding -- taxation effects on capital -- marginal propensity to consume vs. save -- existing capital preservation -- contrast with 5.3.48 on funding

refashioned: When government spending is financed through debt funding, it is financed by the annual destruction of previously existing capital -- by diverting a portion of annual production that had been maintaining productive labor toward maintaining unproductive labor instead. However, because taxes under the funding system are lighter than they would need to be if the full cost were raised in a single year, the private incomes of individuals are less burdened, and their ability to save and accumulate capital is less impaired. So while funding destroys more existing capital, it simultaneously hinders the accumulation of new capital less than pay-as-you-go taxation would. Under the funding system, the frugality and industry of private individuals can more readily repair the damage that government waste and extravagance inflict on the nation's total capital.
elegant: Debt funding finances government by destroying existing capital -- redirecting productive resources to unproductive uses. But because it keeps taxes lower than pay-as-you-go financing would require, private incomes are less burdened and individuals retain more ability to save and rebuild capital. Funding destroys more old capital but hinders new capital formation less, allowing private frugality to partially repair government waste.
summary: Debt funding destroys existing capital more than pay-as-you-go taxation but imposes lighter current taxes, preserving individuals' ability to save and accumulate. Private frugality can therefore partially offset government waste under the funding system.
distilled: Debt funding destroys existing capital more than current taxation but preserves greater private saving capacity, allowing individual frugality to partially repair the damage.
notes: Funding vs. current taxation tradeoffs -- capital destruction vs. accumulation hindrance -- private savings as repair mechanism -- nuanced comparison of fiscal methods -- see 5.3.49 for temporal analysis

refashioned: However, the funding system holds this advantage over pay-as-you-go taxation only during wartime itself. If the expenses of war were always met through revenue raised within the year, the extraordinary taxes needed to produce that revenue would last no longer than the war. The ability of private individuals to accumulate capital, though reduced during the war, would be considerably greater during the peace that followed than it ever is under the funding system. War would not necessarily have caused the destruction of any existing capital, and peace would have generated the accumulation of far more new capital than is possible with perpetual funding in place. Wars would generally be concluded more quickly and undertaken with far less carelessness. The people, feeling the complete weight of the war's cost during its actual prosecution, would soon grow weary of it; and the government, needing to maintain public support, would not be compelled to continue the war any longer than genuinely necessary. The foreknowledge of heavy and unavoidable wartime burdens would also deter the people from demanding war frivolously when there was no real or substantial interest to fight for. The periods during which private saving capacity was diminished would occur more rarely and be of shorter duration. The periods during which that capacity operated at its highest vigor would be much longer than they can ever be under the system of perpetual funding.
elegant: Funding's advantage exists only during wartime. If wars were financed through current taxation, extraordinary taxes would end with the war, peacetime savings would be greater, and capital accumulation would flourish. Crucially, wars would be shorter and rarer: people bearing their full cost would tire of them quickly, and the prospect of heavy taxation would discourage frivolous warmongering. Pay-as-you-go financing would mean shorter periods of impaired savings and longer periods of robust capital accumulation.
summary: Pay-as-you-go war financing would end taxes with the war, boost peacetime savings, and -- most importantly -- make wars shorter and rarer because citizens bearing the full cost would resist prolonged or frivolous conflicts.
distilled: Pay-as-you-go war financing would make wars shorter and rarer by forcing citizens to bear their full cost, while preserving greater peacetime capital accumulation.
notes: War finance and democratic accountability -- fiscal illusion under funding -- pay-as-you-go as peace incentive -- citizen cost-bearing as war deterrent -- strongest argument against perpetual funding -- cf. 5.3.34 on citizen insulation

refashioned: Once funding has progressed far enough, the multiplication of taxes it brings can impair private savings in peacetime just as severely as pay-as-you-go financing would during wartime. Britain's peacetime revenue currently exceeds ten million pounds per year. If this revenue were free and unencumbered by debt obligations, it would be sufficient -- with proper management and without borrowing a single shilling -- to wage the most vigorous war. British citizens are currently as burdened by taxes in peacetime, and their ability to save is as impaired, as it would have been during the most expensive war had the destructive system of perpetual funding never been adopted.
elegant: Advanced funding eventually makes peacetime taxes as burdensome as wartime taxes would be under pay-as-you-go. Britain's ten-million-pound peacetime revenue, if unencumbered by debt, could finance the most vigorous war without borrowing. Instead, citizens now bear in peace what they would have borne only in war had perpetual funding never existed.
summary: Perpetual funding has made Britain's peacetime tax burden equivalent to what wartime taxation would have been without funding. The ten-million-pound annual revenue, if not committed to debt service, could finance major wars without any borrowing.
distilled: Perpetual funding has made Britain's peacetime tax burden as heavy as wartime taxes would have been without funding, eliminating the fiscal distinction between peace and war.
notes: Peacetime burden equals wartime burden -- 10 million annual revenue consumed by debt service -- long-run consequence of perpetual funding -- fiscal erosion of peace dividend -- culmination of funding critique

refashioned: It has been argued that paying public debt interest is simply the right hand paying the left -- the money stays in the country, merely transferring revenue from one group of citizens to another, leaving the nation no poorer. This defense is entirely founded on the false reasoning of the mercantile system, and after the extensive examination I have already devoted to that system, it may be unnecessary to say more. The argument also assumes that all public debt is owed to domestic creditors, which is not true -- the Dutch and several other foreign nations hold a very substantial share of our public funds. But even if the entire debt were owed domestically, it would be no less harmful.
elegant: The claim that debt interest is just the right hand paying the left -- a mere domestic transfer making the nation no poorer -- rests on mercantilist sophistry. It wrongly assumes all debt is held domestically, when in fact the Dutch and other foreigners own a large share. But even if the debt were entirely domestic, it would remain pernicious.
summary: The 'right hand paying the left' defense of public debt relies on mercantilist fallacies and the false assumption that all debt is domestically held. Even purely domestic debt would be harmful.
distilled: The argument that domestic debt interest is merely a harmless internal transfer rests on mercantilist sophistry and ignores that debt harms the economy regardless of who holds it.
notes: Right hand/left hand fallacy -- mercantilist reasoning -- foreign holders of British debt (Dutch) -- domestic debt still pernicious -- refutation of debt neutrality -- see Book 4 on mercantile system

refashioned: Land and capital stock are the two fundamental sources of all revenue, both private and public. Capital stock pays the wages of productive labor, whether that labor is employed in agriculture, manufacturing, or commerce. The management of these two original sources of revenue belongs to two different groups of people: the proprietors of land, and the owners or employers of capital stock. The proprietor of land has a direct interest, for the sake of his own revenue, in keeping his estate in the best condition possible -- by building and repairing his tenants' houses, by making and maintaining the necessary drains and enclosures, and by undertaking all the other expensive improvements that properly belong to the landlord. But when various land taxes diminish the landlord's revenue significantly, and when various duties on the necessities and conveniences of life reduce the real purchasing power of that already diminished revenue, the landlord may find himself entirely unable to make or maintain those expensive improvements. Once the landlord ceases to do his part, it becomes altogether impossible for the tenant to continue doing his. As the landlord's distress deepens, the agriculture of the country must necessarily decline.
elegant: Land and capital stock are the two sources of all revenue, managed respectively by landowners and capital employers. Landowners have strong direct incentives to maintain their estates through investment in buildings, drainage, and improvements. But when land taxes diminish their revenue and duties on necessities reduce its real value, they may become unable to afford these essential investments. Once landlords stop doing their part, tenants cannot compensate, and agriculture inevitably declines.
summary: Land and capital stock are the two fundamental revenue sources. Excessive taxation can impoverish landlords to the point where they cannot maintain their estates, causing agricultural decline as tenants cannot substitute for absent landlord investment.
distilled: Excessive taxation impoverishes landlords, destroying their ability to invest in their estates, which inevitably causes agricultural decline.
notes: Two sources of revenue: land and capital -- landlord investment incentives -- tax burden on agriculture -- cascading effects of overtaxation -- landlord-tenant interdependence -- see 5.3.53 for capital stock effects

refashioned: When various taxes on necessities and conveniences cause the owners and employers of capital stock to find that their income will not buy as much in their country as an equal income would buy almost anywhere else, they will be inclined to relocate. And when, to collect these taxes, most merchants and manufacturers -- that is, most of the employers of large capitals -- are continually subjected to the humiliating and harassing visits of tax collectors, this inclination to leave will quickly become actual departure. The country's industry will inevitably decline with the removal of the capital that supported it, and the ruin of trade and manufacturing will follow the decline of agriculture.
elegant: When taxes reduce the purchasing power of capital income below what it would buy elsewhere, and when tax collection subjects merchants and manufacturers to constant harassment, capital owners will relocate. Industry collapses with the departure of its supporting capital, and the ruin of trade and manufacturing follows agriculture's decline.
summary: Excessive taxation drives capital owners to relocate by reducing their purchasing power below foreign levels and subjecting them to harassing tax collection. Capital flight then destroys industry, trade, and manufacturing.
distilled: Excessive taxation drives capital flight by reducing purchasing power and subjecting capital owners to harassment, destroying the industry that depends on their investment.
notes: Capital mobility and tax competition -- capital flight -- tax harassment of merchants -- cascading economic decline: agriculture then industry -- purchasing power comparison across countries

refashioned: To transfer the greater part of revenue from the owners of land and capital stock -- the people with a direct personal interest in maintaining every particular piece of land and managing every particular portion of capital well -- to a different class of people (the public creditors, who have no such particular interest) must, over time, lead to both the neglect of land and the waste or removal of capital. A public creditor naturally has a general interest in the prosperity of agriculture, manufacturing, and commerce, and therefore in the good condition of the country's land and the sound management of its capital. If these things declined seriously, tax revenues might no longer suffice to pay the annuity or interest owed to them. But a public creditor, considered solely as such, has no interest in the condition of any specific piece of land or the management of any specific portion of capital. As a creditor, he has no knowledge of it, no ability to inspect it, and no concern for it. Its ruin may be unknown to him and cannot directly affect him.
elegant: Transferring revenue from landowners and capital employers -- who have direct, personal stakes in maintaining their specific assets -- to public creditors who have only a general, abstract interest in national prosperity must inevitably cause land neglect and capital waste or removal. A public creditor has a general interest in national prosperity but no particular interest in any specific piece of land or any specific portion of capital. He has no knowledge of it, no ability to inspect it, and no care about it. Its ruin may be entirely unknown to him and cannot directly affect him.
summary: Transferring revenue from those with direct interests in specific productive assets to public creditors with only abstract general interests leads inevitably to land neglect and capital waste. Public creditors lack the knowledge, oversight, and motivation to maintain any particular economic asset.
distilled: Shifting revenue from asset owners with direct stakes to public creditors with only abstract interests causes inevitable neglect of land and waste of capital.
notes: Misaligned incentives -- specific vs. general interest -- information asymmetry in public debt -- creditor detachment from productive assets -- principal-agent problem in public finance -- key theoretical point

refashioned: The practice of funding has gradually weakened every state that adopted it. The Italian republics appear to have originated it. Genoa and Venice, the only two that can still claim an independent existence, have both been enfeebled by it. Spain seems to have learned the practice from the Italian republics, and -- its taxes being probably less wisely designed -- has been weakened even more relative to its natural strength. Spain's debts are of very ancient standing, predating the end of the sixteenth century, about a hundred years before England owed a single shilling. France, despite all its natural resources, struggles under an oppressive load of the same kind. The Republic of the United Provinces is as enfeebled by its debts as either Genoa or Venice. Is it reasonable to suppose that in Great Britain alone, a practice that has brought weakness or dissolution to every other country would prove entirely harmless?
elegant: Perpetual funding has enfeebled every nation that adopted it. It weakened Genoa and Venice, debilitated Spain (whose debts predate England's by a century), burdens France despite its vast resources, and has enfeebled the Dutch Republic. Is Britain uniquely immune to a practice that has brought weakness or dissolution everywhere else?
summary: Every nation that adopted perpetual funding has been weakened by it -- from the Italian republics to Spain, France, and the Dutch Republic. Smith challenges the assumption that Britain could be uniquely immune to its destructive effects.
distilled: Perpetual funding has weakened every nation that adopted it, and there is no reason to believe Britain will prove uniquely immune.
notes: Comparative fiscal history -- Genoa, Venice, Spain, France, Dutch Republic -- universal pattern of debt-induced decline -- Spanish debt predating English by a century -- rhetorical challenge to British exceptionalism

refashioned: It may be objected that the tax systems of those other countries are inferior to England's. I believe they are. But it should be remembered that when even the wisest government has exhausted all proper subjects of taxation, urgent necessity forces it to resort to improper ones. The wise Republic of Holland has on some occasions been compelled to adopt taxes as burdensome as most of Spain's. Another war, begun before any substantial progress had been made in reducing public debt and growing as expensive as the last, might by irresistible necessity make Britain's tax system as oppressive as Holland's or even Spain's. To the credit of Britain's current system, it has so far hindered industry so little that even during the most expensive wars, the frugality and good management of private individuals have been able -- through saving and accumulation -- to repair all the damage that government waste and extravagance inflicted on the nation's total capital. At the close of the most expensive war Britain ever fought, agriculture was as flourishing, manufacturers as numerous and fully employed, and commerce as extensive as ever before. The capital supporting all these activities must therefore have been as large as it had ever been. Since the peace, agriculture has improved further, house rents have risen in every town and village (proof of increasing wealth), and most major taxes have been yielding more each year (clear proof of growing consumption, which can only be sustained by growing production). Britain seems to bear with ease a burden that nobody half a century ago believed she could support. Let us not, however, rashly conclude that she can bear any burden, or even be too confident that she could support without great distress a burden only somewhat heavier than the one already imposed.
elegant: Britain's tax system has admittedly hindered industry less than those of Holland or Spain. Private frugality has so far repaired the damage of government waste even during the costliest wars -- agriculture, manufacturing, and commerce all thrived at war's end. Since the peace, rising house rents and growing tax yields confirm increasing wealth and consumption. But this resilience has limits that must not be tested too confidently. When the wisest government exhausts proper taxation, necessity forces it to improper expedients, as Holland has already experienced. Another expensive war before substantial debt reduction could force Britain into taxation as oppressive as Holland's or Spain's. That Britain bears today's burden with apparent ease should not inspire rashly optimistic conclusions about her capacity to bear any burden at all.
summary: Britain's tax system has been less destructive than its continental counterparts, and private frugality has so far compensated for government waste. But this success should not breed complacency -- another expensive war could force taxation to unsustainable levels, and the current burden already stretches national capacity.
distilled: Britain's current fiscal resilience, sustained by private frugality rather than government prudence, should not be mistaken for unlimited capacity to bear debt.
notes: British fiscal resilience vs. continental comparison -- private frugality compensating for government waste -- rising house rents and tax yields as prosperity indicators -- warning against complacency -- Holland and Spain as cautionary examples

refashioned: Once national debts have accumulated beyond a certain point, I believe there is scarcely a single instance of their having been fairly and completely repaid. The liberation of public revenue, if it has been achieved at all, has always come through bankruptcy -- sometimes openly declared, but more often disguised as a pretended payment.
elegant: Once national debts pass a certain threshold, they have virtually never been fully and honestly repaid. Debt liberation, when it occurs at all, has always come through bankruptcy -- sometimes open, more often disguised.
summary: Historically, once national debts exceed a certain threshold, they are never honestly repaid. Relief comes only through bankruptcy, whether openly declared or disguised.
distilled: National debts, once they accumulate past a certain point, are never honestly repaid -- only resolved through open or disguised bankruptcy.
notes: Historical inevitability of sovereign default -- open vs. disguised bankruptcy -- no historical precedent for honest full repayment -- pessimistic conclusion on public debt -- see 5.3.58-66 for bankruptcy methods

refashioned: The most common device for disguising a real public bankruptcy as a pretended payment has been raising the denomination of the coin. If a sixpence were by act of Parliament or royal proclamation raised to the denomination of a shilling, and twenty sixpences to that of a pound sterling, then someone who had borrowed twenty shillings (nearly four ounces of silver) under the old denomination would repay with twenty sixpences (less than two ounces of silver) under the new. A national debt of about 128 million pounds -- roughly the capital of Britain's funded and unfunded debt -- could in this way be 'paid' with about 64 million of current money. This would of course be a pretended payment only, effectively defrauding public creditors of ten shillings in every pound owed to them.
elegant: The most common disguise for sovereign bankruptcy is raising the denomination of the coin -- calling smaller coins by larger names. If a sixpence becomes a 'shilling,' debts denominated in shillings can be repaid with half the silver. Britain's 128 million pound debt could thus be 'repaid' with 64 million in real value, defrauding creditors of half their due.
summary: Governments most commonly disguise bankruptcy by raising coin denominations, effectively repaying debts with less metal than originally borrowed. Britain's entire 128 million pound debt could theoretically be halved through such currency debasement.
distilled: The most common form of disguised sovereign bankruptcy is raising coin denominations to repay debts with less precious metal than originally borrowed.
notes: Currency debasement as hidden default -- denomination manipulation -- 128 million pound debt example -- 50% real devaluation -- inflation as debt repudiation -- see 5.3.59 for broader consequences

refashioned: The damage would extend far beyond public creditors. Every private creditor would suffer a proportional loss -- and this without any benefit, indeed with great additional harm, to public creditors themselves. If public creditors were generally in debt to others, they could partially offset their losses by repaying their own debts in the debased currency. But in most countries, public creditors are predominantly wealthy people who are more often creditors than debtors in their private dealings. This kind of pretended payment therefore typically worsens the losses of public creditors rather than alleviating them, while extending the damage to a vast number of innocent people. It causes a general and deeply destructive upheaval of private fortunes, enriching the idle and wasteful debtor at the expense of the industrious and frugal creditor, and transferring a great portion of national capital from hands that would have grown and improved it to hands that will likely squander and destroy it.
elegant: Currency debasement harms far more than public creditors -- every private creditor suffers a proportional loss without any compensating advantage. Since public creditors tend to be wealthy net creditors in their private dealings, the debasement actually worsens rather than alleviates their losses while extending the calamity to vast numbers of innocent people. The broader effect is a massive, destructive redistribution of private fortunes, enriching idle and profuse debtors at the expense of industrious and frugal creditors, transferring a great part of national capital from hands likely to increase it to hands likely to destroy it.
summary: Currency debasement extends far beyond public creditors, devastating all private creditors and causing a catastrophic redistribution of wealth from the frugal and productive to the idle and wasteful, transferring national capital into destructive hands.
distilled: Currency debasement causes a catastrophic redistribution of national wealth from productive creditors to wasteful debtors, destroying capital far beyond the scope of the public debt alone.
notes: Distributional effects of currency debasement -- wealth transfer from creditors to debtors -- productive vs. destructive capital holders -- collateral damage to private contracts -- moral and economic case against debasement

refashioned: When a state must declare bankruptcy, just as when an individual must, a fair, open, and honestly declared bankruptcy is always the least dishonorable course for the debtor and the least harmful for the creditor. A nation's honor is surely very poorly served when, to cover the disgrace of real bankruptcy, it resorts to a transparent trick of currency manipulation -- easily seen through and simultaneously extremely destructive.
elegant: When bankruptcy is unavoidable, an honest and open declaration is always least dishonorable to the debtor and least harmful to the creditor. Disguising real bankruptcy through currency manipulation is both transparent and far more destructive.
summary: Open, honest bankruptcy is less dishonorable and less destructive than disguised bankruptcy through currency manipulation, which is easily seen through and causes far greater harm.
distilled: Honest, open bankruptcy is always preferable to disguised default through currency manipulation, which is both transparent and far more destructive.
notes: Honest vs. disguised default -- sovereign bankruptcy ethics -- transparency in fiscal crisis -- currency manipulation as self-defeating -- practical case for open default

refashioned: Yet almost all states, ancient and modern alike, have resorted to this trick when driven to necessity. The Romans, at the end of the First Punic War, reduced the As -- the base coin denomination for computing all other values -- from twelve ounces of copper to just two ounces. They effectively raised two ounces of copper to a denomination that had always represented twelve ounces. This enabled the republic to pay its great war debts with one-sixth of what it actually owed. Such a sudden and drastic bankruptcy would, we might imagine, have provoked violent popular outrage. It appears not to have done so.
elegant: Almost all states have resorted to this trick. The Romans after the First Punic War reduced the As from twelve ounces of copper to two, paying their war debts at one-sixth of face value. Despite this drastic default, it apparently provoked no popular outrage.
summary: The Romans after the First Punic War reduced their base coin from twelve to two ounces of copper, repaying debts at one-sixth their value. Despite this dramatic default, no popular outcry resulted.
distilled: The Romans disguised sovereign default by reducing the As from twelve to two ounces of copper, paying debts at one-sixth value without provoking public outrage.
notes: Roman currency debasement -- First Punic War -- As reduced 6:1 -- popular acquiescence to debasement -- historical precedent for disguised default -- see 5.3.62 for political explanation

refashioned: The law enacting this debasement was, like all Roman coin legislation, introduced by a tribune and passed through the popular assembly -- and was probably quite popular. In Rome, as in all ancient republics, the poor were constantly in debt to the rich and powerful, who lent them money at exorbitant interest rates to secure their votes in annual elections. These debts, never repaid, accumulated into sums too large for the debtor or anyone else to pay. Debtors, fearing severe enforcement, were compelled to vote for whatever candidate their creditor recommended. Despite all laws against bribery and corruption, the bounty of candidates and occasional senatorial distributions of money were the principal means by which poorer citizens of the late Roman Republic supported themselves. To free themselves from subjection to their creditors, the poorer citizens continually demanded either a complete abolition of debts or what they called 'new tables' -- a law entitling them to full discharge upon paying only a portion of their accumulated debts.
elegant: The debasement law was popular because in Rome, as in all ancient republics, the poor were perpetually indebted to the rich, who lent at exorbitant rates to secure their votes in annual elections. These debts, never repaid, accumulated beyond any possibility of settlement. Debtors were compelled by fear of severe enforcement to vote for their creditors' candidates. The poor constantly demanded either complete debt abolition or 'new tables' -- laws allowing partial payment as full discharge. Despite all laws against bribery, candidate bounties and senatorial grain distributions were the poor citizens' principal livelihood. Currency debasement served the same liberating function as the new tables they had long demanded.
summary: Rome's currency debasement was popular because the poor were trapped in unpayable debts to the rich, who used lending as a tool of political control. The debasement functioned as the debt relief the poor had long demanded.
distilled: Roman currency debasement was politically popular because it functioned as the debt relief that Rome's perpetually indebted poor had long demanded.
notes: Roman debt politics -- tribune legislation -- debt bondage and vote control -- new tables (novae tabulae) -- currency debasement as populist policy -- class conflict in ancient finance

refashioned: The law reducing all coins to one-sixth their former value effectively allowed debtors to pay their debts with one-sixth of what they actually owed -- equivalent to the most favorable 'new tables.' To satisfy the common people, the rich and powerful had been forced on several occasions to consent to laws abolishing debts or introducing new tables. They probably agreed to this debasement partly for the same reason and partly because, by liberating public revenue, it might restore vigor to the government they themselves controlled. An equivalent operation today would instantly reduce a debt of 128 million pounds to just 21,333,333 pounds, 6 shillings, 8 pence.
elegant: The six-fold debasement was equivalent to the most generous debt relief possible. The wealthy consented partly to appease the public and partly to restore fiscal vigor to a government they controlled. Applied to Britain's debt, an equivalent operation would reduce 128 million pounds to roughly 21.3 million overnight.
summary: Rome's wealthy agreed to currency debasement both to satisfy popular demand for debt relief and to restore government fiscal health. An equivalent reduction applied to Britain's 128 million pound debt would reduce it to about 21.3 million.
distilled: Rome's wealthy consented to currency debasement to satisfy popular debt relief demands and restore government finances, a model that would slash Britain's debt by five-sixths.
notes: Elite consent to debasement -- dual motivation: popular appeasement and fiscal restoration -- British equivalent calculation -- 128 million to 21.3 million -- see 5.3.64 for further Roman debasements

refashioned: During the Second Punic War, the As was reduced further -- first from two ounces of copper to one ounce, then from one ounce to half an ounce, making it one-twenty-fourth of its original value. Combining all three Roman operations into one, a debt of 128 million in today's money could be reduced to just 5,333,333 pounds, 6 shillings, 8 pence. Even Britain's enormous debt could be wiped out in this fashion.
elegant: During the Second Punic War, the As was further reduced to one-twenty-fourth of its original value. Combining all Roman debasements, a 128 million pound debt could be slashed to about 5.3 million -- eliminating even Britain's enormous debt overnight.
summary: Successive Roman debasements during the Second Punic War reduced the As to one-twenty-fourth of its original value. Applied cumulatively to British debt, such debasement could reduce 128 million pounds to roughly 5.3 million.
distilled: Cumulative Roman-style currency debasement could theoretically reduce Britain's 128 million pound debt to just 5.3 million, but at devastating economic cost.
notes: Second Punic War debasement -- As reduced to 1/24th original -- cumulative debasement calculation -- theoretical elimination of British debt -- implicit warning about consequences

refashioned: Through such methods, the coins of virtually all nations have been gradually reduced further and further below their original value, with the same nominal sum coming to represent a smaller and smaller quantity of silver. Nations have sometimes also adulterated the standard of their coins for the same purpose -- that is, mixed in a greater proportion of base metal alloy. If, for example, eight ounces of alloy were mixed into each pound weight of silver coin instead of the current eighteen pennyweights, then a pound sterling would be worth little more than six shillings and eightpence of current money. The quantity of silver in six shillings and eightpence would effectively be raised to the denomination of a pound sterling. Adulterating the standard has exactly the same effect as what the French call an 'augmentation' -- a direct raising of coin denominations.
elegant: Through these methods, all nations' coins have gradually been reduced below their original precious metal content. Besides reducing coin weight, nations have also adulterated their standard by mixing in more base metal. If British silver coin contained eight ounces of alloy per pound weight instead of the current eighteen pennyweights, a pound sterling would be worth only about six shillings eightpence in real value. Adulterating the standard achieves exactly the same result as directly raising the denomination.
summary: Nations have universally reduced their coins below original value through two methods: diminishing the weight of precious metal and adulterating the standard with base metal alloy. Both achieve the same effect of making the same denomination represent less real value.
distilled: Nations have universally debased their currencies through either weight reduction or alloy adulteration, both achieving the same effect of making nominal denominations represent less real precious metal.
notes: Universal pattern of currency debasement -- weight reduction vs. standard adulteration -- French 'augmentation' -- equivalent methods of hidden default -- long-term erosion of monetary standards

refashioned: An augmentation -- a direct raising of the denomination of the coin -- is always, and from its very nature must be, an open and acknowledged operation. By means of it, coins of a smaller weight and bulk are simply called by the same name that had previously been given to coins of greater weight and bulk. Adulterating the standard, by contrast, has generally been a concealed operation. Through it, coins are issued from the mint carrying the same denomination, and designed to look as nearly as possible the same in weight, bulk, and appearance as coins previously in circulation that contained much greater real value. When King John of France debased his coin in order to pay his debts, all officers of his mint were sworn to secrecy. Both operations are unjust. But a simple augmentation is an injustice of open violence, whereas adulteration is an injustice of treacherous fraud. The latter operation, therefore, once it has been discovered -- and it can never be concealed for very long -- has always excited far greater popular outrage than the former. After any considerable augmentation, the coin has very rarely been restored to its former weight. But after the greatest adulterations, it has almost always been restored to its former fineness. Nothing less has ever been sufficient to appease the fury and indignation of the people.
elegant: Denomination raising is open injustice -- smaller coins are simply given the names of larger ones. Standard adulteration is secret fraud -- coins of reduced fineness are disguised to look identical to honest ones. When King John of France debased his coins, mint officers were sworn to secrecy. Both methods are unjust, but secret fraud provokes far greater outrage once discovered. Augmented coins are rarely restored to original weight, but adulterated coins are almost always restored to original purity -- only this has ever appeased public fury.
summary: Open denomination changes and secret coin adulteration are both unjust, but secret adulteration provokes far greater outrage when discovered. Historically, adulterated coins have almost always been restored to their original purity to satisfy public anger, while denomination changes have rarely been reversed.
distilled: Open currency manipulation is injustice by violence; secret adulteration is injustice by fraud -- and fraud, once discovered, provokes far greater public outrage and is more likely to be reversed.
notes: Open vs. concealed debasement -- King John of France -- mint secrecy oaths -- public reaction asymmetry -- violence vs. fraud -- irreversibility of augmentation vs. reversibility of adulteration

refashioned: Near the end of Henry VIII's reign and the beginning of Edward VI's, English coins were not only raised in denomination but also adulterated in standard.
