Similar frauds were practiced in Scotland during the minority of James VI, and have occurred occasionally in most other countries. It seems entirely futile to expect that Britain's public revenue can ever be completely liberated, or even that any considerable progress can be made toward that liberation, while the surplus revenue beyond peacetime expenses remains so very small. Such liberation clearly cannot happen without either a very substantial increase in public revenue or an equally substantial reduction in public spending.
elegant: Both Henry VIII and the Scottish regency during James VI's minority debased their coinage through both methods. But setting aside such desperate expedients, Britain's public revenue cannot be liberated while the surplus beyond peacetime expenses remains negligible. Liberation requires either a major revenue increase or a major spending reduction.
summary: Historical examples of debasement in England and Scotland aside, Britain cannot realistically liberate its public revenue while the surplus beyond peacetime expenses is negligible. Only substantial revenue increases or spending reductions could achieve this.
distilled: Britain's fiscal liberation is impossible without a major increase in revenue or reduction in spending, as the current surplus beyond peacetime expenses is negligible.
notes: Henry VIII and Edward VI debasement -- Scottish debasement under James VI -- transition from historical survey to policy proposals -- revenue augmentation vs. expense reduction -- sets up 5.3.68-69

refashioned: A more equitable land tax, a more equitable tax on house rents, and reforms to the customs and excise system such as those discussed in the previous chapter could potentially produce a considerable revenue increase without adding to the burden on most people -- simply by distributing the existing weight more evenly. However, even the most optimistic reformer could hardly claim that such improvements would be sufficient either to fully liberate public revenue or even to make enough progress during peacetime to prevent or compensate for further debt accumulation in the next war.
elegant: More equitable taxes on land, houses, customs, and excise could raise considerable additional revenue by redistributing the burden more fairly. But even the most optimistic projector could not claim these reforms would suffice to liberate public revenue or prevent further debt accumulation in the next war.
summary: Tax equalization across land, houses, customs, and excise could raise additional revenue without increasing the overall burden, but even the most optimistic estimate falls short of what would be needed to achieve fiscal liberation or prevent further wartime debt accumulation.
distilled: More equitable domestic taxation could raise revenue but would be insufficient to liberate public finances or prevent further wartime debt accumulation.
notes: Tax reform proposals -- equitable land tax and house tax -- customs and excise reform -- revenue redistribution vs. revenue increase -- insufficient for debt liberation -- see Book 5 Chapter 2 for detailed proposals

refashioned: By extending the British tax system to all provinces of the empire inhabited by people of British or European descent, a much greater revenue increase could be achieved. But this could scarcely be done consistently with British constitutional principles without granting fair and equal parliamentary representation to all those provinces -- each province's representation proportional to its tax contribution, just as Great Britain's representation relates to taxes levied on Great Britain. The private interests of many powerful individuals and the entrenched prejudices of large groups currently present obstacles to such a great change that may be very difficult, perhaps entirely impossible, to overcome. Without claiming to determine whether such a union is practicable, it may nonetheless be worthwhile in a speculative work of this kind to consider how far the British tax system could be extended across the empire, what revenue it might produce, and how such a union might affect the happiness and prosperity of the various provinces involved. Such a speculation can at worst be regarded as a new Utopia -- less entertaining, certainly, but no more useless or fanciful than the old one.
elegant: Extending British taxation across the empire could raise far more revenue, but constitutional principles demand that this be accompanied by proportional parliamentary representation for all provinces. Powerful interests and deep prejudices may make such a union impossible. Nevertheless, it is worth exploring speculatively: how the British tax system might extend across the empire, what revenue it could yield, and how it might affect imperial prosperity. At worst, this is a new Utopia -- less amusing than More's but no more fanciful.
summary: Extending British taxation to all imperial provinces could generate substantial revenue but would constitutionally require proportional parliamentary representation. Though powerful interests may make this impossible, Smith considers it a worthwhile speculative exercise.
distilled: Imperial tax extension could generate major revenue but would require proportional parliamentary representation -- a constitutionally necessary reform that powerful interests may make impossible.
notes: Imperial taxation and representation -- 'no taxation without representation' principle -- constitutional constraints -- speculative utopianism -- Thomas More reference -- American colonial context -- sets up 5.3.70-77

refashioned: The land tax, stamp duties, and the various duties of customs and excise constitute the four principal branches of British taxation. Ireland is certainly as able to pay a land tax as Great Britain, and our American and West Indian colonies are more able. Where a landlord is subject neither to tithes nor poor rates, he can certainly pay more land tax than one burdened by both. Tithes, where there is no negotiated fixed payment and they are collected in kind, reduce a landlord's potential rent more than a land tax amounting to five shillings per pound. Such a tithe typically amounts to more than a quarter of the actual rent remaining after the farmer has recovered his capital and a reasonable profit. If all negotiated fixed tithe payments and all impropriated tithes were eliminated, the full church tithe of Great Britain and Ireland could not be estimated at less than six or seven million pounds. Without any tithe, landlords could afford six or seven million more in land taxes without being worse off than many currently are. America pays no tithe and could therefore easily afford a land tax. American and West Indian lands, being generally worked directly by their owners rather than leased to tenants, could not be assessed by rent rolls. But neither was British land assessed by rent rolls in 1693 -- rather by a loose and inaccurate estimation. American lands might be assessed similarly, or through an equitable valuation based on an accurate survey, such as those recently conducted in Milan and the dominions of Austria, Prussia, and Sardinia.
elegant: Britain's four tax branches -- land tax, stamps, customs, and excise -- could all extend to the empire. Ireland and America could afford land taxes as well or better than Britain. American landlords pay no tithes or poor rates, so a land tax would be less burdensome for them than for British landlords already paying both. If all British tithes were converted to land tax, landlords could pay six to seven million more. American lands, though not rented out, could be assessed either by estimation (as British lands were in 1693) or by accurate survey as practiced in Milan, Austria, Prussia, and Sardinia.
summary: All four branches of British taxation could be extended to the colonies. America's tithe-free landlords could afford land taxes more easily than British ones. Assessment methods could follow either the rough British precedent of 1693 or the more accurate continental survey methods.
distilled: Ireland and the American colonies could afford land taxes as well or better than Britain, since their landlords bear neither tithes nor poor rates.
notes: Four branches of British taxation -- land tax extension to colonies -- tithe burden comparison -- assessment methods: rent rolls vs. surveys -- Milanese cadastral survey -- Austrian, Prussian, Sardinian models -- no taxation without representation context

refashioned: Stamp duties could clearly be levied without any variation in all countries where legal procedures and the documents transferring both real and personal property are the same or nearly the same. Extending British customs laws to Ireland and the colonies, provided it came with an equally important extension of free trade, would be enormously beneficial to all parties. All the burdensome restrictions currently oppressing Irish trade and the distinction between enumerated and non-enumerated American commodities would be entirely eliminated. Countries north of Cape Finisterre would be as open to all American products as southern countries currently are to some of them. Trade between all parts of the British empire would become as free as Britain's internal coastal trade is now. The empire would thus contain an immense internal free market for the products of all its provinces. Such a vast expansion of market access would quickly compensate both Ireland and the colonies for any increase in customs duties.
elegant: Stamp duties could be levied uniformly wherever legal forms of property transfer are similar. Extending British customs to Ireland and the colonies, accompanied by an extension of free trade, would eliminate all restrictive trade distinctions -- the burdens on Irish trade and the distinction between enumerated and non-enumerated American commodities would vanish entirely. Trade between all parts of the empire would become as free as Britain's internal coastal trade, creating an immense internal market. Such a vast expansion of market access would quickly compensate both Ireland and the colonies for any increase in duties.
summary: Stamp duties could be uniformly applied across the empire. Extending customs laws paired with free trade would eliminate all trade restrictions, creating an immense imperial free market that would more than compensate for any duty increases.
distilled: Uniform imperial customs paired with free trade would create an immense internal market that would more than compensate colonies for any increased duties.
notes: Stamp duty uniformity -- customs extension with free trade -- enumerated vs. non-enumerated commodities abolished -- Cape Finisterre trade boundary -- imperial free market -- coastal trade analogy -- mutual benefit argument

refashioned: The excise is the only part of the British tax system that would need to be adapted for different imperial provinces. It could be applied to Ireland without change, since Irish production and consumption are essentially identical to Britain's. But for America and the West Indies, where production and consumption differ significantly from Britain's, some modification would be necessary -- similar to the adjustments made when applying excise rules to Britain's own cider and beer producing regions.
elegant: Only the excise would require imperial adaptation. It could apply to Ireland unchanged, but American and West Indian differences in production and consumption would need modifications, as with Britain's own regional variations for cider and beer counties.
summary: The excise is the only British tax requiring adaptation for imperial extension. Ireland could adopt it unchanged, while American and West Indian differences in production and consumption would require modifications.
distilled: Only the excise would need modification for imperial extension, since American and West Indian production and consumption patterns differ from Britain's.
notes: Excise adaptability -- Irish similarity to Britain -- American and West Indian differences -- cider and beer county precedent -- practical considerations for imperial taxation

refashioned: For example, the fermented liquor called beer in America, which is actually made from molasses and bears very little resemblance to English beer, forms a considerable part of the common drink of the American people. This liquor keeps for only a few days and therefore cannot, like English beer, be prepared and stored for sale in large breweries. Every private family must brew it for their own use, in the same manner as they cook their own food. But to subject every private family to the invasive visits and examination of tax collectors, in the same manner as we subject the keepers of alehouses and commercial brewers, would be entirely incompatible with liberty. If, for the sake of equality, it were thought necessary to tax this liquor, it could be taxed by taxing the raw material from which it is made -- either at the place of manufacture, or, if trade circumstances rendered such an excise impractical, by laying a duty on its importation into the colony where it was to be consumed. Besides the duty of one penny per gallon already imposed by Parliament on molasses imported into America, Massachusetts Bay levies a provincial tax of eightpence per hogshead on molasses imported in ships belonging to any other colony, and South Carolina levies fivepence per gallon on molasses imported from the northern colonies. Alternatively, if neither of these methods proved convenient, each family might compound for its consumption of this liquor, either according to the number of persons in the household (as English families compound for the malt tax), or according to the different ages and sexes of those persons (as various taxes are levied in Holland), or along the lines proposed by Sir Matthew Decker for all taxes on consumable goods in England. This mode of taxation, as previously noted, is not the most convenient for goods of rapid consumption, but it might be adopted where no better method is available.
elegant: American 'beer,' actually brewed from molasses by individual households, cannot be taxed through brewery inspections without violating liberty -- subjecting every private family to tax collectors' visits would be intolerable. Instead, the raw material could be taxed at manufacture or by import duty at the consuming colony, with several existing colonial molasses duties serving as precedents. Alternatively, families could compound for consumption based on household size (as English families compound for malt tax), age and sex (as in Holland), or along lines proposed by Sir Matthew Decker for all consumption taxes. Though compounding is not the most convenient method for rapidly consumed goods, it may be adopted where no better approach is available.
summary: American household-brewed molasses beer cannot be taxed through invasive inspections. Alternative approaches include taxing the raw material at manufacture or import, or household composition payments based on family size. Several colonial precedents already exist for molasses duties.
distilled: American household-brewed molasses beer should be taxed through raw materials or family composition rather than invasive household inspections incompatible with liberty.
notes: Molasses beer taxation -- liberty vs. tax collection -- household brewing untaxable directly -- raw material taxation -- composition payments -- Massachusetts Bay and South Carolina precedents -- Sir Matthew Decker's proposal -- practical excise adaptation

refashioned: Sugar, rum, and tobacco are commodities that are nowhere necessities of life but have become objects of almost universal consumption, making them excellent subjects for taxation. If a colonial union were established, these commodities could be taxed either before leaving the manufacturer or grower, or -- if that did not suit circumstances -- they could be deposited in public warehouses at both the place of production and at every port of the empire to which they might be shipped. There they would remain under joint custody of the owner and the revenue officer until delivered to the consumer, the domestic retailer, or the export merchant. Tax would not be due until delivery. Goods delivered for export would go duty-free upon proper security that they would actually leave the empire. These are perhaps the principal commodities for which a colonial union would require significant changes to the current British tax system.
elegant: Sugar, rum, and tobacco -- universally consumed luxuries rather than necessities -- are ideal tax subjects. Under imperial union, they could be taxed at production or held in bonded public warehouses until delivery, with tax due only at that point. Exports would go duty-free with proper security. These are the main commodities requiring tax system changes under union.
summary: Sugar, rum, and tobacco as universally consumed non-necessities are ideal taxation subjects. Under imperial union, they could be taxed at production or through bonded warehouses, with duty deferred until delivery and exports exempt.
distilled: Sugar, rum, and tobacco -- universally consumed luxuries -- are ideal imperial tax subjects that could be efficiently taxed through production levies or bonded warehouse systems.
notes: Luxury taxation -- sugar, rum, tobacco -- bonded warehouse system -- deferred duty -- export duty exemption -- practical mechanism for imperial tax collection -- consumption tax principles

refashioned: What revenue this extended tax system might produce across all imperial provinces is impossible to determine precisely. Under the current system, more than ten million pounds of revenue is annually raised from fewer than eight million people in Great Britain. Ireland has more than two million people, and according to accounts presented to the Continental Congress, the twelve associated American provinces contain more than three million -- though these figures may have been exaggerated to encourage their own people or intimidate ours. Let us therefore assume that North American and West Indian colonies together contain no more than three million, making the entire British empire in Europe and America about thirteen million inhabitants. If the system raises more than ten million from fewer than eight million people, it should raise more than sixteen million, two hundred and fifty thousand pounds from thirteen million. From this, of course, the revenue currently raised in Ireland and the colonies for their own civil governments would need to be deducted.
elegant: The precise revenue yield of extending British taxation across the empire is impossible to determine, but the arithmetic is suggestive. Britain currently raises over ten million pounds from under eight million people. Ireland adds more than two million people; the American colonies, according to their own congress's figures (though perhaps exaggerated), add more than three million. Assuming the whole British empire contains about thirteen million inhabitants, the system should yield over sixteen million, two hundred and fifty thousand pounds -- minus whatever is already raised locally in Ireland and the plantations for their own civil governments.
summary: Extending British taxation proportionally across the empire's thirteen million inhabitants could yield over sixteen million pounds annually, compared to the current ten million from Britain's eight million alone, minus existing local revenues.
distilled: Proportional extension of British taxation to the empire's thirteen million inhabitants could raise over sixteen million pounds annually.
notes: Revenue projection -- 13 million empire population -- 16.25 million potential revenue -- proportional taxation calculation -- Continental Congress population figures -- possible exaggeration -- deduction for local government costs

refashioned: The expenses of Ireland's civil and military establishment, together with interest on its public debt, averaged just under 750,000 pounds per year in the two years ending March 1775. According to a careful accounting, the revenue of the principal American and West Indian colonies before the current disturbances amounted to 141,800 pounds. This figure, however, omits the revenue of Maryland, North Carolina, and all recent territorial acquisitions on both the continent and the islands, which might add another thirty or forty thousand pounds.
elegant: Ireland's civil, military, and debt expenses averaged under 750,000 pounds annually. The principal American and West Indian colonies raised about 141,800 pounds, though this omits Maryland, North Carolina, and newer acquisitions that might add thirty to forty thousand more.
summary: Ireland's annual government expenses ran under 750,000 pounds, while the principal American and West Indian colonies raised about 141,800 pounds in revenue, with some colonies omitted from the accounting.
distilled: Ireland's annual expenses were about 750,000 pounds and the colonies raised roughly 141,800 pounds, with several territories unaccounted for.
notes: Irish government expenses -- colonial revenue figures pre-1775 -- Maryland and North Carolina omitted -- incomplete colonial accounting -- baseline for imperial revenue projections

refashioned: For simplicity, let us assume that the revenue needed to support civil government in Ireland and the colonies amounts to one million pounds. This would leave fifteen million, two hundred and fifty thousand pounds for general imperial expenses and debt repayment. If the present British revenue could spare one million annually for debt repayment in peacetime, this improved revenue could spare six million, two hundred and fifty thousand. This great sinking fund could be augmented each year by the interest on debt retired the previous year, potentially increasing so rapidly that it could discharge the entire national debt within a few years and completely restore the currently weakened vigor of the empire.
elegant: Assuming one million covers Irish and colonial governance, the remaining 15.25 million could fund both the empire and aggressive debt repayment. If Britain currently spares one million for debt reduction, this system could spare 6.25 million -- a sinking fund growing annually through compound savings that could eliminate the entire national debt within years and restore imperial vigor.
summary: After covering local governance costs, an imperial tax system could devote 6.25 million pounds annually to debt repayment -- over six times the current amount -- potentially eliminating the entire national debt within years through compounding savings.
distilled: An imperial tax union could generate 6.25 million pounds annually for debt repayment, potentially eliminating the national debt within years through compounding savings.
notes: Imperial sinking fund -- 6.25 million annual debt repayment -- compound growth of sinking fund -- rapid debt elimination -- imperial fiscal restoration -- optimistic projection

refashioned: In the meantime, the people could be relieved of some of the most burdensome taxes -- particularly those on necessities of life and on manufacturing materials. The laboring poor would then be able to live better, work more cheaply, and send their goods to market at lower prices. Cheaper goods would increase demand, and consequently increase demand for the labor that produced them. This increased demand for labor would both grow the number and improve the circumstances of the working poor. Their consumption would rise, and with it, the revenue collected from the remaining taxes on their consumption.
elegant: Meanwhile, the most oppressive taxes on necessities and manufacturing materials could be lifted. Workers would live better, produce cheaper goods, and stimulate greater demand. Rising demand for labor would increase both the number and prosperity of workers, whose growing consumption would in turn increase tax revenue.
summary: Imperial tax revenue could allow the removal of oppressive taxes on necessities and manufacturing, creating a virtuous cycle: cheaper goods increase demand, which increases employment and wages, which increases consumption and tax revenue.
distilled: Removing taxes on necessities and manufacturing materials would create a virtuous cycle of cheaper goods, greater demand, more employment, and ultimately higher tax revenue.
notes: Tax relief on necessities -- virtuous cycle economics -- supply-side reasoning -- labor demand effects -- consumption-driven revenue growth -- welfare improvement for laboring poor

refashioned: Revenue from this system might not immediately increase in proportion to the number of people subjected to it. Considerable indulgence would need to be shown for some time to provinces newly burdened with unfamiliar taxes. And even when the same taxes were levied as uniformly as possible everywhere, they would not everywhere produce revenue proportional to population. In a poor country, consumption of the principal commodities subject to customs and excise duties is very small. In a thinly inhabited country, the opportunities for smuggling are very great.
elegant: Imperial revenue would not immediately scale with population. New provinces would need transitional leniency, and even uniform taxation would not produce proportional revenue everywhere. Poor countries consume less of taxed goods, and thinly settled countries offer far greater smuggling opportunities.
summary: Imperial tax revenue would not immediately match population ratios due to the need for transitional leniency in newly taxed provinces, lower consumption in poorer regions, and greater smuggling opportunities in thinly settled areas.
distilled: Imperial tax revenue would lag population proportions due to poverty, thin settlement enabling smuggling, and the need for transitional leniency in newly taxed provinces.
notes: Revenue proportionality limits -- transitional tax leniency -- poverty and consumption -- smuggling and population density -- practical constraints on imperial taxation

refashioned: Consumption of malt liquors among Scotland's lower classes is very small, and the excise on malt, beer, and ale produces less there than in England relative to population and duty rates (which differ for malt due to supposed quality differences). Smuggling in these particular branches is not significantly greater in Scotland than England. But the distillery duties and most customs duties produce less in Scotland than in England per capita -- not only because of lower consumption of taxed goods but also because smuggling is much easier. In Ireland, the lower classes are even poorer than in Scotland, and many areas are similarly thinly populated. Irish consumption of taxed commodities, relative to population, would be even lower than Scotland's, with smuggling opportunities about the same. In America and the West Indies, by contrast, white people even of the lowest rank live in much better circumstances than their English counterparts, and their consumption of all the luxuries they typically enjoy is probably much greater.
elegant: Scottish excise and customs yield less per capita than England's, not only because Scots consume less of the taxed commodities but because smuggling is much easier in a thinly populated country. Ireland's inferior ranks are even poorer than Scotland's, with many areas equally thinly inhabited, so Irish yields would be lower still. But in America and the West Indies, the contrast reverses: white people even of the lowest rank live in much better circumstances than their English counterparts, and their consumption of taxable luxuries is probably much greater.
summary: Tax yields per capita decrease from England to Scotland to Ireland due to poverty and smuggling, but American and West Indian colonists of all ranks consume more taxable goods than the English, suggesting higher potential yields there.
distilled: Tax yields vary with wealth and settlement density -- lower in Scotland and Ireland due to poverty and smuggling, potentially higher in America where even the poorest whites consume more luxuries than the English.
notes: Regional tax yield variation -- Scottish vs. English excise -- Irish poverty -- smuggling and thin settlement -- American prosperity and consumption -- comparative colonial living standards

refashioned: The Black population, which constitutes the majority of inhabitants in both the southern continental colonies and the West Indian islands, lives in a state of slavery and is undoubtedly in a worse condition than the poorest people in Scotland or Ireland. We should not, however, assume that they are worse fed or that their consumption of goods subject to moderate duties is less than that of the English lower classes. It is in their masters' interest that they be well fed and kept in good health, just as it is in a farmer's interest to keep his working animals well maintained.
elegant: The enslaved Black majority in the southern colonies and West Indies, though in worse condition than the poorest Scots or Irish, are not necessarily worse fed. Masters have an economic interest in keeping slaves well nourished and healthy, just as farmers maintain their working animals.
summary: Though enslaved people in the colonies are in worse condition than the poorest British subjects, their masters' economic self-interest ensures they are adequately fed, similar to how farmers maintain working livestock.
distilled: Enslaved people's consumption of taxable goods may not be less than that of England's poor because masters have an economic incentive to keep them well fed.
notes: Slavery and consumption -- master's economic interest in slave health -- livestock analogy -- colonial consumption patterns -- taxation implications of enslaved population -- Smith's critique of slavery

refashioned: Accordingly, enslaved workers almost everywhere receive their allowance of rum and of molasses or spruce beer, just as white servants do. This allowance would probably not be withdrawn even if these goods were subject to moderate duties. Consumption of taxed commodities per capita would therefore likely be as high in America and the West Indies as in any part of the British empire. Smuggling opportunities, however, would be much greater, since America is far more thinly populated relative to its size than either Scotland or Ireland.
elegant: Enslaved workers receive standard allowances of rum and molasses beer like white servants, and moderate duties would not change this. Per capita consumption of taxable goods in America likely matches any part of the empire, though the thinly settled territory offers much greater smuggling opportunities.
summary: Per capita consumption of taxable goods in America matches or exceeds other parts of the empire, since even enslaved workers receive standard rum and molasses allowances. However, America's thin population creates much greater smuggling opportunities.
distilled: American per capita consumption of taxable goods matches the rest of the empire, but the vast, thinly settled territory creates far greater smuggling opportunities.
notes: Enslaved workers' consumption -- rum and molasses allowances -- per capita consumption parity -- smuggling risk from thin settlement -- tax collection challenges in America

refashioned: If the revenue currently raised by multiple duties on malt and malt liquors were consolidated into a single duty on malt, smuggling opportunities in the most important excise branch would be almost entirely eliminated. And if customs duties, instead of being spread across nearly every imported article, were confined to a few goods of the most general use and consumption, and if collection were governed by excise laws rather than customs procedures, smuggling opportunities -- while not entirely eliminated -- would be greatly reduced. Through these two apparently simple and easy reforms, customs and excise duties could probably produce revenue in proportion to consumption even in the most thinly populated provinces, just as they currently do in the most densely populated ones.
elegant: Two apparently simple reforms could largely solve the smuggling problem. First, consolidating the multiple duties on malt and malt liquors into a single malt duty would nearly eliminate smuggling in the most important excise branch. Second, confining customs duties to a few goods of the most general consumption and collecting them under excise laws would greatly reduce smuggling opportunities. Together, these changes could make customs and excise revenue proportional to consumption even in the most thinly populated provinces.
summary: Two simple reforms -- consolidating malt duties and restricting customs to a few major goods under excise-style collection -- could largely eliminate smuggling and make revenue proportional to consumption across all imperial provinces.
distilled: Consolidating malt duties and limiting customs to a few major goods under excise collection rules would largely solve the smuggling problem across the empire.
notes: Tax simplification -- malt duty consolidation -- customs reform -- excise-style collection -- anti-smuggling measures -- proportional revenue across provinces -- practical reform proposals

refashioned: It has been argued that the Americans have no gold or silver money -- their internal commerce runs on paper currency, and whatever gold and silver reaches them is sent to Great Britain in payment for imported goods. Without gold and silver, it is claimed, they cannot possibly pay taxes. If we already take all their gold and silver, how can we extract what they do not have?
elegant: Critics argue that Americans cannot pay taxes because they have no gold or silver, using paper currency internally and sending all precious metals to Britain for imports. How, they ask, can you tax people who have no money to give?
summary: Critics argue that Americans cannot pay imperial taxes because they lack gold and silver money, conducting internal trade with paper currency and sending all precious metals to Britain.
distilled: The objection that Americans cannot pay imperial taxes because they lack gold and silver money is based on a misunderstanding of their monetary system.
notes: American currency objection -- paper money in colonies -- gold and silver sent to Britain -- common argument against colonial taxation -- see 5.3.85-93 for refutation

refashioned: The present scarcity of gold and silver money in America is not the result of the poverty of that country, or of the inability of its people to purchase those metals. In a country where the wages of labor are so much higher and the price of provisions so much lower than in England, the great majority of people must surely have the means to purchase a greater quantity of gold and silver, if it were either necessary or convenient for them to do so. The scarcity of those metals is therefore the result of choice, and not of necessity.
elegant: America's scarcity of precious metals reflects choice, not poverty. With wages much higher and provisions much cheaper than in England, Americans could easily afford more gold and silver if they needed or wanted it. Their preference for other uses of capital is deliberate.
summary: America's lack of gold and silver money reflects a rational choice rather than poverty, since high wages and low provision costs mean Americans could easily afford precious metals if they chose.
distilled: America's scarcity of precious metals reflects rational economic choice rather than poverty, given the country's high wages and low provision costs.
notes: American monetary choice -- high wages, low prices -- ability vs. willingness to hold precious metals -- rational preference for paper -- refutation of poverty argument

refashioned: Gold or silver money is needed or useful for conducting either domestic or foreign business. As shown in the second book of this work, a country's domestic commerce can, at least in peacetime, be conducted through paper currency with nearly the same convenience as with gold and silver. For Americans, who can always profitably invest more capital in land improvement than they can readily obtain, it makes sense to minimize the cost of an expensive instrument of commerce like gold and silver. They prefer to use the surplus production that would otherwise go toward purchasing precious metals to instead purchase tools of trade, clothing materials, household goods, and the ironwork needed for building and expanding their settlements and plantations -- acquiring active, productive capital rather than dead stock.
elegant: Gold and silver serve domestic and foreign commerce. But as shown in Book 2, paper currency handles domestic trade nearly as well. Americans, who can always profitably invest more capital in land than they possess, rationally minimize the expense of precious metals, redirecting that spending toward productive capital -- tools, materials, and equipment for their expanding settlements.
summary: Americans rationally prefer paper currency for domestic trade, redirecting the capital that would otherwise be tied up in gold and silver toward productive investments in tools, materials, and settlement expansion.
distilled: Americans rationally choose paper over precious metals for domestic commerce, freeing capital for productive investment in land improvement and settlement expansion.
notes: Paper currency efficiency -- dead stock vs. active capital -- American investment priorities -- land improvement opportunities -- rational monetary choice -- cross-reference Book 2 on paper money

refashioned: Colonial governments find it in their interest to supply the people with a quantity of paper money fully sufficient for transacting domestic business -- and generally more than sufficient. Some of these governments, that of Pennsylvania in particular, derive actual revenue by lending this paper money to their citizens at interest. Others, like that of Massachusetts Bay, issue paper money during extraordinary emergencies to defray public expenses, and afterwards, when it suits the colony's convenience, redeem it at whatever depreciated value it has gradually fallen to. In 1747, Massachusetts paid the greater part of its public debts with only one-tenth of the money for which its bills had originally been issued. It suits the convenience of the colonists to save the cost of employing gold and silver in their domestic transactions, and it suits the convenience of the colonial governments to supply them with a medium which, though attended with some very considerable disadvantages, enables them to achieve that saving.
elegant: Colonial governments supply ample paper money, sometimes earning revenue by lending it at interest (as Pennsylvania does) or issuing it for emergencies and redeeming it at depreciated values (as Massachusetts Bay did, paying debts at one-tenth face value in 1747). Both colonists and their governments benefit from avoiding the expense of precious metals, despite paper money's significant drawbacks.
summary: Colonial governments supply paper money that saves the cost of precious metals. Some like Pennsylvania profit by lending it at interest; others like Massachusetts issue it during emergencies and redeem at depreciated values, effectively inflating away debts.
distilled: Colonial governments supply paper money that benefits both settlers and governments by avoiding precious metal costs, though some colonies exploit it by redeeming at depreciated values.
notes: Colonial paper money -- Pennsylvania lending model -- Massachusetts Bay depreciation (1747) -- paper money as de facto inflation tax -- colonial fiscal expedients -- see Hutchinson's History of Massachusetts Bay

refashioned: The excess of paper money inevitably drives gold and silver out of colonial domestic transactions, for the same reason it has driven those metals from most domestic transactions in Scotland. In both cases, it is not poverty but the enterprising and ambitious spirit of the people -- their eagerness to put every available resource to work as active, productive capital -- that has created this surplus of paper money.
elegant: Excess paper money drives gold and silver from domestic circulation in both America and Scotland -- not because of poverty, but because enterprising people prefer to deploy all resources as productive capital rather than holding dead stock in precious metals.
summary: Paper money displaces gold and silver in America and Scotland not because of poverty but because their enterprising populations prefer to invest all available capital productively rather than hold precious metals.
distilled: Paper money displaces precious metals in America and Scotland because enterprising populations prefer productive investment over holding dead metallic stock.
notes: Gresham's Law variant -- paper displacing metal -- entrepreneurial spirit -- productive vs. dead capital -- Scottish parallel -- enterprise as cause of paper money preference

refashioned: In the external commerce which the different colonies carry on with Great Britain, gold and silver are used more or less exactly in proportion to their necessity. Where those metals are not needed, they seldom appear. Where they are needed, they are generally found. In the commerce between Britain and the tobacco colonies, British goods are generally advanced to the colonists on fairly long credit, and are afterwards paid for in tobacco valued at an agreed price. It is more convenient for the colonists to pay in tobacco than in gold and silver. It would likewise be more convenient for any merchant to pay for goods from his correspondents with other goods he happens to deal in rather than with money. Such a merchant would have no need to keep any part of his stock idle and in ready cash for answering occasional demands; he could keep a larger quantity of goods in his warehouse at all times, and deal on a greater scale. But it seldom happens that all of a merchant's correspondents find it convenient to accept payment in his goods rather than money. The British merchants who trade to Virginia and Maryland happen to be a particular set of correspondents to whom it is more convenient to receive tobacco than gold and silver. They expect to make a profit from selling the tobacco; they could make none from selling gold and silver. Those metals therefore very seldom appear in the commerce between Great Britain and the tobacco colonies. Maryland and Virginia have as little occasion for precious metals in their foreign trade as in their domestic commerce. They are said, accordingly, to have less gold and silver money than any other colonies in America. Yet they are regarded as being as thriving and consequently as wealthy as any of their neighbors.
elegant: In colonial external trade, gold and silver appear exactly where necessary and nowhere else. The tobacco colonies pay Britain in tobacco rather than precious metals because it is more convenient for both sides -- colonists keep their stock fully employed, and British tobacco merchants profit from reselling tobacco but would gain nothing from selling gold and silver. Maryland and Virginia therefore have less precious metal than any other colony, yet are among the most prosperous, demonstrating that scarcity of specie indicates efficient commerce rather than poverty. Just as any merchant would prefer to pay his correspondents in goods he deals in rather than in idle cash, the tobacco trade operates through commodity exchange that benefits all parties.
summary: The tobacco colonies trade with Britain almost entirely through commodity exchange rather than precious metals, because both sides find it more profitable. Their scarcity of gold and silver reflects commercial efficiency, not poverty -- they are among the most prosperous colonies.
distilled: The tobacco colonies' near-total absence of gold and silver in trade reflects efficient commodity exchange rather than poverty, as they rank among the most prosperous colonies.
notes: Commodity exchange vs. specie trade -- tobacco as medium of exchange -- Virginia and Maryland trade patterns -- precious metal scarcity as efficiency indicator -- trade credit systems -- refutation of poverty argument

refashioned: In the northern colonies -- Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey, and the four New England governments -- the value of produce exported to Britain falls short of the manufactures imported for their own use and for re-export to other colonies for which they serve as carriers. A balance must therefore be paid to the mother country in gold and silver, and this balance they generally manage to find.
elegant: The northern colonies import more from Britain than they export, requiring them to settle the balance in gold and silver -- which they consistently manage to find despite their supposed scarcity of precious metals.
summary: The northern colonies, running trade deficits with Britain, regularly pay the balance in gold and silver, contradicting claims that they lack the means to do so.
distilled: The northern colonies' ability to regularly pay their trade deficit with Britain in gold and silver proves they can obtain precious metals when needed.
notes: Northern colonial trade balance -- deficit with Britain paid in specie -- Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey, New England -- evidence against scarcity-of-money argument

refashioned: In the sugar colonies, the value of produce annually exported to Britain far exceeds all goods imported from there. If the sugar and rum sent to the mother country were paid for within the colonies, Britain would have to send out a very large balance in money every year, and politicians of a certain school would consider the West India trade extremely disadvantageous. However, many principal sugar plantation owners reside in Britain, and their rents are remitted as sugar and rum -- the produce of their estates. The sugar and rum that West Indian merchants buy on their own account are not equal in value to the goods they sell there annually. A balance must therefore be paid to these merchants in gold and silver, and this balance is generally found.
elegant: The sugar colonies export far more to Britain than they import, but no cash surplus flows back because absentee plantation owners receive their rents in sugar and rum. West Indian merchants sell more goods to the colonies than they buy in produce, so the colonies pay the difference in gold and silver -- which they reliably find.
summary: Though sugar colony exports exceed imports, absentee plantation owners receive rents in commodities rather than cash. The resulting balance owed to British merchants is paid in gold and silver, which the colonies consistently manage to produce.
distilled: Sugar colony trade balances are complicated by absentee landlords receiving commodity rents, but the colonies still manage to pay merchant balances in gold and silver.
notes: Sugar colony trade -- absentee plantation owners -- rents remitted as commodities -- merchant trade balance -- specie availability -- West India trade mechanics

refashioned: The difficulty and irregularity of payments from the different colonies to Great Britain have not been at all proportional to the size of the balances respectively owed by them. Payments have generally been more regular from the northern colonies than from the tobacco colonies, even though the former have typically paid a fairly large balance in money while the latter have either paid no balance at all or a much smaller one. The difficulty of obtaining payment from the various sugar colonies has been greater or smaller in proportion not to the size of their respective balances, but to the quantity of uncultivated land they contained -- that is, to the greater or lesser temptation for planters to overextend themselves by attempting to settle and cultivate more land than their capital could properly support. Returns from Jamaica, where there is still much uncultivated land, have generally been more irregular and uncertain than those from the smaller islands of Barbados, Antigua, and St. Christopher's, which have been completely cultivated for many years and have offered less scope for speculative planter enterprise. The newer acquisitions of Grenada, Tobago, St. Vincent's, and Dominica have opened fresh fields for speculation of this kind, and returns from those islands have lately been as irregular and uncertain as those from Jamaica.
elegant: Colonial payment irregularity correlates not with the size of balances owed but with the quantity of uncultivated land available for speculative expansion. The northern colonies, despite owing larger balances, pay more regularly than the tobacco colonies. Sugar colony payment difficulties track available frontier land: Jamaica, with much uncultivated territory tempting planters to overextend, has always been less reliable than fully cultivated Barbados or Antigua. Newer acquisitions like Grenada and Tobago have opened fresh fields for the same pattern of overambitious enterprise.
summary: Colonial payment regularity depends not on the size of debt but on the temptation of uncultivated land, which encourages planters to overextend their capital. Fully cultivated islands pay reliably; those with frontier land for speculation do not.
distilled: Colonial payment irregularity correlates with available uncultivated land -- which tempts planters into overextension -- rather than with the size of balances owed.
notes: Payment regularity and land availability -- planter overextension -- Jamaica vs. Barbados -- speculative enterprise -- frontier land as economic destabilizer -- Grenada, Tobago, St. Vincent's, Dominica as new speculative frontiers

refashioned: It is not, therefore, colonial poverty that causes the present scarcity of gold and silver money in most colonies. Their strong demand for active, productive capital makes it convenient for them to hold as little dead stock as possible, and disposes them to content themselves with a cheaper, though less convenient, instrument of commerce than gold and silver. They are thereby able to convert the value that those metals would represent into tools of trade, clothing materials, household goods, and the ironwork necessary for building and extending their settlements and plantations -- acquiring productive stock rather than dead stock. In those branches of business that cannot be conducted without gold and silver money, they can always find the necessary quantity of those metals; and when they fail to find it, their failure is generally the result not of necessary poverty but of unnecessary and excessive enterprise. It is not because they are poor that their payments are irregular, but because they are too eager to become excessively rich. Even if all colonial tax revenue beyond local government expenses were to be remitted to Britain in gold and silver, the colonies have ample resources to purchase the required quantity of those metals. They would simply need to exchange a portion of their surplus produce -- which they currently use to purchase productive stock -- for dead stock instead. In conducting their domestic business, they would be obliged to employ a costly instead of a cheap instrument of commerce, and the expense of purchasing this costly instrument might somewhat dampen the enthusiasm of their excessive enterprise in land improvement. It might not, however, be necessary to remit any part of the American revenue in gold and silver at all. It could be remitted in bills of exchange drawn upon and accepted by particular merchants or companies in Britain, to whom a part of America's surplus produce had been consigned. These merchants would pay the American revenue into the treasury in money, after having received the corresponding value in goods; and the entire business might frequently be transacted without exporting a single ounce of gold or silver from America.
elegant: Colonial scarcity of precious metals reflects rational economic choice, not poverty. High demand for productive capital makes colonists prefer cheap paper over expensive metallic money, converting the value that gold and silver would represent into tools of trade, clothing materials, household goods, and ironwork for expanding their settlements -- acquiring productive stock rather than dead stock. When gold and silver are genuinely needed in business, they can always find the necessary quantity. When they fail, the cause is not necessary poverty but unnecessary and excessive enterprise -- overambitious expansion beyond their capital's reach. Even if all colonial tax revenue beyond local government expenses were remitted to Britain, it need not travel as precious metal. Bills of exchange drawn on British merchants receiving American commodity consignments could transfer the entire value through existing trade channels, without exporting a single ounce of gold or silver from America.
summary: Colonial precious metal scarcity reflects rational preference for productive capital over dead stock, not poverty. When needed, gold and silver are always found. Colonial tax revenue could be remitted to Britain through bills of exchange on commodity consignments, without exporting any precious metals at all.
distilled: Colonial precious metal scarcity reflects rational capital allocation, not poverty, and tax remittances could flow through bills of exchange without any physical transfer of gold or silver.
notes: Rational monetary choice -- productive vs. dead capital -- bills of exchange for tax remittance -- no physical specie transfer needed -- excessive enterprise as payment problem -- comprehensive refutation of monetary objection to colonial taxation

refashioned: It is not contrary to justice that both Ireland and America should contribute toward discharging Great Britain's public debt. That debt was contracted in support of the government established by the Glorious Revolution -- a government to which Ireland's Protestants owe not only their present authority in their own country but every guarantee they possess for their liberty, property, and religion; a government to which several American colonies owe their charters and constitutions; and a government to which all American colonies owe the liberty, security, and property they have enjoyed since. The public debt was contracted in defense not of Britain alone but of all the empire's provinces. The immense debt from the last war in particular, and much of the debt from the war before, were both properly incurred in defense of America.
elegant: It is not contrary to justice that Ireland and America should contribute toward discharging Britain's public debt. That debt was contracted in support of the Revolutionary government that guarantees Irish Protestant authority, liberty, property, and religion, and that provides American colonies with their charters, constitutions, and the liberty and security they have enjoyed since. The debt was incurred in defense not of Britain alone but of all imperial provinces, with the immense debts of the last two wars contracted primarily in defense of America itself.
summary: It is just for Ireland and America to contribute to British debt repayment, since the debt was incurred defending the entire empire -- particularly America -- and sustaining the government that guarantees Irish and American liberties.
distilled: Ireland and America should justly contribute to British debt repayment because it was incurred defending the entire empire, especially America, and sustaining the government that protects their liberties.
notes: Justice of imperial taxation -- Glorious Revolution settlement -- Irish Protestant interests -- American colonial charters -- defense costs as shared obligation -- Seven Years' War as American defense

refashioned: Through union with Great Britain, Ireland would gain not only free trade but other advantages far more important, which would more than compensate for any tax increase accompanying the union. Through union with England, Scotland's middle and lower classes gained complete liberation from an aristocracy that had always oppressed them. Through union with Britain, most Irish people of all ranks would gain equally complete liberation from a far more oppressive aristocracy -- one founded not on the natural and respectable distinctions of birth and fortune, as Scotland's was, but on the most odious distinctions of religious and political prejudice. Such distinctions, more than any others, inflame the arrogance of oppressors and the hatred of the oppressed, and commonly make inhabitants of the same country more hostile to one another than citizens of different countries ever are. Without union with Britain, the people of Ireland are unlikely for many generations to come to consider themselves one people.
elegant: Union with Britain would give Ireland far more than free trade. Scotland's union liberated its common people from aristocratic oppression. Ireland's aristocracy is worse -- founded not on birth and fortune but on religious and political prejudice, which inflames oppressor arrogance and victim hatred more than any other distinction. Without union, Ireland's people may never see themselves as one nation.
summary: Union with Britain would liberate Ireland from a religious and political aristocracy more oppressive than Scotland's, which was merely based on birth. Religious distinctions generate more intense hatred between compatriots than differences between nations, and without union, Ireland's divisions may never heal.
distilled: Union with Britain would liberate Ireland from a uniquely oppressive aristocracy based on religious and political prejudice -- divisions that, without union, may never be healed.
notes: Anglo-Irish union argument -- Scottish union precedent -- religious vs. birth-based aristocracy -- sectarian division -- political prejudice as social poison -- nation-building through union

refashioned: No oppressive aristocracy has ever prevailed in the colonies. Even so, they would gain considerably in happiness and stability from union with Britain. At a minimum, it would free them from the bitter and venomous factional conflicts that are inseparable from small democracies, and which have so frequently divided the loyalties of their people and disturbed the peace of their governments -- governments that are, in their form, nearly democratic. If total separation from Great Britain should occur, which seems very likely to happen unless prevented by such a union, those factions would become ten times more intense than they have ever been. Before the present troubles began, the authority of the mother country had always been able to restrain those factions from escalating beyond gross insults and brutality. If that restraining power were entirely removed, they would probably soon erupt into open violence and bloodshed. In all great countries united under a single government, the spirit of party commonly prevails less in the remote provinces than at the center of the empire. The distance of those provinces from the capital, from the principal arena of factional competition and ambition, makes them more detached and impartial spectators of the conduct of all parties. Party spirit prevails less in Scotland than in England. In the event of union, it would probably prevail still less in Ireland than in Scotland; and the colonies would probably soon enjoy a degree of harmony and unanimity at present unknown in any part of the British empire. Both Ireland and the colonies would of course be subjected to heavier taxes than they currently pay. But with diligent application of the public revenue toward discharging the national debt, the greater part of those taxes might not be of long continuance, and public revenue could soon be reduced to what was necessary for maintaining a moderate peacetime establishment.
elegant: Even without oppressive aristocracy, colonies would benefit greatly from union through liberation from the bitter factionalism inseparable from small democracies, which have so frequently divided their people and disturbed their governments. Total separation, which seems very likely without union, would intensify these factions tenfold. Before the present troubles, British authority restrained them from escalating beyond insult and brutality; without it, open violence and bloodshed would probably follow. In all great unified countries, party spirit prevails less in remote provinces than at the center -- Scotland already demonstrates this compared to England. Under union, the colonies would enjoy unprecedented harmony. Heavier taxes would be temporary if diligently applied to debt reduction, and public revenue could soon settle at a moderate peacetime level.
summary: Colonial union with Britain would moderate the vicious factionalism endemic to small democracies, which separation would intensify into violence. Distance from the imperial center would cool partisan passions, and heavier taxes could prove temporary if applied diligently to debt reduction.
distilled: Union would moderate colonial factionalism that separation would intensify into violence, while distance from the imperial center would cool partisan passions and heavier taxes could prove temporary.
notes: Small democracy factionalism -- separation risk -- violence prediction -- moderating effect of imperial distance -- Scottish precedent -- temporary tax burden -- prescient analysis of American post-independence politics

refashioned: The East India Company's territorial acquisitions, which rightfully belong to the Crown -- that is, to the state and people of Great Britain -- could become another revenue source, potentially more abundant than all those already discussed. Those countries are reported to be more fertile, more extensive, and, relative to their size, much richer and more populous than Great Britain. Drawing substantial revenue from them would probably not require introducing any new tax system into countries already sufficiently -- indeed excessively -- taxed. It might be more appropriate to lighten rather than increase their burden, and to draw revenue not by imposing new taxes but by preventing the embezzlement and misapplication of the vast sums they already pay.
elegant: The East India Company's territories, rightfully belonging to the Crown, could yield more revenue than all other sources combined. These lands are reputedly more fertile, extensive, and wealthy than Britain. New taxes would be unnecessary and inappropriate -- these countries are already overtaxed. Revenue should come instead from preventing the embezzlement and misapplication of existing tax collections.
summary: The East India Company's territories, rightfully Crown property, could become the richest revenue source by preventing embezzlement of their already excessive taxes rather than imposing new ones on these fertile, wealthy, and over-burdened lands.
distilled: Revenue from India should come from preventing embezzlement of existing taxes rather than imposing new ones on already overburdened territories.
notes: East India Company territories -- Crown rights -- Indian revenue potential -- existing overtaxation -- embezzlement and misapplication -- reform vs. new taxation -- Smith's critique of Company governance

refashioned: If it proves impractical for Great Britain to draw any significant additional revenue from the sources discussed above, the only remaining option is to reduce spending. In both the collection and expenditure of public revenue, though there may still be room for improvement, Britain appears to be at least as economical as any of its neighbors. Its peacetime military establishment is more modest than that of any European state that can claim to rival it in wealth or power. None of these areas, therefore, seems to offer scope for major spending cuts.
elegant: If no significant new revenue is available, Britain must cut spending. But Britain already appears as economical as its neighbors in both tax collection and expenditure, with a more modest peacetime military than any comparable European power. Little room for domestic savings exists.
summary: If additional revenue proves unobtainable, Britain must reduce spending, though it already appears more economical than comparable European states in both revenue administration and military establishment.
distilled: If new revenue is impossible, Britain must cut spending -- though it already operates more economically than comparable European states.
notes: Expenditure reduction as last resort -- British fiscal efficiency relative to Europe -- modest peacetime military -- limited scope for domestic savings -- transition to colonial expense argument

refashioned: The peacetime establishment of the colonies was, before the current troubles began, very considerable -- and is an expense that can and should be eliminated entirely if no revenue can be drawn from them. This constant peacetime expense, though large, is insignificant compared to what colonial defense has cost during wartime. The last war, fought entirely for the colonies' sake, cost Britain upwards of ninety million pounds, as previously noted. The 1739 Spanish war was also principally undertaken on their behalf, and between it and the ensuing French war, Britain spent upwards of forty million pounds -- much of which should properly be charged to the colonies. These two wars cost Britain more than double the entire national debt that existed before the first of them began. Without those wars, the debt might well have been fully repaid by now. Without the colonies, the first war might not have happened, and the second certainly would not have. These expenses were incurred because the colonies were considered provinces of the British empire.
elegant: Colonial peacetime expenses should be entirely eliminated if the colonies yield no revenue. But peacetime costs are trivial compared to wartime defense: the last war cost over ninety million, and the Spanish and French wars together over forty million -- much of it properly chargeable to the colonies. These two wars cost more than double the pre-existing national debt. Without the colonies, neither might have occurred, and the debt might be fully repaid.
summary: Colonial peacetime expenses, though significant, pale beside wartime defense costs exceeding 130 million pounds for wars fought on colonial behalf. Without the colonies, these wars might not have occurred and the national debt might already be repaid.
distilled: Colonial defense has cost Britain over 130 million pounds in wars fought on their behalf -- more than double the pre-existing national debt that might otherwise have been fully repaid.
notes: Colonial defense costs -- 90 million (Seven Years' War) + 40 million (1739-1748 wars) -- counterfactual debt repayment -- colonies as cause of wars -- cost-benefit of empire -- strongest argument for colonial revenue contribution or withdrawal

refashioned: But countries that contribute neither revenue nor military force toward supporting the empire cannot be considered provinces. They may perhaps be considered appendages -- a kind of splendid and showy display for the empire. But if the empire can no longer afford the cost of maintaining this display, it should certainly abandon it. If it cannot raise revenue to match its expenses, it should at least reduce its expenses to match its revenue. If the colonies, despite refusing to submit to British taxes, are still treated as provinces, their defense in some future war may cost Britain as much as it ever has before.
elegant: Countries contributing neither revenue nor military force are not provinces but mere ornamental appendages. If the empire cannot afford this display, it must abandon it. If revenue cannot rise to match expenses, expenses must fall to match revenue. Treating non-contributing colonies as provinces guarantees future defense costs as enormous as past ones.
summary: Colonies that contribute neither revenue nor military force are merely expensive ornaments, not true provinces. If the empire cannot afford them, it must let them go or face continued enormous defense costs.
distilled: Colonies contributing neither revenue nor military force are expensive ornaments, not provinces, and the empire must either extract contributions from them or relinquish them.
notes: Provinces vs. appendages -- empire as ornament -- fiscal realism -- expense must match revenue -- stark choice: contribution or separation -- anticipates American independence

refashioned: Britain's rulers have, for more than a century, entertained the people with the fantasy that they possessed a great empire on the western side of the Atlantic. This empire, however, has so far existed only in imagination. It has been not an empire but the project of an empire; not a gold mine but the project of a gold mine -- a project that has cost, continues to cost, and if pursued in the same way is likely to continue costing immense sums, without ever producing any profit. For the effects of the colonial trade monopoly, as I have shown, are for the great body of the people sheer loss rather than profit.
elegant: For over a century, Britain's rulers have entertained the people with the fantasy of a great western empire. But it has been only the project of an empire, the project of a gold mine -- costing immense sums without producing profit. The colonial trade monopoly, as demonstrated, brings the general population loss, not gain.
summary: Britain's supposed American empire has been an expensive fantasy for over a century -- not an empire or a gold mine, but merely the costly project of each, whose trade monopoly brings the general population only losses.
distilled: Britain's American empire has been an expensive fantasy whose colonial trade monopoly delivers only losses, not profits, to the general population.
notes: Empire as fantasy -- project vs. reality -- gold mine metaphor -- colonial trade monopoly costs -- imperial illusion -- see Book 4 on trade monopoly effects -- penultimate argument of Wealth of Nations

refashioned: It is surely time that our rulers either realize this golden dream they have been indulging in -- perhaps as much as the people have -- or else wake from it themselves and try to wake the people too. If the project cannot be completed, it should be abandoned. If certain provinces of the British empire cannot be made to contribute toward supporting the whole, it is surely time that Great Britain free herself from the cost of defending those provinces in wartime and supporting any part of their civil or military establishments in peacetime, and adjust her future plans and ambitions to the real modesty of her circumstances.
elegant: It is time for Britain's rulers to either realize their imperial dream or wake from it. If the colonial project cannot be completed, abandon it. If provinces will not contribute to the empire's support, Britain must stop bearing their defense and governance costs and adjust her ambitions to the reality of her means.
summary: Smith concludes that Britain must either make its colonial empire contribute to imperial costs or abandon the project entirely, adjusting national ambitions to match actual fiscal circumstances.
distilled: Britain must either make its colonies contribute to imperial support or abandon them entirely, adjusting its ambitions to the reality of its means.
notes: Final argument of Wealth of Nations -- realize or abandon the imperial dream -- fiscal realism -- accommodate ambition to means -- prescient conclusion anticipating American independence -- 'real mediocrity of her circumstances'
